0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	0	Human papillomavirus 16 virus-like particles use heparan sulfates to bind dendritic cells and colocalize with langerin in Langerhans cells Latifa Bousarghin1,, Pascale Hubert1, Elisabeth Franzen1, Nathalie Jacobs1,2, Jacques Boniver1 and Philippe Delvenne1.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	1	1 University Hospital of Liege, Department of Pathology, Tour de Pathologie B35, B-4000 Liege, Belgium 2 Department of Virology, Faculty of Medicine, Imperial College London, St Mary's Campus, Norfolk Place, London W2 1PG, UK.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	2	Correspondence Latifa Bousarghin bousarghin{at}univ-tours.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	3	Present address: Laboratoire de Virologie Moleculaire, INSERM U618, Faculte de Pharmacie, 31 Avenue Monge, 37000 Tours, France.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	4	Because of their role in initiating antiviral immune response, DC and LC represent an ideal target for immune evasion by viruses.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Several viruses interfere with DC function, especially measles virus (Grosjean et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	6	, 1997), vaccinia virus (Drillien et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	7	, 1999) and dengue virus (Tassaneetrithep et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	8	 The study of the interactions between HPV and DC or LC has been complicated by the fact that native infectious HPV virions cannot be isolated in large enough quantities either in vitro or in vivo.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	9	 However, HPV to DC or HPV to LC interactions may be studied by using HPV virus-like particles (VLPs) that morphologically mimic native virions (Lenz et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	10	 HPV VLPs are non-enveloped icosahedral particles, composed of the L1 major capsid protein, which form via self-assembly in the nucleus after high level expression of L1 in eukaryotic cells (Kirnbauer et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	11	 (2002) reported that DC and LC are able to bind and internalize HPV VLPs.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	12	 However, in contrast to DC, LC incubated with VLPs do not upregulate activation markers, do not initiate immune response and do not migrate in vivo out of skin explants (Fausch et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	13	In this study, we showed that HPV 16 VLPs bind similarly to DC and LC but use different types of cell binding and intracellular trafficking.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Heparan sulfates are necessary for VLPs to bind to DC but not to LC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Electron microscopy analysis demonstrated a colocalization of HPV 16 VLPs and langerin in LC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	16	 However, no difference between LC and DC was observed for the endocytosis pathway.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	17	Carboxy-fluorescein diacetate succinimyl ester (CFDA-SE) labelling of HPV 16 VLPs.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Purified HPV 16 VLPs were diluted in PBS (pH 8 5) to 0.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	19	 CFDA-SE (Molecular Probes) was then added to a final concentration of 100  microM (Drobni et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Succinimyl ester group reacts with primary amines on the VLPs and forms stable conjugates.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Inside cells, acetate on the CFDA-SE is cleaved off by intracellular esterases and yields highly fluorescent particles.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	22	 After incubation for 2 h at room temperature, reactions were subjected to centrifugation in a sucrose density gradient using 30 and 70 % to separate VLPs from free CFDA-SE.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Fractions (1 ml) were collected, L1 positive fractions were pooled in PBS and sedimented by ultracentrifugation.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	24	 The pellet was resuspended in 0 15 M NaCl.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	25	To characterize the integrity of CFDA-SE-labelled VLP, VLPs were tested by ELISA with the H16.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	26	V5 monoclonal antibody (mAb) (Christensen et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Plates were coated with the VLP at different dilutions, stored overnight at 4  degrees C, washed four times with PBS and blocked with 1 % fetal calf serum (FCS).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	28	 The mAb was diluted at 1 : 5000 in PBS-FCS and allowed to bind to HPV VLP for 1 h at room temperature.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	29	 After four stringent washes, the bound primary antibody was probed with the relevant streptavidin-labelled secondary antibody and the absorbances on the ELISA plate were read at 450 nm.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	30	Generation of human DC and LC DC culture.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) were isolated from heparinized leukocyte enriched buffy coats of healthy adult donors by Lymphoprep (Lucron Bioproduct) density-gradient centrifugation applying 400 g at room temperature.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	32	 After two washes, PBMCs were plated on tissue culture dishes at a density of 1x107 cells ml to 1 in RPMI 1640 without serum and incubated for 24 h at 37  degrees C to select adherent cells.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Non-adherent cells were washed away with RPMI 1640 and remaining adherent cells were cultured for 6 days in medium containing 800 U granulocyte to macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF; Amoytop Biotech) ml to 1 and 20 U interleukin (IL) 4 (Biosource) ml to 1.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Routinely, about 70 % of DC displayed a CD1a+ phenotype as assessed by flow cytometry.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	35	 CD34+ cells (1x105), isolated from cord blood mononuclear cells using the MACS Direct CD34 Progenitor Cell Isolation kit (Miltenyi Biotec), were seeded in T25 flasks (Sarstedt) in 10 ml RPMI 1640 medium supplemented with 10 % FCS, antibiotics and 50  microM mercaptoethanol (all from Gibco-BRL).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Cultures were supplemented with previously optimized concentrations of the following human molecules: 20 ng stem cell factor ml to 1, 10 U thrombopoietin ml to 1, 25 ng Flt3 ligand ml to 1, 200 U GM-CSF ml to 1, 50 U tumour necrosis factor (TNF)-, ml to 1 100 U IL4 ml to 1 and 5 ng transforming growth factor (TGF)- ml to 1.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	37	 All these agents were purchased from PeproTech, except for GM-CSF and IL4, which were obtained from Amoytop Biotech and Biosource, respectively.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	38	 The cells were cultured at 37  degrees C in a humidified atmosphere and in the presence of 5 % CO2.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	39	 At day 7, the cellular density was adjusted to 2x104 per cm2 and the cells were fed, at days 7 and 14, with GM-CSF, IL4, TNF- and TGF-.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	40	 At day 18, cells were collected from cultures by vigorous pipetting to prepare single-cell populations.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	41	 To detect cell-associated VLPs, DC and LC were collected, respectively, on day 6 and 18 and transferred to new 24-well plates at a density of 2x105 cells ml to 1.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	42	 DC or LC were exposed to CFDA-SE-labelled VLPs or VLPs alone (10  microg ml to 1) in RPMI 1640 medium for 1 h at 37  degrees C.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Unbound labelled VLPs were removed by extensive washing with PBS.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	44	 RPMI 1640 medium was then replaced with RPMI 1640 containing 10 % FCS and cells were incubated at 37  degrees C for 6 h.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Flow cytometry measured the fluorescence of DC and LC, resulting from the uptake of labelled VLPs.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The relative fluorescent intensity was measured using FACSVantage SE and by Cellquest software (Becton Dickinson).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Typically, 20 000 events were collected for each experiment.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	48	Transmission electron microscopy.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	49	 DC and LC were incubated with VLPs as described above for different lengths of time.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Cells were centrifuged at room temperature and prepared for electron microscopy.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	51	 They were fixed at room temperature in 4 % glutaraldehyde (Laborimpex), post-fixed in 1 % osmium tetroxide (Laborimpex) for 1 h at 4  degrees C.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Cells were then dehydrated in graded (70, 90, 100 %) ethanol solutions (VWR International).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Fixed cells were embedded in Epon (Serva) and propylene oxide (Laborimpex), and hardened at 60  degrees C.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Ultrathin sections were stained with uranyl acetate (Fluka) and lead citrate (Leica).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	55	 These sections were examined using a transmission electron microscope LEO 906E (60 kV) (Zeiss).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	56	 DC and LC were incubated with HPV 16 VLPs.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	57	 After two washes with PBS, specimens were incubated for 1 h at 4  degrees C with anti-langerin antibody (Beckman).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Other sections were incubated with an unrelated antibody (anti-CD3 mAb) and with anti-6 integrin antibody (Sigma).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Fixed antibodies were revealed with anti-mouse IgG coupled to 20 nm colloidal gold particles (Tebu-bio).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Cells were washed, fixed and treated as above for electron microscopy analysis.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	61	 DC and LC were incubated with cell trafficking inhibitors at the following concentrations: 25  microM chlorpromazine (Sigma), which induces the misassembly of clathrin-coated pits at the plasma membrane by preventing clathrin recycling, 2  microM cytochalasin D (Sigma), which causes the disruption of actin filaments and actin polymerization inhibition, 25  microM nystatin and 5  microg filipin ml to 1 (Sigma), which inhibit the caveolae pathway.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	62	 For the blocking of mannose-type receptors, LC were also preincubated with mannan from Saccharomyces cerevisiae 5 mg ml to 1 (Sigma).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Labelled VLPs were incubated with DC and LC in the presence of inhibitors for 1 h.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Washed cells were then incubated in culture medium for 6 h.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Fluorescence of DC and LC, resulting from the uptake of CFDA-SE-labelled VLPs, was measured by flow cytometry as described earlier.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	66	Analysis of VLP to heparan sulfate interactions.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Heparan sulfate expression in LC and DC was detected by anti-syndecan-1 and anti-syndecan-4 mAb (Santa Cruz Biotechnology) followed by goat anti-mouse phycoerythrin (PE) antibody and analysed by flow cytometry.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	68	Labelled VLPs were incubated with heparin (heparin leo; Leo Pharma) at 37  degrees C for 1 h before adsorption to DC and LC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	69	 These cells were then washed with PBS and incubated with appropriate medium for 6 h at 37  degrees C.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Internalization efficiency was assessed by detecting cell fluorescence by flow cytometry.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	71	To examine the role of heparan sulfates in cell binding, DC and LC were also incubated with heparinase II (1 U ml to 1; Sigma), which cleaves -N-acetyl-D-glucosaminidic linkage, in medium containing 20 mM Tris/HCl, 50 mM NaCl, 4 mM CaCl2, 0 01 % BSA, pH 6 8.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	72	 After incubation for 1 h at 37  degrees C and one wash with PBS, DC and LC were incubated with labelled VLPs.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	73	To reduce the sulfation of heparan sulfate on the cell surface, DC and LC were cultured for 48 h in the presence of sodium chlorate (100  microM) as described previously (Bousarghin et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Sodium chlorate acts as a competitive inhibitor for sulfate recognition by ATP sulfurylase, the first enzyme in the sulfate assimilation pathway (Farley et al.

0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	102	  HPV 16 VLPs use heparan sulfates to bind to DC Since the difference observed in entry kinetics between DC and LC could be explained by the use of different types of cell binding, we investigated if heparan sulfates are used by VLPs to enter into DC or LC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	103	 We first examined the ability of heparin to block binding and cell entry.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Labelled HPV 16 VLPs were preincubated with heparin for 1 h at 37  degrees C and their capacity to enter into DC or LC was investigated by cell fluorescence (Table 1).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	105	 In the presence of heparin, fluorescence was inhibited by 76 plus or minus 5 % in DC whereas no inhibition (12 plus or minus 2 %) was observed with LC (Table 1).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	106	 To determine if this difference was not due to the origin of cells used to induce the differentiation of DC and LC, we also generated DC with CD34+ cells and showed that the entry of VLPs was inhibited in the presence of heparin (51 plus or minus 13 % of inhibition), suggesting that heparan sulfates are receptors for DC but not for LC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	107	 We also investigated the heparan sulfates expression by immunostaining with anti-human syndecan-1 and syndecan-4 antibodies.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	108	 The results showed that DC and LC express similar levels of syndecan-4 whereas syndecan-1 was poorly expressed (Fig.

0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	160	 In LC, vesicles containing VLPs were located near the nucleus after an incubation of 10 min (Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	161	 6c), whereas more time was needed for DC (data not shown).
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	162	When using VLP at low concentration (0 2  microg ml to 1), they were also observed in coated pits and cytoplasmic vesicles of LC with a clathrin morphology (Fig.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	163	The purpose of the present report was to investigate further the interactions between HPV 16 VLPs and DC or LC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	164	 We showed that these antigen-presenting cells differentially interact with HPV 16 VLPs.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Although DC and LC are able to bind and internalize HPV 16 VLPs, difference in entry kinetics was observed between both cell types with a faster entry of HPV 16 VLPs into LC compared with DC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	166	 As a correlation between entry kinetics and cell receptors has been previously shown with other viruses (Narayan et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	167	, 2003), we looked for potential different types of HPV 16 VLPs binding to DC and LC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	168	 The most described epithelial receptors for HPV are heparan sulfates and integrin (Evander et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Our inhibition experiments with heparin or sodium chlorate confirm that DC use heparan sulfates to bind HPV 16 VLPs in contrast to LC in agreement with the data of Yan et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	170	 (2004) showing that HPV 6b L1 VLPs uptake by DC is inhibited in the presence of heparin.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Other pathogens such as Chlamydia trachomatis also use heparan sulfates to enter DC (Matyszak et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	172	 (2002) suggested that heparan sulfates moiety detected on DC may also play an immunoregulatory role.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	173	 In fact, heparan sulfates and their degradation products have been reported to deliver costimulatory signals to T cells and maturation signals to DC (Wrenshall et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	174	, 1991; Kodaira  and  Platt, 2000; Johnson et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	175	 This may explain why HPV VLPs initiate DC (but not LC) maturation and activation.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	176	HPV 6b genotype has been shown to interact with epithelial cells by 6 integrin (Evander et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	177	 However, this receptor is poorly expressed in DC and LC and probably not implicated in the differences of HPV 16 VLPs uptake between both cell types.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	178	 (2004) also reported that 6 integrin is not responsible for the initiation of binding of HPV 6b L1 VLPs by LC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	179	LC express several receptors that facilitate antigen recognition and uptake, including Fc receptors, DEC205 multilectin and langerin.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Langerin is exclusively expressed by LC (Valladeau et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	181	, 1999) and is localized not only on the cell surface, but also intracellularly in close association with Birbeck granules.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	182	 This molecule functions as an endocytic receptor (Valladeau et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Upon binding to the cell surface, anti-langerin antibodies are rapidly internalized and delivered to Birbeck granules (Valladeau et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Electron microscopy analysis showed that HPV 16 VLPs colocalize with anti-langerin antibodies.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Indeed they were detected together in coated pits and in large cytoplasmic vesicles.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	186	 These data are in agreement with recent studies showing that the processing pathway of HPV 6b L1 VLPs in LC is associated with langerin+ compartments (Yan et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	187	, 2004) and that other viruses, such as HIV, also use langerin and lectin or mannose to enter into LC and DC, respectively (Turville et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Our electron microscopy analysis showed a colocalization of HPV 16 VLPs and langerin in large cytoplasmic vesicles resembling to endosome, which may be related to the observation that langerin is associated with the CD1a recycling compartment (McDermott et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	189	 HPV 6 VLPs were also shown to be colocalized with CD1a+ endosome (Yan et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	190	, 2004), but the loading mechanism was not determined.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	191	 When mannan, which was shown to be able to inhibit HIV entry in LC, was used a 40 % inhibition of VLP entry was observed suggesting that other proteins are also involved in the VLP binding to LC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	192	 It will be interesting to determine the direct effects of langerin in VLP binding by further experiments and if other lectins are also involved in the uptake of VLPs by LC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	193	As the cell surface binding of HPV 16 VLPs differed in DC and LC, we wondered if their internalization was also different as suggested by Fausch et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	194	 (2003) showed that DC use a clathrin-mediated endocytosis whereas LC use a different pathway, which is not associated with clathrin or caveolae.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	195	 (2004) show that HPV 6 VLP enter in LC by a caveolae-dependent pathway.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	196	 Entry pathways can be inhibited at different stages by specific inhibitors, such as chlorpromazine, cytochalasin D, nystatin and filipin.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	197	 When using these drugs, HPV 16 VLP entry was only inhibited in the presence of chlorpromazine and cytochalasin D whereas no inhibition was observed with the caveolae inhibitors, nystatin and filipin.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	198	 These results suggest that VLP enter in DC and LC by a clathrin-mediated pathway and are in agreement with the direct demonstration of HPV 16 VLPs in coated pits and cytoplasmic vesicles with a clathrin morphology in LC and DC preparations processed for electron microscopy.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	199	 The differences between these studies might be related to the different methods used to analyse HPV VLPs internalization although we cannot exclude different endocytosis pathways according to the origin of cells used to generate LC.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	200	 In agreement with this hypothesis, the LC used in this study poorly expressed syndecan-1 in contrast to the LC generated by Yan et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	201	The fact that HPV 16 VLPs use different types of cell binding to DC and LC might have important functional consequences.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	202	 It has been shown that the maturation of DC and LC depends not only on receptors involved in the uptake of pathogens but also on receptors directly acting on DC activation (Niedergang et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Moreover, a cooperation between these two types of receptors has been shown to be important for the diversity of DC or LC responses and to determine the outcome of the immune response (Gantner et al.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	204	 As receptors implicated in DC maturation activate nuclear factor kappa B and mitogen-activated protein kinase pathways (Janeway  and  Medzhitov, 2002), it will be interesting to characterize the cytoplasmic factors implicated in DC or LC maturation in the presence of VLPs and to determine if heparan sulfates are able to interact with these factors.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	205	Future research addressing the recognition of HPV VLP by DC and LC will provide insight on how these cell surface receptors regulate antigen-presenting functions and may contribute to the development of novel strategies that specifically prevent or treat HPV infections and associated (pre)neoplasic lesions.
0.14963757.15831940.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Detection of neutralizing antibodies against human papillomaviruses (HPV) by inhibition of gene transfer mediated by HPV pseudovirions.

0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	0	Implication of the product of the bovine herpesvirus type 1 UL25 gene in capsid assembly Nathalie Desloges and Claire Simard.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	1	Institut National de la Recherche Scientifique, Centre INRS-Institut Armand-Frappier, 531 Bd des Prairies, Laval, Quebec, Canada H7V 1B7.

0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	3	Present address: University of Witten/Herdecke, Institute of Microbiology and Virology, Stockumer Str.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	4	During the replication process, cleavage and packaging of viral DNA are tightly linked functions at least requiring the following seven genes in HSV-1: UL6, UL15, UL17, UL25, UL28, UL32 and UL33 (Poon  and  Roizman, 1993; Taus et al.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	5	, 1990; Lamberti  and  Weller, 1996, 1998; al-Kobaisi et al.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Viruses mutated in one of these genes synthesize near-wild-type levels of viral DNA but fail to cleave and package concatemeric DNA into capsids, resulting in an accumulation of B (intermediate) capsids in infected cells, with the exception of the UL25 mutant, which was shown to cleave newly synthesized viral DNA (McNab et al.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Moreover, in contrast to the latter study where no packaging of matur DNA was observed, Stow (2001) reported that a significant amount of DNA synthesized by the UL25 mutant was packaged stably into capsids.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	8	To propagate a BHV-1 deletion mutant with a potentially lethal mutation in the UL25 gene to study the function of this gene, it was necessary to develop a complementing cell line expressing the UL25 protein in trans.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	9	 For this purpose, RK13 cells (rabbit kidney cells, ATCC CCL-377) were stably transfected with 2  microg ScaI-linearized pRetroTET-OFF/UL25, encoding the complete UL25 ORF under the control of a tetracycline-regulated promoter (Fig.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	10	 A selected cell line grown in the absence of doxycycline, a tetracycline derivative compound (Gossen et al.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	11	, 1995), expressed a 63 kDa protein that reacted specifically with the UL25 antiserum (results not shown; Desloges et al.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	12	 This polypeptide represents the full-length product of UL25, since its size correlated with that of the protein observed in BHV-1-infected cells (Desloges et al.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	13	 This cell line, named RK13/UL25+, was used subsequently as a complementing host cell for the construction of a UL25 deletion mutant.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	14	View larger version (33K):    Fig.

0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	33	 These findings demonstrate that the -Gal reporter gene cassette interrupts, as intended, the UL25-encoding sequence of the virus mutant.

0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	50	 of 5 and then harvested at different times p.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	51	, after which the total number of virus particles present either extracellularly or intracellularly in each sample was determined by titration assays, as described previously (Desloges  and  Simard, 2003).
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	52	 BHV-1 was capable of replicating efficiently in both RK13 and RK13/UL25+ cells, reaching similar maximal virus yields at 21 h p.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	53	 In contrast, BHV-1UL25 could only replicate in RK13/UL25+ cells, as no progeny was produced in RK13 cells (Fig.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	54	 These results demonstrate that the UL25 gene product is necessary for virus replication in non-complementing cells, as was observed also with an HSV-1 UL25 deletion mutant (Ali et al.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	55	 In addition, the virus yield obtained with BHV-1UL25 on RK13/UL25+ cells was similar to that of BHV-1 virus yield recovered from either cell line, indicating that the RK13/UL25+ cell line was capable of fully complementing the UL25 defect of the mutant virus.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	56	 These results demonstrate that the amount of the UL25 protein within the complementary cell line is sufficient to allow replication of BHV-1UL25 to BHV-1 levels, indicating that no mutations in other essential genes had been introduced during the recombination event giving rise to the mutant.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	57	To identify the step at which the UL25 deletion mutant replication aborts in RK13 cells, we examined whether the mutation compromised the expression of late viral genes products.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	58	 For this purpose, the expression of the BHV-1 gene trans-inducing factor protein encoded by the UL48 gene, a late gene (Misra et al.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	59	, protein lysates were prepared from BHV-1UL25- and BHV-1-infected RK13 cells and analysed by immunoblot for the presence of the UL48 gene product using a BHV-1-specific UL48 antiserum directed against an Escherichia coli-expressed T7 tag to UL48 fusion protein.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	60	 The antiserum detected a 50 kDa protein in lysates collected at 18 h p.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	61	 from both BHV-1UL25- and BHV-1-infected RK13 cells (Fig.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Moreover, the production of the UL48 gene product was abrogated by PAA treatment (Fig.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	63	 2C, +PAA), confirming further that UL48 is a 2 gene.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Thus, these results demonstrate that the UL25 defect does not impair the expression of viral genes of the 2 class or, consequently, the expression of genes of the earlier classes (, 1, 2 and 1).
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	65	 These results also demonstrate indirectly that the mutation does not compromise viral DNA synthesis, since genes whose expression is dependent strictly on viral DNA synthesis (such as UL48) are expressed efficiently.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	66	To obtain direct evidence that the UL25 defect does not compromise viral DNA synthesis in RK13 cells, Southern blotting analysis of HindIII digests of total cell DNA isolated from BHV-1UL25-infected RK13 and RK13/UL25+ cells was performed.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	67	 The HindIII fragment N, representing the leftward terminal region of the BHV-1 linear viral genome, was used as probe (Fig.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Probe N hybridized to a major 2 4 kbp and two minor non-well-resolved 14 and 15 kbp fragments present in DNA from BHV-1UL25-infected RK13 cells obtained at 12 and 24 h p.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	69	 In contrast, no hybridization signal was observed at 0 h p.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	70	 3A, lane 1), demonstrating that the bands observed represented newly synthesized viral DNA.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	71	 The DNA profile observed at 24 h p.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	72	 3A, lane 3) was very similar to that observed in BHV-1UL25-infected RK13/UL25+ cells (Fig.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	73	 The 2 4 kbp bands common to the two profiles co-migrated with the KpnI to HindIII insert of the recombinant plasmid pKS/Nhd, which harbours the complete HindIII fragment N (Fig.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	74	 3A, lane 5), demonstrating that these bands represented the leftward terminal 2 4 kbp HindIII fragment N of the BHV-1 linear genome.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	75	 The sizes of the other two bands correlated to those expected for head-to-tail HindIII genomic fragments (Fig.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	76	 1, N to F and N to H head-to-tail fragments are in the range of 14 and 15 kbp, respectively), indicating the presence within infected cell lysates of viral DNA, which was in the form of either immature DNA concatemers or of circular unit-length genomes, or both.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Interestingly, the levels of the 2 4 kbp fragment observed were similar in the two cell lines.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	78	 These findings indicate that DNA replication of BHV-1UL25 is as effective in RK13 cells as in complementing RK13/UL25+ cells.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Moreover, the much higher abundance of terminal versus head-to-tail HindIII fragments indicate that mutant viral DNA synthesized in infected cells is processed efficiently into linear unit-length genomes.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	80	View larger version (56K):    Fig.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Synthesis, processing and packaging of BHV-1UL25 DNA.

0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Thin sections were prepared for electron microscopy analysis.

0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Magnification, x70 000; bars, 100 nm.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	93	  To determine whether mutant viral DNA is packaged into capsids, thin sections of BHV-1UL25-infected RK13 and RK13/UL25+ cells as well as BHV-1-infected RK13 cells, collected at 18 h p.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	94	, were examined by transmission electron microscopy to assess the presence of full (C), intermediate (B) and empty (A) capsids, as described previously (Desloges  and  Simard, 2003).
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Significant numbers of all three capsid types were found on sections from both BHV-1-infected RK13 cells (A capsids, 35 7 %; B capsids, 16 7 %; C capsids, 47 6 %) and BHV-1UL25-infected RK13/UL25+ cells (A capsids, 29 6 %; B capsids, 51 7 %; C capsids, 18 7 %).
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Each of these infected cell samples (Fig.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	97	 3B, upper left and right panels, respectively) presented several C capsids surrounded by a bilayer envelope.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	98	 In contrast, most of the capsids in BHV-1UL25-infected RK13 cells were of types A and B (40 0 and 57 2 %, respectively), as illustrated in Fig.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	99	 3(B, lower left panel), showing an accumulation of both capsid types in infected cells.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	100	 The generation of empty A capsids devoid of both DNA and internal structure is believed to result from an abortive packaging event.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Abortive packaging has been observed also in mutants of the dsDNA bacteriophage P22, which presents similarities to alphaherpesviruses concerning the DNA packaging and capsid assembly process.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	102	 In Salmonella cells infected with mutants of phage P22 defective in genes 4, 10 and 26, it was shown that the procapsids are assembled and that viral concatemeric DNA is packaged but that the newly filled capsids are unstable and lose their DNA (Strauss  and  King, 1984).
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	103	 The phenotype observed in bacterial cells infected with these mutants is an accumulation of empty A capsids, similar to those observed in BHV-1UL25-infected RK13 cells.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	104	However, careful examination of these infected cells revealed the presence of few electron-dense cored C capsids (2 8 %).
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	105	 3(B, lower right panel), in which a complete enveloped C capsid is shown in the extracellular compartment of BHV-1UL25-infected RK13 cells.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	106	 It was reported previously that the HSV-1 UL25 mutant (KUL25NS) does not package matur DNA (McNab et al.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Recently, Stow (2001) detected successfully low levels of KUL25NS DNA being packaged and retained into capsids.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	108	 The latter findings are corroborated in the present study by the observation of few full C capsids in electron micrographs of thin sections of BHV-1UL25-infected RK13 cells.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	109	 However, it appears that these enveloped C capsids were either non-infectious or their number was too low for cytopathogenesis, as no virus was detected in one-step growth curve analyses.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Also, it could be that UL25 mutant genomes are packaged efficiently into capsids but are released subsequently and then degraded rapidly, as suggested by Stow (2001).
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	111	In summary, we describe the engineering and characterization of a UL25 deletion mutant of BHV-1.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Our results show that the mutant is not impaired in its ability to synthesize viral proteins and to replicate and cleave viral DNA into unit-length genomes.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Moreover, the mutant is still able to encapsidate viral DNA, albeit at very low levels.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Further studies will be required to elucidate more precisely the role played by UL25 in the encapsidation process and especially in the stabilization of the packaged DNA into the capsid.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Characterization of an essential HSV-1 protein encoded by the UL25 gene reported to be involved in virus penetration and capsid assembly.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	116	 The herpes simplex virus UL33 gene product is required for the assembly of full capsids.

0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	121	 The herpes simplex virus type 1 cleavage/packaging protein, UL32, is involved in efficient localization of capsids to replication compartments.
0.14988111.12917469.html.plaintext.txt	122	 The product of the herpes simplex virus type 1 UL25 gene is required for encapsidation but not for cleavage of replicated viral DNA.

0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	0	A Multistep, ATP-dependent Pathway for Assembly of Human Immunodeficiency Virus Capsids in a Cell-free System.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Hill,* Mei Lie Wong,  and Ramanujan S.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	2	To understand the mechanism by which human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV) capsids are formed, we have reconstituted the assembly of immature HIV capsids de novo in a cell-free system.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	3	 Capsid authenticity is established by multiple biochemical and morphologic criteria.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Known features of the assembly process are closely reproduced, indicating the fidelity of the cell-free reaction.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Assembly is separated into co- and posttranslational phases, and three independent posttranslational requirements are demonstrated: (a) ATP, (b) a detergent-sensitive host factor, and (c) a detergent-insensitive host subcellular fraction that can be depleted and reconstituted.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Assembly appears to proceed by way of multiple intermediates whose conversion to completed capsids can be blocked by either ATP depletion or treatment with nondenaturing detergent.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Specific subsets of these intermediates accumulate upon expression of various assembly-defective Gag mutants in the cell-free system, suggesting that each mutant is blocked at a particular step in assembly.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Furthermore, the accumulation of complexes of similar sizes in cells expressing the corresponding mutants suggests that comparable intermediates may exist in vivo.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	9	 From these data, we propose a multi-step pathway for the biogenesis of HIV capsids, in which the assembly process can be disrupted at a number of discrete points.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	10	The protein shell of the human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV)1 virion, termed the HIV capsid or core, is composed of ~1,500 copies of the Pr55 Gag structural protein precursor (for review see Gelderblom, 1991).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	11	 For proper assembly of the capsid to occur, Pr55 chains must undergo myristoylation (Gheysen et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	12	, 1989), an NH2-terminal modification thought to occur co-translationally (Towler et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	13	 The myristoylated chains are targeted to the host plasma membrane where assembly takes place concomitant with RNA encapsidation.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	14	 As capsids are formed, they bud into the plasma membrane, which results in envelopment and subsequent release of viral particles from the cell.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Coincident with these events, the immature viral particles undergo a maturation process, involving proteolytic processing of the precursor structural proteins and condensation of the capsids into collapsed, electron-dense cores (for review see Gelderblom, 1991; Wills and Craven, 1991).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	16	Much of our knowledge of HIV capsid assembly comes from studies of viral particle formation in cultured cells transfected with viral genes.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	17	 EM studies of these cells have indicated that the plasma membrane is the site of capsid assembly (Gelderblom, 1991; Wills and Craven, 1991).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Analysis of various mutants of Pr55 have revealed key domains required for efficient capsid assembly and targeting to the plasma membrane (Gheysen et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	19	, 1993; Wang and Barklis, 1993; Hockley et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	20	 However, the actual mechanisms involved in coordinating the formation of an HIV capsid from 1,500 Gag monomers have not been elucidated.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Many important questions about HIV capsid assembly remain unanswered, including whether assembly is an energy-dependent process, whether host proteins are required for assembly to take place, and whether assembly proceeds by way of discrete intermediates.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	22	A major obstacle to addressing these questions experimentally has been the inherent difficulty of studying capsid assembly in cellular systems.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	23	 In cells, many of the events in question proceed extremely rapidly and are not readily amenable to manipulation, making it difficult to identify trans-acting factors and energy substrates that may be required for assembly.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Development of a cell-free system that recreates capsid biogenesis would greatly facilitate a biochemical dissection and mechanistic understanding of capsid formation.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	25	In this study, we report the development of a cell-free system for the assembly of immature HIV capsids that appears to reproduce known features of capsid structure and biogenesis, including the phenotypes of a variety of assembly-competent and assembly-defective Gag mutants.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	26	 We use this system to demonstrate that capsid formation can be dissociated into co- and posttranslational phases, each of which has distinct requirements.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	27	 The reactions that occur during the posttranslational phase are dependent on ATP and at least two independent host factors, distinguished by their sensitivity to detergent.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	28	 In addition, the posttranslational phase appears to proceed by way of previously unrecognized assembly intermediates.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Expression of Gag mutants that are defective for assembly results in accumulation of these assembly intermediates in the cell-free system.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Similar findings are obtained in cellular systems.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Together, these data indicate that HIV capsid formation is a regulated, energy-dependent, multi-step process involving trans-acting host factors.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	32	Materials and Methods Plasmid Constructions.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	33	All plasmid constructions for cell-free transcription were made using PCR and other standard nucleic acid techniques (Sambrook et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Plasmid vectors were derived from SP64 (Promega, Heidelberg, Germany) into which the 5 untranslated region of Xenopus laevis globin had been inserted at the HindIII site (Melton et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	35	 The gag ORF from HIV genomic DNA (a kind gift of Jay Levy, University of California, San Francisco, CA) was introduced downstream from the SP6 promoter and the globin untranslated region.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	36	 The GA mutation was made by changing glycine at position 2 of Gag to alanine using PCR.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	37	 The Pr46 mutant was made by introducing a stop codon after gly 435 which removes p6; Pr41 has a stop codon after arg 363 (in the COOH-terminal region of p24).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	38	 These truncation mutants are comparable to those described by Jowett et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	39	 To make the D2 mutant, amino acids from gly 250 through val 260 were deleted (Hockley et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	40	 All changes engineered by PCR were verified by DNA sequencing.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	41	Transcription with SP6 polymerase and translation of the transcription products in wheat germ extract containing [35S]methionine (ICN Biochemicals, Irvine, CA) were performed as previously described (Lingappa et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	42	, 1994), except for modifications noted below.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Improved assembly was obtained when wheat germ extract, prepared as described before (Erickson and Blobel, 1983; Lingappa et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	44	, 1994), was subjected to ultracentrifugation at 50,000 rpm (TLA 100 rotor; Beckman Instruments, Palo Alto, CA) for 15 min at 4 degrees C and the supernatant used for in vitro translation (Lingappa, J.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	45	 10  microM myristol CoA (MCoA; Sigma Chemical Co.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Louis, MO) was added at the start of translation when indicated.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Translation reactions ranged in volume from 20 to 100  microl and were incubated at 25 degrees C for 150 min.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Some reactions were adjusted to a final concentration of the following agents at times indicated in figure legends: 0.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	49	2  microM emetine (Sigma Chemical Co); 1.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Results of some cell-free translation and assembly reactions were repeated using rabbit reticulocyte lysate that was prepared as described previously (Merrick, 1983).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	51	 In pulse-chase experiments, translation reactions contained [35S]cysteine (Amersham Corp.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	52	, Arlington Heights, IL) for radiolabeling.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	53	 4 min into translation, 3 mM unlabeled cysteine was added, and the reaction was continued at 25 degrees C for variable chase times, as indicated.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	54	A standard curve for quantity of translation product was established by immunoblotting a cell-free translation product and standards of known concentration (Lingappa, J.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	55	 The amount of Pr55 was determined by interpolation on this curve.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	56	Cell-free reactions were diluted into ice cold NP40 buffer (containing 10 mM TrisAc, pH 7.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	57	4, 100 mM NaCl, 4 mM MgAc, 50 mM KAc, and 1% NP-40) and layered onto the following gradients.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	58	 All sucrose solutions were made using the same buffer.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	59	 After centrifugation (TLS55 rotor; Beckman Instruments), 200  microl fractions were collected serially from the top.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Sucrose step gradients for batch separation of soluble and particulate material (used in Figs.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	61	 1, 2, and 4) contained 600  microl of 66% sucrose, 900  microl of 40% sucrose, and 500  microl of 20% sucrose, and were centrifuged at 30,000 rpm for 35 min at 4 degrees C.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Particles of 500-750-S partition into fractions 4-6, which were collected for further analysis.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Linear 10-50% sucrose gradients (used in Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	64	 1) were centrifuged at 30,000 rpm for 35 min at 4 degrees C.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Immature HIV capsids synthesized in the cell-free system resemble authentic capsids by biochemical and morphologic criteria.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	66	 (A and B) Migration of capsids on velocity sedimentation gradients.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	67	 (A) Cell-free translation and assembly reactions containing 10  microM MCoA and 35S methionine were programmed with HIV Gag transcript and performed as described in Materials and Methods.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	68	 At the end of the reaction, samples were diluted into buffer containing 1% NP-40 and separated into soluble and particulate fractions on sucrose step gradients.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Material in the particulate fraction ( > 500-S) was further analyzed by a variety of methods.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Shown here is an analysis of the particulate fraction by velocity sedimentation on a linear sucrose gradient.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Radiolabeled Pr55 protein in the gradient fractions was visualized by SDSPAGE and autoradiography.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	72	 The autoradiograph shows 10 consecutive fractions of a gradient with the top of the gradient at the left side.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	73	 (B) Cell culture medium was collected from transfected Cos cells that were releasing immature HIV particles.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Virus particles were harvested by ultracentrifugation through a 20% sucrose cushion, as described in Materials and Methods.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Authentic immature capsids were generated by treating these harvested particles with detergent to remove their envelopes.

0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	157	Estimates of S-values of Gag-containing complexes seen on 13 ml sucrose gradients were determined by the method of McEwen (1967) using the following formula: S = I / 2t where S is the sedimentation coefficient of the particle in Svedberg units, I is the time integral for sucrose at the separated zone minus the time integral for sucrose at the meniscus of the gradient,  is rotor speed in radians/sec, and t is time in sec.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	158	Values for I were determined for particles of a density of 1.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	159	3 g/cm3 and for a temperature of 5 degrees C, according to tables published by McEwen (1967).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Calculated S-values for different fractions in the gradients are labeled as markers above each gradient tracing (Figs.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Markers such as BSA (5-S), macroglobulin (20-S), Hepatitis B Virus capsids (100-S), ribosomal subunits (40-S and 60-S), and polysomes ( > 100-S) were used to calibrate the gradients and to confirm the calculated S-values.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	162	 However, it should be noted that the S-value assignments for each Gag-containing complex are meant to be very approximate estimates that allow a general description of the complex and should not be interpreted as constituting a detailed biophysical analysis.

0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	192	Transfections and Production of Authentic Capsids.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	193	Cos-1 cells were transfected by the method of Forsayeth and Garcia (1994) using plasmids pSVGagRRE-R and pSVRev (Smith et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	194	, 1993) that were a kind gift of D.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Rekosh (University of Virginia, Charlottesville, VA).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	196	 4 d after transfection, immature HIV particles were purified from the culture medium by sedimentation through a 4 ml 20% sucrose cushion in an SW 40 rotor at 29,000 rpm for 120 min (Mergener et al.
