0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	198	 These de-enveloped, authentic immature HIV capsids were used as standards and analyzed in parallel with the products of cell-free reactions by a variety of methods, including velocity sedimentation, equilibrium centrifugation, and electron microscopy.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	199	Lysate of transfected Cos cells was prepared by solubilizing transfected cells on 60-mm plates in 700  microl 1% NP-40 buffer.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	200	 This detergent lysate was passaged 20 times through a 20-gauge needle, and clarified by centrifugation for 10 min at 2000 g, and 150  microl of this supernatent was loaded onto 13 ml gradients for analysis, as described.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Gag polypeptide present in the fractions was visualized by immunoblotting with a monoclonal antibody to Gag (Dako, Santa Barbara, CA).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Bound antibody was detected using an enhanced chemiluminescence system (Amersham Intl.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Band density was determined as described under image analysis below, and relative band densities were confirmed by quantitating films representing different exposure times.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	204	Cell-free reactions as well as authentic capsid standards were rapidly separated into soluble and particulate fractions on 2 ml 20-80% linear sucrose gradients by centrifugation for 10 min at 30,000 rpm.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Under these conditions, authentic capsids partition into fractions 3-5, as determined in advance by immunoblotting of standards with Gag antibody.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	206	 EM grids were glow discharged, and a drop of the Gag antibody was placed on each grid and allowed to air dry.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Grids were inserted into eppendorf tubes containing particulate material from sucrose gradients and incubated for 10 min at 4 degrees C to allow antibodies to bind to Gag-containing particles.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Grids were then rinsed in water, and negative staining with uranyl acetate was performed as described (Dubochet et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	209	 The following negative controls were analyzed in parallel: control transfections, in which Cos cells were transfected with lac Z-containing plasmids; and mock cell-free reactions, which were generated by programming in vitro transcriptions with buffer instead of gag cDNA and using this mock transcript for cell-free translation and assembly reactions.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Experiments were repeated three additional times in a single blind fashion.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	211	 In each of these experiments, the microscopist was able to correctly assign the identity of each sample based on the presence or absence of particles.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	212	Autoradiographs were digitized using an AGFA Focus Color Plus scanner and Adobe Photoshop software (Adobe Systems Incorporated, Mountain View, CA).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Mean band densities were determined and adjusted for band size and background.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	214	Results Reconstitution of Immature HIV Capsid Assembly in a Cell-free System.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	215	Since we were interested in dissecting the early steps of capsid assembly rather than the better understood late stage of capsid maturation, we chose to study formation of immature HIV capsids, which undergo all of the steps of capsid assembly except the final protease-dependent maturation event.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Assembly of immature capsids in cells requires expression of only the HIV Pr55 protein (Gheysen et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	217	 However, we and others (Sakalian et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	218	, 1996) have found that standard in vitro translation systems, consisting of a cytosolic extract, amino acids, an ATP regenerating system, and in vitro synthesized transcript coding for Pr55 Gag, fail to support assembly of HIV capsids (data not shown).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Since assembly of HIV capsids, as well as assembly of other retroviral capsids, is known to require myristoylation of Gag (Gheysen et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	220	, 1989) as well as targeting of Gag to membranes (Jacobs et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	221	, 1989; Bryant and Ratner, 1990; Rhee and Hunter, 1990; Wang and Barklis, 1993; Platt and Haffar, 1994; Hockley et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	222	, 1994), we modified the standard system to ensure that these events take place.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	223	 MCoA was added to the reaction, and cellular extracts were fractionated to optimize capsid assembly.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	224	 Translation of transcript encoding Gag in this cell-free system resulted in the synthesis of ~2 ng of Pr55 protein/ microl translation reaction (data not shown).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	225	We expected some of these newly synthesized Pr55 chains to become myristoylated, target to membrane vesicles present in the cellular extract, and assemble into stable capsids.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Other Pr55 chains might achieve some but not all of the steps in capsid assembly, and would therefore be detectable as heterogeneous assembly intermediates.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	227	 To quantify the amount of assembly, an efficient method of separating assembled capsids from the remainder of the translation reaction was required.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	228	 This was achieved in two steps.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	229	 First, after completion of the assembly reaction, membrane vesicles were solubilized using the nonionic detergent NP-40.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	230	 This treatment, which removes membranes enveloping capsids but does not affect the integrity of fully assembled capsids (Yu et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	231	, 1994), should solubilize unassembled Pr55 chains that may be anchored to membranes.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Secondly, the detergent-treated, completed reaction was size fractionated on a sucrose step gradient into a soluble fraction (containing material of  < 500-S) and a particulate fraction (containing material between 500- and 1,000-S) that would be expected to contain completed immature capsids (Royer et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	233	 Thus, while our standard translation and assembly reaction was carried out in the absence of detergent to allow association with membrane vesicles, analysis of the reaction product was performed in the presence of detergent, allowing the assembly status of the naked proteinacious capsid to be assessed.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	234	We found that the particulate fraction from a typical translation and assembly reaction contained between 15 and 40% of the total Pr55 synthesized (see Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	235	 To assess whether this fraction contained properly assembled immature capsids, it was further analyzed by velocity sedimentation on linear sucrose gradients, equilibrium centrifugation in CsCl, and EM.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	236	 For comparison, authentic immature HIV capsids produced in transfected cultured COS-1 cells were analyzed in parallel.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	237	 We found that both detergent-treated capsids generated in the cell-free system and detergent-treated (de-enveloped) authentic capsids behaved as a relatively homogenous population of particles of ~750-S (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	238	 1, A and B), with a buoyant density of 1.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	239	 Additionally, cell-free assembled capsids and the authentic standard were identical in size as judged by gel filtration (data not shown).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	240	 When examined by EM, we found that capsids made in the cellfree system (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	241	 1 E, 1-4) were morphologically similar to authentic capsids released from transfected cells (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	242	 1 E, 5 and 6) and had the expected diameter of ~100 nm (Gelderblom, 1991).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	243	 Thus, on average, 25% of the radiolabeled Pr55 protein synthesized in the cell-free system assembles into particles that closely resemble authentic immature HIV capsids generated in transfected cells, as judged by EM appearance as well as the biochemical criteria of size, sedimentation coefficient, and buoyant density.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	244	Fidelity of Cell-free HIV Capsid Assembly.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	245	To determine whether the process of capsid assembly in the cell-free system is the same as that which occurs in cells, we examined whether known characteristics of capsid assembly were also reconstituted.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	246	 Studies in cellular systems have demonstrated that myristoylation of Gag is required for proper capsid assembly (Gheysen, 1989; Gottlinger, 1989).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	247	 This NH2-terminal modification is thought to occur co-translationally (Wilcox et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	248	 To assess the role of myristoylation in the cell-free system we omitted MCoA from the assembly reaction, or added it posttranslationally at 90 min into the reaction (when  > 90% of Pr55 chains have finished synthesis; data not shown).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	249	 In both cases, a dramatic decrease in capsid assembly was observed (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	250	 Consistent with these data, we found that a Gag mutant that fails to become myristoylated (GA) also does not assemble in the cell-free system (see Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	251	In cells, assembly of HIV capsids takes place at the inner surface of the host cell plasma membrane (Gelderblom, 1991; Wills and Craven, 1991).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Membrane targeting of Pr55 chains is directed by the NH2-terminal myristate moiety and by internal domains of the Pr55 polypeptide (Jacobs et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	253	, 1989; Bryant and Ratner, 1990; Wang and Barklis, 1993; Platt and Haffar, 1994; Hockley et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	254	 Studies using Pr55 mutations have shown that abolishing membrane targeting results in inefficient capsid assembly and failure of capsid release (Jacobs et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	255	, 1989; Bryant and Ratner 1990).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	256	 For this reason, targeting to plasma membranes is thought to facilitate the nucleation of Gag chains at a site within the cell where assembly, envelopment, and budding of the newly formed capsids can occur.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	257	 If immature HIV capsid assembly in the cell-free system requires membrane fragments (which are present in the wheat germ extracts used), it should be sensitive to addition of detergent at concentrations that solubilize membranes.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	258	 Thus, as a final criterion of authenticity of the cell-free capsid assembly reaction, we investigated the sensitivity of cell-free capsid assembly to the presence of detergent during the translation and assembly reaction.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	259	 We treated the assembly reaction with a gentle, nonionic detergent that does not inhibit any of the enzymatic reactions involved in protein synthesis (Walter and Blobel, 1980) and thus would not be likely to affect protein interactions involved in assembly.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	260	 As expected, the detergent Nikkol added to a concentration of 0.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	261	1% at the beginning of the translation reaction had no effect on Gag polypeptide synthesis (data not shown).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	262	 2 B, Nikkol at this concentration largely abolished capsid assembly.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	263	 This effect was not observed when Nikkol was used at a concentration of 0.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	264	002%, which is below that required to disrupt lipid bilayers (Walter and Blobel, 1980).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	265	 Furthermore, we found that Nikkol added after the completion of the 150 min assembly reaction did not diminish the amount of assembly, even when added to a concentration of 1.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	266	 Thus, it appears that whereas the completed capsid particle itself is not sensitive to Nikkol (even at high concentrations), assembly of this structure is inhibited by concentrations of Nikkol that are sufficient to solubilize membranes.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	267	 These data are consistent with the idea that membranes are required for newly synthesized Pr55 to be efficiently assembled into capsids in the cell-free system.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	268	 Thus, the dependence of assembly on cotranslational myristoylation and the apparent requirement for membranes indicate that capsid assembly in the cell-free system faithfully reproduces characteristics of capsid assembly that have been described in cellular systems.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	269	Studies of capsid assembly in cell culture model systems have revealed that certain mutations within the Gag coding region disrupt immature HIV capsid assembly.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	270	 As a third criterion for fidelity, we examined the assembly phenotypes in the cell-free system of four previously described mutations in Gag (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	271	 3 A): (a) the Pr46 mutant, in which the COOH-terminal p6 domain of Gag is deleted (Royer et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	272	, 1994); (b) the Pr41 mutant, in which the deleted domains include p6, p7, and the distal end of p24 containing the p24-p7 protease cleavage site (Gheysen et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	273	, 1994); (c) the D2 mutation, in which 10 amino acids of the p24 domain of Gag (upstream of the p24-p7 protease cleavage site) are deleted (Hockley et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	274	, 1994); and (d) the GA mutation, an NH2-terminal single amino acid substitution that abolishes myristoylation of Gag (Gottlinger et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	275	, 1989; Bryant and Ratner, 1990).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	276	 Upon expression in cells, only the Pr46 mutant was capable of producing viral particles indistinguishable from those produced by expression of wild-type Gag (Royer et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	277	 Each of the other three mutants fails to result in proper viral particle production and release (Gheysen et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	278	, 1989; Bryant and Ratner, 1990; Jowett et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	279	Assembly reactions were programmed with transcript encoding each of these mutations and the amount of immature capsid produced was quantitated as described in the legend of Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	280	 3 B, the Pr41 and GA mutants failed to assemble into completed capsids, while ~40% of the total translation product of the assembly-competent Pr46 mutant and wild-type Gag assembled into completed capsids.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	281	 The D2 mutant appeared to have generated a small amount of material in the region of completed capsids, but further analysis of this material revealed it to be the trail of a large Gag complex (of ~400- 500 S) that does not comigrate with completed capsid (see Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	282	 Thus, like Pr41 and GA, D2 did not assemble into the 750-S completed capsid.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	283	 Together, these data indicate that the cell-free system appears to faithfully reproduce phenotypes of a variety of assembly-defective and -competent mutations in Gag.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	284	Posttranslational Requirements for Capsid Assembly.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	285	For optimum assembly to occur, the cell-free reaction must be incubated at 25 degrees C for at least 150 min (data not shown).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	286	 We observed that whereas the majority of Pr55 synthesis occurs during the first hour of this incubation, significant capsid formation does not take place until the final 90 min of the reaction.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	287	 Thus, an aliquot of the reaction incubated for only 50 min contains ~60% of the full length Pr55 chains that are present in an aliquot incubated for the standard 150 min (data not shown).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	288	 However, essentially none of the chains present at the 50 min time point has assembled into capsids (data not shown), while at 150 min 25% have completed the assembly process (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	289	 This indicated to us that it might be possible to completely separate the translation and assembly phases of the reaction.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	290	 To confirm this, a reaction was split into two aliquots at 50 min into the incubation.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	291	 To one aliquot we added emetine, which blocks translation by inhibiting chain elongation, and then both aliquots were incubated to 150 min.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	292	 While total Pr55 synthesis in the emetine-treated reaction was 60% of the control (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	293	 4 A, compare gel lanes 1 and 2), the proportion of capsid assembly in this treated reaction was comparable to that of the untreated control (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	294	 4 A, bar graph), indicating that assembly takes place even when translation is halted.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	295	 Based on these data, one would expect that manipulations performed after emetine treatment would have effects on only the posttranslational phase of assembly and should not affect Pr55 synthesis, which is already completed.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	296	Having established a means of analyzing events specific to assembly, we then examined whether the previously described detergent sensitivity of HIV capsid assembly (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	297	 2 B) was due to an effect on co- or posttranslational events.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	298	 We treated Pr55 reactions with emetine and 0.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	299	1% Nikkol at 50 min into the reaction, continued the incubation to 150 min, and then determined the amount of assembly as previously described.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	300	 Under these conditions, assembly was dramatically reduced (data not shown), just as it had been when Nikkol was added at the start of translation (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	301	 Therefore, we conclude that the detergent sensitive step(s) in HIV capsid assembly occurs posttranslationally.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	302	Next we examined whether posttranslational events in capsid assembly are dependent on the presence of ATP.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	303	 Translation of Gag was allowed to proceed for 50 min, at which point further protein synthesis was inhibited with emetine.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	304	 The sample was divided, and one aliquot was depleted of ATP by the addition of apyrase, an enzyme that hydrolyzes free ATP.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	305	 After completion of the assembly reaction, samples were analyzed as previously described for the amount of assembly that had occurred.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	306	 We found that depletion of free ATP from the assembly reaction resulted in a dramatic reduction in capsid assembly (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	307	 The effect of ATP depletion was not reversed by addition of the nonhydrolyzable analogues, AMP-PNP or GTP-S (data not shown), suggesting that ATP hydrolysis, and not just ATP binding, is required.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	308	 As expected, addition of apyrase did not change the total amount of Pr55 synthesis (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	309	 4 A, compare gel lanes 2 and 3).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	310	 Furthermore, adding apyrase to the reaction after capsid assembly was completed had no effect on the amount of assembly (data not shown), ruling out the possibility of an effect of apyrase or ATP depletion on capsid stability.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	311	 These data indicate that there is a requirement for ATP in the capsid assembly process, and that this ATP dependence is distinct from the energy requirements of protein synthesis.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	312	A Subcellular Fraction Is Required for Capsid Assembly.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	313	Given that the Gag protein itself is not known to bind or hydrolyze ATP, the requirement for this energy substrate suggests that a host protein or proteins are involved in the assembly reaction.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	314	 Demonstrating that such a host factor is required would involve showing that assembly fails to occur when this factor is depleted from the cellular extracts used in the assembly reaction.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	315	 Furthermore, adding back the depleted fraction to the reaction should restore assembly.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	316	 Thus, we sought to fractionate the translation extract in a manner that would leave intact all of the components needed for translation but remove at least one component required for assembly.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	317	 The cellular extract used for translation and assembly was subfractionated by ultracentrifugation into two portions: HSS and HSP.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	318	 The HSS, depleted of components that were 90-S or greater, supported Pr55 translation but not its assembly (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	319	 This indicates that the HSP likely contains an assembly specific host factor(s).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	320	 This was demonstrated directly by showing that addition of the HSP posttranslationally (after emetine treatment) to unassembled Gag chains synthesized in the HSS resulted in a considerable restoration of particle assembly (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	321	 As expected, total synthesis of Pr55 was unaltered by addition of the HSP (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	322	 Together, these data indicate that a subcellular fraction of the eukaryotic cell lysate is required for posttranslational events in capsid assembly to take place.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	323	We had previously observed that detergent also disrupts the posttranslational phase of capsid assembly (data not shown).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	324	 We examined, therefore, whether the HSP contained the detergent-sensitive component that is required for capsid formation.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	325	 HSP was prepared from a cell extract treated with detergent (0.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	326	 The resulting HSP was washed with detergent-free buffer and added posttranslationally to an assembly reaction.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	327	 We found that the HSP from the detergent-treated extract was as active in promoting posttranslational capsid formation as the control HSP (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	328	 Thus, separate detergent-sensitive and -insensitive host factors appear to be involved in the posttranslational phase of HIV capsid assembly.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	329	 Furthermore, the detergent-insensitive host factor can be depleted by ultracentrifugation and then reconstituted by posttranslational addition.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	330	Intermediates in the Assembly of HIV Capsids.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	331	The existence of multiple specific requirements for HIV capsid biogenesis, including host factors and ATP, suggests that discrete biochemical intermediates may exist during the assembly process.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	332	 To date, such intermediates in capsid assembly have not been described, most likely due to the difficulty of detection in cellular systems where they would be present only transiently and in minute quantities.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	333	 Since the cell-free system is less efficient at forming completed capsids than are cellular systems, it might constitute a better system for detecting such assembly intermediates.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	334	 Consistent with this possibility, we found that under conditions where only a small amount of 750-S capsid assembly occurs in the cell-free reaction, analysis of the reaction products on 13 ml velocity sedimentation gradients revealed the presence of a series of Gag-containing complexes, in addition to 750-S completed capsids (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	335	 These complexes, which have calculated sedimentation coefficients of ~10-S, 80-S, and 150-S, will henceforth be referred to as complexes A, B, and C, respectively.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	336	If these complexes represent assembly intermediates, they would be expected to be present in large quantities at early time points, and to be diminished at later times in the reaction.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	337	 To assess whether these complexes displayed this behavior, we used a pulse-chase analysis to follow a small cohort of radiolabeled Pr55 chains over time.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	338	 The cell-free reaction was performed with radiolabeled cysteine.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	339	 After the first 4 min of translation, an excess of unlabeled cysteine was added to abolish further labeling of subsequently synthesized Pr55 chains.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	340	 We observed that the total amount of radiolabeled Pr55 was the same at 25 and 150 min into the pulse-chase reaction (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	341	 5 B), indicating that neither further radiolabeling nor degradation of Pr55 had occurred after 25 min and confirming that the same population of Pr55 chains was being analyzed at both times.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	342	 Aliquots of the cell-free reactions were removed at the times indicated, treated with detergent, and then analyzed on 13 ml velocity sedimentation gradients.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	343	At 25 min into the reaction, all of the radiolabeled Pr55 was found in complexes A, B, and C (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	344	 5 C), with no radiolabeled Pr55 present in the region of completed 750-S capsids.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	345	 While complexes A and B appear as peaks at ~ the 10-S and 80-S positions of the gradient, complex C appears as a less distinct shoulder in approximately the 150-S position.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	346	 In marked contrast, examination of the assembly reaction at 150 min showed that a significant amount of radiolabeled Pr55 was assembled into completed capsids that migrated in the 750-S position (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	347	 Correspondingly, the amount of Pr55 in complexes A, B, and C was diminished by precisely the amount that was now found to be assembled, demonstrating that at least some of the material in complexes A, B, and C constitutes intermediates in the biogenesis of completed 750-S capsids.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	348	At extremely short chase times (i.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	349	, 13 min), when only some of the radiolabeled chains have completed synthesis, full length Pr55 chains were found exclusively in complex A on 13 ml sucrose gradients, while nascent chains that are not yet completed were in the form of polysomes of greater than 100-S (data not shown).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	350	 Thus, polysome-associated nascent chains of Gag constitute the starting material in this pathway, and the 10-S complex A, which contains completed Gag chains, is likely to be the first intermediate in the formation of immature capsids.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	351	 It is possible, therefore, that complexes B and C represent later assembly intermediates in the pathway of capsid formation.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	352	If complexes A, B, and C do in fact constitute intermediates in assembly, one would predict that blockade of assembly would result in accumulation of Gag chains in the form of complexes with those S values.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	353	 Furthermore, one would expect that blockade at different points along this pathway would result in accumulation of complexes A, B, and C in various combinations, as determined by the order of their appearance along the assembly pathway.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	354	 For example, if an ordered pathway of intermediates exists, then blockade at early points in the pathway should result in accumulation of one or two Gag-containing complexes corresponding to early putative assembly intermediates, while blockade at a very late point in the pathway would result in accumulation of all the putative assembly intermediates but not the final completed capsid product.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	355	 To test these predictions, we blocked assembly in a variety of ways, both pharmacologically and through the use of mutations, and examined the Gag-containing complexes that were formed.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	356	Pharmacological Blockade Results in Accumulation of Assembly Intermediates.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	357	Capsid assembly was disrupted by adding either apyrase posttranslationally (as in Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	358	 3) or detergent co-translationally (as in Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	359	 2), and the reaction products were analyzed by velocity sedimentation as described for Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	360	 Material in fractions corresponding to the assembly intermediates and completed capsid were quantified and are presented in Table I.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	361	 The untreated reaction contained Pr55 in complexes A, B, and C, as well as a peak in the final 750-S capsid position, while the treated reactions, as expected, contained no peak at the position of the final capsid product (Table I).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	362	 Treatment with either apyrase or detergent resulted in accumulation of additional material in complexes B and C, but did not result in accumulation of additional material in complex A.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	363	 This is consistent with the idea that complexes B and C are the more immediate precursors of the 750-S completed capsids, and that these interventions block the conversion of complexes B and C into the fully assembled capsid end product.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	364	 Effect of ATP Hydrolysis and Detergent Treatment on Assembly Intermediates.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	365	Assembly-defective Mutants Are Arrested at Specific Points in the Assembly Pathway.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	366	To determine whether the putative assembly intermediates accumulate when capsid assembly is blocked by specific mutations in Gag, cell-free reactions were programmed with each of the previously described assembly-competent and -defective Gag mutants (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	367	 3), incubated for 150 min, and then analyzed by velocity sedimentation.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	368	 Reactions programmed with wild-type Gag (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	369	 6 A) or the assembly-competent Pr46 mutant (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	370	 6 B) were found to have nearly identical profiles, in which  > 30% of the radiolabeled Gag chains synthesized formed completed immature capsids (that migrate at 750-S), and the remainder was in the form of residual putative assembly intermediates A and B.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	371	 Thus, these two assembly-competent forms of Gag appear to be indistinguishable in the cell-free system just as they are when expressed in cells (Royer et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	372	 6 C shows the same analysis for the assembly defective Pr41 mutant.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	373	 We found that all of the radiolabeled chains at the end of the Pr41 cell-free reaction were contained in a single complex that peaks at ~10-S and corresponds to complex A.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	374	 Since the 10-S peak was very large and led to an irregular trail that could be masking 80- or 150-S peaks, we reanalyzed the products of a Pr41 reaction on a gradient that allowed high resolution in the 1-200-S size range (data not shown) and confirmed that all of the Pr41 translation product was present in complex A, which was ~10-S in size.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	375	 Thus, in the cell-free system, it appears that Pr41 fails to progress beyond complex A, which is likely to represent the first intermediate in the assembly pathway.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	376	Like Pr41, the myristoylation-incompetent GA mutant failed to assemble into 750-S capsids (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	377	 6 D), but unlike Pr41, GA had distinct peaks in both the 10- and 80-S regions of the gradient (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	378	 These data indicate that the GA mutant, which contains the entire Gag coding region except for the myristoylation signal, is capable of forming complex A, which appeared to be the first assembly intermediate in the pulse-chase experiment, as well as complex B, but does not progress further towards forming completed capsids.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	379	 These data suggest that complex B is likely to be the second assembly intermediate formed in the biogenesis of immature HIV capsids.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	380	Previously, we had shown that in the absence of exogenously added MCoA, wild-type Gag failed to assemble in the cell-free system (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	381	 2 A), consistent with previous observations that myristoylation is required for proper capsid assembly to occur.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	382	 Thus, a cell-free reaction programmed with wild-type Gag but performed in the absence of MCoA would be expected to be blocked at the same point in the assembly pathway as the GA mutant.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	383	 Consistent with this, we found that assembly performed in the absence of MCoA resulted in formation of only complexes A and B (data not shown), and therefore closely resembled the GA mutant shown in Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	384	Analysis of a cell-free reaction programmed with the D2 mutant is shown in Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	385	 Unlike the previously described assembly-defective mutants, D2 was found to form a spectrum of Gag-containing complexes, including peaks corresponding to complexes A and B (at ~10- and 80-S), a shoulder corresponding to complex C (in the 150-S region), and an additional peak of ~400-500-S, that will henceforth be referred to as complex D.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	386	 Note that complex D trails into the 750-S region, accounting for the appearance of a small amount of assembly in the simpler analysis presented in Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	387	 However, the detailed analysis presented here makes it clear that in fact there is no discrete peak in the region of completed capsid (750-S).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	388	 Thus, the D2 mutant appears to form a series of complexes corresponding in size to the assembly intermediates seen in the pulse-chase experiment (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	389	 5), as well as an additional complex of larger size, but fails to produce the completed 750-S product.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	390	Gag-containing Complexes within Mammalian Cells.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	391	Having demonstrated by pulse-chase analysis, pharmacologic blockade, and analysis of mutants that assembly intermediates appear to exist in the cell-free system, we then examined whether complexes of the same sizes are present in mammalian cells that are expressing wild-type Gag or Gag mutants.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	392	 The finding of such complexes would be consistent with the existence of similar transient intermediates in vivo.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	393	Cos cells transfected with wild-type Gag were lysed in detergent, and the lysate was analyzed on 13 ml velocity sedimentation gradients, as in Figs.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	394	 Gradient fractions were immunoblotted with Gag antibody, and the relative amount of Gag polypeptide present in each fraction was quantitated as described in Materials and Methods (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	395	 The cell lysate contained Pr55 in a spectrum of complexes ranging from 10- to ~200-S.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	396	 Since cells efficiently release completed HIV capsids, most of the completed capsid would be expected to be in the medium at steady state.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	397	 This was confirmed by the finding that a substantial amount of fully assembled 750-S capsid was present in the medium (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	398	 7 A, open circles), while the cell lysate contained no 750-S capsids (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	399	 We conclude, therefore, that within cells, Pr55 is present in a heterogeneous mixture of complexes that have S values similar to complexes A, B, and C, the assembly intermediates found in the cell-free system.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	400	If these complexes correspond to the assembly intermediates seen in the cell-free system, one would expect that different assembly-defective mutants would result in the accumulation of the same sized complexes in cellular systems as they do in the cell-free system.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	401	 Thus, we examined whether the Pr41 mutant, which appears to be blocked after the first assembly intermediate in the cell-free system, and the D2 mutant, which appears to be blocked at the end of the assembly pathway in the cell-free system, resulted in corresponding patterns of Gag-containing complexes within cells.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	402	 Cos cells were transfected with each of these mutants, and the medium as well as the lysate were examined by immunoblotting.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	403	 As expected, medium from cells transfected with the assembly-defective Pr41 or D2 did not contain 750-S completed capsids (data not shown).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	404	 The cell lysate of Cos cells transfected with the Pr41 mutant contained only material that peaked in the 10-S region of the velocity gradient (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	405	 7 B), resembling what had been found when the Pr41 mutant was expressed in the cell-free system (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	406	 The observation that the Pr41 reaction product migrated as a single complex that peaked in the 10-S region was confirmed by analysis on a variety of different velocity sedimentation gradients that allowed higher resolution in the 1-200-S size range (data not shown).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	407	 In contrast, the cell lysate of Cos cells transfected with the D2 mutant contained a spectrum of immunoreactive complexes that ranged in size from 10-500-S (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	408	 7 C), resembling what had been found when D2 was expressed in the cell-free system (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	409	 Thus, the data from transfected cells suggests that the behavior of Gag mutants in the cell-free system reflects events in capsid assembly that occur in living cells.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	410	In this paper, we first demonstrate that immature HIV capsids can be assembled in a cell-free system.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	411	 We establish that the capsids produced closely resemble immature HIV capsids produced in cellular systems (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	412	 1) and that key known features of capsid assembly are faithfully reproduced in this cell-free system (Figs.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	413	 We then use it to dissect assembly into a number of steps.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	414	 First, through the use of an inhibitor of protein synthesis, we demonstrate that assembly can be resolved into a co-translational phase, during which Pr55 polypeptides are synthesized, followed by a posttranslational phase, during which additional events necessary for assembly take place.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	415	 Being able to separate these two phases allows us to analyze reactions specific to the assembly process, independent of other events such as protein synthesis.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	416	By manipulating the posttranslational phase of assembly, we then demonstrate that it has at least three specific requirements (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	417	 First, ATP is necessary, since the enzyme apyrase is able to effectively block the posttranslational progression of completed Pr55 chains into fully assembled capsids.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	418	 Second, this phase is sensitive to nonionic detergent, implying that membrane fragments are likely to be involved.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	419	 Third, using a depletion and reconstitution approach, we demonstrate that a subcellular fraction of eukaryotic cell lysate is required for the posttranslational assembly events to take place.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	420	In addition, multiple criteria are used to demonstrate that the posttranslational phase of assembly proceeds by way of a series of Gag-containing complexes that appear to constitute intermediates in the cell-free capsid assembly reaction (Figs.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	421	 Finally, we show that complexes resembling assembly intermediates may also be present in cellular systems that are producing immature HIV particles, and that mutants in Gag have a similar behavior in both cellular and cell-free systems (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	422	Novel Requirements for HIV Capsid Assembly.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	423	To date, studies have not revealed whether HIV capsid assembly occurs by way of a passive process of Gag polypeptide multimerization, or whether assembly is an active, regulated process requiring Gag associations with other proteins, as well as Gag-Gag interactions.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	424	 By demonstrating that the posttranslational phase of assembly requires ATP and a detergent-insensitive host cell component, our data indicate that in fact HIV capsid assembly is an energydependent, coordinated process in which host proteins play a crucial role.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	425	 Thus, the model of HIV capsid assembly supported by our data is conceptually very different from the view that many viral capsids are formed from capsid monomers by way of a passive process of "self assembly," requiring no components besides the individual capsid protein subunits (Klug, 1980).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	426	 Indeed, while host factors have not previously been documented to play a role in the assembly of HIV capsids, the possibility of their existence has been raised by data demonstrating that yeast expressing Gag do not support HIV capsid assembly (Jacobs et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	427	, 1989), while baculovirus and mammalian systems of expression do (for review see Boulanger and Jones, 1996).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	428	 Such studies imply that yeast either contain a factor that inhibits HIV capsid assembly (that is absent in higher eukaryotes) or lack a factor necessary for assembly (that is present in higher eukaryotes).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	429	 Our data support the latter possibility.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	430	 Consistent with the notion that previously unrecognized host factors may be important at various points in the HIV life cycle is the recent demonstration that cyclophilins are associated with the HIV virus particle and are required for infectivity (Luban et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	431	The finding that HIV capsid assembly requires ATP as well as host cell components suggests that the posttranslational phase of assembly may occur via a step-wise pathway of previously unrecognized assembly intermediates.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	432	 We present three lines of evidence to support this view.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	433	 First, using a pulse-chase analysis we demonstrate that a population of lower molecular weight Gag-containing complexes, referred to as complexes A, B, and C, is present at early time points in capsid assembly, and that Gag polypeptides from this population are converted into the final capsid product over time.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	434	 Note that the possibility that these complexes represent polyribosomes has been ruled out by the demonstration that they are not sensitive to RNase A used at concentrations that result in complete digestion of messenger RNA (Lingappa, J.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	435	 At very short chase times, all of the radiolabeled Pr55 in the pulse-chase reaction is present in complex A, suggesting that this may be the first intermediate in the assembly reaction, appearing after completed Gag chains are released from ribosomes.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	436	 It remains to be determined whether complex A constitutes either a monomer or dimer of Gag, or whether it is composed of a Gag chain associated with a host protein.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	437	Secondly, we show that by blocking assembly pharmacologically, using either apyrase or detergent, material in two of these complexes (complexes B and C) accumulates, indicating that they are likely to be precursors to the completed 750-S capsid end product.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	438	 Note that these data do not exclude the existence of other intermediates that might occur later in the pathway.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	439	 Such intermediates would not be seen with apyrase or detergent blockade, since these agents appear to block assembly by preventing progression beyond the 150-S complex.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	440	 The demonstration that both detergent and ATP depletion appear to result in the accumulation of the same assembly intermediates raises the possibility that this point in the assembly pathway may be a critical one, in which a variety of events necessary for assembly must take place in a coordinated fashion.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	441	 Further work will be required to determine whether this represents an important point of regulation in the assembly pathway.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	442	Finally, the analysis of three different Gag mutants that are known to be assembly defective lends further support to the presence of assembly intermediates.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	443	 We find that each mutant results in the accumulation of different subsets of these assembly intermediates.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	444	 Thus, a mutant that appears to be blocked after the first step in the assembly pathway results in the accumulation of complex A alone (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	445	 6 C), while one that appears to be blocked after the second step of the pathway results in accumulation of complex A and complex B (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	446	 A spectrum of complexes, including complexes A, B, and C, as well as the larger complex D, is seen upon expression of a mutant that appears to be blocked at a very late step in the assembly pathway (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	447	 Thus, analysis of these mutants supports the existence of intermediates in the assembly of HIV capsids, and also suggests an order to the appearance of such intermediates during the process of capsid assembly.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	448	There are a number of caveats to our demonstration of assembly intermediates.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	449	 First, one or more of these putative intermediates could in fact constitute a side reaction or dead end byproduct off the main pathway of capsid assembly.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	450	 The most likely candidate for such a dead-end byproduct is complex D, which is only clearly apparent in the analysis of the assembly-defective D2 mutant (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	451	 Arguing against the possibility that complexes A, B, or C are simply nonproductive side reactions is the finding that the amount of each of these complexes varies inversely with the amount of completed, immature capsid formed.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	452	 Such behavior would be expected for assembly intermediates but not for dead-end byproducts or side reactions.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	453	 For example, the quantity of each of these complexes decreases over time in the pulse-chase experiment, during a period when completed capsids are appearing and the total number of radiolabeled Gag chains present is constant (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	454	 Likewise, complexes B and C increase in quantity when formation of capsids is blocked (Table I).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	455	 Additionally, in an analysis of a mutant that is more efficient in capsid production than wild-type cells, we find that the amount of complex A drops to very low levels when very large amounts of capsid are being made (Hill, R.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	456	 Lingappa, unpublished observation).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	457	 Thus, the simplest interpretation of our data is that the Gag complexes A, B, and C constitute true assembly intermediates, although definitive proof of this must await a functional examination of each of these intermediates in isolation.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	458	A second caveat is that our analysis could be complicated by instability of Gag-containing complexes.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	459	 Thus, lower molecular weight complexes could actually result from disassembly of a higher order complex.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	460	 This seems unlikely to be a significant problem in our system, given that we have not observed any of the Gag-containing complexes to be labile in our studies.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	461	 For example, in the pulse- chase experiments (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	462	 5), there is a clear-cut progression over time from complexes A, B, and C to completed immature capsids.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	463	 Residual amounts of complexes A and B present at the end of the incubation are likely due to incomplete conversion resulting from depletion and inactivation of necessary factors over time.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	464	A third caveat that should be noted is that there may exist additional intermediates in HIV capsid assembly that are not obvious from our current analysis.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	465	 Finally, we wish to point out that the S-values assigned to each of the complexes described here are only approximate S-values, calculated from the migration of these complexes in velocity sedimentation gradients (see Materials and Methods).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	466	 While one or more complexes may not appear to be distinct in a particular experiment or a particular gradient (i.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	467	 5 C), the specific complexes described here have been seen repeatedly in many different experiments and under a variety of gradient conditions and therefore are likely to represent discrete complexes that are difficult to resolve perfectly in every experiment given their transient and dynamic nature.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	468	A Multi-step Pathway for the Assembly of HIV Capsids.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	469	Together, our results support a model of capsid assembly as a stepwise process consisting of discrete biochemical events with specific requirements for ATP and at least one detergent-insensitive component of eukaryotic cell lysate.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	470	 8 presents the simplest scenario that unifies the data presented here.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	471	 While further analysis of this system may reveal additional complexities, this scheme presents a biochemical framework against which hypotheses can now be tested.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	472	 A model for the assembly of immature HIV capsids.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	473	 This model is based on the simplest interpretation of the data presented.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	474	 Newly synthesized Gag proteins are myristoylated cotranslationally.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	475	 Nascent Gag polypeptides appear to chase into completed immature capsids by way of a series of Gag-containing complexes (complexes A, B, C, and D).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	476	 Evidence presented in the text suggests that complexes A, B, and C may constitute assembly intermediates.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	477	 It is less clear whether complex D constitutes an assembly intermediate or a side reaction.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	478	 Both ATP and a subcellular fraction of eukaryotic cell extract are required for assembly to take place, while detergent and apyrase are proposed to disrupt assembly at the indicated position.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	479	 The points along the pathway at which various mutants of Gag are arrested are indicated below the model.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	480	 [View Larger Version of this Image (11K GIF file)].
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	481	While intermediates along such a pathway have not been demonstrated previously within cells, this could be a consequence of their transient nature and the difficulties involved in manipulating cellular systems.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	482	 Further work will be required to determine to what extent the mechanism of cell-free HIV capsid assembly reflects biochemical events that occur in vivo.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	483	 Here we show that, under steady state conditions, cells releasing immature HIV capsids contain Pr55 complexes that correspond in approximate size to complexes A, B, and C, the assembly intermediates observed in the cell-free system.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	484	 In addition, assembly-defective mutants arrested at specific complexes in the cell-free system appear to be arrested in the form of similar sized complexes when they are expressed in cells (Fig.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	485	 While these data do not constitute proof that assembly intermediates exist in cells, they lend support to the idea that the process of HIV capsid assembly in the cell-free system is closely correlated to the capsid assembly process in cells.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	486	 It should be noted that in other biological systems, transient intermediates that have been well documented in cell-free reactions have yet to be identified in cells.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	487	 For example, in the case of targeting of nascent secretory proteins to the endoplasmic reticulum, signal recognition particle-bound nascent chains have been demonstrated biochemically only in cell-free systems (Walter and Blobel, 1983), even though genetic evidence confirms the importance of signal recognition particles in vivo (Hann and Walter, 1991).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	488	A Mechanistic View of HIV Capsid Assembly.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	489	In addition to allowing us to identify novel steps in HIV capsid assembly, the cell-free system also allows us mechanistic insights into known aspects of capsid assembly.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	490	 For example, our data suggest that the reason that certain Gag mutants fail to assemble is because they lack domains of the Gag polypeptide that may be required, either directly or indirectly, for progression from one assembly intermediate to the next along the proposed pathway for HIV capsid assembly.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	491	 Similarly, our results indicate that in the absence of the myristate moiety or in the absence of intact membranes, capsid assembly fails to progress beyond specific stages in the assembly process.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	492	Altogether, we demonstrate that capsid assembly can be disrupted at different points in the proposed assembly pathway by five different means: (a) omitting MCoA during the co-translational phase of the reaction, (b) depleting ATP during the posttranslational phase, (c) treating with detergent either at the start of translation or posttranslationally, (d) removing the detergent-insensitive subcellular component(s) from the eukaryotic cell lysate used for the assembly reaction, and (e) programming the reaction with assembly-defective Gag mutants.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	493	 While details of the mechanisms underlying these forms of blockade remain to be determined by further analysis, these data reveal the power of this approach for elucidating the biochemical events that underlie capsid assembly.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	494	Cell-free Assembly of Other Viral Capsids.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	495	Cell-free systems have been used in the past to assemble simple viral particles whose formation is dependent only on cytosolic components of host cells (Molla et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	496	 In the current study we demonstrate that such systems can also be used to reconstitute the assembly of much more complex viral capsids, such as HIV capsids, that require co-translational modifications as well as membrane targeting for their biogenesis.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	497	 These data suggest that the cell-free system can be used to examine capsid assembly mechanisms of many different types of viruses.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	498	Previously, we used a cell-free system to study the mechanism of assembly of a Hepatitis B Virus (HBV), a completely unrelated virus (Lingappa et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	499	 Unlike HIV capsids, HBV capsids are formed free in the cytoplasm of the host cell (for review see Ganem, 1991).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	500	 We found that these capsids assemble by way of an intermediate that is associated with at least one host protein.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	501	 When this intermediate was isolated, manipulation of energy substrates resulted in release of the completed capsid end product.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	502	 Thus, while cell-free HIV and HBV capsid assembly differ greatly in many details and in their complexity, they share some general mechanistic themes.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	503	 Capsid formation in both systems involves assembly intermediates, the use of energy substrates, and association with host proteins.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	504	 Thus, we propose that viruses of very different types may assemble their capsids via a step-wise pathway using host cell machinery.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	505	 Whether the same or different host machinery is recruited by various viruses remains to be determined.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	506	Implications of the Cell-free System for Viral Assembly.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	507	To allow an analysis of the earliest events in capsid biogenesis, we designed this cell-free system to assemble the simplest version of an HIV capsid, one that does not undergo maturation and lacks HIV genomic RNA and HIVspecific proteins (except for Gag).
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	508	 Now that the method has been established, it should be possible to supplement this system with such additional components in a manner that will extend the reconstitution and allow the roles of other components in capsid assembly to be determined.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	509	 For example, using a modified version of this system, it should be possible to determine the requirements for encapsidation of viral RNA and viral specific enzymes.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	510	 Note that although no HIV-specific RNA besides the gag transcript is included in the cell-free reactions described in this study, it is entirely possible that nonspecific RNA from the cellular extract becomes incorporated into the capsids that are made.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	511	Recent studies demonstrating the highly dynamic nature of HIV (Ho et al.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	512	, 1995) indicate that the only successful approach to combating this infection will be simultaneous, multi-drug therapy.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	513	 Antiretroviral agents currently in use target only two aspects of the HIV life- cycle, namely reverse transcription and protease-dependent virion maturation.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	514	 In order to develop novel targets for future antiretroviral therapy, a mechanistic analysis of other aspects of the HIV life cycle, such as capsid assembly, must be aggressively pursued.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	515	 The work presented here establishes a means of carrying out such a biochemical analysis for assembly of the HIV capsid.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	516	 Furthermore, these data indicate the existence of novel steps in viral assembly that appear to be amenable to blockade.
0.15107806.9024688.html.plaintext.txt	517	Received for publication 20 August 1996 and in revised form 4 November 1996.

0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	0	Focal Adhesion Kinase Plays a Pivotal Role in Herpes Simplex Virus Entry* Natalia Cheshenko, Wen Liu, Lisa M.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the Departments of Pediatrics and  Microbiology, Mount Sinai School of Medicine, New York, New York 10029.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received for publication, March 31, 2005 , and in revised form, June 29, 2005.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	3	We reported previously that both serotypes of HSV trigger inositol triphosphate-mediated release of endoplasmic reticulum (ER) Ca2+ stores and that Ca2+ signaling plays a critical role in viral entry (7).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Pharmacological inhibition of ER Ca2+ release or chelation of intracellular Ca2+ reduces nuclear transport of the viral tegument protein VP16, a surrogate marker for capsid transport, and the downstream events in the viral life cycle, including expression of viral immediate-early genes and viral plaque formation.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Activation of Ca2+ signaling is associated with triggering of phosphorylation signaling pathways.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Specifically, we observed previously that HSV-1 and HSV-2 trigger the phosphorylation of focal adhesion kinase (FAK) within 5-10 min following exposure of Vero (monkey kidney) or CaSki (human cervical epithelial) cells to virus.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	7	 FAK phosphorylation appears to occur downstream of release of ER Ca2+ stores, as treatment of cells with 2-aminoethoxydiphenyl borate, an inositol triphosphate receptor antagonist that prevents release of ER Ca2+, or chelation of intracellular Ca2+ blocks the virus-induced phosphorylation of FAK.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Activation of both pathways (Ca2+ and FAK phosphorylation) requires exposure to entry-competent virus, as HSV-1 deleted in the glycoproteins essential for penetration (glycoproteins B, D, and H-L) fails to induce Ca2+ release or to trigger FAK phosphorylation, whereas Ca2+ release and phosphorylation are preserved following exposure to the repaired viruses and to inactivated virus, which retain the ability to penetrate cells.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	9	 These findings led to the proposal of a new paradigm for HSV entry in which HSV triggers inositol triphosphate-mediated release of ER Ca2+ stores, which may facilitate fusion of the viral envelope and cell membrane, allowing delivery of capsids to the cytoplasm (7).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	10	 In response to activation of the Ca2+ pathways, we hypothesize that FAK and related signaling pathways are activated, which may promote transport of the viral capsids to the nuclear pores.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	11	 This study was designed to test this hypothesis and to evaluate whether HSV exploits FAK signaling pathways to promote its nuclear transport.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	12	 We used complementary molecular techniques, including dominant-negative variants, small interfering RNA (siRNA), and knockout cells, to explore the role played by FAK in HSV invasion.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	13	 We tested the hypothesis with both serotypes using human and murine cells.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Our findings indicate that FAK phosphorylation plays a central role in promoting transport of viral capsids.

0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	114	  To determine whether phosphorylated FAK contributes to HSV infection, we used several different strategies.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	115	 First, we exposed MEF cells derived from embryonic FAK-deficient mice (FAK-/-) (9) and control MEF cells (FAK+/+) to HSV-2 and examined FAK response and susceptibility to infection.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	116	 HSV-2 induced an 3-fold increase in the level of phosphorylated FAK as a percentage of total FAK compared with mock-infected cells (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	117	 2A, left panel); the response persisted for 1 h.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	118	 In contrast, no FAK or phosphorylated FAK was detected in FAK-/- cells (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Moreover, FAK-/- cells showed reduced susceptibility to infection by either serotype (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Viral titers were reduced by 93 and 96% in FAK-/- cells relative to FAK+/+ cells for HSV-1 and HSV-2, respectively.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Notably, no reduction in susceptibility to vesicular stomatitis virus was observed for FAK-/- cells relative to FAK+/+ cells.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Susceptibility to HSV infection was partially restored if cells were transfected with the wild-type FAK gene (data not shown).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	123	To more carefully explore which steps in viral infection are impaired in FAK-/- cells, we compared viral binding and nuclear transport of the viral tegument protein VP16 in FAK-/- and FAK+/+ cells.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	124	 The results demonstrate that there was no reduction in binding of virus to cells in FAK-/- cells relative to FAK+/+ cells (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	125	 However, nuclear transport of VP16 1 h after citrate treatment was substantially reduced in FAK-/- cells compared with FAK+/+ cells (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	126	 The blots were scanned, and optical densitometry corrected for differences in loading.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	127	 of 10 pfu/cell, there was an 93% reduction in the relative amounts of VP16 detected in the nuclei of FAK-/- cells compared with FAK+/+ cells.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	128	 The amount of nuclear VP16 detected was comparable with that observed if FAK+/+ cells were infected with 10-fold less virus (m.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	129	 To ensure that nuclear VP16 reflects transported and not newly synthesized protein, experiments were also conducted in the presence of cycloheximide, an inhibitor of protein synthesis (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Comparable amounts of nuclear VP16 were detected 1 h after citrate treatment in FAK+/+ cells independent of cycloheximide treatment and accounted for 73% of total cell-associated VP16.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	131	 As anticipated, a substantial reduction in viral ICP4 expression was also observed in FAK-/- cells compared with FAK+/+ cells, consistent with impaired delivery of viral DNA to the cell nucleus and thus viral gene expression (data not shown).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Taken together, these results suggest that, in the absence of FAK, viral invasion is blocked at a step post-binding, leading to reduced nuclear transport of VP16 and inhibition of downstream events, including expression of immediate-early gene products and plaque formation.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	133	Because the embryonic knockout cells are murine and because our goal is to identify the signaling pathways required for HSV infection of human target cells, we adopted a complementary strategy to assess the role of FAK and its phosphorylation in human cervical epithelial cells.

0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	181	  Our previous study suggested that phosphorylation of FAK is triggered downstream of Ca2+ signaling because pharmacological agents that block the release of ER Ca2+ or chelation of intracellular Ca2+ prevent virus-induced phosphorylation of FAK (7).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	182	 These observations suggest that Ca2+ signaling should be preserved in FAK-/- cells.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	183	 To test this directly, we examined the virus-induced Ca2+ signaling response by excitation ratio fluorometry of cells loaded with the Ca2+ indicator fura-2.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	184	 FAK+/+ and FAK-/- cells were exposed sequentially to PBS or HSV-2(G) at a m.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	185	 A rapid increase in the superfusate flow rate of PBS alone, simulating the conditions elicited by the addition of virus to the bathing medium, had no effect on resting [Ca2+]i.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	186	 The resting [Ca2+]i of FAK+/+ and FAK-/- cells were comparable (100 nM) (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Exposure of both FAK+/+ and FAK-/- cells to HSV resulted in a significant rapid increase in [Ca2+]i, which peaked within 1 min and returned to the base line within 3 min (p  <  0.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	188	001, analysis of variance) (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	189	 8), although the mean change in peak [Ca2+]i was greater for FAK+/+ cells compared with FAK-/- cells (181.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	190	1 versus 70  plus or minus  45 nM, respectively; mean  plus or minus  S.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	191	, n = 20 cells), possibly reflecting a reduction in virus-induced Ca2+ signaling in the absence of FAK or perturbations of other signal transduction pathways in the knockout cells.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	192	 The ability of HSV to induce a significant Ca2+ response in FAK-/- cells supports the notion that FAK phosphorylation occurs downstream of virus-induced release of ER Ca2+.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	193	View larger version (114K):    FIG.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Viral capsid-incorporated GFP co-localizes with microtubules following infection of CaSki or FAK+/+ cells, but not FAK-/- cells.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Cells were infected with HSV-1(KOS) (GFP-VP26) at a m.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	196	 of 50 pfu/cell and, at the indicated times post-infection, fixed and stained.

0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	198	 The results are representative of those obtained in three independent experiments.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	199	  Pyk2 is a non-receptor tyrosine kinase related to FAK; is activated by various extracellular signals, including an increase in [Ca2+]i; and is overexpressed in embryonic FAK-/- cells (15, 16).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	200	 We hypothesized that HSV may also trigger phosphorylation of Pyk2, which could contribute to signaling pathways required for capsid transport.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	201	 CaSki, FAK+/+, and FAK-/- cells were serum-starved and then exposed to HSV-2(G) at 1 pfu/cell or mock-infected.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Cell lysates were prepared at different times post-infection and analyzed for phosphorylated and total Pyk2 proteins.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	203	 HSV-2 triggered Pyk2 phosphorylation within 5 min following inoculation of cells (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	204	 The response was substantially greater in FAK-/- cells, presumably reflecting the increase in total Pyk2 in these cells and the absence of any FAK (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	205	 The observation that Pyk2 phosphorylation occurs in the absence of FAK suggests that Pyk2 is phosphorylated independent of FAK phosphorylation.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	206	 To further address the independence of Pyk2 and FAK phosphorylation, we again took advantage of siRNA strategy.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	207	 CaSki cells were transfected with control nonspecific siRNA or with Pyk2- or FAK-specific siRNA and then mock-infected or infected with HSV-2(G).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Transfection with Pyk2-specific siRNA led to an 70% reduction in Pyk2 expression and virus-induced Pyk2 phosphorylation (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	209	 In contrast, virus-induced Pyk2 phosphorylation was preserved in cells transfected with FAK-specific siRNA (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	210	 9B, middle panels), and virus-induced FAK phosphorylation was preserved in cells transfected with Pyk2-specific siRNA (lower panels, which show results with FAK+/+ cells; similar results were obtained with CaSki cells).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	211	To evaluate whether Pyk2 phosphorylation contributes to HSV infection, plaque assays were conducted in cells transfected with siRNA specific for FAK or Pyk2 alone and in combination.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Compared with cells transfected with control nonspecific siRNA, HSV-2 infection was inhibited by 74  plus or minus  6, 60  plus or minus  5, and 94  plus or minus  7% in CaSki cells transfected with siRNA for FAK, Pyk2, or both, respectively (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Consistent with the low level of Pyk2 phosphorylation observed in FAK+/+ cells (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	214	 9A), transfection of these cells with Pyk2-specific siRNA had little inhibitory effect (22%), whereas transfection with FAK-specific siRNA reduced viral infection by 71%.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	215	 In contrast, transfection of FAK-/- cells with Pyk2-specific siRNA further reduced viral infection by  > 99%.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	216	 To directly evaluate whether Pyk2 phosphorylation also contributes to nuclear transport, CaSki cells were transfected with nonspecific or Pyk2-specific siRNA, and the effects on viral binding and VP16 transport to the nucleus were evaluated.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	217	 Transfection with Pyk2-specific siRNA had no effect on viral binding (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	218	 10B), but had a modest inhibitory effect on nuclear transport of VP16 (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Optical densitometry scanning of the gels demonstrated an 40% reduction in nuclear VP16 following Pyk2-specific siRNA transfection, consistent with the modest inhibition of viral plaque formation (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Similarly, transfection with Pyk2-specific siRNA also had a moderate effect on delivery of GFP to the nuclear pore as detected by confocal microscopy (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Together, these results suggest that HSV induces phosphorylation of Pyk2 independent of phosphorylation of FAK and that, although FAK plays the predominant role, activation of both kinases contributes to viral infection.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	222	View larger version (10K):    FIG.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Effect of exposure of cells to HSV-2 on [Ca2+]i.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	224	 FAK+/+ (A) and FAK-/- (B) cells were loaded with the Ca2+ indicator dye fura-2 and exposed to HSV-2 (m.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	225	0), and changes in [Ca2+]i were monitored.
