0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	230	 HSV induces Pyk2 phosphorylation.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	231	 A, CaSki, FAK+/+, and FAK-/- cells were serum-starved overnight and then challenged with HSV-2(G) (m.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	232	 At the indicated times post-infection, cell lysates were prepared and analyzed by Western blotting for phosphorylated and total Pyk2 proteins.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	233	 B, additionally, CaSki cells were transfected with control, Pyk2-specific, or FAK-specific siRNA and, 24 h later, mock-infected or infected with HSV-2(G).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	234	 5 min post-infection, cell lysates were prepared and analyzed for the indicated tyrosine-phosphorylated protein (Pyk2 phosphorylated at Tyr402 (Pyk2[pY402])), FAK, and Pyk2.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	235	 The results are representative of three independent experiments.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	236	  Several studies suggest that HSV uses microtubule-based transport to delivery viral capsids to the nuclear pore, where viral DNA is released into the nucleus (1, 17-19).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Immunofluorescence studies demonstrate that HSV-1 capsids co-localize with dynein and dynactin.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	238	 Microtubule-depolymerizing agents, such as nocodazole, block HSV infection in culture and in animal models (1).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	239	 Moreover, nuclear transport of capsids is reduced by dynein inhibitors (19).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Precisely how HSV (or other viruses) engages and regulates the microtubule complexes is not known.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	241	 It has been suggested that cellular kinases triggered by viral infection or perhaps encoded by viruses themselves may play this regulatory role.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	242	 The results obtained in this study support this notion and suggest that cellular FAK and the related tyrosine kinase Pyk2 are activated by HSV to promote transport along microtubules.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	243	View larger version (37K):    FIG.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	244	 Pyk2 also contributes to HSV infection.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	245	 A, CaSki, FAK+/+, and FAK-/- cells were transfected with FAK-specific siRNA, Pyk2-specific siRNA, or both siRNAs and then, 24 h later, challenged with serial dilutions of HSV-2(G).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	246	 Plaques were counted 48 h post-infection, and viral titer (plaque-forming units/ml) were determined.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	247	 The results are means  plus or minus  S.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	248	 of two independent experiments conducted in duplicate.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	249	 B, CaSki cells were transfected with nonspecific (NS) or Pyk2-specific (siPyk2) siRNA and then, 24 h later, exposed to serial dilutions of purified HSV-2(G) at the m.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	250	 indicated for 5 h at 4  degrees C.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	251	 The input and cell-bound viral particles were detected by analyzing Western blots of cell lysates for glycoprotein D (gD).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Blots were also probed with mAb to -actin to control for cell lysate loading.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	253	 C, transfected cells (Cell) were exposed to HSV-2(G) (m.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	254	 = 10 pfu/cell) in a synchronized infection assay; and 1 h post-entry, nuclear extracts (Nucl) were prepared and analyzed for the presence of the viral tegument protein VP16 by Western blotting.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	255	  FAK was originally identified as a tyrosine kinase localized to focal adhesions, which are multiprotein structures that link the extracellular matrix to the actin cytoskeleton through integrin receptors.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	256	 More recent studies indicate that FAK also participates in the regulation of microtubule function.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	257	 For example, integrin-mediated activation of FAK is required for microtubule stabilization in mouse fibroblasts (20).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	258	 Additionally, FAK phosphorylation at Ser732 is important for microtubule organization, nuclear movement, and neuronal migration (21).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	259	 The latter study suggests that FAK phosphorylation regulates microtubule-based nuclear translocation and neuronal migration.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	260	 Pyk2 (also called FAK2) belongs to the same family of non-receptor tyrosine kinases as does FAK.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	261	 In contrast to FAK, which is expressed ubiquitously, Pyk2 expression is more restricted, but is found in hematopoietic, neuronal, and epithelial cells.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	262	 Pyk2 shares substantial homology with FAK and interacts with intracellular signaling molecules to activate a variety of cellular pathways, including regulation of microtubules (15).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	263	 Notably, increases in intracellular Ca2+ levels are associated with Pyk2 phosphorylation.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	264	 We found that HSV also induces Pyk2 phosphorylation independent of FAK.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	265	 Pyk2 phosphorylation was most evident in FAK-/- fibroblasts, which are known to overexpress Pyk2 (15), and also contributed to viral infection post-binding.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	266	 Thus, the observation that HSV capsid nuclear transport occurs via microtubules and the association of FAK and Pyk2 with microtubule regulation suggest that HSV triggers these cellular kinases to harness the microtubule machinery for its nuclear transport.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	267	Several viruses activate FAK or related signaling pathways, but the precise role played by these pathways in viral invasion or pathogenicity has not been delineated previously.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	268	 FAK is activated by integrin binding and aggregation.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	269	 Thus, viruses that bind integrin receptors, such as adenovirus and human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8), trigger FAK phosphorylation.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	270	 Adenovirus induces tyrosine phosphorylation of FAK within 15 min following infection of human corneal fibroblasts, but its role in viral pathogenicity is not known (22).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	271	 HHV-8 glycoprotein B, which possesses an RGD motif, binds to integrin receptors on target cells and triggers rapid phosphorylation of FAK and related signaling pathways.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	272	 The finding that HHV-8 infection of FAK-null cells is substantially reduced suggests that FAK may also be required for HHV-8 entry, but this has not yet been experimentally demonstrated (23-25).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	273	 Additionally, binding of HIV gp120 to T cells also triggers tyrosine phosphorylation of FAK (26), which may promote apoptosis (27), but has not yet been demonstrated to play any role in HIV entry or nuclear transport.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	274	It is not clear yet how HSV activates the FAK cell signaling pathway.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	275	 Although glycoprotein B is highly conserved among herpesviruses, only HHV-8 glycoprotein B possesses the RGD motif and interacts with integrin molecules as a receptor (28).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	276	 Recent studies demonstrate that HSV-1 glycoprotein H binds to v3 integrins; however; the functional significance of this interaction is unclear (29).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	277	 A recombinant virus with the RGD motif in glycoprotein H mutated to RGE shows no impairment in entry or infectivity in vitro (30) and also induces FAK phosphorylation.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	278	The results from our study suggest that FAK phosphorylation occurs downstream of Ca2+ signaling and is triggered either directly by the increase in [Ca2+]i or in response to Ca2+-dependent viral penetration.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	279	 This notion is supported by the findings that HSV induces an increase in [Ca2+]i in FAK-/- cells (Fig.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	280	 9) and that treatment of cells with pharmacological agents that block release of ER Ca2+ stores or chelation of intracellular Ca2+ prevents the virus-induced phosphorylation of FAK (7).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	281	 In contrast to what has been observed for HHV-8 glycoprotein B or HIV gp120, no single HSV glycoprotein-cell interaction appears to be sufficient to activate the requisite cell signaling pathways.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	282	 Our studies with deletion viruses indicate that penetration-competent virus is required to induce signaling.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	283	 This follows from the observations that HSV-1 deleted in glycoprotein L or glycoprotein D, both of which bind but do not penetrate, fails to induce the signaling responses, whereas heat-inactivated virus induces phosphorylated FAK (7).
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	284	 Possibly, one of the HSV envelope glycoproteins interacts with a cell-surface receptor to trigger the signaling cascade, but the interaction is dependent on the other glycoproteins being present in the viral envelope.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	285	 This could occur if, for example, the other glycoproteins induce a conformational change in and/or recruit the requisite glycoprotein(s) to a specific site at the membrane.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	286	Defining precisely how HSV triggers the signaling pathways is critical, as the viral proteins involved are excellent candidate targets for antiviral therapies.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	287	 Although targeting critical cellular pathways such as FAK phosphorylation will undoubtedly have pleiotropic and potentially deleterious effects as suggested by the reduction in magnitude of virus-induced Ca2+ transients in FAK-/- cells and the observed changes in morphology of FAK knockout cells (15), targeting the viral proteins that activate the requisite signaling pathways should lead to the development of novel specific antiviral therapies.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	288	 The results from this study provide an important piece to the puzzle and suggest that blockade of HSV-triggered phosphorylation of FAK and, to a lesser extent, Pyk2 will prevent nuclear transport, a critical step in the establishment of HSV infection.
0.15668444.15994312.html.plaintext.txt	289	   FOOTNOTES   * This work was supported in part by National Institutes of Health Grants AI061679 and HD43733 (to B.

0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	0	Modes of intercellular transcription factor movement in the Arabidopsis apex Xuelin Wu1, Jose R.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Crawford3, Yoon Rhee4, Vitaly Citovsky4, Patricia C.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	2	 Zambryski3 and Detlef Weigel1,5,*.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	3	1 Plant Biology Laboratory, The Salk Institute for Biological Studies, La Jolla, CA 92037, USA 2 Department of Biology, University of California San Diego, La Jolla, CA 92093, USA 3 Department of Plant and Microbial Biology, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, USA 4 Department of Biochemistry and Cell Biology, State University of New York, Stony Brook, NY 11794-5215, USA 5 Department of Molecular Biology, Max Planck Institute for Developmental Biology, D-72076 Tubingen, Germany.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	4	* Author for correspondence (e-mail: weigel{at}weigelworld.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	5	Key words: Arabidopsis, Protein trafficking, Movement protein, LEAFY, APETALA1.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	6	Although plants lack homologs of the well-known metazoan peptide ligands, such as EGF, TGFss or Hedgehog, plant cells can also communicate via secreted molecules (Fletcher et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	7	, 2001; McCarty and Chory, 2000).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	8	 However, in contrast to animals, cytoplasmic continuity between plant cells is the rule, not the exception.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Most plant cells are connected by plasmodesmata, plasma membrane-lined channels that provide cytoplasmic continuity between adjacent cells.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Plasmodesmata, which are used in the transport of nutrients and signaling molecules including RNAs and proteins, can be divided into two major groups (Crawford and Zambryski, 1999; Haywood et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	11	 The primary plasmodesmata form during cytokinesis, whereas the secondary plasmodesmata develop between cells that are not necessarily clonally related.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	12	 The size exclusion limit (SEL) of the different types of plasmodesmata can be measured using fluorescent tracer molecules.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	13	 In most cases, plasmodesmata in younger tissues have larger SEL and are morphologically simpler than those in older tissue (Crawford and Zambryski, 2001).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	14	Two modes of movement through plasmodesmata have been proposed.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Targeted movement involves specific interactions between the transported macromolecules and plasmodesmata components.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	16	 This leads to an increase in the SEL and is therefore not limited by the endogenous SEL of a given cell.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	17	 By contrast, non-targeted movement resembles passive diffusion and is governed by the endogenous SEL of the plasmodesmata involved (Crawford and Zambryski, 2000; Imlau et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	18	 The best understood case of targeted movement is probably the trafficking of plant viral movement proteins (MPs), which can move over long distances in plants and are key to the spreading of plant viral infections.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	19	 A good example of non-targeted movement is provided by green fluorescent protein (GFP).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Using transient transfection by bombardment, it has been shown that native GFP can move several cells away from its source.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	21	 In addition to the SEL, multimerization and the addition of nuclear or ER localization signals can hinder, or even prevent, GFP from leaving the source cell (Crawford and Zambryski, 2000; Crawford and Zambryski, 2001).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	22	Apart from viral proteins, studies of macromolecule movement in plants have focused traditionally on long-distance transport of photosynthates and larger molecules or complexes through the phloem (Lucas, 1995; Zambryski and Crawford, 2000).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	23	 A good example is the sucrose transporter SUT1, whose mRNA is transported into the phloem before it is translated (Kuhn et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Moreover, grafting experiments have demonstrated the existence of long-distance mRNA movement in plants (Kim et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	25	 More recently, studies conducted in several plant species have demonstrated that non-cell-autonomous effects of transcription factors involved in plant development can be mediated by protein movement (reviewed by Haywood et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	26	The first example of transcription factor movement was discovered through studies of the homeodomain protein KNOTTED1 (KN1) in maize.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Most plant organs originate post-embryonically from meristems, which include stem cells set aside during embryogenesis.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	28	 In the aerial part of the plant, new organs emerge from the shoot apical meristem (SAM), which consists of three tissue layers, L1-L3.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	29	 KN1 protein is found throughout the maize SAM but kn1 mRNA is absent from the L1 layer (Jackson et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	30	 In leaf injection experiments, not only was KN1 transported to the surrounding tissue through plasmodesmata, but KN1 also increased the SEL of plasmodesmata, enabling the transport of kn1 sense RNA and protein complexes (Kragler et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	31	 KN1 can also move away from its source of expression when expressed from heterologous promoters in Arabidopsis (Kim et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	32	 There is similar evidence that the Antirrhinum MADS-box transcription factor DEFICIENS (DEF) moves from inner to outer tissue layers in developing flowers, although the extent of movement is stage- and organ-dependent (Perbal et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	33	In Arabidopsis, two endogenous transcription factors move into neighboring cells: SHORTROOT (SHR) (Nakajima et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	34	, 2001) and LEAFY (LFY) (Sessions et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	35	 RNA of the GRAS-family transcription factor SHR is expressed in the stele of the root (Helariutta et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	36	, 2000), but SHR protein is found in both the stele and the surrounding endodermis, which is missing in shr mutants.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Further studies using transgenic misexpression confirmed that movement of SHR from the root stele to endodermis is required for endodermis development (Nakajima et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	38	 RNA of the plant-specific transcription factor LFY is expressed in all three layers of young floral primordia, which are mis-specified as shoots in strong lfy mutants (Weigel et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Surprisingly, LFY RNA expression in the L1 of developing flowers is sufficient to fully rescue the lfy-mutant phenotype.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	40	 In such transgenic plants, LFY protein, but not LFY RNA, is detected in all layers of the rescued flowers, indicating that LFY protein moves from the L1 into inner layers (Sessions et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	41	 By contrast, the transcription factor APETALA1 (AP1), which has similar in vivo functions as LFY but is structurally unrelated, behaves largely cell-autonomously (Sessions et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	42	Although movement of transcription factors in Arabidopsis and other plants is by now well-established, there are still major gaps in understanding the underlying mechanisms.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Here, we characterize the mode of LFY movement in Arabidopsis SAMs and floral primordia.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Using functional LFY-GFP fusion proteins, we show that LFY moves more readily from the L1 into deeper cell layers than laterally into adjacent, clonally related cells.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	45	 By contrast, a functional AP1-GFP fusion is unable to move from its source cells.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Comparison of the dynamics of LFY-GFP fusion proteins with other GFP fusions suggests that this movement is driven by diffusion.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Deletion experiments failed to identify a specific movement signal in LFY, which is compatible with the conclusion that LFY movement is non-targeted.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	48	 The hypothesis of non-targeted movement is also supported by the finding of a correlation between cytoplasmic localization and the ability of these proteins to move to adjacent cells.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	49	  LFY-GFP fusions PstI sites were added to both ends of the mGFP5 coding sequence (Haseloff et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	50	, 1997) using oligonucleotide primers.

0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	123	  We then examined the behavior of GFP, which does not display targeted movement.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	124	 We chose a dimerized version of GFP (2xGFP) because it has a molecular weight of approximately 54 kDa, which is similar to LFY, which is 47 kDa in size.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	125	 In previous leaf bombardment studies, it has been demonstrated that 2xGFP can move at least occasionally into neighboring cells, whereas adding a nuclear localization signal (NLS) nearly fully blocks this movement (Crawford and Zambryski, 2000).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Here, 2xGFP and NLS:2xGFP, when expressed stably in the L1, behaved similarly.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	127	 In vegetative and inflorescence apices, 2xGFP could move at least six cells into the L2 and L3 layers, forming a gradient with the highest levels in the L1 (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	128	 It appeared both cytoplasmic and nuclear in the leaf epidermis (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	129	 In agreement with bombardment studies, only a small amount of NLS:2xGFP was able to enter the L2 layer in apices, with no GFP signal detected in the L3 layer (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Its subcellular localization was assayed in the leaf epidermis, where most of the GFP signal came from the nuclei (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	131	To confirm that the GFP signal was indeed from dimerized GFP instead of a breakdown product resulting in monomeric GFP, whole-cell protein extracts were prepared from transgenic seedlings after imaging and analyzed by western blot with an anti-GFP antibody.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	132	 For NLS:2xGFP, a major band at about 57 kDa was observed (predicted size 58 kDa), indicating that it was stable (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Similarly, 2xGFP migrated at about 50 kDa (predicted size 54 kDa), and only a small amount of degradation product was observed for 2xGFP.

0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	141	  Absence of movement of a functional AP1-GFP fusion To exclude the possibility that all GFP fusion proteins can move, we examined N- and C-terminal fusions of GFP to the transcription factor AP1.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	142	 We have previously reported that AP1 has largely cell-autonomous effects when expressed in the L1 layer, indicating that AP1 does not move into internal layers, although protein localization was not directly examined (Sessions et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	143	 In strong ap1 mutants, sepals and petals fail to develop, and secondary flowers develop in the axil of sepals that have been converted into bracts.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	144	7 kb promoter fragment drives expression of a reporter gene in a pattern similar to that of endogenous AP1 (Hempel et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	145	, 1997), and when fused to an AP1 cDNA can largely rescue the phenotype of the strong ap1-15 allele (M.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Yanofsky, personal communication).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Expression of the C-terminal AP1:GFP fusion from the AP1 promoter rescued most aspects of the ap1-15 mutant phenotype, although rescue was variable in different lines (Fig.

0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	149	View larger version (75K):    Fig.

0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	155	 By contrast, GFP:AP1 is largely cytoplasmic and moves into deeper tissues layers from the L1 (F).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	156	  We subsequently expressed both fusions under the control of the ML1 promoter to test for their movement.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	157	 When AP1:GFP (55 kDa) was expressed under the ML1 promoter, we observed some gain-of-function phenotypes associated with the overexpression of AP1 in the L1 (Sessions et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	158	, 2000), such as the development of bracts subtending the flowers (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	159	 The GFP signal in apices from these plants was restricted to the L1 layer (Fig.

0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	164	 The cytoplasmic localization may well be causally related to the ability of this fusion to move and to the inability to rescue the mutant phenotype; however, it is unlikely that movement itself interferes with AP1 function.

0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	167	 4B), confirming that the observed fluorescence signal reflected the behavior of the fusion protein.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	168	Movement of LFY-GFP fusions from the L1 layer To avoid artifacts caused by the addition of GFP to a specific domain of the LFY protein, we generated three different LFYGFP fusions: GFP:LFY, an N-terminal fusion; GLFY, with an insertion of GFP at amino acid 31; and LFY:GFP, a C-terminal fusion.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	169	 We used these fusions, which increase the size of LFY by about half, from 47 to 74 kDa, to further characterize the movement of LFY, which has been previously detected using anti-LFY antibodies (Sessions et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	170	 The fusions were introduced into lfy-12/+ plants under the control of the ML1 promoter.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	171	 To test independently for functionality, the N- and C-terminally tagged versions were also expressed under the control of the constitutive CaMV 35S promoter.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	172	 All five transgenes were able to rescue the lfy-12 mutant phenotype, and to cause the typical gain-of-function phenotypes associated with overexpression of LFY (Weigel and Nilsson, 1995), which indicates that the three GFP fusions were fully functional.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	173	Using the ML1 promoter lines, we examined the subcellular localization of the LFY-GFP fusions, as well as their movement from the L1 layer (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	174	 All three fusions were detected in both the nucleus and cytoplasm, which was best seen in leaf epidermal cells (GLFY shown in Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	175	 3C), and all produced more cytoplasmic signal than NLS:2xGFP (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	176	 In leaf epidermal cells, a punctate signal that appeared along the cell wall was observed with all three fusions (GLFY shown in Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	177	 3C), which suggests a possible association with plasmodesmata pit fields.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	178	 GLFY and GFP:LFY moved three to four cell layers into the L2 and L3 in both the vegetative and inflorescence apices, forming a gradient with the highest concentration in the L1 (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Both GLFY and GFP:LFY were restricted to the epidermal layer in maturing leaves (data not shown).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	180	 LFY:GFP moved further, approximately 10 cell layers in apices (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	181	 In leaves, its distribution in the epidermis was similar to that of GLFY and GFP:LFY, but it could also be detected in the underlying mesophyll cells (data not shown).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Overall, LFY:GFP appeared more cytoplasmic than GLFY and GFP:LFY.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	183	 This observation was confirmed by quantifying the total signal intensity in the nucleus and cytoplasm of the epidermal cells of emerging leaves from all three fusions (see Materials and Methods).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	184	 For GLFY and GFP:LFY, the nuclear to cytoplasmic signal ratios were very similar, 1:2.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	185	 By contrast, the nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio of LFY:GFP was 1:5.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	186	4, a twofold increase compared with GLFY and GFP:LFY.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Western blots probed with an anti-GFP antibody demonstrated that there was little degradation of the fusion proteins, indicating that the in vivo fluorescence signal came from the intact fusion proteins (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Taken together, the behavior of LFY-GFP fusions is intermediate between that of 2xGFP and NLS:2xGPF, both with respect to their cytoplasmic localization and their ability to move from the L1 layer.

0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	193	 The signal from LFY:GFP, which has the longest moving range, appears `fuzzy' because of its higher cytoplasmic localization (D).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	194	 All three fusions are localized to both the nucleus and cytoplasm in leaf epidermal cells, and bright spots are sometimes found along the cell wall with GLFY (shown in C).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	195	  Lateral movement of GLFY within tissue layers Movement of LFY-GFP fusions from the L1 to deeper layers indicated that they can pass through the secondary plasmodesmata, which connect cells that are not clonally related.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	196	 To study the lateral movement of LFY within each tissue layer, we took advantage of a mutated enhancer from the AGAMOUS (AG) gene, which drives reporter gene expression in the inflorescence meristem in addition to the normal AG domain in the center of floral meristems (Hong et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	197	We expressed 2xGFP, NLS:2xGFP and GLFY under the control of the CaMV 35S minimal promoter fused to the mutated AG enhancer (AG intron*).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Except for the subcellular localization, the expression patterns of NLS:2xGFP (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	199	 5B) were indistinguishable, with fluorescent signal in the inflorescence meristem and central domain of young floral primordia.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	200	 The signal in both the shoot and floral meristems had discrete boundaries, indicating that GFP neither moved from the inflorescence meristem into emerging floral primordia, nor moved from the center of stage 3 flowers to the periphery (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	201	 However, a gradient of 2xGFP could be seen extending into deeper cell layers in L3 in stage 3 flowers (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	202	 5E), which is consistent with our earlier observation.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Thus, compared with movement from the L1 to internal layers, lateral movement of 2xGFP and NLS:2xGFP within tissue layers is much more limited, or possibly even absent.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	204	 The much reduced movement of 2xGFP and NLS:2xGFP within L1 and L2, compared with movement between layers, suggests that the plasmodesmata SEL within these two layers is lower than that between layers.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	205	View larger version (118K):    Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Restricted lateral protein movement in the Arabidopsis shoot apex.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Confocal images of GFP fluorescence for inflorescence meristems with surrounding young floral primordia from AG intron*::NLS:2xGFP (A,D), AG intron*::2xGFP (B,E) and AG intron*::GLFY (C,F) plants.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	208	 The confocal images have been overlaid with images from the transmitted-light channel for orientation only.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Note that the confocal images are optical sections, which is not true for the transmitted-light images.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	210	 The mutated AG sequences in the reporters activate expression in the shoot apical meristem and the center of young flowers.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Close-up views of stage 3 flowers reveal discrete lateral boundaries of the GFP signal (D-F).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	212	 No lateral movement is obvious in any of the three cases.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	213	  Similarly, GLFY could not move laterally within the same tissue layer (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	214	 We have previously found that periclinal, as well as anticlinal, sectors of LFY can rescue mutant parts of flowers, indicating that LFY moves in both directions (Sessions et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	215	 One possibility for the apparently different behavior of LFY and GLFY is that the greater size of GLFY, compared with endogenous LFY, reduces its ability to move laterally within tissue layers.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	216	We used a functional assay to test this assumption.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	217	 For this, we took advantage of the fact that the mutated AG enhancer is active in lfy mutants.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	218	 When we expressed LFY and GLFY under the control of this enhancer in lfy-12 plants, the same fraction of transgenic lines showed rescue in flowers (4 out of 12 lines for LFY and 4 out of 11 lines for GLFY; no significant difference using Fisher's exact test), suggesting that GLFY has similar activity to LFY.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	219	 However, the rescued flowers differed in phenotype.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Both GLFY and LFY rescued the development of the two inner whorls, which contain stamens and carpels, and in which the AG enhancer is active (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	221	 6), but only LFY was able to rescue petal development.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	222	 All four of the lfy-12; AG intron*::LFY lines that showed phenotypic rescue produced at least some flowers with petals, and many flowers had the normal complement of four petals.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	223	 By contrast, none of the four lfy-12; AG intron*::GLFY lines produced flowers with petals.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	224	 As GLFY appears to be as active as LFY in the inner two whorls where it is produced, the difference in their activity in the outer two whorls is consistent with the conclusion that LFY can move more extensively than GLFY.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	225	View larger version (75K):    Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Rescue of lfy-12 mutant flowers by LFY and GLFY expression in the center of the floral primordia.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	227	 A wild-type Arabidopsis flower (A) and a shoot-like structure that replaces a flower in lfy-12 mutants (B) are shown.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Both AG intron*::LFY and AG intron*::GLFY can rescue the stamens and carpels of lfy-12 mutant flowers (C,D), but only LFY rescues petals completely (arrow in C).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	229	  Requirement of LFY movement for normal flower development Although it has been established that LFY can move within flowers (Sessions et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	230	, 2000) (this work), it is unclear whether LFY movement is required for normal flower development, because LFY protein and RNA are expressed throughout young flowers (Parcy et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	231	 The difference between LFY and GLFY in their apparent ability to move within layers allowed us to address this question by expressing LFY and GLFY under the control of the LFY promoter and comparing their ability to rescue lfy-12 mutants.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Of ten LFY::LFY transgenic lines in the lfy-12 background, three showed complete rescue, and the remaining seven showed nearly complete rescue, with only a few flowers having reduced petal or stamen number.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	233	 By contrast, only six out of fourteen LFY::GLFY lines in the lfy-12 background showed a similar degree of rescue; the remaining eight lines resembled weak or intermediate lfy mutants and were sterile.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	234	 This difference between their ability to rescue is statistically significant based on Fisher's exact test.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	235	 Although only the opposite result  to  full ability of movement-compromised LFY to rescue lfy mutants  to  would have been entirely conclusive, our finding is consistent with the notion that LFY movement may be required for normal flower development.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	236	 However, we cannot exclude the possibility that GLFY is somewhat less active as a transcription factor than native LFY, although no difference in activity could be observed when tested from the 35S and AtML1 promoters.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	237	Movement of mutant LFY proteins To further test whether LFY movement is regulated, we investigated whether deleting parts of the LFY protein abolishes intercellular movement.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	238	 Three large, non-overlapping deletions were made in the LFY coding sequence, each removing approximately one third of the protein (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	239	 All three were linked to GFP at the N terminus and expressed under the ML1 promoter.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Although they differed in the extent with which they moved from L1 to inner layers, all three deletion variants were still able to move from L1 into the inner layers in both vegetative and inflorescence apices.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	241	 GFP:LFY1, with an N-terminal deletion, behaved very similar to GFP:LFY.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	242	 It was mostly located in the nucleus, and formed a gradient of four to five cell layers into the L2 and L3 (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	243	 GFP:LFY2, with a central deletion, was expressed at lower levels and was largely cytoplasmic, presumably because of the deletion of the NLS.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	244	 GFP signal could be clearly detected for at least three cell layers into the L2 and L3 (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	245	 7C), but its low expression levels may have been limiting our ability to determine its actual range of movement.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	246	 GFP:LFY3, with a C-terminal deletion, showed the least degree of movement, moving only one to two cell layers from the L1 (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	247	 However, most of the GFP signal was found in large aggregates, sometimes associated with the cell membrane when imaged in the leaf epidermis (data not shown), suggesting that GFP:LFY3 is improperly folded and localizes to a specific subcellular compartment, which may affect its movement.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Furthermore, all three truncated versions were able to enter mesophyll cells from the epidermis in maturing leaves (data not shown).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	249	View larger version (70K):    Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	250	 Movement of truncated LFY from the L1.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	251	 (A) Diagram of GFP:LFY and the three truncated forms of the GFP:LFY fusion protein.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	252	 GFP-coding sequence is shown in green and LFY-coding sequence in light blue, along with restriction sites used to make the deletions: B, BamHI; P, PstI; X, XbaI; S, StyI; H, HindIII.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	253	 (B-D) Confocal images of GFP fluorescence in inflorescence apices of 2-week-old plants.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	254	 All three forms of truncated GFP:LFY move from the L1 to the inner tissue layers.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	255	 GFP:LFY1 is mostly located in the nucleus (B), whereas GFP:LFY2 appears to be largely cytoplasmic (C).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Both can move several cell layers from the L1.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	257	 GFP:LFY3 is mainly found in the form of large aggregates, but can still move one to two cell layers from the L1 (D).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	258	  As large deletions may cause mis-folding of a protein, we also generated GFP fusions of four weak and intermediate lfy alleles mutating specific residues in GLFY.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	259	 All four fusions were functional, as they rescued lfy-12 plants to the phenotype corresponding to the lfy allele used for the fusion.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	260	 When expressed in the L1 layer, all of them could move into the underlying tissue layers.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	261	 Products of the fusions of the two weak lfy alleles, glfy-2 and glfy-20, showed near wild-type movement (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	262	 3A), whereas the products of the two intermediate alleles, glfy-3 and glfy-9, moved somewhat less well into the L2 and L3, about two to three cell layers (Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	263	 Taken together, these data suggest either the presence of redundant movement signals, or the absence of a specific movement signal.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	264	View larger version (104K):    Fig.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	265	 Movement of mutant GLFY fusions from the L1.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	266	 (A) Diagram of fusions of GFP to weak alleles lfy-2 (P240L) and lfy-20 (N306D), and intermediate alleles lfy-3 (T244M) and lfy-9 (R331K) in the GLFY background.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	267	 (B-E) Confocal images of GFP fluorescence in inflorescence apices of 2-week-old plants.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	268	 All fusion proteins can move from the L1 into interior layers, although to different degrees.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	269	Mode of LFY movement Several lines of evidence are compatible with the view that LFY movement is non-targeted.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	270	 First, GFP-LFY fusions produced in the L1 formed limited gradients extending into deeper layers.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	271	 Their movement range was between that of 2xGFP and NLS:2xGFP, which move in a non-targeted fashion (Crawford and Zambryski, 1999; Crawford and Zambryski, 2000; Kim et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	272	 This is in contrast to the nearly uniform distribution in the shoot apex (reflecting an active mechanism of cell-to-cell transport) that is observed when a viral movement protein fusion is expressed in the L1.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	273	 Second, size affects LFY movement, as native LFY was more effective in rescuing lfy defects in adjacent cells in the same tissue layer than the larger GLFY fusion.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	274	 The effect of size is one of the prominent characteristics of non-targeted movement (Zambryski and Crawford, 2000).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	275	 Third, although differing in stability and sub-cellular localization, all three GFP-LFY truncations and fusions of four mutant lfy alleles were able to move from the L1 into interior cell layers.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	276	 Although one cannot exclude the possibility that LFY has several redundant movement signals, the simpler explanation is that the LFY protein sequence does not contain a specific movement or export signal.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	277	It has been suggested that non-targeted movement, like targeted movement, occurs through plasmodesmata.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	278	 The potential localization of foci of GFP-LFY fusion proteins along the cell wall in the leaf epidermis supports this hypothesis.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	279	 This also suggests that the size exclusion limit of the secondary plasmodesmata connecting tissue layers in the Arabidopsis apex is greater than 74 kDa (the size of the LFY-GFP fusions), which is consistent with previous estimates for nascent leaves (Zambryski and Crawford, 2000).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	280	Movement within and between tissue layers An important new finding is that GFP variants, as well as GLFY, move more easily in the apical-basal direction than laterally.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	281	 Using in vivo function as a criterion, we found that the GLFY fusion was less efficient than the native LFY in moving from the center of floral primordia to the periphery.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	282	 This functional difference is most likely a result of their size difference, because both proteins are fully functional in the cells where they are produced.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	283	 Similar to previous studies that have demonstrated that the inner central zone (L3) does not allow fluorescent tracer uploading from the vascular tissue (Gisel et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	284	, 2002), we observed much more limited lateral movement within the L3.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	285	 Thus, intercellular movement needs to be considered in the context of the specific location and developmental stage within the plant.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	286	That lateral movement is less easily achieved than apical-basal movement may also explain the fact that LFY does not move out of floral primordia into the inflorescence meristem in wild type (Parcy et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	287	, 2000), as lateral movement would be required for efficient protein exchange between the two tissues.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	288	 The inflorescence meristem may even form a symplasmic domain that is insulated from emerging floral primordia (Rinne and van der Schoot, 1998), thus restricting movement of all macromolecules.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	289	 Alternatively, there may be selective gating, such that movement of only certain macromolecules from floral primordia into the inflorescence meristem (and vice versa) is permitted.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	290	 A similar mechanism may also be responsible for maintaining discrete whorl boundaries within the flower.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	291	 In this context, it is noteworthy that floral homeotic proteins that are expressed in distinct whorls of the developing Arabidopsis flower, such as AP1 and AP3, do not move, whereas LFY, which is expressed throughout the flower, does (Jenik and Irish, 2001; Sessions et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	292	Movement and subcellular localization LFY and LFY-GFP fusions can move into the inner tissue layers from the L1.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	293	 By contrast, AP1:GFP does not move between tissue layers.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	294	 This cannot be simply due to size, because an N-terminal fusion, GFP:AP1, could move well.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	295	 Furthermore, GFP:AP1 (55 kDa) is smaller than either NLS:2xGFP (57 kDa) or LFY-GFP fusions (74 kDa).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	296	 Therefore, if LFY is moving by diffusion, AP1 and AP1:GFP must be actively retained in the cells where they are expressed.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	297	 One way to achieve the retention may be by subcellular localization, such as nuclear or ER localization.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	298	 From this study, we have found that there is a good correlation between nuclear localization and movement: 2xGFP, which is highly cytoplasmic, can move a considerable distance from the L1, and the same is true for the predominantly cytoplasmic GFP:AP1 fusion.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	299	 AP1:GFP, which appeared to be exclusively nuclear, did not move.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	300	 Between these two extremes, NLS:2xGFP showed little cytoplasmic localization and moved only one cell layer.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	301	 The GFP-LFY fusions all showed more cytoplasmic localization than NLS:2xGFP, and all moved farther than NLS:2xGFP but less than 2xGFP.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	302	 Among the three GFP-LFY fusions, LFY:GFP had the most cytoplasmic localization and moved the farthest.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	303	Another possible mechanism for retaining a protein could be through the formation of large protein complexes with more exclusive subcellular localization, or simply with sizes above the SEL of plasmodesmata.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	304	 This may contribute to the retention of MADS domain proteins such as AP1, as several of them, including AP1, are known to form heteromultimers in the absence of DNA (Egea-Cortines et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	305	 In addition, it has been shown that AP3, a MADS-domain transcription factor that does not move between tissue layers, needs to heterodimerize with another MADS-domain protein, PISTILLATA (PI), in order to localize to the nucleus (McGonigle et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	306	 It is possible that the GFP:AP1 fusion disrupts such interactions, thereby interfering with biological activity and nuclear localization, as well as with retention in the cells where it is produced.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	307	In this context, it is noteworthy that SHR is found in both the nucleus and cytoplasm of the stele, where it is produced.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	308	 From there, SHR moves exactly one cell diameter, into the adjacent endodermis, where it is located entirely in the nucleus (Nakajima et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	309	 This observation is consistent with a model in which SHR gets trapped in the nuclei of the endodermis through interaction with a partner that causes translocation to the nucleus, similar to the AP3/PI interaction (McGonigle et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	310	Mechanisms of movement Our results are compatible with the view that LFY movement is driven by diffusion.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	311	 However, it remains unclear whether the same conclusion can be drawn regarding the intercellular movement of other transcription factors.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	312	 Another well-studied example of a trafficking transcription factor is KN1 of maize (Kim et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	313	 As with LFY, KN1-GFP fusions are detected in the nucleus and cytoplasm, and in a punctate pattern associated with the cell wall (Kim et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	314	 In contrast to LFY, for which various deletions did not prevent movement, a simple mutation in the homeodomain and the potential NLS of KN1 abolished its movement.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	315	 Furthermore, experiments with tobacco have indicated the presence of a cellular component that is limiting for KN1 movement, and have suggested that the mode of KN1 trafficking may be related to the targeted movement of viral movement proteins (Kragler et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	316	 However, other results are consistent with KN1 moving in a non-targeted fashion.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	317	 In bombardment assays, KN1-GFP moved considerably less well than a fusion of GFP to the movement protein of TVCV (Kim et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	318	 Furthermore, movement of KN1 expressed from the SCR promoter in the shoot apex of transgenic Arabidopsis plants was rather limited (Kim et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	319	, 2002), similar to that of NLS:2xGFP or GFP:LFY expressed from the ML1 promoter (this work).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	320	 Further studies in a nonheterologous system will be required to clarify the mechanisms behind KN1 movement.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	321	 A complex relationship between targeted and non-targeted movement is also indicated by a recent study, in which a dominant-negative form of the tobacco NON-CELL-AUTONOMOUS PATHWAY PROTEIN 1 (NtNCAPP1) was overexpressed.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	322	 In such transgenic plants, trafficking of viral movement protein, but not of KN1, was affected (Lee et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	323	 Interestingly, tobacco LFY protein appears more uniform in such transgenic plants, which also have phenotypes reminiscent of LFY overexpressing plants.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	324	 The causal relationship between these observations needs further investigation, but it will be interesting to combine the dominant-negative NtCAPP1 overexpressing plants with the tools presented here.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	325	It is also worth noting that the determinants underlying transcription factor movement may be species-dependent.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	326	 Like LFY, its Antirrhinum ortholog FLORICAULA (FLO) has non-cell-autonomous effects in mosaic studies (Carpenter and Coen, 1995).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	327	 In contrast to LFY, the extent to which FLO can rescue mutant flowers varies depending on the layer in which FLO is expressed (Hantke et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	328	 As FLO protein has not been examined in these mosaics, it is unknown whether the differential rescue ability is caused by differences in FLO movement, or is only a result of downstream effects, such as the documented abnormalities in target gene expression in the mosaics (Hantke et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	329	 Another example of interspecific differences is provided by DEF of Antirrhinum, which was found to move from the L2 to the L1 in a stage- and organ-dependent manner (Perbal et al.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	330	 However, the DEF ortholog AP3 of Arabidopsis does not move between layers (Jenik and Irish, 2001), which indicates that subtle differences in sequence, or interspecific differences in the translocation machinery, affect transcription factor movement, the latter being consistent with the interspecific differences that have been reported for GFP movement (Crawford and Zambryski, 2001).
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	331	 These observations highlight that care must be taken when extrapolating from one transcription factor assayed in a single species or single tissue.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	332	In conclusion, we have presented evidence that the transcription factor LFY moves in a non-targeted fashion.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	333	 We are proposing the testable hypothesis that movement is a default mechanism for many proteins in the Arabidopsis shoot apex, unless they are either efficiently targeted to specific subcellular locations or retained through formation of protein complexes.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	334	 More case studies are needed to determine whether our results can indeed be generalized to include other proteins, other tissues and other species.
0.15670726.12835390.html.plaintext.txt	335	   ACKNOWLEDGMENTS   We thank: Steve Barlow for help with confocal microscopy; Virginia Butel for generating GLFY; Ji Hoon Ahn and Marty Yanofsky for gifts of material; and Ray Hong, Jan Lohmann, Alexis Maizel, Javier Palatnik, Markus Schmid, Jon Werner and Philip Wigge for discussions and critical reading of the manuscript.

0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	0	Developmental regulation and significance of KNOX protein trafficking in Arabidopsis Jae-Yean Kim, Zhuang Yuan* and David Jackson.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	1	Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, 1 Bungtown Road, Cold Spring Harbor, NY 11724, USA.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	2	Author for correspondence (e-mail: jacksond{at}cshl.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	3	Key words: Homeodomain, KNOX, Shoot meristem, knotted1, GFP, Plasmodesmata, Protein trafficking, Arabidopsis thaliana.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	4	The use of the green fluorescent protein (GFP) greatly facilitated the development of in vivo trafficking assays.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Tissue-specific GFP expression studies also revealed dynamic regulation of PD SEL.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Estimates for PD SEL in mesophyll or trichome cells of mature leaves have been obtained from microinjection experiments, and range from one to a few kDa (Wolf et al.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	7	, 1989; Waigmann and Zambryski, 1995).
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	8	 However, in immature sink tissues the observation of GFP diffusion suggests that the PD SEL may be as high as 30-50 kDa in these tissues (Imlau et al.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Developmental changes in GFP diffusion are correlated with changes in PD structure during leaf development, from simple linear channels to complex branched forms (Oparka et al.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	10	 It is also evident that GFP can diffuse cell-to-cell in some mature tissues, depending on the tissue type and species (Crawford and Zambryski, 2000; Itaya et al.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Developmental modifications to PDs are also relevant to MP localization and trafficking.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	12	 For example, TMV or cucumber mosaic virus MP has been shown to be targeted to plasmodesmata and trafficked between cells only when the leaf reached a certain developmental stage (Ding et al.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	13	 These observations of GFP diffusion and MP trafficking reveal developmental regulation of PD function, suggesting that signaling through PDs is important in plant development.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	14	 The idea that MP trafficking is related to that of endogenous proteins is also supported by the fact that trafficking is extremely rapid (Ding, 1998), and that a plant MP-related protein, CmPP16, can traffic itself and mRNA through PDs (Xoconostle-Cazares et al.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	15	 However, the extent to which trafficking of endogenous proteins is developmentally regulated is unclear.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Endogenous trafficking proteins include phloem proteins (Balachandran et al.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	17	, 1997) as well as several developmental transcription factors such as LEAFY (LFY), SHORTROOT (SHR) and KNOTTED1 (KN1).
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	18	 The LFY meristem identity protein acts non-autonomously and is able to traffic from the L1 layer to the L2 and L3 meristem cells and to complement a lfy mutant (Sessions et al.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	19	 In the root, the SHR protein traffics from the stele into the endodermal cell layer, and trafficking appears to be required for its function in cell fate specification (Nakajima et al.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	20	 The influence of tissue-specific or developmental signals in trafficking of these proteins is largely unknown.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	21	The first endogenous protein shown to traffic cell-to-cell was the maize homeodomain protein, KN1.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Mosaic analysis of a dominant Kn1 allele showed that it acts non-autonomously during maize leaf development (Hake and Freeling, 1986).
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Later, in situ hybridization and immunolocalization experiments showed that KN1 protein is detected outside the domain of mRNA expression, suggesting the possibility of KN1 trafficking (Jackson et al.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Microinjection studies of fluorescently labeled KN1 protein showed directly that KN1 has the ability to traffic between mesophyll cells, to increase PD SEL and to specifically transport its mRNA (Lucas et al.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	25	 These studies suggested that the KN1 protein itself could be the cell non-autonomous signal, and in support of this hypothesis we showed that a GFP-tagged KN1 fusion is able to traffic in the leaf and shoot apical meristem (SAM) in Arabidopsis (Kim et al.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Arabidopsis encodes four class I KN1-related homeobox (KNOX) genes (Bharathan et al.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	27	 The most closely related to KN1 are KNOTTED 1-like homeobox protein 1/BREVIPEDICELLUS (KNAT1/BP) and SHOOTMERISTEMLESS (STM); KNAT1 is thought to be the Arabidopsis ortholog of KN1 (Bharathan et al.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	28	, 2000), but STM has closer functional similarity to KN1 on the basis of similar null mutant phenotypes and expression patterns (Long et al.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	29	 STM and KN1 function in SAM initiation and/or maintenance, and KNAT1/BP is involved in the regulation of inflorescence architecture (Byrne et al.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	30	 The possible involvement of trafficking in the function of the Arabidopsis KNOX proteins has not been investigated.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	31	In this report we show a specific difference in inter-layer trafficking in the Arabidopsis leaf between GFPMP and GFPKN1.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Our observations suggest that different mechanisms are involved in the trafficking of these proteins.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	33	 We also show that GFPKN1 trafficking is under tissue-specific regulation and can be influenced by developmental stage.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	34	 In support of a biological function of KNOX protein trafficking, KN1 and the related Arabidopsis proteins STM and KNAT1 could traffic out of the L1 layer of the shoot apical meristem, and movement was correlated with the complementation of stm-11 mutant phenotypes.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Based on these findings, we discuss the potential roles for trafficking of KNOX gene products during development.

0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	261	We previously showed that 35S-GFPKN1 plants develop KNOX over-expression phenotypes (Kim et al.

0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	264	In summary, GUSKN1 was cell-autonomous and partially complemented stm-11 if expressed in all meristem layers, but not when expressed specifically in the L1.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	265	 These data support the hypothesis that trafficking out of the L1 is required for shoot rescue in the pAtML1-KNOX expression lines.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	266	 Over-expression of the GUSKN1 fusion did not produce KNOX over-expression phenotypes, suggesting either that the over-expression phenotypes require the trafficking function of KN1, or that the GUS fusion interrupts some other function of KN1 involved specifically in generating over-expression phenotypes.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	267	Developmental and tissue-specific control of KN1 trafficking In plants with simple leaves, KNOX genes are usually expressed only in the SAM, though developmental consequences of ectopic leaf expression and the expression of KNOX genes in compound leaves indicate that they can function during leaf development (Bharathan et al.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	268	 We found that GFPKN1 trafficking was regulated tissue-specifically in the leaf.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	269	 Whereas it could traffic from mesophyll to epidermis, trafficking did not occur from epidermis to mesophyll, in either leaf primordia or in fully expanded leaves.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	270	 Consistent with these observations, distinctive phenotypes arose from layer-specific expression of KN1.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	271	 As expected, the mesophyll-specific expression of GFPKN1 resulted in strong KNOX over-expression phenotypes, similar to constitutive (35S promoter driven) expression (Lincoln et al.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	272	 However, epidermal-specific expression of GFPKN1 produced a relatively mild, rumpled phenotype.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	273	 This mild phenotype is probably due to the restriction of KN1 in the epidermis, though the fact that epidermal expression is able to alter leaf shape does indicate a non autonomous effect of KN1 that is presumably not due to trafficking.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	274	 Similar unidirectional signaling was observed in periclinal chimeras of the floral organ identity genes GLOBOSA (GLO) and DEFICIENS (DEF) in Antirrhinum.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	275	 Some effects of DEF and GLO expression were non cell-autonomous, however these effects were only partially explained by movement, as DEF also moves from L2 to L1 but not in the opposite direction (Perbal et al.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	276	 In this study we showed that the lack of protein movement out of the epidermis was not, however, a general phenomenon.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	277	 Both GFP and GFPTVCV MP moved freely from epidermis to mesophyll, demonstrating that the PDs between epidermal and mesophyll cells are open to both diffusion-mediated and selective protein movement.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	278	Uni-directional trafficking of KN1 in the leaf suggests that KN1 normally traffics from inner to outer layers, and may reveal a directional signaling pathway.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	279	 Although class I KNOX genes are not normally expressed in the simple leaves of maize, rice and Arabidopsis, they are expressed in compound leaves (Bharathan et al.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	280	 For example, LeT6 is expressed in tomato leaf primordia as well as in the SAM (Chen et al.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	281	 showed that LeT6 mRNA expression was strong in the L2/L3 layers and reduced or absent from the L1 layer of the SAM, and we note that this expression pattern continues in the young leaf primordia (Chen et al.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	282	 It would be interesting therefore to test whether KNOX proteins traffic directionally in the tomato compound leaf; such a process could provide a mechanism for regulation of leaf morphology by signaling from inner to outer layers during development.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	283	 Classic studies involving inter-specific periclinal leaf chimeras indeed indicate the potential for direction signaling during leaf morphogenesis (reviewed by Tilney-Bassett, 1986).
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	284	In support of the hypothesis that KN1 traffics through PDs, it showed a punctate pattern resembling that seen with GFPMP, which has been linked with plasmodesmata in studies using electron microscope level immunolocalization (Ding et al.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	285	 Our results imply, however, that the mechanism of KN1 trafficking differs from that of the viral MP.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	286	 This could be because tissue-specific receptors that recognize distinct trafficking motifs in the different proteins.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	287	 This idea is supported by the recent report that non-cell-autonomous pathway protein (NCAPP1), a putative PD receptor, interacts with CmPP16 and TMV MP but not with KN1 (Lee et al.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	288	 Alternatively, tissue-specific post-translational modification(s) of KN1 might affect its ability to traffic.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	289	 For example, phosphorylation regulates the trafficking of TMV MP (Citovsky et al.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	290	, 2000), and perhaps a similar mechanism controls KN1 trafficking.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	291	KN1 and related Arabidopsis KNOX proteins STM and KNAT1 traffic in the SAM Whereas KN1 was unable to traffic from epidermal to mesophyll cells in the leaf, it could traffic from epidermal (L1) cells to underlying cells in the inflorescence SAM.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	292	 Two Arabidopsis homologs of KN1, KNAT1 and STM, could also traffic in the SAM, suggesting that hypothetical signal(s) for trafficking in KN1 are conserved in other KNOX proteins.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	293	 These signal(s) could be made up of a simple, short sequence and/or complex structural motif(s).
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	294	 So far, studies using viral MPs and rice phloem proteins suggest that recognition by the PD trafficking machinery involves structural motifs (Haywood et al.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	295	, 1998), though a short sequence motif appears to control the trafficking of the heat shock cognate 70 chaperone (Aoki et al.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	296	 In the case of KN1, a short peptide, homologous to a region near the N terminus of the protein, can interfere with its trafficking, though it is not known whether this sequence motif is sufficient for trafficking (Kragler et al.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	297	We observed a relatively short range of GFPKNOX protein trafficking in the Arabidopsis SAM, which generated a steep gradient of GFP fluorescence spanning approximately 23 cell layers.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	298	 In contrast, GFPKN1 can traffic over at least 3-5 cell layers in the leaf (Kim et al.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	299	 GFPTVCV MP or free GFP moved further than GFPKNOX in the SAM, through more than six cell layers.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	300	 This suggests that KNOX protein trafficking in the meristem is relatively restricted, and may be used for short range signaling.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	301	 The more pronounced nuclear localization of GFPKN1 in the meristem than in the leaf may be the cause of its shorter range of trafficking, as nuclear localization probably restricts its chance to interact with PD.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	302	 A similar mechanism was proposed for the restriction of SHR trafficking (Nakajima et al.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	303	, 2001) and of GFP diffusion (Crawford and Zambryski, 2000).
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	304	 In the maize shoot apex, a KN1 protein gradient is also evident between the SAM and leaf primordia (Jackson, 2002).
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	305	 Although the biological significance of these KNOX protein gradients is not yet clear, it is possible that they are used to activate target genes at different positions along the gradient (Jackson, 2002).
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	306	Caution is required in interpreting the trafficking of GFP fusion proteins.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	307	 The GFP tag increases the size of the protein and may affect trafficking efficiency.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	308	 However, the GFPKN1 fusion used in this study produced normal KN1 overexpression phenotypes and also complemented the stm mutation, suggesting it retained normal biological function(s).
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	309	 In addition, the low quantum yield for GFP, relative to other fluorophores, may well result in a significant underestimation of the range over which the tagged protein can traffic.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	310	Biological function of KNOX homeodomain protein trafficking The critical question is what, if any, is the function of KNOX protein trafficking in intercellular signaling? The conservation of trafficking ability in KNOX proteins of different species suggests that their function requires trafficking, and the nuclear localization of GFPKNOX proteins following trafficking in the SAM suggests that they can function in transcription in target cells.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	311	 Cell-to-cell trafficking of KNAT1 could explain the non cell-autonomous regulation of epidermal cell fate by KNAT1, reported by Venglat et al.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	312	GFPKNOX expression in the L1 rescued shoot formation in stm-11 mutants, and trafficking was probably required for this rescue, because the cell-autonomous GUSKN1 fusion did not result in rescue.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	313	 Whereas this failure to rescue could be because GUSKN1 was inactive, this was not the case since it could partially rescue stm-11 when expressed in all meristem cell layers using the 35S promoter.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	314	 However, the rescue of stm-11 by 35S-GUSKN1 was only partial, and we speculate that full KN1 function in the SAM might require its intercellular trafficking.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	315	 A functional requirement for KN1 trafficking in the wild-type situation remains to be tested by determining if expression of the non-trafficking version of KN1 under a faithful STM promoter can complement the stm mutant.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	316	Our results suggest that the correct spatial and temporal expression pattern and/or level of KN1/STM in the SAM is required for full complementation of stm-11.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	317	 In contrast to the AtML1 promoter, use of the STM promoter resulted in GFPKN1 expression at a relatively homogeneous level in the different SAM layers.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	318	 These expression differences are probably the reason why the two constructs resulted in different complementation phenotypes; pAtML1-GFPKN1 (or KN1) expression always resulted in partial complementation of stm and abnormal phyllotaxy, while complementation using pSTM-GFPKN1 (or KN1) was more complete and produced seedlings with normal phyllotaxy.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	319	 In this regard, intercellular protein trafficking might provide a way to regulate the distribution and concentration of key developmental regulators across a cellular domain like the SAM.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	320	 Intercellular KN1/STM trafficking may be a redundant `fail-safe' mechanism to ensure all cells adopt the SAM fate, analogous to the mechanism originally proposed by Mezitt and Lucas (Mezitt and Lucas, 1996) for non-autonomous action of FLORICAULA, and supported by the demonstration of LFY trafficking (Sessions et al.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	321	Plants expressing the non-trafficking 35S-GUSKN1 fusion did not have the usual KN1 over-expression phenotypes.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	322	 We therefore hypothesize that KN1 trafficking might be required to generate the over-expression phenotypes, or that movement per-se is important for function, rather than simply which cells contain KN1.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	323	 One possible mechanism would be if KN1 was modified and gained a novel function during intercellular movement.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	324	 Partial unfolding of KN1 is required for passage through PDs (Kragler et al.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	325	, 1998), and could expose KN1 to post-translational modification(s).
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	326	 Alternatively, the lack of a KNOX overexpression phenotype in the 35S-GUSKN1 plants could be because the fusion of GUS inhibits the ability KN1 to interact with partner proteins, such as Arabidopsis homologs of KN1 interacting protein (KIP), a BEL1-like TALE homeodomain protein (Smith et al.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	327	 Such interacting proteins may be differentially expressed or differentially required for the over-expression and SAM functions of KN1.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	328	 Lastly, the nuclear localization of STM is required for its activity (Gallois et al.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	329	, 2002), and if the fusion of GUS interfered with KN1 nuclear localization specifically in the leaf this could also affect its ability to generate over-expression phenotypes.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	330	In conclusion, KN1 trafficking is under temporal and tissue-specific developmental control, and trafficking ability is conserved in STM and KNAT1.
0.15854263.12900451.html.plaintext.txt	331	 Our results suggest that trafficking of KNOX homeodomain proteins is functionally significant, and may coordinate the development of source and target cells, or provide a redundant `fail-safe' mechanism to control the fate of cells in the SAM.
