0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	6	E2 has recently been proposed as a potential immune target for vaccines aimed at treating pre-malignant disease (Schiller  and  Hildesheim, 2000).
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	7	 This has been supported by data from the cotton tail rabbit papillomavirus (CRPV) model, where vaccination of rabbits with DNA encoding CRPV E2 was found to protect against the development of papillomas following subsequent tumour challenge (Han et al.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	8	 There are limited data on responses to E2 in patients with HPV-associated disease.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Serology studies have provided conflicting results with IgA and IgG responses to a cryptic peptide correlating with antigen exposure in cervical cancer patients (Dillner et al.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	10	, 1995), while IgA (but not IgG) responses detected using a baculovirus-produced E2 protein were associated with low- rather than high-grade cervical intraepithelial neoplasia CIN) and cervical cancer (Rocha-Zavaleta et al.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	11	 These assays variously can detect linear or conformational epitopes, respectively, so their lack of concordance may not be surprising.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	12	 A single study has investigated naturally occurring E2-specific T-cell responses in women with HPV-associated CIN where helper T-cell responses to the E2 C terminus, but not to the N terminus, occurred at the time of viral clearance (Bontkes et al.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Clearly there is a need for further baseline investigations of naturally occurring E2-specific immune responses in patients with HPV-associated disease.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	14	VIN is associated with high-risk HPV-16 infection in over 90 % of cases and has shown a significant increase in incidence over recent decades, particularly in younger women (van Beurden et al.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	15	 It is a chronic disease characterized by recurrence following standard treatment (Herod et al.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	16	 It therefore provides an excellent opportunity for the study of naturally occurring HPV-specific immune responses in women with persistent high-risk HPV infections.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	17	 This immunity is likely to have arisen as a consequence of chronic exposure to the virus but may be insufficient to effect disease regression and virus clearance.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	18	 The relapsing and recurring nature of VIN is likely to represent an ongoing battle between viral and immune factors in the natural control of this disease.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Thus, a comparison of HPV-specific immunity in women with chronic HPV infections and in those without may provide some insight into those immunological responses that play an important role in the natural history of HPV-associated disease.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	20	We have previously described an interferon- (IFN-) ELISPOT assay, which facilitates the detection of HPV-16 E2-specific memory T-cell responses to E2 C terminus protein following its processing and presentation by autologous dendritic cells (DCs) (Davidson et al.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	21	 The advantage of this system is that it is not limited by the use of HLA-restricted peptides but rather allows the study of the full range of T-cell responses that may have arisen as a consequence of natural antigen presentation in vivo.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	22	 In the present study, we have measured the 86 amino acid C-terminal E2- and virus-like particle (VLP) L1-specific T-cell responses in women with HPV-16-associated VIN and healthy female volunteers using this methodology and proliferation.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	23	 HPV-16 L1 VLP-specific T-cell responses were measured as a positive control, since previous studies have found high proportions of healthy volunteers and patients with HPV-16-associated high-grade CIN to respond to this antigen.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	24	 In addition we measured full-length GST to E2- and both GST to L1 and VLP L1-specific serological responses in the VIN and control subjects.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Forty ml of blood from each subject was heparinized (6000 iU heparin per 20 ml blood), layered on to Lymphoprep lymphocyte separation medium (LSM; Nycomed-Amersham) and centrifuged at 900 g for 20 min at 20  degrees C.

0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	130	A dominant antibody response in humans against HPV-16 capsids involves a type-specific epitope only present on assembled capsids and not on the individual pentavalent capsomeres (Heino et al.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	131	 The L1 forms pentamers when its N terminus is fused to GST and this can allow detection of other L1-reactive antibodies.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Thus, the GST to L1 assay may allow epitopes that are ordinarily hidden within the fully assembled capsid phenotype to become available for serological reactivity and this may explain why more responses were seen using this assay than with the VLP assay.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Previous studies of HPV-16 VLP-specific antibodies in women with high-grade VIN found approximately 60 % of patients to be seropositive, but these studies did not determine the HPV status of the lesions and therefore may not have identified HPV-16-negative disease (Hildesheim et al.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	134	We found HPV-16 E2-specific Ig in one of the healthy volunteers, consistent with this population's lack of exposure to HPV-16, but only 2/18 HPV-16-positive high-grade VIN patients were seropositive.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	135	 From previous studies, serological responses to the E2 protein appear to correlate with antigen exposure (Lehtinen et al.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	136	 However, it is not clear how the different assays (baculoviral protein, peptide and GST fusion) for E2 antibodies can be directly compared.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	137	 In particular, we do not know whether the GST to E2 fusion protein has any native conformation in the ELISA.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Nevertheless, the relatively infrequent detection of E2-specific Ig responses in our VIN patient cohort may indicate a lack of E2 expression by high-grade VIN lesions.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	139	 The E2 open reading frame is typically disrupted following virus integration into the host cell genome, a process that has been shown to occur during the malignant transformation of HPV-infected cells (Graham  and  Herrington, 2000; Peitsaro et al.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	140	Cell-mediated immunity is likely to play a pivotal role in eradicating established HPV infection and effecting disease regression.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	141	 IFN- ELISPOT potentially allows the detection of low-frequency memory CD8+ cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs) and CD4+ T helper 1 (Th1) cells, since both release IFN- following re-exposure to specific antigens (Sallusto et al.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Multiple restimulation of normal donor T-cell cultures with autologous E2 C terminus protein-pulsed DCs was shown to induce CTLs capable of E2-specific lysis of autologous lymphoblastoid cell lines infected with a recombinant vaccinia virus encoding HPV-16 E2 (Davidson et al.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Thus, there is an E2-specific CTL repertoire available in normal individuals.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Other studies using overlapping peptides from the HPV-16 E2 protein have revealed a broad E2-specific T helper cell repertoire in healthy volunteers (de Jong et al.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	145	 DCs pulsed with HPV-16 VLP have also been shown to stimulate primarily type 1-dominated T helper cell responses (Lenz et al.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	146	, 2001) and MHC class I-restricted CTL responses (Rudolf et al.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	147	 The specific release of IFN- by CD4+ Th1 cells and CD8+ CTLs following stimulation with E2 and VLP protein antigens may therefore provide a useful measure of those cell-mediated immune responses that are likely to be important in the natural clearance of HPV infections.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	148	 In the present study, ELISPOT responses to C-terminal E2 and L1 required a 4 day stimulation of T cells with autologous protein-pulsed DCs; a 24 h stimulation of bulk PBMC cultures with antigen was not sufficient to reveal these responses.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	149	 This suggests that appropriate antigen processing and presentation is necessary to demonstrate these low-frequency memory responses.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	150	VLP L1-specific T-cell responses were more prevalent in the VIN group compared with the controls, both by IFN- ELISPOT (72 % vs 53 %, P=NS) and by proliferation assay (94 % vs 53 %, P < 0 02).
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	151	 All but one of the patients who were seropositive for L1-specific Ig also demonstrated L1-specific proliferative T-cell responses.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Twelve of these patients additionally showed L1-specific IFN- release by ELISPOT.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	153	 All but one of the healthy volunteers were seronegative for HPV-16 L1-specific Ig, but a significant proportion of the group were L1-specific proliferative and IFN--releasing T-cell responders.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	154	 In the absence of HPV-16 L1-specific antibodies, the T cells measured by these assays most likely reflect cross reactivity with, or shared, epitopes following exposure to other HPV types.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	155	 There is evidence for this in the studies of Williams et al.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	156	 (2002) for HPV-11 and Steele et al.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Overall, HPV-16-positive VIN patients have high levels of antibodies to the viral capsid proteins and these are likely to be capable of neutralizing the virus.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	158	 This antibody production is presumably also reflected in the high prevalence of T-helper responses measured by either proliferation or ELISPOT.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	159	E2 seropositivity is not prevalent in the disease and, as with T-helper responses (de Jong et al.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	160	, 2002), may reflect exposure to different HPV types with shared epitopes.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	161	 However, there does appear to be a subgroup of patients with specific T-cell responses to E2, as measured by proliferation and ELISPOT.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	162	 These two patients were clinical responders in a trial of an HPV vaccine (E.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	163	 The clinical outcome may be a result of a shift in immune factors that clear the lesion(s) (which may be heterogeneous) and concomitant reduction in local virus immune suppression (Tindle, 2002).
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	164	 None of the healthy volunteers showed evidence of E2-specific T-cell responses either by proliferation assay or by ELISPOT.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	165	 This is consistent with the results of Bontkes et al.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	166	 (1999), who found no E2-specific T-helper cell responses in healthy control subjects using an IL-2 release assay (Bontkes et al.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	167	, 1999), but contradictory to the findings of de Jong et al.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	168	 (2002), who found frequent strong T-helper cell responses to HPV-16 E2 peptides in four out of eight normal donors.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	169	There are several explanations for the discrepancies noted in these studies.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Firstly, there was only evidence of exposure to HPV-16 in one of the healthy volunteers recruited into this study.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	171	 (2002) tested anonymous donors for E2-specific T-helper cell responses and had no details regarding the age, sex, cervical smear history or HPV-16 VLP antibody status of their subjects.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Secondly, the methodology used was very different.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	173	 used 30-mer overlapping peptides from the full HPV-16 E2 sequence.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Significant cross-reactivity was seen between particular HPV-16 E2-specific T-cell responses and homologous peptides from other HPV types.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Thus, the measured responses may reflect priming with HPV types other than HPV-16 itself.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	176	 Furthermore, it is not clear whether all of the peptides investigated in this study are naturally processed by antigen-presenting cells in vivo.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	177	 In contrast, since the intact E2 C terminus protein was used to measure T-cell responses in this study, any measured E2-specific immunity must reflect stimulation with naturally processed peptides.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	178	 This is also true for the study by Bontkes et al.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	179	 (1999), where E2 C terminus or N terminus proteins were used to stimulate PBMCs for 7 days before testing the supernatant for IL-2 concentration.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	180	 However, the assays used in the present study should also test responses to the HPV-16 E2 N terminus, since it is possible that we are missing a significant response not evident in the IL-2 release assays (Bontkes et al.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	181	It appears that exposure to HPV-16-positive VIN stimulates both antibody and T-cell responses to L1 protein but these may not always be sufficient to clear the lesions.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	182	 In contrast, E2-specific T-cell responses are rare, although a repertoire exists, so it is possible that their absence may facilitate the persistence of VIN lesions.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Without clear proof of E2-specific T-cell responses associated with lesion resolution, it is unclear whether a lack of responsiveness indicates the inappropriateness of the assay or a true absence of E2-specific T cells.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Nevertheless, these studies of immunity to an early and late HPV-16 protein in VIN provide a baseline for comparison of responses to vaccines such as chimeric VLPs including L1 to E7 to E2 (Schiller  and  Hildesheim, 2000).
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	185	 The challenge is to demonstrate such immune responses in patients at the time of virus clearance (systemic and local analyses), and for this, long term follow-up studies of large numbers of young women are required.
0.16015147.12867639.html.plaintext.txt	186	 This will resolve whether E2 is simply non-immunogenic or whether absence of immunogenicity is specifically associated with persistence of HPV-16 infection.

0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	0	ET-1 receptor gene expression and distribution in L1 and L2 cells from hypertensive sheep pulmonary artery Elena V.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Balyakina1, Daohong Chen2, Mayme L.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	2	 Lawrence2, Suzanne Manning2, Richard E.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	3	 Shappell2, and Barbara Meyrick1,2.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	4	Departments of 2 Pathology and 1 Medicine and Center for Lung Research, Vanderbilt University Medical Center, Nashville, Tennessee 37232-2650.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	5	We examined gene and surface expression and activity of the endothelin (ET)-1 receptors (ETA and ETB) in subendothelial (L1) and inner medial (L2) cells from the main pulmonary artery of sheep with continuous air embolization (CAE)-induced chronic pulmonary hypertension (CPH).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	6	 According to quantitative real-time RT-PCR, basal gene expression of both receptors was significantly higher in L2 than L1 cells, and hypertensive L2 cells showed significantly higher gene expression of ETB than controls.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Expression of both genes in hypertensive L1 cells was similar to controls.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Fluorescence-activated cell sorter analysis confirmed the increased distribution of ETB in hypertensive L2 cells.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Although only the ETA receptors in control L2 cells showed significant binding of [125I]-labeled ET-1 at 1 h, both receptors bound ET-1 to hypertensive cells.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Exposure to exogenous ET-1 for 18 h revealed that only the L2 cells internalized ET-1, and internalization by hypertensive L2 cells was significantly reduced when compared with controls.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Treatment with ETA (BQ-610) and ETB (BQ-788) receptor antagonists demonstrated that both receptors contributed to internalization of ET-1 in control L2 cells, whereas in hypertensive cells only when both receptor antagonists were used in combination was significant suppression of ET-1 internalization found.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	12	 We conclude that in sheep receiving CAE, alterations in ETB receptors in cells of the L2 layer may contribute to the maintenance of CPH via alterations in their expression, distribution, and activity.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	13	ETA receptor; ETB receptor; smooth muscle cells; pulmonary hypertension; endothelin.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	14	SINCE ITS DISCOVERY 12 YEARS AGO, endothelin (ET) has been shown to contribute to a wide variety of physiological and pathophysiological processes in various systems (22).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	15	 The ET family of 21 amino acid peptides exists in three distinct isoforms: ET-1, ET-2, and ET-3.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	16	 It is an extremely potent vasoconstrictor resulting in slowly developing and sustained contraction.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Although the endothelial cell was originally described as the source of ET-1, it is now known that several other cell types, including pulmonary vascular smooth muscle cells, synthesize this peptide (33, 36).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	18	The biological effects of ET-1 are mediated by two distinct ET receptor subtypes, ETA and ETB (1, 35).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The affinity of the ETA receptor for ET-1 has been shown to be ~100 times that for ET-3 (ET-1  >  ET-2  >  ET-3), whereas the affinity of the ETB receptor is equipotent for all three isoforms of ET (34).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Early reports indicated that the ETA receptor on smooth muscle was responsible for the vasoconstrictor effect of ET-1, whereas the ETB receptor on endothelial cells modulated ET-1-induced vasodilation.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	21	 However, recent pharmacological studies suggest that there are two classes of ETB with cell specific effects, ETB1 on endothelial cells mediating vasodilation and ETB2 on smooth muscle cells mediating vasoconstriction (9).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	22	 The ETB receptor also functions as a "clearance receptor" and is particularly important in the lung, where 50% of ET-1 is retained (22, 29).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	23	ET-1 has been linked to the development of chronic pulmonary hypertension (CPH).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Increased expression of the peptide has been demonstrated in endothelial cells of pulmonary arteries from patients with idiopathic and secondary forms of pulmonary hypertension (15), and arterial-to-venous ratios of ET-1 protein were found to be elevated above the normal range in patients with pulmonary hypertension (40).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Several studies have linked increased expression of ET-1 to the development of hypoxia-induced CPH in rats (5, 24), and use of ET-1 receptor antagonists has been shown both to inhibit progression of the disease and to promote recovery (4, 10, 43).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	26	Although these studies support a central role for ET-1 in the pathogenesis of CPH, the picture is likely more complicated than first suspected, in that prepro-ET-1 (ppET-1) mRNA is decreased in the monocrotaline model of CPH, and in addition, we recently reported regional variability in ppET-1 gene expression in the pulmonary artery of normal sheep.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Furthermore, we found in a model of CPH, sheep receiving continuous air embolization (CAE) into the main pulmonary artery, that ppET-1 gene expression in the main pulmonary artery and peripheral lung gradually decreased with the onset of pulmonary hypertension while the midregion artery (9th-10th generation) showed a gradual increase (42).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	28	At least four cell types have been identified in the bovine main pulmonary artery: subendothelial L1 cells, inner medial L2 cells, and outer medial L3S and L3R cells (12, 13).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	29	 We recently showed that L1 cells (a cell with characteristics of both endothelial and smooth muscle cells) cultured from control sheep produce strikingly more ET-1 than L2 cells (mature smooth muscle cells) under basal conditions, but when exposed to exogenous ET-1, only the L2 cells internalize exogenous ET-1 (41).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	30	 The present study examines whether ETA and ETB gene and surface expression is altered in L1 and L2 cells from control and hypertensive sheep.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	31	 This study also examines whether ET-1 receptor distribution and activity are altered in L1 and L2 cells cultured from hypertensive sheep induced by 12 days of CAE.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	32	 The protocol for delivery of CAE into the sheep pulmonary artery has been described previously, and the physiological and structural changes for this model of CPH have been reported in detail (16, 32).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Briefly, a left thoracotomy was performed on yearling mixed-breed sheep under general anesthesia, and pulmonary artery and left atrial catheters were inserted.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	34	 A jugular venous introducer and carotid artery catheter were placed through a neck incision.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	35	 After a recovery period of 3-5 days, a Swan-Ganz catheter was positioned in the pulmonary artery through the jugular vein introducer.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Baseline measurements of pulmonary arterial pressure (Ppa), cardiac output (CO), and left atrial pressure (Pla) were made, and pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) was calculated using the formula: PVR = (Ppa  Pla)/CO.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	37	 After baseline measurements, the sheep received CAE (n = 3) into the pulmonary artery by way of the proximal port (lying in the right heart) of the Swan-Ganz catheter over a 12-day period.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	38	 The rate of air embolization administered was sufficient to cause an increase in PVR that was ~2.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Physiological measurements were performed each day, and the rate of air flow was adjusted as necessary to maintain the elevation in PVR.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Surgically prepared animals not receiving air but maintained for the same time period served as controls (n = 3).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	41	 At the end of the experiment, the animals were killed with an overdose of sodium barbiturate (pentobarbital sodium 325 mg   ml1   5 kg1 body wt, Euthanazia-5 solution; Henry Schein, Port Washington, NY), and the lungs were removed.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	42	 The main pulmonary artery was dissected from a point 1 cm from its exit from the right ventricle to its point of entry into the right and left lungs, and a section was taken for routine light microscopy and for 1- microm sections of epoxy-embedded tissue.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Cells were isolated from the subendothelial (L1) and inner medial (L2) layers of the main pulmonary artery from control and hypertensive sheep as previously described (41, 42).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Briefly, the artery was opened, and the endothelial layer was removed by gentle scraping; the subendothelial L1 cells were isolated from pulmonary artery segments by deep scraping.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	45	 The inner media L2 cells were isolated either by a modified explant technique or by enzymatic dissociation.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Using phase contrast microscopy, we identified L1 and L2 cell colonies by their morphology, trypsinized them in "cloning rings" and transferred them into culture dishes.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Both cells types were seeded and cultured in RPMI-1640 containing 100 U/ml penicillin, 100  microg/ml streptomycin, 40  microg/ml gentamicin, 2 mmol/l L-glutamine (GIBCO-BRL, Grand Island, NY), and 15% heat-inactivated calf serum (Atlanta Biologicals, Norcross, GA).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Confluent cells (passages 3-6) were used for all experiments; higher passage numbers have been associated with a substantial increase in ETB receptor density (27).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Cell lines cultured from each of three different control and three different hypertensive animals were used for each assay.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	50	 All experiments were carried out in RPMI-1640 containing 0.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Experiments were initiated after overnight incubation of the cells in that medium.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	52	 For real-time RT-PCR analysis of ETA and ETB gene expression, cells were harvested 90 min after addition of 0.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	53	 For dose-response studies of ET-1 internalization, intracellular levels of ET-1 were measured after 18-h exposure to exogenous ET-1 at concentrations from 0.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Experiments with ETA (BQ-610) and ETB (BQ-788) antagonists included a 2-h preincubation period before addition of exogenous ET-1 (10 nM) for 18 h.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	55	 The dose of each antagonist used in these experiments was based on dose-response curves.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	56	 The concentrations of BQ-610 tested were from 1 to 100  microM, and those for BQ-788 were from 0.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	57	 The dose chosen was the dose that gave a 50% reduction in uptake of exogenous ET-1 by control L2 cells.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	58	 For ET-1 binding assays, cells in two P150 dishes were pretreated with either BQ-610 or BQ-788 for 2 h before isolation of cell membranes.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Untreated L1 and L2 cells and cells treated with each antagonist alone served as controls.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	60	Quantitative real-time RT-PCR for ETA and ETB.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Total RNA was isolated with RNA STAT-60 reagent (TEL-TEST "B", Friendswood, TX).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	62	 mRNA copy numbers of ETA and ETB in L1 and L2 cultured cells from control and hypertensive sheep were determined by real-time quantitative RT-PCR using a Lightcycler fluorescence temperature rapid-air cycler (Roche Molecular Biochemicals, Indianapolis, IN) with cDNA (ETA) or RNA (ETB) standard curves and the double-stranded DNA binding fluorescent probe SYBR green (38).

0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	64	0  microl 1 x  SYBR green RNA master-mix (Roche Molecular Biochemicals), 0.

0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	66	The cDNA template for ETA standard curves was derived by reverse transcription of total RNA from control L2 cells (17).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Total RNA from L2 cells was used as a template for standard curves for the RT-PCR assay for ETB.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Copy number for ETA and ETB standard templates was assigned based on the concentration of the total cDNA or RNA and the known number of base pairs (bp) in the full-length cDNAs or RNA of ETA and ETB, respectively.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	69	 The primers for ETA (based on the human sequence) were: 5' AGC TTC CTG GTT ACC ACT CAT CAA 3' (forward) and 5' TCA ACA TCT CAC AAG TCA TGA G 3' (reverse), which give a 714-bp product (corresponding to nucleotides 136-850) (45).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	70	Primers for ETB were derived from a newly generated sheep cDNA sequence, because our first attempts at real-time RT-PCR using primers generated from the human ETB cDNA sequence revealed several nonspecific products.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Briefly, RT-PCR amplimers for sheep ETB were cloned into pGEM-T Easy Vector System (Promega, Madison, WI) and transformed into DH5a-competent cells.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Positive colonies were selected by color screening, and the plasmid DNA was isolated using a QIAprep Spin Miniprep Kit (QIAGEN).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Digestion of the plasmid DNA with EcoRI gave inserts of the expected size (701 bp).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Comparison of the sequence of these clones with the human sequence demonstrated 89-90% homology.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	75	 New ETB primers were designed to amplify a 297-bp fragment from this sequence using DNA-STAR software.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	76	 The utilized ETB primers were: 5'-TTT GGC CAC TTC CCG TCT CTG TTT 3' (forward) and 5' ATT TGG GTG GTC TCC GTG GTT CTG 3' (reverse).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	77	The one-step real-time RT-PCR reactions consisted of the following steps: reverse transcription at 55 degrees C for 15 min, denaturation at 95 degrees C for 1 min, amplification for 55 cycles, and melting curve analysis from 95 to 65 degrees C at a rate of 0.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	78	1 degrees C/s under continuous fluorescence monitoring.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	79	 The amplification program for ETA consisted of heating at 20 degrees C/s to 95 degrees C, cooling at 20 degrees C/s to 57 degrees C, annealing at 57 degrees C for 5 s, heating at 20 degrees C/s to 72 degrees C, elongation at 72 degrees C for 29 s, and heating at 5 degrees C/s to 86 degrees C for fluorescence acquisition.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	80	 The amplification program for ETB consisted of heating at 20 degrees C/s to 95 degrees C, cooling at 20 degrees C/s to 55 degrees C, annealing at 55 degrees C for 5 s, heating at 20 degrees C/s to 72 degrees C, elongation at 72 degrees C for 14 s, and heating at 5 degrees C/s to 79 degrees C for fluorescence acquisition.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	81	 The specificity of the amplimer in each reaction was confirmed by melting curve analysis, with initial gel confirmation that this large peak corresponded to the expected amplimer (representative melting curve analysis for ETB shown in Fig.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	82	 The contribution to fluorescence signal of any nonspecific products and/or primer dimers was eliminated by increasing the temperature to 2 degrees C below the melting temperature of the specific product, which eliminated any other minor cDNAs (which have lower melting temperatures) (38).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Copy numbers of mRNA were calculated from serially diluted standard curves generated from cDNA or RNA templates (17, 38).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Serial dilutions (1:10) over a range of three orders of magnitude were used to generate the standard curves.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	85	 The serially diluted standards were simultaneously amplified with the unknown samples to generate a linear standard curve by the fit-points method of analysis with five points.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Standard curves for both ETA and ETB consistently had correlation coefficients of 0.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	87	00 (representative sample for ETB is shown in Fig.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Control samples run in triplicate had a variance of ~10%.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	89	 All biological samples fell on the standard curves, and copy numbers of the unknown samples were calculated with the Lightcycler software (version 3).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	90	 ETA and ETB values were normalized to the copy numbers of the housekeeping gene glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (G3PDH) and multiplied by 100 (%) to correct any variation in amount of RNA utilized per assay.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	91	 All samples for an individual receptor subtype were analyzed in the same assay, eliminating any contribution of interassay variability.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	92	ET-1 ligand-receptor maximal binding assay.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Control and hypertensive L2 cells were pretreated with BQ-610 and BQ-788 alone and together for 2 h before isolation of crude cell membrane fractions (CMF) as previously described (42).

0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	96	 The reaction was performed in a total volume of 200  microl in 50 mM Tris buffer.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Controls for nonspecific binding were carried out in parallel using 20  microg of CMF protein mixed with 0.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	98	5  microM unlabeled ET-1 plus 0.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	99	 The reaction was terminated by passing the reaction mix through a Glass Fiber C-grade filter paper (Whatman, Maidstone, England) and washing it in PBS.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	100	 The bound radioactive disintegrations on the filter paper were then counted on an autoradiocounter for [125I].

0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	102	Assessment of ETA and ETB by flow cytometry.

0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	228	 9A); pretreatment with either BQ-610 or BQ-788 significantly suppressed the increase in intracellular ET-1 by 18 and 25%, respectively.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Simultaneous exposure to both antagonists caused an additive inhibitory effect (~40%), although the level of intracellular ET-1 remained significantly elevated above basal levels (P  <  0.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	230	View larger version (20K):    Fig.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	231	   Effect of the ETA and ETB receptor antagonists BQ-610 and BQ-788 alone and in combination on uptake of exogenous ET-1 (10 nM) in L2 cells from control sheep (A) and hypertensive sheep (B).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Cells were pretreated with antagonists for 2 h, washed, and then exposed to ET-1 for 18 h (hatched bars).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	233	 Controls (open bars) did not receive ET-1 treatment.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Data are expressed as means  plus or minus  SE, n = 6, except for the experiments with both antagonists where n = 3.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	235	Basal levels of intracellular ET-1 in the hypertensive L2 cells were similar to those in control cells (Fig.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	236	 9B), although uptake by hypertensive cells was ~50% less than by control cells (Fig.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Unlike the response of the control cells, pretreatment of the hypertensive L2 cells with either BQ-610 of BQ-788 failed to inhibit the ET-1-stimulated increase in intracellular ET-1 (Fig.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	238	 Simultaneous exposure to both antagonists, however, caused significant and striking inhibition of the ET-1-stimulated increase in intracellular ET-1 such that the level of intracellular ET-1 returned to basal values.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	239	In a previous study, our group identified differences in the ET-1 system in L1 and L2 cells from control sheep (41).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	240	 L1 cells, like endothelial cells, were found to synthesize and release ET-1, whereas L2 cells had less synthetic capacity for ET-1 but, rather, had the propensity to internalize exogenous ET-1.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	241	 The present study extends these findings and examines ETA and ETB gene and surface expression, Bmax sites, and activity as assessed by ET-1 internalization by L1 and L2 cells from the main pulmonary artery of control sheep and those with sustained pulmonary hypertension induced by CAE.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	242	 The present in vitro study documents that the hypertensive L2 cells, as seen in vivo, maintain their hypertrophic appearance, whereas the L1 cells from the thickened subendothelial layer revert to an appearance similar to controls.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	243	 In addition, we show that L2 cells from control and hypertensive animals exhibit significantly higher basal expression of both the ETA and ETB genes than L1 cells and that ETB gene and surface expression in hypertensive L2 cells was significantly increased compared with controls.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	244	 The present findings also confirm that L2, but not L1, cells from control sheep internalize exogenous ET-1 in a dose-dependent manner and further demonstrate that L2 cells from hypertensive sheep internalize less ET-1 than controls.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	245	 In addition, we found that in control cells, the ETA receptors were mainly responsible for binding ET-1 to the L2 cells, but after 18 h of exposure to ET-1, both receptors played a role in internalization.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	246	 Using ETA and ETB receptor antagonists, our study also demonstrates that in hypertensive cells, both receptors bound radiolabeled ET-1; internalization of ET-1, however, was inhibited only when the ETA and ETB antagonists were used in combination.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	247	Function of ETA and ETB receptors.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	248	 In humans, ETA and ETB are encoded by distinct genes located on chromosomes 4 and 13, respectively (32).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	249	 In pulmonary vascular smooth muscle cells, the ETA receptor is linked to vasoconstriction as well as hypertrophy and smooth muscle proliferation, whereas the ETB receptor is linked to clearance of ET-1 from the circulation as well as both vasoconstriction and vasodilation (22, 36, 39).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	250	 Studies in the pulmonary vasculature suggest that the actions of ET-1 are mediated by at least three receptors: one ETA receptor and two ETB receptor subtypes.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Pharmacological studies in several species indicate that the endothelial ETB receptor (designated ETB1) mediates vasodilatation, whereas the ETB2 receptor expressed in smooth muscle acts as vasoconstrictor (5, 7, 9).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	252	ETA and ETB receptors are G protein-coupled receptors that undergo agonist-stimulated desensitization or inactivation (26).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Desensitization is thought to prevent both overstimulation and damage to activated cells as well as saturation by weak stimuli.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	254	 Phosphorylation has been identified as the major mechanism for rapid desensitization for many G protein-coupled receptors.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	255	 In humans, ETA receptors have been shown to have a prolonged period of desensitization occurring within 5 min of exposure to ET-1; sensitization is restored between 80 and 120 min (8).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	256	 This prolonged desensitization period seems to be unique to the ETA receptor and may explain, at least in part, the prolonged contraction of smooth muscle cells in response to ET-1 (6).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	257	 The ETB receptors, on the other hand, are rapidly deactivated (via phosphorylation and dehydration) and lose  > 80% of their initial activity within 5 min of agonist stimulation.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	258	 This rapid deactivation of ETB has been linked to the short-term vasodilatory effect of ET-1 (7).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	259	 The present study shows that both ETA and ETB receptors bind and are responsible for internalization of exogenous ET-1; however, our data in hypertensive cells suggest that both receptors types have become desensitized.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	260	ETA and ETB receptors in L1 and L2 cells from control sheep.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	261	 Both ETA and ETB receptors have been identified in pulmonary and systemic vascular smooth muscle cells, e.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	262	, rat aorta (30), human internal mammary artery and vein, porcine coronary arteries (37), and rat and human pulmonary artery (28).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	263	 In humans, ETA receptors were found in both resistance and conduit arteries, and in the main pulmonary artery, ETA receptors predominated (90%) (5).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	264	 Tracheal smooth muscle from rats and mice, however, exhibited approximately equal numbers of the two receptor subtypes (18), whereas ETB receptors were 50% more numerous than ETA in rat pulmonary artery smooth muscle cells (23).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	265	 Thus the distribution and density of ET-1 receptors on various smooth muscle types may vary between species and location (5, 31).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	266	The present study demonstrates that L1 and L2 cells from control sheep express both the ETA and ETB genes.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	267	 The significantly lower expression of both genes in L1 cells compared with L2 cells substantiates our previous suggestion that the L1 cell contributes little to the maintenance of vascular tone in the main pulmonary artery.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	268	 The paucity of ET-1 receptors in L1 cells also corroborates our finding that these cells fail to internalize exogenous ET-1.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	269	Our binding studies confirm the notion that activity of the ETA receptors predominates in L2 cells from the main pulmonary artery of control sheep.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	270	 With long-term exposure, however, it seems that both receptors participate equally in the internalization process.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	271	 This difference is likely to reflect the effects of long- and short-term exposure, the ETB receptor becoming more active when exposure to ET-1 is prolonged perhaps as a result of an increase in the requirement for internalization, and degradation of ET-1.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	272	 Previous studies in isolated, perfused rat lungs (29) have also shown that both receptors play a role in clearance of ET-1 (14).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	273	ETA and ETB receptors in hypertensive L2 cells.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	274	 Alterations in ET-1 receptors have been demonstrated in several models of CPH.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	275	 For example, increased ETA gene expression was demonstrated in rat lungs and increased ETB gene expression in the rat main pulmonary artery after exposure to hypoxia for 48 h (25).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	276	 After 14 days of hypoxia, increased expression of both ETA and ETB was found in the distal pulmonary arteries of rats, ETA expression occurring mainly in the media and ETB in the intima; no change in expression of either receptor was found in the large muscular pulmonary arteries (39).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	277	 In contrast to the hypoxic models, in monocrotaline-induced CPH, ETB receptor mRNA was shown to be decreased in the lung (46).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	278	The present study demonstrates a selective and significant increase in ETB gene and surface expression in and receptor binding by the hypertensive L2 cells compared with controls.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	279	 Further confirmation of the increase in ETB receptors on hypertensive L2 cells is shown by our finding of an increase in early internalization of ET-1 by ETB.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	280	 Similar increases in ETB gene expression have been reported in the pulmonary arteries of patients with chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (44).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	281	 The ETB signaling pathway has been linked to the regulation of ppET-1 gene expression in rat mesangial cells (19).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	282	 The present study confirms this notion since, in a previous study, we showed that ppET-1 gene expression in the main pulmonary artery was decreased in hypertensive sheep compared with controls.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	283	Although our studies demonstrate that, in the short term, internalization and clearance of ET-1 by ETB in the hypertensive cells may be increased, our studies with the ETA and ETB receptor antagonists suggest that, in the longer term, this scenario does not occur.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	284	 Rather, our data demonstrate that ET-1-stimulated internalization of exogenous ET-1 is decreased in hypertensive L2 cells compared with controls and that the sensitivity of the individual ET-1 receptors is lost.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	285	 It is only when the ETA and ETB antagonists are added simultaneously that suppression of ET-1 uptake occurs.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	286	 Similar findings have been demonstrated in isolated perfused lungs from rats with hypoxic CPH (23).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	287	 One possible explanation for the failure of each antagonist alone to inhibit ET-1 uptake is that the concentration of antagonists used in the study was not sufficient to inhibit ETA and ETB receptors in hypertensive L2 cells.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	288	 This would seem unlikely, because both antagonists failed to exert an inhibitory effect.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	289	 Another possibility is that phosphorylation of the receptor/ligand complex and/or receptor recycling are altered in the hypertensive cells.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	290	 This notion requires further study.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	291	Another possible explanation is that concurrent treatment with the ETA and ETB antagonists involves simultaneous activation and heterodimerization of the two receptors (26).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	292	 Recent studies suggest that ET-1 binds simultaneously to both an ETA and ETB receptor (2, 11).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	293	 This heterodimerization between two fully functional G protein-coupled receptors is suggested to result in a new receptor/ligand binding complex with functional properties different from those of either receptor alone (21).
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	294	 Thus it is possible that when the individual ETA and ETB receptors of hypertensive L2 cells are desensitized to exogenous ET-1, their simultaneous stimulation results in heterodimerization of ETA and ETB receptors and internalization of ET-1 by a different pathway.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	295	 This new pathway would seem to be extremely effective, since intracellular levels of ET-1 in the hypertensive L2 cells returned almost to basal values.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	296	 Further studies are needed to elucidate this possible explanation.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	297	In summary, we have shown that gene and surface expression and activity of the ETB, but not the ETA, receptors in L1 and L2 cells from control and hypertensive sheep are different.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	298	 Control and hypertensive L2 cells exhibit significantly higher steady-state basal expression of both the ETA and ETB genes than L1 cells.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	299	 In agreement with this finding, we found that only the L2 cells internalize exogenous ET-1.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	300	 In the short term, the ETA receptors are mainly responsible for binding of ET-1, but with longer exposure, both receptors contribute to internalization.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	301	 In hypertensive L2 cells, we showed that ETB gene and surface expression and Bmax by this receptor were significantly elevated above baseline.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	302	 Uptake of exogenous ET-1 by these cells, however, was less pronounced than in control cells.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	303	 Furthermore, we found that only concurrent treatment with both ETA and ETB antagonists suppressed ET-1 uptake in the hypertensive cells, suggesting an alteration in their structure.
0.16787788.12060559.html.plaintext.txt	304	 We conclude that changes in gene and surface expression and activity of the ETB receptors in L2 cells from hypertensive sheep may contribute to the development and maintenance of CPH through an altered sensitivity to locally produced ET-1.
