0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	0	Detection of antibodies against a human papillomavirus (HPV) type 16 peptide that differentiate high-risk from low-risk HPV-associated low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions Leticia Rocha-Zavaleta1, Juana P.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Ambrosio1, Maria de Lourdes Mora-Garcia2, Fernando Cruz-Talonia3, Jorge Hernandez-Montes2, Benny Weiss-Steider2, Vianney Ortiz-Navarrete4 and Alberto Monroy-Garcia2.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	2	1 Department of Molecular Biology and Biotechnology, Institute of Biomedical Research, National University of Mexico, Circuito Escolar S/N, Cd Universitaria, Apdo Postal 70228, DF CP 04510 Mexico City, Mexico 2 Laboratory of Immunobiology (L-326), Unit of Research on Cellular Differentiation and Cancer, FES Zaragoza, National University of Mexico, Mexico City, Mexico 3 National Center for Clinics of Dysplasias (CENACLID), General Hospital of Mexico, Mexico City, Mexico 4 Unit of Molecular Biomedicine, CINVESTAV, IPN, Mexico City, Mexico.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	3	Correspondence Alberto Monroy-Garcia albertomon{at}yahoo.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	4	Genital HPV infection frequently induces antibody-mediated immune responses, mostly directed against the viral capsid (Wang et al.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	5	 The HPV capsid is composed of two structural proteins, a largely internal minor capsid protein (L2) and a major protein (L1), which is 30 times more abundant than L2 (Kirnbauer et al.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	6	, 1993) and represents about 80 % of the total viral protein.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	7	 L1 is an important target of the immune system.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Immunological assays based on the use of HPV capsids are known to detect type-restricted antibodies, possibly due to the presentation of type-specific conformational epitopes.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Interestingly, the HPV-16 capsid exposes not only type-restricted but also type-common antigenic epitopes (Heino et al.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Thus, in addition to specific antibodies (Cason et al.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	11	, 1992), widely cross-reactive antibodies have been found to react against peptide sequences on the L1 protein of both high- and low-risk HPV types (LeCann et al.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	12	We have previously described a peptide (IHSMNSTIL) derived from the HPV-16 L1 protein (16L1 peptide) that binds to HLA class I allele B*3901 and elicits proliferative responses in lymphocytes from patients with cervical cancer associated with either HPV-16 or -18 (Monroy-Garcia et al.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Further analysis of this peptide using Lipman and Pearson's ALIGN program showed that the sequence presented a substantial amino acid identity with the corresponding sequence in HPV-18 (88 9 % identity), HPV-16-related types (77 8 to 66 7 % identity) and HPV-18-related types (88 9 to 66 7 % identity).
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Interestingly, comparison with the corresponding sequences in HPV-6 and -11 demonstrated an identity level of 55 6 %.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	15	 This observation raised the question of whether antibodies generated against these sequences could cross-react with the 16L1 peptide.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	16	 This study aimed to evaluate the anti-peptide reactivity of antibodies produced in patients with high-risk HPV-associated low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions (LSIL) and cervical cancer and to compare it with the reaction of antibodies from women with low-risk HPV-associated LSIL to assess their potential cross-reactivity.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	17	 All reagents used for the isolation and amplification of DNA were purchased from Gibco-BRL.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Biopsies were treated with proteinase K as described elsewhere (Kaye et al.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	19	 DNA was extracted with phenol/chloroform and precipitated with ethanol.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	20	 HPV DNA was amplified using the general primers MY09 (5'-CGTCCMARRGGAWACTGATC-3') and MY11 (5'-GCMCAGGGWCATAAYAATGG-3') (Manos et al.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	21	, 1989), which amplified a conserved 450 bp fragment from the L1 gene.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Genomic DNA (100 ng) was denatured by heating the reaction to 95  degrees C for 30 s.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Annealing of primers was performed at 45  degrees C for 30 s and extension at 72  degrees C for 60 s.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	24	 The cycle was repeated 30 times.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	25	 PCR products were electrophoresed in 2 % agarose gels, stained with ethidium bromide and visualized in a UV transilluminator.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Specific amplification of HPV-16 was achieved by using the primers Pr3 (5'-GTCAAAAGCCACTGTGTCCT-3') and Pr4 (5'-CCATCCATTACATCCCGTAC-3'), which amplified a 499 bp fragment covering the HPV-16 E7 gene plus fragments of the E6 and E1 genes.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Amplification of HPV-18 was performed using the primers Pr1 (5'-CCGAGCACGACAGGAACGACT-3') and Pr2 (5'-TCGTTTTCTTCCTCTGAGTCGCTT-3'), which amplified a 172 bp fragment including parts of the HPV-18 E6 and E7 genes, as described previously (Karlsen et al.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	28	 An internal control to ensure DNA integrity was performed by amplifying the -globin gene using the primers PC03 and PC04 as described previously (Saiki et al.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	29	 As a positive control, DNA from SiHa (a cervical cancer-derived cell line containing one to two HPV-16 copies per cell) or HeLa (a cervical cancer-derived cell line positive for the presence of HPV-18) cells was run concurrently with each reaction.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Additionally, negative controls to assess the presence of contaminants were carried out using purified water (Gibco-BRL) and PBS instead of template DNA.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Patients whose DNA sample could not be amplified were excluded from the study.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	32	Detection of high- and low-risk HPV types by hybrid capture.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	33	 The HPV Test Hybrid Capture II kit (Digene) for the detection of high-risk HPV types (16, 18, 31, 33, 35, 39, 45, 51, 52, 56, 58, 59 and 68) or low-risk types (6, 11, 42, 43 and 44) was used.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	34	 DNA (250 to 500 ng in 20  microl) was extracted from cervical tissue and placed in a tube containing 30  microl specimen transport medium.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	35	 NaOH-based denaturation reagent (25  microl) was added to each sample and the tubes were mixed vigorously and incubated at 65  degrees C for 45 min.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Hybridization and hybrid detection were performed according to the manufacturer's instructions.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Carrier DNA and plasmid DNA containing the HPV-16 or HPV-11 genome were used as negative and positive calibrators, respectively, and were run in triplicate with each test.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	38	 An assay was considered valid only when the results from the negative and positive calibrators showed a coefficient of variation 15 % and the positive : negative calibrator mean values ratio was 2 0.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	39	 The cut-off value for positivity was calculated for each assay and was defined as the mean relative light units (RLU) value of the positive calibrator.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Patients who were positive for both low- and high-risk types were excluded from the study.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	41	 The nonamer peptide IHSMNSTIL was generated by solid-phase synthesis on a multiple peptide automatic synthesizer (Applied Biosystems Synergy Personal Peptide Synthesizer 432A; Perkin Elmer).
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Repeated cycles of addition of 9-fluorenylmethoxycarbonyl (Fmoc)-protected amino acids to a polystyrene resin were alternated with an Fmoc deprotection procedure (Gausepohl et al.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	43	 After completion of the synthesis, the peptide was cleaved from the resin and the side chain-protective groups removed by treatment with trifluoroacetic acid containing 5 % water.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Finally, the peptide was analysed by reverse-phase HPLC for amino acid composition and purity.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	45	 A 75 % pure peptide preparation was lyophilized and dissolved in sterile PBS before use.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Serum IgG and mucosal IgA antibodies were detected using the 16L1 peptide as the target antigen in a standard ELISA.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	47	 ELISA plates (Maxisorp; Nalge Nunc) were coated with 500 ng 16L1 peptide per well diluted in sodium carbonate/bicarbonate buffer (0 1 M sodium carbonate, 0 1 M sodium bicarbonate, pH 9 6) at 4  degrees C overnight.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Plates were then washed four times with TBS containing 0 1 % Tween 20 (TBS/Tween 20).
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Non-specific binding sites were blocked with 200  microl 2 % BSA in TBS/Tween 20 for 2 h at 37  degrees C.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	50	 After washing as described above, 100  microl cervical mucus diluted 1 : 2 or serum diluted 1 : 100 in blocking buffer was added to the plate and further incubated for 2 h at 37  degrees C.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	51	 After washing, alkaline phosphatase-conjugated rabbit anti-human IgA secretory component (Dako), which reacts specifically with free human secretory component and secretory component bound to secretory IgA, or rabbit-anti human IgG (Dako) were diluted 1 : 500 in blocking buffer and 100  microl was added to each well.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	52	 The plates were incubated for 1 5 h at 37  degrees C.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	53	 After washing, alkaline phosphatase substrate Sigma 104 (Sigma) was diluted in a 10 % diethanolamine solution (pH 9 8; Sigma) and added to the plates.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	54	 The absorbance was read at 405 nm in an ELISA plate reader.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	55	 All samples were tested in triplicate for each antibody class.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	56	 The assay was considered valid only when the coefficient of variation of the triplicates was 10 %.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Additionally, all samples were tested on two wells not coated with peptide to define non-specific reactivity.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	58	 The final ELISA value was calculated by subtracting the non-specific reactivity mean absorbance from the triplicate mean absorbance.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	59	 To control for inter-assay variation, positive IgG and IgA controls selected from a previous study (Rocha-Zavaleta et al.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	60	, 2003) were included in each plate and tested as described.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Plates with an inter-assay coefficient of variation  > 10 % were not considered valid.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	62	 The cut-off value for positivity was calculated on the basis of the distribution of absorbance of the control group and was defined as the mean absorbance+3 SD after exclusion of outliers.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	63	 The calculated cut-off value for IgG seropositivity was 0 440 and for IgA was 0 237.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	64	 To evaluate the differences between the proportions of positive samples in the different groups, data were arranged in the form of two-by-two contingency tables and analysed by Fisher's exact test to calculate the odds ratios (OR), 95 % confidence intervals (CI) and P values.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	65	 The Wilcoxon signed rank test and Student's t-test were used to compare the mean signal strength (absorbance) of the various groups.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	66	 All tests were two-tailed and the basic significance level was taken as P=0 05.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Sensitivity, specificity, predictive values and efficiency of the ELISA were calculated using standard medical biostatistical formulae.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Characteristics of the groups of patients included in the study.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	69	The presence or absence of HPV DNA was verified using the general MY09/MY11 primers for PCR.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Low- and high-risk types were determined by hybrid capture test.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	71	 HPV-16 was detected using the Pr3/Pr4 type-specific primers for PCR.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Clinical diagnosis was based on cytological analysis and was corroborated by histopathological analysis.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	73	  We first investigated the presence of IgG antibodies against the 16L1 peptide in serum samples.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	74	 A small proportion of patients with low-risk HPV-associated LSIL (6 5 %) tested positive for the presence of IgG antibodies.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	75	 This proportion was similar to the proportion of seropositive individuals in the normal population (P=0 1) (Fig.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	76	 In contrast, more than 90 % of patients infected with high-risk HPV were positive for the presence of IgG.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	77	 The difference between this group and the negative controls was highly significant (P < 0 0001).
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Moreover, the mean signal strength of antibody response in high-risk HPV-associated LSIL patients was 3 7-fold higher than the mean signal strength in control samples.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	79	 PCR analysis of DNA from high-risk HPV-associated LSIL samples indicated that 60 8 % of patients were infected with HPV-16, while 17 4 % were infected with HPV-18 and 21 6 % with other high-risk types.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	80	 However, the proportion of seropositive subjects in each group was similar (P > 0 1) (Table 2).
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	81	 This seemed to indicate that most LSIL patients infected by high-risk HPV types produced antibodies that reacted against the 16L1 peptide.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Thus, we next addressed the question of whether these antibodies could also be found in patients who had developed a high-risk HPV-associated cervical tumour.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Results showed that only 57 7 % of cervical cancer patients had antibodies against the 16L1 peptide.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The proportion of seropositive subjects in the cervical cancer group was significantly higher than that observed in the negative controls (P < 0 0001).
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	85	 However, seropositivity in cervical cancer patients was significantly lower than that detected in high-risk HPV-associated LSIL patients (P < 0 0001).
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	86	 This suggested that the presence of viral DNA in cervical cancer patients does not correlate with the presence of IgG antibodies against the peptide.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Furthermore, statistical analysis revealed that the proportion of seropositive patients whose tumours were HPV-18 positive was significantly lower than the proportion in patients with HPV-16-associated tumours (P=0 03) (Table 2).
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	88	View larger version (30K):    Fig.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	89	 IgG antibody responses against the 16L1 peptide in sera from women without evidence of HPV infection (control), patients with LSIL infected with low-risk or high-risk HPV types and patients with cervical cancer (CeCa) who are also positive for the presence of high-risk HPV types.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	90	 The mean absorbance value of each group is represented as a solid line.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	91	 The cut-off value for positivity (0 440) is indicated as a dotted line.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Statistical differences between groups are shown.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	93	 P values were calculated using Fisher's exact test.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Prevalence of IgG serum antibodies against the 16L1 peptide in patients with LSIL and cervical cancer infected with different high-risk HPV types.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	95	  Our results demonstrated a difference in anti-peptide IgG response between low- and high-risk HPV-infected women with a diagnosis of LSIL.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Thus, we next addressed the significance of the 16L1 peptide-based ELISA for the detection of high-risk HPV infection in LSIL and cervical cancer patients.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	97	 As shown in Table 3, the 16L1 peptide-based ELISA was able to detect a high proportion (91 6 %) of LSIL patients who were actually infected with high-risk HPV types and produced low levels of false-positive and false-negative results.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	98	 The probability that an LSIL patient is infected with high-risk HPV types, given a positive ELISA value, was high (positive predictive value=97 7 %).
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	99	 However, the probability of not being infected with high-risk genotypes, given a negative ELISA result, was lower (negative predictive value=87 7 %).
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	100	 The efficiency of the ELISA to detect high-risk HPV infection in LSIL patients was higher than 90 %.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	101	 In comparison, the ELISA was not quite as sensitive for the detection of high-risk viruses in patients with cervical cancer, having a low negative predictive value (52 7 %) and, as a consequence, a reduced level of efficiency (70 4 %).
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Sensitivity, specificity, predictive values and efficiency of the 16L1 peptide-based ELISA for serological detection of high-risk HPV infection in LSIL and cervical cancer.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	103	Individuals who tested positive in both ELISA and high-risk HPV type hybrid capture were considered a true positive; individuals who tested positive in ELISA but were negative for the presence of high-risk HPV DNA by hybrid capture were considered a false positive; individuals who tested negative in both ELISA and high-risk HPV-type hybrid capture were considered a true negative; and individuals who tested negative in ELISA but were positive for the presence of high-risk HPV DNA by hybrid capture were considered a false negative.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	104	  Detection of IgA antibodies against the 16L1 peptide in cervical secretions Since the results showed that IgG antibodies against the 16L1 peptide were present in the sera of high-risk HPV-infected LSIL patients, we next determined whether reactive IgA antibodies could also be found in cervical secretions from these women.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Once more, ELISAs revealed that LSIL patients infected with low-risk HPV genotypes were largely negative for the presence of anti-16L1 peptide antibodies (Fig.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	106	 In addition, IgA reactivity in the high-risk HPV-associated LSIL population was significantly higher than that observed in the negative-control group and in the low-risk HPV group.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	107	 HPV-16 is by far the most frequent high-risk HPV type infecting women in Latin America (Bosch et al.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Thus, to determine whether mucosal IgA antibodies against the 16L1 peptide were more prevalent in women infected with HPV-16 than in women infected with any high-risk HPV type, we evaluated the presence of IgA in cervical secretions of HPV-16-associated LSIL patients.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	109	 2, the proportion of IgA-positive subjects in the HPV-16-infected group was significantly higher than that of the control group (P < 0 0001).
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	110	 However, statistical comparison of the IgA positivity in the high-risk HPV- and HPV-16-associated LSIL groups indicated that the responses were similar in both groups [OR=1 3; 95 % CI=0 8 to 2 1; P=0 09].
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	111	View larger version (27K):    Fig.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	112	 IgA antibody responses against the 16L1 peptide in cervical secretions from women without evidence of HPV infection (control), patients with LSIL infected with low-risk or high-risk HPV types and patients with evidence of infection with HPV-16.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	113	 The mean absorbance value of each group is represented as a solid line.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	114	 The cut-off value for positivity (0 237) is indicated as a dotted line.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Statistical differences between groups are shown.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	116	 P values were calculated using Fisher's exact test.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	117	  To ascertain whether the presence of serum IgG correlated with the detection of cervical IgA, a statistical analysis of the proportion of positive subjects in each group was performed.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	118	 As shown in Table 4, there was no difference in the proportion of women positive for the presence of IgG and IgA in the non-infected group (P=0 4).
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Interestingly, when all patients diagnosed with LSIL were analysed together, no difference was detected between the IgG and IgA responses (P=0 06).
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	120	 However, separate analysis of LSIL patients infected by low- or high-risk HPV types showed that the proportion of cervical IgA responders was significantly higher than the proportion of IgG seropositives in the group of patients infected by low-risk HPV types.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	121	 In contrast, in the patients infected with high-risk HPV, the proportion of IgG seropositives was significantly higher than that of cervical IgA positives (P < 0 0001).
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	122	 In this group, the likelihood of presenting circulating IgG antibodies to the 16L1 peptide was six times higher than that of presenting mucosal IgA antibodies against the peptide.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	123	 This suggested that, during early infection by high-risk HPV genotypes, the antibody response is mediated predominantly by systemic IgG antibodies.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Statistical comparison of serum IgG and cervical IgA responses against the 16L1 peptide.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	125	Serological studies, using virus-like particles (VLPs) as antigenic targets, have demonstrated that the majority of women infected with HPV-16 produce an IgG antibody response (Kirnbauer et al.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Here, we found that most women with high-risk HPV type-associated LSIL generated systemic IgG antibodies against the 16L1 peptide.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	127	 However, antibodies detected in VLP-based assays are mainly type restricted and directed against conformational epitopes (Christensen et al.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Therefore, it might be possible that anti-16L1 and anti-VLP antibodies are generated in parallel as a response against infection.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	129	 To ascertain whether these antibodies co-exist in infected humans, the population studied herein is currently being tested in a VLP-based ELISA.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	130	It is generally accepted that IgG antibodies against HPV capsid antigens are long lasting (Af Geijersstam et al.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	131	, 2000) and may be a marker of past and current infection.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	132	 From the information presented in Table 3, it appears that systemic IgG antibodies against the 16L1 peptide are good indicators of current infection.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Nevertheless, we cannot conclude this, because we did not analyse women with a previous history of HPV infection and the number of seropositive patients who were negative for the presence of viral DNA was too small.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	134	 To ascertain whether antibodies against the 16L1 peptide are markers of prior infection, it will be necessary to test groups of currently non-infected women, who had a previous infection that was either treated successfully or cleared naturally.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	135	 On the other hand, we observed that a small proportion of patients with LSIL were seronegative, regardless of the presence of HPV DNA.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	136	 With reference to this, an earlier study of incident HPV infection demonstrated that some women with a persistent HPV infection never seroconverted (Carter et al.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Thus, it is possible that the seronegative patients detected in this work do not produce antibodies against the peptide.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	138	Here we demonstrated that IgG antibodies against the 16L1 peptide were detected in sera from most LSIL patients infected with high-risk HPV types and were almost absent in low-risk HPV-associated LSIL and uninfected women.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	139	 In as much as HPV infection is associated with risk factors such as age and sexual activity (Giuliano et al.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	140	, 1999), it could be postulated that the apparent cross-reactivity between high-risk HPV types might reflect shared epidemiological risk factors.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	141	 This is unlikely, because the epidemiological data presented in Table 1 showed that mean values for age, number of sexual partners and pregnancies were similar between high- and low-risk HPV-associated LSIL and even non-infected women.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	142	 This suggests strongly that the antibodies detected are not associated with these risk factors.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Another possibility might be that patients included in the high-risk HPV-associated LSIL group were previously infected with HPV-16.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	144	 To determine whether previous HPV-16 infection occurred in these women, a study of the presence of HPV-16 DNA in archive tissue samples is warranted.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	145	A more likely explanation might be that the difference in antibody responses is associated with the level of sequence conservation of the peptide region.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	146	 This hypothesis is supported by previous work in which antibodies raised against a peptide sequence containing the 16L1 peptide reacted with HPV-16 VLPs but not with HPV-11 VLPs (Heino et al.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	147	 The 16L1 peptide is located within the structure of the h2 and h3 -helices of the C-terminal laterally projecting domain of L1 (Chen et al.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	148	 They form, together with the h4 helix, the surface of contact with other L1 monomers.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Consequently, this site is important for the assembly of viral capsids and is relatively conserved among different HPV types.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	150	 However, comparison of the corresponding sequences in the high- and low-risk types detected by the hybrid capture test used in this work showed interesting differences.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	151	 For instance, all five low-risk types differed at three or more amino acid positions from the 16L1 peptide sequence.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	152	 In contrast, only three of the 12 high-risk types differed at more than three amino acid positions from the 16L1 peptide.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Moreover, changes at positions 1, 5 or 8 were found in four of five low-risk types, while only four of 12 high-risk types had these changes.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	154	We also observed that a high proportion of patients with cervical cancer were positive for the presence of systemic IgG antibodies against the 16L1 peptide.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	155	 In an earlier study (Dillner et al.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	156	, 1990), IgG responses to peptides covering the complete amino acid sequence of the HPV-16 L1 protein were examined in sera from patients with cervical cancer.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Interestingly, a peptide region that included the 16L1 peptide sequence was demonstrated to be largely unreactive.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	158	 This divergence might be attributable to differences in the amino acid sequences.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	159	 (1990), the 16L1 peptide sequence was included as a part of a 20 amino acid peptide, which meant an extension of nine amino acids at the N terminus and one amino acid at the C terminus of the 16L1 peptide.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	160	 In this respect, there is evidence to indicate that recognition and binding of antibodies to a particular epitope are highly influenced by the extension of a peptide sequence.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	161	 In fact, extension of a single amino acid can induce a reduction in monoclonal antibody recognition of two to three orders of magnitude (Uray et al.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	162	, 2003), while an extension of 13 amino acids can result in complete loss of antibody binding (Calderon-Aranda et al.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Therefore, extensions of the 16L1 peptide might account for the lack of response observed in the former report.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	164	Interestingly, patients with high-risk HPV-associated invasive cervical cancer showed a reduced antibody response against the 16L1 peptide compared with high-risk HPV-associated LSIL.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	165	 In agreement with our results, previous studies have shown that IgG responses against different L1-derived peptides are significantly prevalent in patients with premalignant lesions (Sharma et al.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	166	, 1996), but are not associated with cervical cancer (Dillner et al.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	167	 Reduction of anti-peptide IgG responses in cervical cancer may be due to a natural decline in antibody titres that occurs over time in infected individuals (Andersson-Ellstrom et al.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	168	, 2000), or may be associated with a lack of antigen expression.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	169	 It is known that transcription of the L1 gene is restricted to terminally differentiated keratinocytes and that the level of cellular differentiation decreases as the grade of neoplasia increases (Stoler et al.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Consequently, the expression of the L1 protein is significantly reduced in advanced lesions associated with high-risk HPV genotypes (Melsheimer et al.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Furthermore, integration of HPV DNA in cervical cancer may cause disruption of the L1 gene (Walboomers  and  Meijer, 1997), affecting the expression of the L1 protein.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Indeed, integration of viral DNA occurs more frequently in HPV-18- than in HPV-16-associated tumours.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	173	 This is consistent with our observation that the prevalence of antibodies was lower in patients with HPV-18- than in patients with HPV-16-associated cervical cancer.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	174	In conclusion, our study indicates that the 16L1 peptide might be a high-risk type-common epitope capable of inducing cross-reactive antibodies in high-risk HPV-associated LSIL patients.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Importantly, antibodies in LSIL patients infected with low-risk HPV types did not react against the peptide, suggesting that the reaction was restricted to high-risk virus types.
0.172249.15302958.html.plaintext.txt	176	 Although more extensive studies to investigate antibody responses against the 16L1 peptide are still required, our primary results suggest that the 16L1 peptide might be useful for the development of serological assays for the study of natural and vaccine-induced immune responses against high-risk HPV, as well as for the early detection of oncogenic HPV infections.

0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	1	00 The Journal of Cell Biology, Volume 157, Number 7, June 24, 2002 1223-1232 Article.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	2	L1 endocytosis is controlled by a phosphorylation-dephosphorylation cycle stimulated by outside-in signaling by L1 Andrew W.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	3	 Schaefer1, Yoshimasa Kamei1, Hiroyuki Kamiguchi1, Eric V.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Wong1, Iris Rapoport6,7, Tomas Kirchhausen6,7, Carol M.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Beach5, Gary Landreth1, Sandra K.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	6	1 Department of Neurosciences, School of Medicine, Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, OH 44106 2 Department of Molecular Biology and Microbiology, School of Medicine, Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, OH 44106 3 Department of Ophthalmology, School of Medicine, Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, OH 44106 4 Cancer Center, School of Medicine, Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, OH 44106 5 Macromolecular Structural Analysis Facility, University of Kentucky, Lexington, KY 40536 6 Department of Cell Biology, Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA 02115 7 The Center for Blood Research, Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA 02115.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	7	Address correspondence to Vance Lemmon, Department of Neurosciences, Case Western Reserve University School of Medicine, Rm.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	8	Key Words: IGSF protein; cell adhesion; growth cones; endocytosis; tyrosine-based sorting motifs.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	9	The L1 cytoplasmic domain (L1CD)* is not required for adhesion, but it is needed for regulation of adhesion by signal transduction and internalization.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Interestingly, mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of the human L1 gene impair the formation of major axon tracts in neural development (for review see Kamiguchi et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	11	 One important function of the L1CD that has been analyzed in detail is the regulation of endocytosis, intracellular trafficking, and cell surface distribution of L1.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Neuronal L1 differs from L1 found in nonneuronal cells such as Schwann cells and neuroblastoma cell lines in that it contains four amino acids (RSLE) in the cytoplasmic domain encoded by the alternatively spliced exon 28 (Miura et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	13	 The RSLE stretch immediately follows tyrosine 1176.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	14	 The composite sequence (YRSLE) forms a tyrosine-based sorting motif that is required for endocytosis of L1 via clathrin-coated pits (Kamiguchi et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Like tyrosine-based sorting signals characterized in other proteins (Ohno et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	16	, 1996), the YRSLE sequence found in L1 serves as a binding site for the  micro2 chain of the clathrin-associated AP-2 complex in vitro, and a number of endocytic machinery components can be coimmunoprecipitated with L1.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Furthermore, mutating tyrosine 1176 (Y1176) or removing the RSLE exon also prevents L1 from interacting with AP-2, and consequently prevents clathrin-mediated endocytosis of L1 (Kamiguchi et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	18	 In dorsal root ganglion (DRG) neurons growing on an L1-Fc substrate, clathrin-mediated endocytosis of L1 occurs preferentially at the rear of growth cones, suggesting local regulation of L1 endocytosis and that its recycling may be important in growth cone motility (Kamiguchi and Lemmon, 2000).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Indeed, blocking AP-2 to mediated internalization of L1 inhibits L1-based neurite growth in part by disrupting a gradient of L1 adhesivity from the growth cone periphery to the central domain (Kamiguchi and Yoshihara, 2001).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Finally, the neuronal form of L1 (with YRSLE) is significantly less adhesive than the nonneuronal form due to its more rapid internalization and shorter dwell time on the cell surface (Long et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	21	Phosphorylation is likely to play a critical role in regulating L1-mediated processes such as neurite outgrowth (Atashi et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	22	 L1 is phosphorylated on both serine and tyrosine residues in cultured neurons, and clustering of L1 on cultured cells with cross-linking antibodies can trigger changes in both kinase and phosphatase activity (Klinz et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	23	, 1999), as well as in the phosphorylation state of L1 (Zisch et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Several kinase activities coimmunoprecipitate with L1.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	25	 We have identified three L1-associated kinases, CKII, p90rsk, and ERK2, that can phosphorylate certain serine residues in the L1CD in vitro (Wong et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Inhibition of p90rsk phosphorylation of L1 impairs DRG neurite outgrowth on L1 but not on laminin substrates.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Furthermore, activation of the MAP kinase cascade, which includes p90rsk and ERK2, requires L1 endocytosis.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Tyrosine kinases, such as p60src and FGF receptor, have also been implicated in L1 signaling (Ignelzi et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	29	, 1994; Doherty and Walsh, 1996), and the receptor tyrosine kinase, EphB2, is capable of phosphorylating L1 (Zisch et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Tyrosine phosphorylation may regulate associations between L1 and the cytoskeleton.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	31	 For example, both L1 and the L1 family members neurofascin and NrCAM associate with the membrane cytoskeleton protein ankyrin, and phosphorylation of a tyrosine within the ankyrin binding site of neurofascin, which is conserved in L1, disrupts this association (Tuvia et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	32	Here, we present evidence that outside-in signaling dynamically regulates the functional state of the L1CD via dephosphorylation.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	33	 We have characterized the mAb 74-5H7 that recognizes a subset of L1 at points of cell to cell contact and in vesicular structures.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	34	 The 74-5H7 epitope is regulated by phosphorylation of L1 and maps to the region immediately preceding the tyrosine-based sorting motif.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	35	 In vitro studies show that phosphorylation within the epitope prevents recognition by 74-5H7 and also binding of AP-2 to L1.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	36	 We have identified the nonreceptor tyrosine kinase p60src as an L1-phosphorylating kinase that preferentially phosphorylates Y1176 of the tyrosine-based sorting motif in vitro.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Cell to cell contact is able to induce changes in the phosphorylation state of L1 that is recognized by 74-5H7.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	38	 These data demonstrate that L1 to L1 binding induces a functional change in the L1CD mediated by a phosphorylation-dephosphorylation cycle.

0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	40	 74-5H7 recognizes a subpopulation of L1 localized to cell to cell contact sites and in growth cones.

0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	58	Characterization of the 74-5H7 epitope In principle, there are several possible explanations for the unique distribution of 74-5H7-IR, including a change in posttranslational modification such as phosphorylation, blocking of the epitope by protein to protein interactions, or conformational change.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Two lines of evidence suggest that phosphorylation is the most likely explanation.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	60	 First, 74-5H7 recognizes L1 by Western blot after fractionation by SDS-PAGE (Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Under these conditions, posttranslational modifications to the L1CD would be preserved, whereas global conformational changes or protein associations would be lost.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Second, bacterially produced, purified recombinant L1CD is recognized by 74-5H7 on Western blots (Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	63	 2 B), indicating that the 74-5H7 epitope is part of the primary structure of the L1CD, suggesting that the epitope is masked by posttranslational modifications of L1 in vivo.

0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	75	  To determine which region of the cytoplasmic domain contained the 74-5H7 epitope, we prepared a series of plasmid constructs containing sequences coding for L1 with various cytoplasmic domain truncations, expressed them in myeloma cells, and examined which ones preserved the 74-5H7 epitope.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Western blot analysis of extracts from myeloma cells expressing different L1 truncations shows that 74-5H7 recognizes full-length L1 and L1 truncated after Y1176, which leaves the first 33 amino acids of the L1CD intact (Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	77	 The mAb also recognizes the nonneuronal form of L1 that lacks the alternatively spliced exon 28 (amino acids 1177 to 1181; unpublished data).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	78	 In contrast, the 74-5H7 does not recognize L1 truncated after lysine 1147 that removes all but the first four amino acids of the cytoplasmic domain (Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	79	 These results suggest that the 74-5H7 epitope resides in the first 33 amino acids of the L1 cytoplasmic domain.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	80	A series of peptides was made to map the precise epitope recognized by 74-5H7.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	81	 First, we synthesized two peptides spanning the first 33 amino acids of the cytoplasmic domain and asked whether 74-5H7 recognized either on dot blots.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Our analysis indicates that 74-5H7 recognizes a 14 amino acid peptide, SEARPMKDETFGEY (residues 1163 to 1176; Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	83	 2 B), but not the peptide, KRSKGGKYSVKDKEDTQVDS (residues 1144 to 1163), consisting of the first 20 amino acids of the L1CD.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	84	 We then used synthetic peptides with alanine scanning substitutions through the 14 amino acid peptide to determine which residues are essential for recognition by 74-5H7.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	85	 This analysis identified five amino acids, SEARPMKDETFGEY (underlined) that when individually changed to alanine, abolish 74-5H7 binding (Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Although only these five amino acids were identified as critical for 74-5H7 binding, we were unable to detect binding to peptides shorter than the SEARPMKDETFGEY sequence, suggesting there may be structural contributions to the epitope from other residues (unpublished data).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	87	 The SEARPMKDETFGEY peptide also competed with purified L1 for 74-5H7 binding, confirming the importance of this sequence for mAb recognition of L1 (Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Thus the 74-5H7 epitope, which is present in L1 at points of cell to cell contact and in small vesicle-like structures, is positioned immediately NH2-terminal to the tyrosine-based sorting motif.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	89	 This motif (YRSL) is present in the neuronal form of L1 and is critical for regulation of L1 endocytosis (Kamiguchi et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	90	Phosphorylation of L1 peptides inhibits 74-5H7 binding The 14 amino acid peptide contains three potential phosphorylation sites, SEARPMKDETFGEY (underlined).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	91	 We synthesized peptides in which one of these residues was phosphorylated, and found that the peptide containing phosphorylated threonine 1172 was no longer recognized by 74-5H7.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	92	 In addition, 74-5H7 recognition of phosphorylated Y1176 peptide was reduced over 80%, although the peptide containing phosphoserine 1163 was strongly reactive (Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	93	 These results suggest that phosphorylation of one or both of these sites, threonine 1172 and Y1176, in L1 could be responsible for its inability to react with 74-5H7, and that the epitope may be transiently unmasked by dephosphorylation.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	94	 However, phosphothreonine has never been reported in L1 (for review see Schaefer et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	95	p60src phosphorylates the L1CD Although phosphorylation of both threonine 1172 and Y1176 disrupt the 74-5H7 epitope, phosphorylation of threonine residues in L1 has not been reported either in vitro or in vivo (Salton et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	96	 In contrast, at least two reports indicate that L1 is tyrosine phosphorylated in vivo (Heiland et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Therefore, we were interested in determining which kinase(s) can phosphorylate L1 on Y1176.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	98	 The nonreceptor tyrosine kinase p60src has been implicated in L1 function (Ignelzi et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Tyrosine phosphorylation of the CTLA-4 T-lymphocyte receptor endocytosis motif by src family kinases is implicated in regulation of its cell surface expression (Bradshaw et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	100	 To determine if L1 could be a substrate for p60src, we tested the ability of purified p60src to phosphorylate recombinant L1CD in vitro, and found that L1 is phosphorylated by this kinase (Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	101	 The phosphorylated L1CD was digested with endoproteinase Asp-N, and the resulting fragments were separated by reverse phase HPLC.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	102	 One major peptide, DETFGEYRSLES, was identified associated with radioactivity.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	103	 The site of phosphorylation of this peptide was determined to be the seventh residue by assessing the elution of radioactivity using covalent sequencing supports to allow tracking of the radiolabeled residue(s); this corresponds to Y1176.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Phosphorylated peptide fragments containing the other three tyrosines present within the L1CD did not coelute with radioactivity, indicating that p60src preferentially phosphorylates Y1176, an amino acid residue that plays a critical role in regulating L1 trafficking and endocytosis.

0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	112	  L1 Y1176 is phosphorylated in vivo The finding that 74-5H7 recognizes dephosphorylated L1, and the restricted distribution of 74-5H7-IR relative to total L1 IR, predicts that some neuronal L1 is phosphorylated on Y1176 in vivo.

0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	132	  Phosphorylation of L1 Y1176 inhibits L1 binding to AP-2 We have shown previously, using an in vitro peptide competition assay, that the peptide FGEYRSLESDNEE blocks binding of a biotin-labeled TGN38 peptide to AP-2 purified from rat brain (Kamiguchi et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	133	 This, and other data, showed that the YRSLE sequence mediates L1 binding to AP-2 (Kamiguchi et al.

0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	135	 To test this for L1, we compared the ability of phosphorylated and unphosphorylated L1 peptides to compete with a peptide spanning the TGN38 tyrosine-based sorting motif for binding to AP-2 (Fig.

0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	138	, 1996b), gave a peptide that retained its ability to block TGN38 binding to AP-2, demonstrating that CKII phosphorylation of L1 would not inhibit binding to AP-2.

0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	145	  74-5H7 binding to L1 is dynamically regulated by cell to cell contact, L1 to L1 homophilic interactions, and L1 cross-linking The results of immunocytochemical studies reported in Fig.

0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	189	 The cells were lysed after various times and the L1 was immunoprecipitated.

0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	191	 74-5H7-IR for L1 peaked at 5 min and returned to baseline levels by 30 min (Fig.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Together, these results indicate that the 74-5H7 epitope is dynamically regulated on cell surface L1, and that it can be induced by L1 to L1 homophilic binding and L1 cross-linking.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	193	View larger version (39K):    Figure 9.

0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	201	 The cells were extracted and L1-immunoprecipitated with protein A beads and the immunoprecipitates were analyzed by Western blot for 74-5H7-IR.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	202	The SEARPMKDETFGEY sequence, where 74-5H7 binds, is perfectly conserved in human, mouse, rat, chicken, and fugu fish L1 homologues.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Although the complete SEARPMKDETFGEY sequence is not conserved in other vertebrate L1 homologues, acidic residues NH2-terminal to Y1176 and a hydrophobic residue at the Y-3 position are conserved not just in direct L1 homologues, but also in the L1 family members Nr-CAM and neurofascin (Hortsch, 1996).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Previous data implicate p60 src in L1 function, because src-/- neurons extend poorly on L1 substrates, suggesting their response to L1 is impaired (Ignelzi et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Our finding that p60src can phosphorylate Y1176 provides potential mechanistic insight into this phenotype.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	206	 We suggest that L1 in src-/- neurons grown on L1 may be relatively hypophosphorylated at Y1176.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	207	 This could alter the regulation of L1 endocytosis; disruption of L1 trafficking could in turn impair neurite outgrowth on L1.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Suter and Forscher (2001) recently showed that p60src activity could be involved in a positive feedback loop strengthening CAM interactions with their cytoskeletal linkages.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Our data support a similar role for p60src in which it could phosphorylate L1 under certain conditions, thereby inhibiting internalization and increasing adhesion.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	210	The 74-5H7 epitope is adjacent to the tyrosine-based motif, Yxx ( is a bulky hydrophobic amino acid) in the L1CD that mediates L1 endocytosis (Kamiguchi et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Studies of tyrosine-based sorting motifs in other proteins indicate that the tyrosine has to be in a nonphosphorylated state for the signals to be active in sorting and endocytosis; i.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	212	, phosphorylation of the tyrosine prevents binding of adaptin proteins to the motif (Boll et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Indeed, our in vitro peptide competition experiments using peptides derived from L1 show that a Y1176-phosphorylated peptide corresponding to the potential p60src phosphorylation site, FGEpYRSLESDNEE, is no longer able to bind the  micro2 chain of AP-2, whereas a serine 1181-phosphorylated peptide corresponding to the CKII phosphorylation site, FGEYRSLEpSDNEE, retains its capacity to associate with  micro2.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	214	 It is highly unlikely that T1172 influences L1 to AP-2 interactions because there is no evidence suggesting it is phosphorylated, and extensive studies show that the fourth residue in the amino-terminal direction does not influence  micro2 binding to tyrosine-based sorting motifs (Boll et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	215	 Our results show that the 74-5H7-IR is inhibited by phosphorylation of Y1176 and that src family kinases may mediate this.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Similarly, clathrin-mediated endocytosis of the T lymphocyte receptor, CTLA-4, has been shown to be negatively regulated by phosphorylation of the critical tyrosine in the endocytosis motif (Bradshaw et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	217	, 1997) and this is likely by src family kinases (Miyatake et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Overall, our results imply that only L1 that can bind 74-5H7 is capable of interacting with the clathrin-mediated endocytic machinery.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	219	 This is consistent with the finding that in growth cones growing on L1 substrates, 74-5H7-IR is at the rear of growth cones, where L1 is internalized and colocalizes with Eps15, a marker for clathrin-coated pits (Kamiguchi et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	220	 We have shown previously that inhibition of L1 endocytosis dramatically increases L1-mediated adhesion (Long et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	221	 L1 at the rear of growth cones growing on L1 is less adhesive than L1 at the front of the growth cones, but this differential is not observed on growth cones growing on N-cadherin (Kamiguchi and Yoshihara, 2001).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Therefore, phosphorylation of Y1176 provides a rapid but reversible means of increasing L1-mediated adhesion.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	223	The hypothesis that the 74-5H7 epitope is regulated by phosphorylation/dephosphorylation implies the involvement of L1 phosphatases in its regulation and is consistent with early results that show that cross-linking L1 activates tyrosine and serine phosphatases (Klinz et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	224	 A number of potential candidate phosphatases exist.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	225	 These include phosphotyrosine phosphatases (PTPases) that prefer substrates containing acidic residues NH2-terminal to the phosphotyrosine such as PTP1B, and rat brain PTP1 (for review see Zhou and Cantley, 1995).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Another candidate is the receptor protein tyrosine phosphatase ss because of its ability to bind heterophilically with L1 family CAMs.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	227	 The phosphatase may also be coexpressed in some of the same cell types as L1 (Peles et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	228	 It has been suggested that acidic residues NH2-terminal to the phosphotyrosine residue are a hallmark for targeted dephosphorylation (Pinna and Ruzzene, 1996) and that the number, nature, and position of the acidic residues may create consensus sequences that are recognized selectively by individual PTPases (Pinna and Donella-Deana, 1994).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	229	The simplest interpretation of our biochemical analysis of the 74-5H7 epitope is that unengaged L1 is phosphorylated on Y1176, and that Y1176 becomes dephosphorylated subsequent to L1 ligand binding.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Dephosphorylation allows interaction with AP-2 and clathrin-mediated endocytosis.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	231	 In this paradigm, the time course of 74-5H7-IR observed in the cell pelleting experiments could reflect internalization and subsequent recycling (and rephosphorylation) of L1.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Our immunohistochemical observations of the distribution of 74-5H7-IR suggest the situation is more complex, however, and that L1 to L1 binding does not always induce L1 endocytosis.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	233	 First, L1 can mediate stable axon fasciculation, suggesting it is not invariably endocytosed at points of L1 to L1 binding.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Second, although growing DRG neurons on L1 increases L1 internalization and subsequent recycling (Kamiguchi and Lemmon, 2000; Kamiguchi and Yoshihara, 2001), endocytosis of L1 occurs preferentially at the rear of the growth cone.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	235	 74-5H7-IR is colocalized with vesicle-like structures in these neurons, rather than just at points of contact between the growth cone and the L1-Fc substrate (Kamiguchi et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	236	 These observations suggest that dephosphorylation of Y1176 and L1 endocytosis in growth cones are not regulated solely by L1 to L1 binding, but also by restricted localization of the dephosphorylation machinery.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	237	 We cannot rule out the possibility that, in vivo, the 74-5H7 epitope in some L1 is masked by interactions with other proteins, such as cytoskeletal components (Brophy, 2001).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	238	 Thus, although 74-5H7 clearly identifies a subset of L1 in cells that are dephosphorylated at Y1176, there may be other populations of L1 that are dephosphorylated at Y1176, but not accessible to the antibody and thus not visualized in immunocytochemical experiments.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	239	In summary, we have used 74-5H7 to show that L1 is dephosphorylated at Y1176 where L1 is internalized and trafficking in growth cones.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	240	 We have also shown that the phosphorylation state of Y1176 determines whether L1 can interact with the clathrin internalization machinery.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	241	 A variety of experiments showed that the phosphorylation/dephosphorylation state of L1 is regulated by cell contact and restricted to specific sites in neurons.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	242	 The phosphorylation of the L1CD on Y1176 by p60src that is important for L1-mediated neurite outgrowth raises the possibility that the regulation of L1 internalization by phosphorylation and dephosphorylation represents a critical regulatory point for L1.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	243	 The ability of L1 to L1 adhesion to influence its endocytosis is reminiscent of how other surfaces can influence integrin expression on neurites (Condic and Letourneau, 1997).
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	244	 In Aplysia, the distribution of apCAM, an IgSF CAM member, is acutely regulated by endocytosis during learning-induced synaptic remodeling (Bailey et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	245	, 1992), whereas in Drosophila, changing the distribution of another IgSF member, fasciclin II, alters synapse size (Schuster et al.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	246	 It appears that regulated endocytosis may be a general mechanism underlying CAM functions in dynamic processes such as cell migration, neurite outgrowth, and synaptic plasticity.

0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	253	 The brains were then broken up into small fragments by passing them through a 300- microm nylon mesh.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	254	 The fragments were incubated on ice in DME supplemented with 1 mM EDTA for 5 min, and then run through 50- microm nylon mesh.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	255	 The fragments were then pelleted by centrifugation, washed with DME/10% FCS, and pelleted again to remove the EDTA.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	256	 A single cell suspension was obtained by trituration with flame-polished Pasteur pipettes.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	257	 The cells were centrifuged through a DME/50% FCS cushion to remove cell fragments and vesicles.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	258	 Finally, the cells were resuspended in DME/10% FCS, counted, and plated in 15-cm tissue culture dishes in a tissue culture incubator (37 degrees C, 5% CO2) for 1 h.
0.175064.12082080.html.plaintext.txt	259	Cell pelleting and L1 cross-linking time course experiments The chick brain cells in suspension were transferred to 15 ml-conical tubes (5 x 106 cells in 5 ml), centrifuged in a clinical centrifuge for 30 s, and then replaced into the tissue culture incubator.

0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	1	1 CNRS UPR9051, Hopital Saint-Louis, Conventionne par l'Universite Paris 7, 1 avenue Claude Vellefaux, 75475 Paris Cedex 10, France 2 Laboratoire des Lyssavirus, Institut Pasteur, 25 rue du Dr Roux, 75724 Paris Cedex 15, France.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	2	* Author for correspondence (e-mail: alisaib{at}infobiogen.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	3	Key words: Retrovirus, Cytoskeleton, Trafficking, Spumavirus.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	4	Spumaviruses, also known as foamy viruses (FVs), are complex animal retroviruses that encode structural (Gag, Env), enzymatic (Pol) and regulatory products (Tas, Bet).
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Although surface Env glycoproteins are needed to enter target cells, interaction and subsequent self-multimerization of Gag molecules lead to capsid formation (Eastman and Linial, 2001; Tobaly-Tapiero et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Several functional regions were identified along the scaffold Gag protein.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	7	 There are three glycine(G)/arginine(R)-rich sequences, the so-called GR boxes, in the C-terminus that are implicated in viral nucleic acid binding and harbor a nuclear localization sequence (NLS) (Schliephake and Rethwilm, 1994; Yu et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	8	, 1996), a 18 amino acid motif (amino acids 43-60) resembling the cytoplasmic targeting and retention signal (CTRS) of type D retroviruses that allows cytoplasmic targeting of Gag (Eastman and Linial, 2001) and, finally, a coiled-coil domain (amino acids 130-160) that is necessary for Gag-Gag interaction (Tobaly-Tapiero et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	9	 The last two motifs are required for capsid assembly.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Although compelling studies have demonstrated the requirement for Gag in the late steps of infection (i.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	11	 packaging of genomic RNA or virus egress), little is known about its role during the early steps of virus cycle.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	12	We have previously shown that incoming human foamy virus (HFV), the prototype of FVs, targets the microtubule organizing center (MTOC) prior to nuclear translocation.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Centrosomal targeting of incoming viral proteins and subsequent viral replication were inhibited by a treatment with nocodazole, demonstrating the involvement of the MT network in FV replication (Saib et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	14	 However, the precise status of the viral material at the MTOC and the mechanism of transport towards this organelle were unknown.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Here, we show that incoming HFV reaches the MTOC as naked and structured capsids.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Remarkably, the Gag protein by itself harbors the determinant to target the MTOC, requiring a domain of 30 amino acids predicted to fold into a coiled coil.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Transport of Gag to the MTOC necessitates the retrograde, MT-dependent, dynein/dynactin motor because it is prevented by overexpression of the central coiled-coil domain (CC1) of p150Glued, the dynactin sidearm subunit.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Finally, a direct interaction between HFV Gag and the cytoplasmic light chain of the dynein LC8 was described, identifying a molecular basis of retroviral transport in infected cells during the early steps of infection.

0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	68	It has been recently shown that cytoplasm-replicating large DNA viruses such as poxviruses and African swine fever virus (ASFV), assemble in aggresomes (Heath et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	69	, 2001), a structure located close to the MTOC and generated in response to high levels of misfolded proteins (Johnston et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Aggresome formation induces a striking redistribution of the intermediate filament protein vimentin into a characteristic halo-like cage around aggregates of proteins (Kopito, 2000).
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	71	 To determine whether accumulation of Gag around the MTOC corresponded to the formation of an aggresome owing to a high level of Gag expression in transfected cells, Cos6 cells transfected with pSG-Gag were labeled with both anti-Gag and anti-vimentin antibodies.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	72	 As shown by fluorescence microscopy (Fig.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	73	 2, right), the vimentin network is not affected in Gag-expressing cells, demonstrating that accumulation of Gag around the MTOC does not lead to the formation of an aggresome.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	74	Mapping of the minimal Gag sequence involved in MTOC targeting Several functional domains have been already mapped along the HFV Gag protein.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	75	 To determine whether these domains (the C-terminal GR boxes and the two recently characterized N-terminal regions responsible for Gag self-assembly) are involved in MTOC targeting, the subcellular localization of a full-length GFP-Gag fusion protein and of deletion mutants was investigated (Fig.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Cos6 cells were transfected with these constructs and the GFP fluorescence was directly observed 20 hours after transfection, following cell fixation.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Although GFP alone diffusely localizes in both the cytoplasm and the nucleus of transfected cells, and never accumulates around the MTOC (data not shown), fusion of GFP to the full-length Gag targets the fusion protein to the centrosome (Fig.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Serial deletions of the C-terminus of Gag, up to residue 270 (mutant M1), do not impair MTOC targeting of the corresponding GFP-Gag fusions.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Deletion of amino acids 180-200 (mutant M3) or 200-250 (mutant M4) has no effect on MTOC targeting, whereas deletion of amino acids 165-180 (mutant M5) totally abolishes centrosomal targeting.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Finally, GFP-Gag150-250 (mutant M2) is present around this organelle.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Taken together, these results suggest that the domain implicated in MTOC targeting encompasses amino acids 150-180.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	82	 This conclusion is, however, clouded by the fact that the M6 mutant encoding for GFP-Gag1-201 is no longer detected at the centrosome.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	83	 To assess whether the absence of MTOC targeting of mutant M6 is due to inadequate positioning of the putative implicated domain regarding the entire fusion protein, the first 200 amino acids of Gag were fused to the N-terminus of GFP and transfected in Cos6 cells.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	84	 In that case, the fusion protein Gag1-200-GFP (mutant M7) was detected at the centrosome, suggesting that the domain involved in MTOC targeting must be flanked with minimal amino acid sequences at both sides to be functional.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Taken together, these results indicate that proper centrosomal targeting does not require the presence of the GR boxes or the domains involved in capsid assembly, but necessitates the sequence between amino acids 150 and 180.

0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	99	Dynein-dynactin is required for centrosomal targeting of Gag Retrograde movements along the MTs (minus-end-directed MT transport) require the dynein motor complex, which is assisted by the 20S dynactin cofactor (Karki and Holzbaur, 1999).
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	100	 The motor activity can be dislodged from the cargo by overexpression of p50/dynamitin, a component of the dynactin complex, disrupting their association (Burkhardt et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	101	 This approach is widely used to demonstrate the involvement of the dynein-dynactin complex in the movement of viruses (Alonso et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	102	 However, whereas dynamitin overexpression was reported to have no other effect on the cytoskeleton in HeLa cells (Burkhardt et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	103	, 1997), it might affect MT organization and centrosome integrity in Cos cells (Quintyne et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Interestingly, it has been shown that overexpression of the central coiled-coil domain (CC1) of p150Glued, the dynactin sidearm subunit, has a more specific inhibitory effect on dynein-based transport than does p50/dynamitin (Quintyne et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Thus, in our assays, HeLa cells and a CC1-expressing vector were used instead of Cos6 cells and p50/dynamitin.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	106	 4A, overexpression of DsRed-CC1 did not affect the MT network, confirming previous studies.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	107	 However, the presence of CC1 prevented MTOC targeting of Gag in co-transfected HeLa cells, whereas Gag was still associated with this organelle in cells transfected with empty DS-Red vector.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	108	 These observations demonstrate that targeting of Gag to the MTOC requires the dynein-dynactin retrograde motor.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	109	 In all these experiments, we only analysed cells that contained evenly distributed recombinant proteins, avoiding those (10% of the transfected cells) that harbored large protein aggregates already reported when using DsRed expressing vectors.

0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	118	HFV Gag directly interacts with the cytoplasmic light chain of dynein Cytoplasmic dynein is a large multisubunit motor complex that is composed of heavy, intermediate and light chains (Karki and Holzbaur, 1999).
