0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	143	Effect of the GagL171G mutation on the viral cycle Finally, to assess the biological role of the coiled-coil motif between amino acids 150 and 180 of HFV Gag in the virus cycle, a full-length viral clone harboring the L171G helix-breaking point mutation was constructed, and its behavior in tissue culture was compared with that of the parental infectious proviral clone.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Cos6 were transfected with the wild-type pHFV13, pHFVGagL171G harboring the L171G mutation in the Gag ORF, pSG-Gag or pCgp9 (a vector encoding for only HFV Gag and Pol viral proteins); 72 hours later, viral protein expression in transfected cells and virus production in culture supernatants were evaluated.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	145	 7, in cell extracts both proviral clones express similar levels of Gag molecules, which are detected as a doublet of 71 kDa and 68 kDa by polyclonal anti-Gag antibodies, demonstrating that the L171G point mutation has no effect on Gag expression, stability and maturation.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Indeed, the 71 kDa band corresponds to the full-length Gag precursor (p71), as visualized in pSG-Gag transfected cells, whereas the 68 kDa product represents its main cleavage product (p68), mirroring the presence of an active viral protease (Giron et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	147	 To assess whether the Gag mutation affected virus egress, supernatants from transfected cells were ultracentrifuged on a sucrose gradient and the resulting pellets, which contained extracellular virions were analysed by western blot using polyclonal anti-Gag antibodies.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	148	 In that case, no major difference was observed between pHFV13 and pHFVGagL171G, demonstrating that virus egress was not impaired by this helix-breaking point mutation in Gag.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	149	 No viral particles were produced from neither pSG-Gag- or pCgp9-transfected cells as expected because, in contrast to other retroviruses, FV particle formation requires the presence of the homologous envelope (Pietschmann et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	150	Finally, virus production in culture supernatants was evaluated following infection of an indicator cell line (the FAG cells), which harbor the GFP ORF under the control of the HFV LTR as already described (Tobaly-Tapiero et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Direct fluorescence observed 48 hours after infection reveals a significant virus production from pHFV13 transfected cells (9x104 FCFU ml to 1), whereas the Gag mutation dramatically reduced infectivity of the corresponding provirus but did not totally abolished it (6.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Values are averages of three independent experiments.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	153	Altogether, our data demonstrate that the L171G mutation in the Gag ORF has no effect on virus egress but drastically reduces infectivity of the corresponding proviral clone.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	154	By EM, we show here that incoming HFV proteins concentrate in the pericentrosomal region as free and structured capsids close to MTs.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	155	 More viral capsids surround the MTOC than expected from the multiplicity of infection used.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Indeed, most extracellular retroviral particles produced during an infection harbor a defective genome and are therefore unable to transactivate the viral LTR of GFP-indicator cells (Tobaly-Tapiero et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	157	 In the case of HIV-1, it has been reported that infectivity to particle ratio is as low as 1 in 60,000 (Kimpton and Emerman, 1992; Piatak et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	158	, 1993), whereas a more recent study softened this conclusion by showing a ratio up to 1 infectious particle in 10 (Andreadis et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Furthermore, we demonstrate that the determinants required to reach the pericentrosomal area are harbored by the scaffold component of viral capsids, the structural Gag protein, because this protein alone targets the centrosome in transfected cells in the absence of other viral partners.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	160	Because the vimentin network is not affected in Gag-transfected cells, accumulation of Gag around the MTOC does not trigger the formation of an aggresome.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	161	 However, similar to the formation of this inclusion body (Garcia-Mata et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	162	, 1999), Gag transport towards the MTOC involves the retrograde dynein-dynactin motor, because it is prevented by overproduction of CC1, the central coiled-coil domain of p150Glued, reported to disrupt the function of this retrograde motor.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Other viruses have been shown to use the MT network for their intracellular transport.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	164	 For instance, adenovirus type 2 (Ad2) and HSV, two nuclear replicative DNA viruses entering the cell through receptor-mediated endocytosis and direct membrane fusion respectively, are transported as naked capsids towards the nucleus via the MT network (Sodeik et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	165	 For ASFV and rabies viruses, two other viruses that use the MT network to move within the infected cell, an interaction with LC8 forms a molecular basis of this trafficking (Alonso et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	166	 The interaction between LC8 and HFV Gag described here could play such a role in the case of FVs.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	167	LC8 was first identified as an integral component of the Chlamydomonas reinhardtii outer dynein arm (Pfister et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	168	, 1982; Piperno and Luck, 1979).
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Since then, this evolutionarily conserved molecule has been shown to interact with many cellular complexes, such as the nitric oxide synthase (Jaffrey and Snyder, 1996) and myosin V (Goode et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	170	, 2000), an actin-based motor mainly located at the plasma membrane that shuttles between the cell periphery and the MTOC along the MT network (Espreafico et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	171	 LC8 is encoded by at least two genes in humans (Naisbitt et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	172	, 2000), leading to the synthesis of dynein light chain 2 (DLC2) and dynein light chain 1 (DLC1), the isoform used in our work.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Interestingly, myosin V has been shown to interact with DLC2 but not with DLC1 (Naisbitt et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Thus, migration of HFV capsids towards the centrosome on the microtubule network probably involves an interaction with dynein LC8 (DLC1) rather than myosin V LC8 (DLC2).
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	175	 In that sense, HFV efficiently targets the centrosomal region and replicates in myosin-V-deficient melanoma S91-6 cells (E.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	176	 However, we cannot exclude the possibility that HFV Gag also interacts with DLC2 as a component of myosin V, favoring its trafficking on actin beneath the plasma membrane devoid of microtubules.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Therefore, interaction between incoming FV capsids and the multifunctional LC8 could provide a bridge to shuttle between an actin-based motor beneath the plasma membrane and the MT network within the cytoplasm.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Remarkably, a similar MT- and dynein-dependent trafficking towards the centrosome was recently described for incoming HIV-1, although the viral and cellular protagonists involved in this retrograde transport were not determined (McDonald et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Nevertheless, these observations suggest that distinct classes of retroviruses might tether the dynein-dynactin complex motor on the MT network during the early stage of infection to reach the nucleus, opening new perspectives in the development of anti-retroviral drugs.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	180	Analysis of the subcellular distribution of Gag deletion mutants reveals that the GR boxes as well as the determinants involved in capsid assembly (the Gag-Gag interaction domain and the CTRS) are not required to target the centrosome, whereas amino acids 150-180 are necessary to reach this organelle.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	181	 This region does not harbor any obvious similarities with the two previously described LC8-interacting motifs, (K/R)XTQT and GIQVD (Lo et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	182	, 2001), but a coiled-coil motif conserved in all primate foamy viruses (Tobaly-Tapiero et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	183	, 2001) seems to be involved in centriolar targeting of Gag.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	184	 In that sense, a single point mutation (L171G) in the Gag ORF, leading to the disruption of the coiled-coil motif, abolishes MTOC targeting of the corresponding GFP-Gag fusion and renders a full-length viral clone non-infectious.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Indeed, whereas Gag assembly and virus release are not affected by this helix-breaking point mutation, productive infection of naive cells is dramatically reduced.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Because this mutation was shown to prevent Gag/LC8 interaction, tethering of the dynein retrograde motor following its entry into the cytoplasm might be impaired, a hypothesis that we are currently exploring.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	187	 The L171G point mutation does not totally abolish infectivity, suggesting that other trafficking pathways might be used by FVs to reach the center of the cell.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	188	 In that sense, intracellular trafficking involving the actin cytoskeleton might account for this observation, an alternative route already put forward for HIV-1 (McDonald et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	189	, 2002) and previously suggested for FVs because Gag was also shown to interact with actin (Giron et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	190	HFV Gag is not the unique partner of LC8 lacking the two characterized LC8-interacting motifs.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Interestingly, all these proteins harbor an -helical coiled-coil in the domain identified as the LC8-binding region.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	192	 For example, the LC8-interacting domain of myosin V is predicted to fold into an amphiphilic helix (Naisbitt et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	193	, 2000) and, similarly, the signal response domain of IB, which was shown to interact with LC8 (Crepieux et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	194	, 1997), folds into a coiled coil as revealed by the COILS program (data not shown).
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Such a hypothesis might also apply to the neuronal form of nitric oxide synthase (nNOS) (Benashski et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	196	 Given that LC8 harbors a similar amphiphilic helix triggering its multimerization (Benashski et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	197	, 1997), interactions between LC8 and myosin V, IB, nNOS and HFV Gag might occur via such specific protein motif interface, constituting a new mode of contact with LC8.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	198	One remaining issue is how the viral genome, wrapped by Gag molecules, is imported into the nucleus.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Interestingly, the dynein-dynactin complex has recently been shown to associate with the nuclear envelope, facilitating the remodeling of this physical frontier (Busson et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Therefore, interaction of Gag with the dynein-dynactin complex could not only drive incoming viral capsids towards the centrosome but also be involved in their subsequent targeting to the nuclear envelope.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Yet, HFV capsids were never detected within the nucleus, nor close to nuclear pores, even later during the replication cycle [here and Fischer et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	202	, 1998)], whereas unassembled Gag proteins and the viral genome are detected in the nucleus early after infection (Saib et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	203	, 1997; Schliephake and Rethwilm, 1994).
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Therefore, in contrast to Ad2 or HSV, those capsids dock to the nuclear pore triggering nuclear translocation of the viral genome (Greber et al.
0.1763323.12857789.html.plaintext.txt	205	, 2001), nuclear import of HFV Gag and genome must be accompanied by disassembly or significant deformation of the core particle at the MTOC.

0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	0	Structure of L-A Virus: A Specialized Compartment for the Transcription and Replication of Double-stranded RNA.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	1	The genomes of double-stranded (ds)RNA viruses are never exposed to the cytoplasm but are confined to and replicated from a specialized protein-bound compartmentthe viral capsid.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	2	 We have used cryoelectron microscopy and three-dimensional image reconstruction to study this compartment in the case of L-A, a yeast virus whose capsid consists of 60 asymmetric dimers of Gag protein (76 kD).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	3	 At 16-A resolution, we distinguish multiple domains in the elongated Gag subunits, whose nonequivalent packing is reflected in subtly different morphologies of the two protomers.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Small holes, 10-15 A across, perforate the capsid wall, which functions as a molecular sieve, allowing the exit of transcripts and the influx of metabolites, while retaining dsRNA and excluding degradative enzymes.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Scanning transmission electron microscope measurements of mass-per-unit length suggest that L-A RNA is an A-form duplex, and that RNA filaments emanating from disrupted virions often consist of two or more closely associated duplexes.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Nuclease protection experiments confirm that the genome is entirely sequestered inside full capsids, but it is packed relatively loosely; in L-A, the center-to-center spacing between duplexes is 40-45 A, compared with 25-30 A in other double-stranded viruses.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	7	 The looser packing of L-A RNA allows for maneuverability in the crowded capsid interior, in which the genome (in both replication and transcription) must be translocated sequentially past the polymerase immobilized on the inner capsid wall.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	8	IN eukaryotic and prokaryotic cells alike, the medium in which genetic information is stored is double-stranded (ds)1 DNA.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	9	 From this repository, genes are copied in the same medium (replication) or into different media (transcription and translation).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Viruses, more limited but less constrained genetic entities than cells, exhibit greater diversity in their replication cycles.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	11	 All four alternative media, single-stranded (ss)RNA, ssDNA, dsDNA, and dsRNA, are used by different virus families to encode their genomes (for review see Roizman and Palese, 1996).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Whereas dsDNA and ssRNA molecules are abundant cellular components, dsRNA and ssDNA molecules are not.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	13	 In these circumstances, one might expect viruses of the latter kinds to have developed special strategies for interfacing with the metabolic resources of their host cells.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	14	One such strategy that is widespread if not universal among dsRNA viruses is their use of capsids as specialized cytoplasmic compartments that genomes are confined to, and are replicated and expressed from (Dryden et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Such capsids are selectively porous protein shells that the genome and replicase reside within, nucleotides infuse into, and nascent strands (positive sense) are extruded from.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	16	The present study addresses the capsid structure and the organization of encapsidated RNA in the L-A virus of yeast, an excellent model system because of its relative simplicity and well-known molecular biology.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	17	6-kbp, single-segment molecule that encodes a major capsid protein (Gag; 680 residues, 76 kD) and a minor capsid protein.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	18	 The latter molecule is a fusion of Gag with Pol, the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (Pol; 868 residues, 100 kD) (Fujimura and Wickner, 1988a; Icho and Wickner, 1989) that is generated by ribosomal frameshifting (Dinman et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The L-A capsid is a spherical particle, ~430 A in diam, composed of 120 copies of Gag (Esteban and Wickner, 1986; Cheng et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	20	, 1994), of which approximately two carry the Pol moiety (Dinman and Wickner, 1992; Ribas, J.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Its surface lattice has the unusual property of being composed of 60 asymmetric dimers (Cheng et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	22	, 1994), configured as an otherwise conventional icosahedron of triangulation class T = 1 (Caspar and Klug, 1962).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Interestingly, 120-subunit capsids have been detected in several other dsRNA viruses, including bacteriophage 6 (Mindich and Bamford, 1988), reovirus (Dryden et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	24	, 1993), orbivirus (Burroughs et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	25	, 1995), aquareovirus (Shaw et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	26	, 1996), and rotavirus (Estes, 1996), but thus far, in no other kind of virus.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	27	Motivated by the expanding generality of this unusual capsid stoichiometry and architecture and the prospect of gaining insight into the features that commend it as a compartment for the sequestration and replication of dsRNA, we have pursued further cryoelectron microscopic studies of the L-A capsid, extending the resolution to 16 A.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Using these data, we have also examined the structural organization of the viral genome, both in the encapsidated state and as released from virions.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Complementary information was obtained by using dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) (Wall and Hainfeld, 1986; Thomas et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	30	, 1994) to measure the mass per unit length of L-A chromosomes extruding directly from capsids, and after isolation.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	31	Materials and Methods Virus Particle Preparation.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	32	L-A virus was extracted from stationary phase cells of Saccharomyces cerevisiae strain TF229 [MATa His(3,4) Leu2 ski2-2 L-A-HN] grown in 1 liter of rich medium, and purified by CsCl equilibrium gradient centrifugation as described (Fujimura and Wickner, 1988b), except that 12.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	33	5 ml CsCl gradients were run at 157,000 g (44,000 rpm in a Beckman NVT65 rotor; Beckman Instruments, Inc.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	34	, Fullerton, CA) for 15 h at 4 degrees C.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	35	 The virus-containing fractions were dialyzed against buffer A (50 mM Tris HCl, 150 mM NaCl, 5 mM EDTA, 1 mM DTT, pH 7.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	36	8) for 6 h, and stored at ~20 mg/ml at 4 degrees C.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	37	 All samples were used within 7 d of purification, as L-A virions tend to lose their dsRNA upon protracted storage.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	38	Virions to be examined by cryoelectron microscopy were dialyzed against buffer A for 8-12 h to remove CsCl.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	39	 They were then diluted in buffer A until (when examined by negative staining) a uniform, dense but not continuous, distribution of particles was observed.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	40	 5- microl drops of virus at this concentration (typically, 2-5 mg/ml) were applied to holey carbon films on 400 mesh copper grids, and observed by cryoelectron microscopy, essentially as described (Booy et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Micrographs were recorded under minimal exposure conditions at nominal magnifications of  x 36,000 or  x 46,000 (~8 e/A2) on Kodak SO-163 films, using an electron microscope (EM400RT; Philips Technologies, Eindhoven, The Netherlands) equipped with modified Gatan anticontaminator blades and a Gatan 626 cryoholder (Gatan, Warrendale, PA).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	42	 In some experiments, bacteriophage T4 was mixed with L-A, and the 40.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	43	5-A axial spacing of its tail-sheath (Moody and Makowski, 1981) was used as an internal magnification standard.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Micrographs were assessed for resolution and stigmation by optical diffraction of large areas, and their defocus values estimated from the positions of the first zero of the contrast transfer function (CTF).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	45	 For the micrographs chosen for analysis, the first zero was in the range of (15 A)1-(27 A)1 (Table I).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Underfocus values () were calculated according to  = 1/k2 , where  is the wavelength of the 100 keV electrons (0.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	47	037 A), and k is the spatial frequency of the first zero (Lepault and Leonard, 1985).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Spectra calculated from powder patterns of genome-revealing difference images of L-A virions.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	49	 The positions and spread of the peaks in these spectra give statistically representative estimates of the predominant spacings between RNA filaments packed in L-A virus capsids.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Because the shape of a spectrum depends on the defocus of the micrographs from which it was calculated, this analysis was repeated for micrographs covering a range of defocus values.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	51	 In each case, difference images were calculated as shown in Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	52	 4, their diffraction patterns calculated and azimuthally averaged, and the powder pattern obtained by summing over many such particles.

0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	54	 The closest-to-focus spectrum is at top, and the furthest-from-focus one is at bottom (Table I).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Each spectrum shows a broad peak in the range of (47 A)1 to (31 A)1 (gray vertical band).

0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	73	Micrographs were digitized on a Perkin Elmer 1010MG microdensitometer (Norwalk, CT) at 12- microm intervals ( x 36,000 negatives) or 16- microm intervals ( x 46,000 negatives), corresponding to 3.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	74	 General image processing operations were carried out using the PIC Software system (Trus et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	75	, 1996), running on Alpha workstations (Digital Equipment Co.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Particles were extracted and preprocessed using the automated procedure of Conway et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Particle orientations were determined by means of the Polar Fourier Transform algorithm, an iterative, model-based procedure (Baker and Cheng, 1996).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	78	 As a starting model, we used our earlier 26A resolution three-dimensional (3-D) map of empty L-A particles (Cheng et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	79	 In all micrographs analyzed, reconstructions of empty and full particles were calculated separately, using Fourier-Bessel techniques (Crowther, 1971; Fuller, 1987; Baker et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Complete icosahedral (532) symmetry was imposed on the final density map.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	81	 The contour level imposed for surface rendering was based on 100% of expected volume, assuming a protein density of 1.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Resolution of the three-dimensional maps was estimated in terms of a Fourier shell correlation procedure (Saxton and Baumeister, 1982; Conway et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	83	, 1993), and was, in each case, very close to the first zero of the CTF.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Data quality was also assessed by eigenvalue spectra (Fuller et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	85	To obtain a distribution of particle orientations that uniformly cover the asymmetric unit (Baker et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	86	, 1989), data from three micrographs were combined.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	87	 All three micrographs were well stigmated and had first zeros at ~(15 A)1.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Three independent reconstructions were first calculated and mutually scaled to the same magnification and density by matching their spherically averaged radial density profiles (Booy et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	89	 A composite reconstruction including  > 80 particles (Table I) was then calculated, the orientation and alignment parameters of each particle refined, and a final map calculated.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	90	 The resolution was 16 A by the above criterion.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	91	To visualize the internal contents of full particles, we first calculated reconstructions from micrographs recorded at several different defocus values.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	92	 The contribution of the capsid shell to each such image was obtained by reprojecting the three-dimensional map in the corresponding orientation, after setting the internal densities to background (solvent) level.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Finally, the projected capsid shell was subtracted from the raw image (Baker et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	94	, 1991), thus providing an unobstructed view of the encapsidated dsRNA.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	95	 As a control, the same procedure was applied to images of empty particles.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Diffraction patterns were calculated for all difference images in each data set.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	97	 These were then added together with equal weighting (combining empty and full particles separately), and azimuthally averaged to obtain the respective one-dimensional powder patterns.

0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	109	 RNase III has an exclusive specificity for dsRNA (Crouch, 1974), and under our conditions, is active only in the presence of 10 mM MgCl2.

0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Empty particles are clearly distinguished from full ones, and almost all capsids appear intact (see below).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	120	 We observed a small percentage of a distinctive polymorphic variant, the "dimeric" capsid (e.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	121	 1 d, large arrowhead), it seems to be a fusion of two capsids, both lacking one icosahedral cap.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Whether they arise from pairing of two partially dissociated capsids or are simply aberrant assembly products is not known.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Filamentous material, presumably RNA released from virions, is usually visible (e.

0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	177	The empty capsid has an essentially identical structure, particularly on the outer surface (data not shown).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	178	 On the inner surface, the match between full and empty capsids is less perfect, but such differences are slight.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Of these, the most prominent are thin arms of density near the twofold axes on the full capsid (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	180	 2 b, right, white arrows) that connect the protein to the underlying genome-associated density.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	181	 These features imply that there is likely to be close contact between the RNA and the capsid wall at these sites, but (by comparison) not elsewhere.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	182	Unlike the impression given at 26-A resolution (Cheng et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	183	, 1994), the capsid wall is seen to be quite porous, perforated with many small holes (Figs.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	184	 There are five classes of holes: those at the fivefold axes (area = ~107 A2); those surrounding the fivefold axes (~165 A2); those on the threefold axes (~118 A2); relatively large Y-shaped holes surrounding the threefold axes (~244 A2); and oblong holes between the A- and B-subunits (~110 A2).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	185	In these maps, the capsids' interiors are icosahedrally symmetric; although there is no reason to suppose that the material in these regions actually conforms to this symmetry, which was imposed by the reconstruction procedure.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	186	 In the empty capsid, internal density is (as expected) at the same level as the solvent outside.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	187	 In the full capsid map, the internal density gives the impression of three concentric shells 35-40 A apart (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	188	 We do not interpret this to mean that the viral RNA is strictly confined to three spherical shells.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Rather, because the micrographs contain a strong signal at these spacings, arising from the distances between nearest-neighbor RNA filaments, the icosahedral density map calculated from them also contains strong features at the same spacings.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	190	 The density of these shells diminishes progressively towards the center, which is probably a valid indication that proportionately more RNA resides at higher radii.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	191	Structures and Interactions of the Nonequivalent A- and B-Subunits.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	192	The A- and B-subunits are very similar in morphology.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	193	 On the outer capsid surface, each subunit is shaped like a boomerang and subdivides into three domains, called A1, A2, A3, and B1, B2, B3, respectively (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	194	 On the inner surface, the two kinds of subunit are less alike, although both present a Y-shaped motif (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	195	 This motif is clearly visible in the spherical sections at inner radii shown in Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	196	 3 a (especially bottom row, third from left).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	197	 In the middle of the capsid wall is a hollow cavity (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	198	 2 b) that separates the inner and outer surface domains.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Within a given penton (Gag decamer), neighboring A- and B-subunits can be aligned by a rotation of ~15 degrees  (see Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	200	 3 e, left), whence we conclude that they are oriented in parallel.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	201	 3 e, right) supports this conclusion.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	202	The internal features of the Gag subunits are conveniently viewed in spherical sections through the density map (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	203	 The protomer should be a Gag dimer.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	204	 In principle, there are three possible pairings of neighboring A- and B-subunits.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	205	 The pairing in which subunits interact across the twofold axis (A3 to B3) involves only a small contact surface.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Consequently, we favor the two more compact arrangements (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	207	 3 d, bottom), in which there are more extensive interactions to stabilize the dimer.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	208	From the spherical sections (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	209	 3 a), we can discern likely boundaries between subunits, and the pattern of interactions that consolidates the surface lattice.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	210	 A-subunits cluster around the fivefold axis via A1-A1 interactions.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	211	 The corresponding region of the B-subunit (B1) makes contacts with A1 and A2, further out from the fivefold axis.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Three B3 domains meet around the threefold axis, whereas across the twofold axis, the contacts are head- to-head between A3 and B3.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Interactions between twofold and threefold axes take place deep in the lattice, from radii at ~184 to 197 A (whereas the protein shell extends from radii 171 to 217 A) via arclike densities (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	214	The thin arms of density linking the capsid with the underlying RNA (see above) are also visualized in the Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	215	 3 a (bottom, far right) for the twofold axes, and they extend from A-subunits.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	216	Packing of dsRNA Inside the L-A Capsid.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	217	The protein shell, accounting for ~73% of the virion mass, tends to dominate images of full particles, in which it is coprojected with the RNA.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	218	 To obtain unimpeded views of encapsidated genomes, we erased the shell contributions from virion images, computationally (Booy et al.

0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	220	 To estimate the interstrand spacings, we measured the positions of diffraction peaks in powder patterns calculated from many such images (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Because phase-contrast imaging accentuates particular spatial frequencies, depending on the defocus, this analysis was performed for micrographs that cover a range of defocus values.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	222	 All of these patterns exhibited broad peaks extending from ~(31 A)1 to ~(47 A)1.

0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	224	 As a control, the same procedure was applied to empty capsids.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	225	 5, dashes) has a small peak in this range, this probably reflects noise amplified by the phase-contrast at this defocus value.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	226	 It is, however, much weaker than the corresponding peak of the full particle powder pattern, confirming that this peak primarily reflects scattering from the RNA.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	227	Resistance of Encapsidated RNA to RNase Digestion.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	228	The interstrand spacings measured above are considerably larger than the values obtained for other dsDNA and dsRNA viruses (Lepault et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Accordingly, one might wonder whether their RNA is partly extruded, with a concomitant loosening up of the portion remaining inside the capsid.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	230	 The presence of empty capsids and free RNA in electron micrographs is consistent with such a hypothesis.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	231	 To test it, we conducted accessibility experiments with RNase III, a nuclease specific for dsRNA.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	232	 The genomes of freshly prepared virions proved entirely resistant to the enzyme (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	233	 6); whereas in a positive control, isolated L-A RNA was extensively digested (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	234	 When virions were preincubated in a low salt buffer, (known to destabilize them) (Esteban and Wickner, 1986), their RNA partially degraded (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	235	 These results imply that the dsRNA is entirely sequestered inside freshly prepared virions.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	236	 This conclusion is consistent with earlier STEM mass measurements that yielded masses for full L-A virions consistent with their containing whole genomes (Cheng et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	237	 RNA is gradually lost on storage, but release from any given particle, once started, appears to proceed quite rapidly.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	238	 The conclusion that the L-A genome is indeed packed more loosely than in other viruses is supported by calculations of packing density (see Discussion).

0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	270	 [View Larger Version of this Image (86K GIF file)].
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	271	The replication cycles of all known dsRNA viruses follow the same pattern (Roizman and Palese, 1996).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	272	 First, dsRNA is transcribed by a polymerase resident within the virion.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	273	 Next, (+) strand transcripts are extruded to serve as (a) mRNA for the synthesis of viral proteins, (b) the species that becomes encapsidated in progeny virions, and (c) used as the template for synthesis of complementary () strands in replication.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	274	 Both transcription and replication take place inside the nucleocapsid, which is the complete virion for fungal dsRNA viruses or an inner core for higher eukaryotic viruses like those of the Reoviridae family (e.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	275	, 1993]; rotavirus [Mansell and Patton, 1990; Labbe et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	276	, 1991]; and orbivirus [Huismans et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	277	 This model also applies to the prokaryotic dsRNA virus, bacteriophage 6 (Mindich and Bamford, 1988).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	278	 What features do these various transcription-cum-replication chambers have in common?.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	279	As noted in the Introduction, stoichiometry data indicate that many dsRNA virus capsids contain 120 copies of at least one protein.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	280	 So far, no other kind of virus capsid has this stoichiometry, which corresponds to the "forbidden" T-number of two (Caspar and Klug, 1962).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	281	 It is of interest to know whether this commonality extends to more detailed aspects of capsid architecture.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	282	 Here, fewer data are available, but we note a definite morphological similarity between L-A capsid and the core of Bluetongue virus (Hewat et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	283	, 1992); this virus is also composed of 120 subunits (Burroughs et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	284	 Aquareovirus cores also show 120 morphological subunits on their surface (Shaw et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	285	 Although reovirus cores are more complex than the L-A capsid, the presence of Y-shaped domains on their inner surface (Dryden et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	286	 Birnaviruses, whose genomes consist of two segments of dsRNA, seem to be an exception since they are single-shelled T=13 particles with no internal core (Bottcher et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	287	Capsid Structure and Control of Assembly.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	288	Our current three-dimensional map at 16-A resolution depicts the 76-kD Gag monomer as an elongated molecule with multiple domains coiled around a central cavity.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	289	 The structural differences seen between the nonequivalent A- and B-subunits are minor, but their bonding environments are entirely different (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	290	 As shown by expression studies (Fujimura et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	291	, 1992), Gag can selfassemble into correctly sized capsids.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	292	 This reaction should be controlled by some switching event that specifies the A and B conformations (Johnson, 1996).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	293	 This switch may operate at the level of dimer formation, yielding protomers of which 60 equivalent copies would then self-assemble into a conventional T = 1 icosahedron.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	294	 The plausibility of this model is supported indirectly by observations in other systems (e.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	295	, the human growth hormone receptor [de Vos et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	296	, 1992]), which attest that an asymmetric homodimer can be a stable state of assembly.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	297	 Alternatively, A-subunits might associate into homo-pentamers, with the switch accompanying the accretion of B-subunits to convert them into decamers capable of forming the capsid pentons.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	298	 The fact that Gag-Pol appears to nucleate assembly of L-A in vivo (Fujimura and Wickner, 1988b), and there are only 1-2 copies of this protein per capsid, argues against the pentamer-based model.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	299	Mass-per-unit-length Measurements Suggest that L-A dsRNA Is A-form.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	300	Our STEM data on the mass-per-unit length of purified L-A dsRNA yield a mean value of 2.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	301	 Acknowledging the spread in these data, they suggest an A-type duplex2.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	302	81 A rise per base pair (Arnott et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	303	, 1972) and 682 D/ bpand are less consistent with a B-form duplex2.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	304	 It has been previously demonstrated by spectroscopy that packaged 6 dsRNA has an A-form structure (Bamford et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	305	 However, x-ray diffraction studies of crystallized reovirus dsRNA (for review see Nibert et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	306	, 1996) were indicative of a double helix with 10 or 11 bp per turn and a 3-A pitch, this corresponds to a structure intermediate between A-form (2.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	307	81-A rise per bp) and B-form (3.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	308	The L-A Capsid as a Molecular Sieve.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	309	One striking feature revealed by our capsid model is its porosity; the capsid wall is perforated by many small holes.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	310	 While their sizes may be revised somewhat when higher resolution data become available, current estimates suggest a strategically useful property.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	311	 None of these holes is large enough to pass an A-form duplex (~23-A diam), but the largest holes (triangular, average distance from apex to base ~15 A; Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	312	 3 e) should readily allow passage of an ssRNA molecule.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	313	 Thus the capsid appears to be configured to function as a molecular sieve: duplex RNA is retained inside, but transcripts may exit.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	314	 It would be expedient for freshly synthesized transcript to be fed directly into an exit port (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	315	 8), as this would forestall formation of secondary structure that might impede export.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	316	 Since there are only one to two copies of Pol per capsid, presumably no more than two transcripts per capsid are being exported at any one time.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	317	 However, the other holes should facilitate the infusion of nucleotides, of which a steady supply is required to sustain synthesis during transcription or replication.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	318	 A further filtering property is that the holes are presumably small enough to exclude potentially degradative enzymes.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	319	 Hypothetical model of a transcriptionally active L-A virion.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	320	 The polymerase (Pol) is covalently attached to a Gag subunit, which we assume to be integrated into the icosahedral surface lattice, thus immobilizing Pol (Icho and Wickner, 1989).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	321	 Pol (and the COOH terminus of Gag) are assumed to reside on the inner surface of the shell, to facilitate access to the substrate dsRNA.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	322	 The shape assigned to Pol in this diagram is arbitrary.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	323	 In this scenario, it is necessary for the genome to be propelled sequentially past Pol as transcription proceeds.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	324	 Transcripts are hypothesized to be extruded directly through the largest holes in the capsid shell (Discussion).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	325	 [View Larger Version of this Image (159K GIF file)].
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	326	Unusually Low Density of dsRNA Packing in L-A.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	327	In projection, encapsidated L-A genomes exhibit punctate and/or swirl motifs (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	328	 Presumably, these two classes of motifs represent distinct views, although it is not clear that the genome is packed in the same way in each particle.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	329	 We infer that the genomes are loosely coiled, with variable spacing between adjacent filaments.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	330	 5) have average Bragg spacings of 36-40 A, corresponding to a center-to-center spacing of 41-46 A between filaments.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	331	 The L-A motifs differ from those of dsDNA viruses such as phages T4 and  (Lepault et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	332	, 1992) and herpes simplex virus (Booy et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	333	, 1991), and other dsRNA viruses such as reovirus (Dryden et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	334	, 1993); these are relatively highly ordered and tightly packed, with center-to-center spacings of 25-30 A.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	335	 In part, the larger spacing in L-A reflects the fact that A-form duplexes are wider than B-form duplexes.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	336	 However, the average interduplex spacing may be calculated independently from the volume available (average internal capsid diam = 348 A) and genome length (1.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	337	 Assuming quasi-hexagonal close packing to a uniform density, a spacing of ~40 A is obtained.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	338	 There is some flexibility in this figure, arising from the center being less populated with RNA, the packing not being perfectly crystalline, and possibly also from some local compaction into multistranded filaments (see below).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	339	 Nevertheless, this figure is in good agreement with the spacings measured directly from the powder patterns (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	340	 Its consistency supports our inferences that (a) the dsRNA genome is fully internalized, and (b) its packing is much looser than in other double-stranded viruses.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	341	RNA extending from capsids often has a uniform mass-per-unit length that is significantly higher than for a single A-form duplex (Fig.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	342	 7), and appears to represent some sort of higher order filament formed by two or more duplexes.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	343	 We have not observed these thicker filaments in preparations of isolated dsRNA, and see no obvious way in which they might arise as an artifact of specimen preparation.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	344	 It may be that within the confines of the capsid, i.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	345	, under conditions of high packing density, some piecewise condensation of duplexes into higher order filaments takes place.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	346	, at much lower density, the RNA gradually relaxes to single duplexes.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	347	Headful Replication and the Churning Model of Transcription.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	348	L-A is also a helper virus for other dsRNA segments in Saccharomyces cerevisiae (Wickner, 1996a).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	349	 These satellite viruses (M1, M2, etc.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	350	) and deletion mutants of L-A itself (such as X) contain more dsRNA segments than L-A, but approximately the same number of base pairs per particle.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	351	 This occurs by "headful replication," whereby one viral (+) strand is packaged, and replicates inside the particle until it is full.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	352	 Subsequently synthesized (+) strands are extruded from the particle (Esteban and Wickner, 1986; Fujimura et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	353	 As noted above, much more room remains available in the packaged L-A capsid than in other double-stranded viruses.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	354	 We can think of two explanations.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	355	 In one, the Gag gene has evolved recently to provide a more capacious capsid, but the genome as a whole has not yet evolved to fully exploit this opportunity for expansion.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	356	 The fact that the multisegmented satellites do not package RNA more densely than L-A appears to argue against this hypothesis.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	357	In the second explanation, we speculate that the maximum viable packing density may be dictated by a requirement for long range mobility of the dsRNA in this transcriptionally active particle.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	358	 The polymerase is thought to reside on the inner surface, anchored by integration of its Gag moiety into the surface lattice (Wickner, 1996a,b).
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	359	 8), large tracts of dsRNA must be propelled sequentially past this fixed point.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	360	 In so doing, the organization of the entire packaged genome must undergo constant revision, or "churning" motion.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	361	 (In contrast, the tightly compressed genomes of dsDNA phages are thought to be in a static vegetative state.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	362	) RNA polymerases are known to be powerful translocases, capable of generating forces in the range of 14 piconewtons (Yin et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	363	 The ability of L-A Pol to function in replication and transcription depends on its being capable of overcoming the frictional drag imposed by the packaged genome.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	364	 We infer that this resistance increases with higher packing density, whence the observed packing density may represent the highest level of frictional resistance against which the enzyme can function effectively.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	365	 This idea is testable by generating insertions in the L-A genome.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	366	Is a similar mechanism operative in other dsRNA viruses? The consideration that dsRNA appears to be packed more densely in the cores of both reovirus (Dryden et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	367	, 1993) and rotavirus (Prasad et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	368	, 1996) than in L-A might suggest otherwise.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	369	 However, these systems, in which transcriptionally active particles have been visualized (Yeager, M.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	370	, 1997), are considerably more complex; more proteins and many more RNA segments are involved, and precisely calibrated spacings for their packaged genomes have yet to be reported.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	371	 Transcription of reovirions is thought to require "activation" by proteases, and concomitant conformational changes (Powell et al.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	372	, 1993), which, we conjecture, may rearrange the core structure, so as to facilitate motion of the dsRNA during transcription.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	373	 Nevertheless, the same overall requirements apply.
0.17798969.9281577.html.plaintext.txt	374	 It will be fascinating to learn more about possible solutions to this problem, and the properties of protein shells that are not only closed containers but also active metabolic compartments.

0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	0	Characterization of Cyclin L2, a Novel Cyclin with an Arginine/Serine-rich Domain PHOSPHORYLATION BY DYRK1A AND COLOCALIZATION WITH SPLICING FACTORS* Katrin de Graaf, Paul Hekerman, Oliver Spelten, Andreas Herrmann, Len C.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Packman , Konrad Bussow||, Gerhard Muller-Newen, and Walter Becker**.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	2	From the Institut fur Pharmakologie und Toxikologie, Medizinische Fakultat der RWTH Aachen, Wendlingweg 2, 52074 Aachen, Germany, Institut fur Biochemie, Medizinische Fakultat der RWTH Aachen, Pauwelstrasse 30, 52074 Aachen, Germany, the  Department of Biochemistry, University of Cambridge, 80 Tennis Court Road, Cambridge CB2 1GA, United Kingdom, and ||Max-Planck-Institut fur Molekulare Genetik, Heubnerweg 6, 14059 Berlin, Germany.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	3	Received for publication, October 1, 2003 , and in revised form, November 14, 2003.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	4	In recent years, several transcription factors have been identified as substrates of DYRK1A (for a review, see Ref.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Particularly, overexpression of DYRK1A has been shown to modulate the transactivation potential of FKHR (forkhead in rhabdomyosarcoma) (10, 11), cAMP-response element-binding protein (12), and GLI1 (13).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Cytoplasmic proteins like eukaryotic initiation factor 2B, tau (14), and dynamin (15) have also been reported to be phosphorylated by DYRK1A, but these proteins might equally well be targets of the cytoplasmic kinases DYRK2 or DYRK3.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	7	 However, although DYRK1A contains a canonical nuclear localization signal and is indeed predominantly targeted to the nucleus (16, 17), a significant fraction of the kinase is also present in the cytoplasm (18).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Within the nucleus, DYRK1A is localized in "nuclear speckles," which represent the splicing factor compartment (17, 19).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	9	 The precise function of DYRK1A in the nucleus is still largely unknown, and it is an open question whether any of the known substrates of DYRK1A is a key mediator of its functions on cell differentiation and proliferation.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	10	 We have therefore performed a more extensive search for interacting proteins and substrates to address this problem.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	11	Several methods have been employed to identify novel substrates of protein kinases.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Routine interaction screens like the yeast two-hybrid system, phage display, and phage expression library screening, yield in many cases substrates of kinases (20 to 23).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Other approaches are based on the specificity of substrate recognition by kinases and aim to identify substrate proteins by searching data bases with experimentally determined or predicted consensus phosphorylation sequences (24, 25).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	14	 More direct strategies include the phosphorylation screening of phage expression libraries (26) or of cell lysates (27), and the identification of phosphoproteins by functional proteomics and mass spectrometry (28).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	15	Here we have employed a new method which allowed us to screen in parallel for interaction partners and substrates of the kinase DYRK1A.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	16	 In this approach, we used an arrayed protein expression library (29, 30) both for interaction screening by overlaying with the radiolabeled recombinant kinase (31), and for a substrate screen by solid phase phosphorylation (26).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	17	 The use of the filter array allowed us to directly identify positive clones without the need of further rounds of purification.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Several DYRK1A-interacting and/or phosphorylated proteins were identified by this approach, and one protein was found in both screens.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	19	 This protein turned out to be a novel member of the cyclin family and was designated cyclin L2.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	20	Here we characterize cyclin L2 as a novel substrate of DYRK1A.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Furthermore, we describe the alternative transcripts generated from the cyclin L2 gene and show that full-length cyclin L2, but not the truncated splicing variant cyclin L2S, is co-localized with the splicing factor SC35 in nuclear speckles.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Using photobleaching techniques, we demonstrate that cyclin L2 and the closely related isoform, cyclin L1, differ strikingly with regard to their intranuclear mobility.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	23	Probe Labeling for Overlay Assays The probe for the interaction screen, GST-DYRK1A-C-K188R, was expressed from the pGEX-2TK vector (GenBankTM accession number U13851 [GenBank] ), which allows labeling of the fusion protein on a vector-encoded phosphorylation site by cAMP-dependent protein kinase.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	24	 The C-terminally truncated mutant of DYRK1A was used as a probe in order to avoid potential nonspecific binding of the repeat structures in the C-terminal domain of DYRK1A (32).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	25	 The kinase-negative point mutant (K188R) of DYRK1A should exhibit enhanced enzyme-substrate interactions.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	26	 For labeling, 20 to 25  microg of GST-DYRK1A-C-K188R bound to glutathione S-Sepharose beads (Amersham Biosciences) were incubated in a volume of 110  microl with 10 units of cAMP-dependent protein kinase (New England Biolabs) in 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	27	5, 10 mM MgCl2, 6 mg/ml dithiothreitol for 30 min at 4  degrees C in the presence of 45  microCi of [-32P]ATP (3000 Ci/mmol).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	28	 The reaction was stopped by adding 10 mM EDTA to a final concentration of 2 mM.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	29	 The Sepharose beads were then washed seven times with 500  microl of ice-cold PBST (137 mM NaCl, 2.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	30	5% (w/v) Triton X-100) in order to remove free [-32P]ATP.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	31	 The labeled protein was then eluted for 10 min on ice in 500  microl of glutathione elution buffer (10 mM reduced glutathione in 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	32	 The typical yield of this reaction was about 15  microCi of incorporated 32P in the eluted protein.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	33	Interaction Screening by DYRK1A Overlay In order to allow refolding of denatured proteins (33), the filter array or nitrocellulose membranes with electroblotted proteins were first incubated for 1 h at room temperature in 6 M guanidinium HCl, 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	34	3, 50 mM dithiothreitol, 2 mM EDTA and then rinsed with TBS, followed by an overnight incubation at 4  degrees C in 150 mM NaCl, 10 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	35	 To reduce false positive signals due to binding of GST, the membrane was blocked by incubation in interaction buffer (0.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	36	5% BSA, 75 mM KCl, 20 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	37	5 mM MgCl2, 1 mM dithiothreitol, 0.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	38	05% Nonidet P-40) containing 1  microg/ microl GST for 1 h at room temperature.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	39	 The membrane was then incubated with 6 x 104 cpm/ml of 32P-labeled GST-DYRK1A-C-K188R in interaction buffer for 18 h at 4  degrees C.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	40	 After washing three times for 10 min each at room temperature with interaction buffer, the membrane was dried and subjected to autoradiography.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	41	Substrate Screening by Solid Phase Phosphorylation The filter with the expression array or polyvinylidene fluoride membranes with electroblotted proteins were preincubated in kinase buffer (25 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	42	5 mM dithiothreitol, 5 mM MgCl2, 5 mM MnCl2), 100 mM NaCl, 3% BSA containing 3  microM cold ATP for 1 h at room temperature to mask proteins with autophosphorylating and/or ATP-binding activities (26).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	43	 The solid phase phosphorylation was done by incubation with 0.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	44	2 units/ml GST-DYRK1A-C in kinase buffer containing 3  microM [-32P]ATP (5  microCi/ml) for 45 min at room temperature.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	45	 This construct has been shown to have the same substrate specificity but higher activity than the full-length kinase when produced in Escherichia coli (34).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	46	 One unit of protein kinase activity was that amount that catalyzed the phosphorylation of 1 nmol of DYRKtide, the standard synthetic peptide substrate (34), in 1 min in kinase buffer containing 100  microM ATP and 200  microM DYRKtide.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	47	 After phosphorylation, the membrane was washed twice with 30 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	48	4, once with 30 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	49	05% Nonidet P-40, twice with 30 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	50	4, without Nonidet P-40, once with 1 M HCl, and again twice with 30 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.

0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	161	Photobleaching Analysis Photobleaching experiments were essentially performed as described (40).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Briefly, living COS-7 cells were analyzed 48 h after transfection with pEGFP-CycL1 or pEGFP-CycL2.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	163	 GFP was excited by the 488-nm line of the argon laser, and emission was detected using a 505 to 550-nm band path filter.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	164	 For fluorescence recovery after photobleaching (FRAP) analysis, the region of interest (nuclear speckle) was bleached using the 488-nm laser at 100% intensity, and pictures were taken over a 10-min period of observation.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	165	 For quantitative FRAP analysis, the optical slice was set to 1  microm, and bleaching was performed with 35 iterations.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	166	 The fluorescence intensity was measured every second within a region of 1  microm in diameter.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	167	 For fluorescence loss in photobleaching (FLIP) analysis, a region of 1  microm in diameter of the nucleoplasm, but distinct from nuclear speckles, was bleached consecutively using the 488-nm laser at 100% intensity.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Pictures were taken over a 5-min period.

0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	196	Phosphorylation of Splicing Factors by DYRK1A Three clones encoding proteins with RS domains were identified both as DYRK1A-interacting proteins and as substrates of the kinase (Table I); clone M24584 codes for the splicing factor SRp75, and N16596 and P23533 [GenBank] both contain partial cDNA coding for an RS domain-containing protein that we designated cyclin L2 (see below).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	197	 A total of four proteins with RS domains were identified (SFRS4, cyclin L2, SFRS5, and SWAP2) as in vitro substrates of DYRK1A, suggesting that DYRK1A may be involved in splicing catalysis.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	198	 We therefore performed in vitro kinase assays to compare the phosphorylation of RS domain-containing proteins by DYRK1A.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	199	 In addition to the proteins identified in the present screen, two additional RS domain-containing proteins (hTRA21 and SF2/ASF) and a well characterized in vitro substrate of DYRK1A (myelin basic protein) (34) were included in this experiment.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	200	 2, cyclin L2 and hTRA21 were phosphorylated with markedly higher intensities than the other RS proteins.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Thus, DYRK1A does not indiscriminately phosphorylate serine residues in the context of RS domains.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	202	 In the present study, we concentrated on the characterization of cyclin L2 and its interaction with DYRK1A, because this protein was independently identified in both screens and because cyclin L2 was an excellent substrate of DYRK1A (see below; Fig.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	203	Structure of Cyclin L2 The amino acid sequence derived from the cDNA clones N16596 and P23533 [GenBank] definitely encodes an RS domain (21 RS dipeptide motifs within 141 amino acids; Fig.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	204	 3A) but shows no extended sequence similarity with any other RS domain-containing protein.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	205	 By a data base search, we identified an uncharacterized full-length mRNA sequence corresponding to these partial cDNAs (GenBankTM accession number AY037150 [GenBank] ).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	206	 The deduced protein encoded by this cDNA exhibits high sequence similarity with cyclin L1 (HUGO gene symbol CCNL1), a recently characterized protein with an N-terminal cyclin domain and a C-terminal RS domain (Fig.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Therefore, we designated the protein encoded by AY037150 [GenBank] cyclin L2 (HUGO gene symbol CCNL2).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	208	 The mouse homologues of cyclin L1 and cyclin L2 have previously been named Ania-6a and Ania-6b, respectively (41).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	209	 The cyclin domain of cyclin L2 (amino acids 69 to 296, as indicated in Fig.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	210	 3A) was defined by comparison with cyclin H, which has been modeled by Andersen et al.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	211	 The cyclin domains of cyclin L1 and L2 are most closely related with cyclin K (HUGO gene symbol CCNK; 33% identical amino acids) and cyclin T1/T2 (HUGO gene symbols CCNT1 and CCNT2; 30 and 32% identical amino acids).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	212	 The RS domains of cyclin L1 and L2 contain 45% identical amino acids, a range that was also found for RS domains of known splicing factors.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	213	Genomic Organization of CCNL2 The human CCNL2 gene is located on chromosome 1 (1p36.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	214	 The gene spans about 13 kb and comprises 11 exons (Fig.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	215	 The comparison of the genomic sequence with public expressed sequence tag sequences allowed us to deduce the existence of three different transcripts, T1 to T3 (Fig.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	216	 The different transcripts are generated by alternative splicing of exon 6a and by the use of alternative polyadenylation sites within exon 6a.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	217	 Inclusion of exon 6a introduces a stop codon, and therefore transcripts T1 and T3 encode a truncated version of cyclin L2 that lacks the RS domain (cyclin L2S, "s" represents "short," Fig.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Because exon 6a is skipped in transcript T2, the resulting mRNA (AY037150 [GenBank] ) encodes the long version of the protein, which is named cyclin L2 and includes the RS domain.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	219	Alternatively Spliced Transcripts of CCNL2 and CCNL1  We performed Northern blot analyses with exon-specific hybridization probes (Fig.

0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	272	Localization of Cyclin L1 and Cyclin L2 to the Nuclear Speckle Compartment Many splicing factors with RS domains are localized in subnuclear structures called nuclear speckles (44).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	273	 Therefore, we generated GFP fusion constructs of cyclin L2, cyclin L2S, and cyclin L1 in order to study the subcellular localization of these proteins by fluorescence microscopy.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	274	 5, the fluorescent signal of both GFP-CycL1 and GFP-CycL2 appeared as discrete, punctate staining within the nucleus.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	275	 Moreover, these structures were co-stained by an antibody directed against the splicing factor SC-35, a well characterized marker protein for the splicing factor compartment (45).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	276	 Interestingly, cells overexpressing GFP-CycL1 consistently exhibited an altered appearance of the SC-35 containing speckles compared with untransfected cells.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	277	 Nuclei of transfected cells contained a higher number of speckles, which were of smaller size (Fig.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	278	 Overexpression of GFPCycL2 did not significantly affect the pattern of speckles (Fig.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	279	 In contrast to GFP-CycL2, GFP-CycL2S, which lacks the RS domain, was evenly distributed to both cytoplasm and nucleus, as previously observed for the short splice variant of cyclin L1 (41).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	280	 No speckled appearance of GFP-CycL2S was observed in the nucleus.

0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	285	  Cyclin L2 in Nuclear Speckles Is a Highly Mobile Protein  Nuclear speckles are considered to be storage compartments from which proteins involved in RNA transcription and processing are constantly recruited to sites of active RNA synthesis (44, 46).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	286	 We used FRAP to analyze the mobility of GFP-CycL1 and GFP-CycL2 in living COS-7 cells.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	287	 After bleaching of GFP fluorescence in a single nuclear speckle, recovery of fluorescence over time was monitored by live cell imaging.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	288	 For GFPCycL2, recovery of fluorescence was observed within 20 to 60 s after bleaching (Fig.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	289	 6A), indicating that the protein in the speckles is highly mobile and rapidly exchanges with unbleached GFP-CycL2 molecules in the nucleus.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	290	 Quantitative analysis showed that the recovery of fluorescence was fast (initial t of 3 to 5 s) but incomplete (Fig.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	291	 This result shows that GFP-CycL2 in nuclear speckles consists of a highly mobile and an immobile fraction.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	292	 In striking contrast, no recovery of fluorescence was observed after bleaching of GFP-CycL1 (Fig.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	293	 Even 10 min after bleaching, no recovery was detected in 14 of 15 cells monitored (data not shown).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	294	 This result indicates that GFP-CycL1 is an immobile component of the nuclear speckles.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	295	View larger version (72K):    FIG.

0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	303	  To confirm that GFP-CycL1 and GFP-CycL2 indeed differed in their intranuclear mobility, we performed FLIP analysis of both proteins in living COS-7 cells.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	304	 Repetitive bleaching of a small area of the nucleus (1  microm) free of nuclear speckles significantly reduced the total nuclear GFP fluorescence of GFPCycL2 expressing cells, indicating that a substantial fraction of the protein has moved through the area subjected to bleaching within the period of 60 s (Fig.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	305	 In contrast, GFP-CycL1 fluorescence was affected exclusively in the bleaching area itself but remained unchanged in the remaining volume of the nucleus.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	306	 Consistent with the FRAP data, this result indicates that cyclin L1 does not freely diffuse within the nucleus.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	307	Mapping the Binding Domain for Cyclin L2 To identify the domain responsible for the interaction of DYRK1A and cyclin L2, we performed pull-down experiments with deletion mutants of DYRK1A (Fig.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	308	 GST-DYRK1A-C, the construct used for interaction screening, lacks the noncatalytic C-terminal domain.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	309	 GST-DYRK1A-CN expresses only the catalytic domain and GST-DYRK1A-NT contains only the N terminus and a small part of the catalytic domain (Fig.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	310	 The serine/arginine-rich splicing factor, SF2 (also called ASF or SRp30a), was used for comparison, because it is known that several splicing factors bind to each other by heterodimerization of their RS domains (47).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	311	View larger version (29K):    FIG.

0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	314	 After washing five times, proteins retained on the Sepharose and 5% of the input (GFP-CycL2-N-containing lysate) were resolved by SDS-PAGE followed by immunoblotting (WB) using a GFP-specific antibody (upper panel).

0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	317	 DYRK1A-NT has a calculated size of 44 kDa, indicating that most of the protein is truncated.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	318	 The baits used are schematically shown in the right panel.

0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	320	 7, similar amounts of GFP-CycL2N were pulled down by SF2 and by DYRK1A-C.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	321	 This result indicates that the C-terminal part of cyclin L2 can interact comparably well with other RS domain-containing proteins and with the protein kinase DYRK1A.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	322	 Cyclin L2 bound also to the related kinase, DYRK2.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	323	 Notably, sequence similarity between DYRK2 and DYRK1A is limited to the catalytic domain and a short segment immediately N-terminal of the catalytic domain that we earlier designated the "DYRK homology box" (DH box) (48).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	324	 The DH box contains a large number of negative charges (35) and may thus bind the RS domain of cyclin L2 by ionic interactions.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	325	 Both DYRK1A-NC, which lacks the DH box, and the N-terminal domain alone bound cyclin L2 only very weakly.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	326	 Taken together, these results suggest that optimal binding of cyclin L2 to DYRK1A (or DYRK2) requires the presence of both the catalytic domain and the DH box.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	327	Interaction of Cyclin L2 with PITSLREp110 Cyclin L1 has been reported to associate with the p110 isoform of PITSLRE (PITSLREp110), an orphan cyclin-dependent kinase (41, 39) (official gene symbol CDC2L1).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	328	 Because of the high sequence similarity of the cyclin domains of cyclin L1 and cyclin L2, we tested whether cyclin L2 also interacted with PITSLREp110 (Fig.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	329	 In co-immunoprecipitation experiments with GFP fusion proteins of cyclin L1, cyclin L2, and cyclin L2S, we observed that PITSLREp110 co-precipitated with cyclin L2, although less efficiently than with cyclin L1.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	330	 Neither cyclin L2S nor an unrelated control protein (the non-RS-splicing factor SF3B1) bound detectably to PITSLREp110.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	331	View larger version (70K):    FIG.

0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	335	 The p110 band of PITSLRE is marked by an arrow.

0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	337	  Identification of in Vitro Phosphorylation Sites Our finding that different arginine/serine-rich splicing factors were not equally well phosphorylated by DYRK1A (Fig.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	338	 2) raises the question of which sites in cyclin L2 are targeted by DYRK1A.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	339	 Bacterially expressed His6-cyclin L2 was phosphorylated by DYRK1A in vitro and subjected to SDS-PAGE.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	340	 9, two slower migrating bands appeared after phosphorylation of cyclin L2 by DYRK1A.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	341	 The three bands were individually analyzed for phosphorylated amino acids by mass spectroscopy in comparison with unphosphorylated cyclin L2.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	342	 Three phosphoserines were identified in the slower migrating bands (Fig.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	343	 9; Ser-330, Ser-338, and Ser-369).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	344	 All of these serine residues are located N-terminal of proline residues, consistent with our previous classification of DYRK1A as a "proline-directed" kinase.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	345	 It should be noted that other phosphorylation sites may have escaped detection, since the predicted size of the tryptic fragments from the RS domain would have been too small to successfully purify and analyze by the present methodology.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	346	View larger version (26K):    FIG.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	347	 Phosphorylation of cyclin L2 by DYRK1A in vitro.
