0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	349	 The three bands were cut, and the indicated phosphorylation sites in each single band were determined by mass spectrometry of tryptic peptides.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	350	 The amino acid sequences surrounding the three phosphorylated sites are shown.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	351	  In Vivo Phosphorylation of Cyclin L2 To analyze whether cyclin L2 is a phosphoprotein in vivo, COS-7 cells transfected with GFP constructs of cyclin L2 alone or with co-transfected DYRK1A, respectively, were incubated with 32P-labeled phosphate.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	352	 CLK3 was compared with DYRK1A, because kinases of the CLK family are known to phosphorylate RS domains of arginine/serine-rich splicing factors (49).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	353	 10A, immunoprecipitated cyclin L2 was in fact a phosphoprotein when expressed in mammalian cells.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	354	 Coexpression of DYRK1A or CLK3 did not detectably alter the level of phosphate incorporation, possibly because cyclin L2 was already strongly phosphorylated by endogenous protein kinases.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	355	 However, a more slowly migrating form of GFP-CycL2 was observed in the immunoprecipitates from DYRK1A-overexpressing cells.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	356	 This band was also detected when total cellular lysates of DYRK1A-expressing COS-7 cells were directly analyzed by Western blotting (Fig.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	357	 10B) but not after transfection of a kinase-negative point mutant of DYRK1A (DYRK1A-K188R).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	358	 This result strongly suggests that cyclin L2 is directly phosphorylated by DYRK1A in living cells.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	359	View larger version (34K):    FIG.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	360	 Phosphorylation of cyclin L2 by DYRK1A in vivo.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	361	 COS-7 cells were co-transfected with 1.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	362	5  microg of plasmids encoding GFP-CycL2 and either GFP, GFP-DYRK1A, GFP-DYRK1A-K188R, or GFP-CLK3 as indicated above the lanes.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	363	 A, cells were incubated with radioactive H3PO4 for 2.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	364	5 h, and GFP fusion proteins were immunoprecipitated under denaturing conditions with GFP antiserum.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	365	 Phosphorylation was detected by autoradiography.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	366	 B, total cellular lysates were subjected to Western blot (WB) analysis with a GFP-specific antibody.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	367	 Two differently exposed films of the same blot are shown to visualize the shifted band of GFP-CycL2 (upper panel) or the detection of DYRK1A and DYRK1A-K188R (lower panel).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	368	Cyclin L2 and the closely related isoform, cyclin L1 (originally named cyclin L (39)) differ from all other members of the cyclin family by the presence of a C-terminal RS domain.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	369	 This unusual domain structure is conserved in the homologous proteins from invertebrates and plants (Drosophila, Caenorhabditis, and Arabidopsis (41)), providing evidence for a conserved function of the RS domain in these proteins.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	370	 The RS domain is a hallmark of many proteins involved in pre-mRNA processing, including the serine/arginine-rich splicing factors (SR proteins), which contain at least one RNA-binding motif, and the SR protein-related polypeptides (50, 51, 47, 52).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	371	 SR protein-related polypeptides constitute an inhomogeneous family of proteins that contain the RS domain in combination with additional domains (e.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	372	 the protein kinase domains in CLK1-CLK4 and CrkRS/CRK7 or the DEAD/H box in RNA helicases) (47, 52).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	373	 The modular domain architecture of cyclin L1 and L2 is thus a typical feature of SR protein-related proteins, although unusual for members of the cyclin family.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	374	RS domains mediate protein-protein interactions with other proteins that contain RS repeats, and they target proteins to the nuclear speckle compartment (50).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	375	 Here we show that cyclin L2 interacts with the alternative splicing factor SF2/ASF (Fig.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	376	 7) and is co-localized with the SR protein SC35 in nuclear speckles (Fig.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	377	 This subcellular distribution is very likely mediated by the RS domain, since a construct of cyclin L2 that lacked the major part of the cyclin domain (cyclin L21 to 222) exhibited a subnuclear distribution indistinguishable from that of the full-length construct (data not shown).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	378	 In contrast, cyclin L2S, which lacks the RS domain, was distributed both in the nucleus and in the cytoplasm (Fig.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	379	 Cyclin L1 was also found to be co-localized with SC35, as previously shown by Berke et al.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	380	 However, cyclin L1 and cyclin L2 differed strikingly in regard to their intranuclear mobility.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	381	Photobleaching experiments showed that a significant fraction of GFP-CycL2 in nuclear speckles was rapidly exchanged by unbleached molecules within the nucleus (FRAP analysis; Fig.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	382	 Moreover, FLIP analysis showed that a considerable portion of nuclear GFP-CycL2 transits a given small region of the nucleus within a time period of 60 s (Fig.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	383	 6B), indicating that the protein diffuses freely in the nucleoplasm when not associated with speckles.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	384	 In contrast, GFP-CycL1 was found immobile in both FRAP and FLIP analysis.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	385	 To our knowledge, the observation that GFP-CycL1 is an immobile component of nuclear speckles is unprecedented in the analysis of proteins with RS domains (for a review, see Ref.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	386	 The different mobilities of cyclin L1 and cyclin L2 indicate that the proteins have different functions despite their highly similar structures.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	387	 Presently, we can only speculate on the reason for the different mobilities of cyclin L1 and cyclin L2.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	388	 The fact that cyclin L1 was co-immunoprecipitated with PITSLREp110 argues against the possibility that the GFP fusion protein is grossly misfolded in the cell.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	389	 Instead, the association of cyclin L1 with its cyclin dependent kinase, PITSLREp110, may constrain the mobility of cyclin L1, whereas the association of cyclin L2 and PITSLREp110 appears weaker (Fig.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	390	Altogether, the presence of the RS domain, the interaction with SF2/ASF, and the localization in the nuclear speckle compartment suggest a role of cyclin L2 in the regulation of RNA splicing.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	391	 Cyclin L1 has previously been reported to stimulate an in vitro splicing reaction (39).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	392	 Notably, however, speckles have also been shown to contain proteins other than splicing factors, including 3'-end mRNA-processing factors, the cyclin T1-CDK9 complex, and the hyperphosphorylated form of RNA polymerase II (53 to 55).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	393	 Thus, a function of cyclin L2 in the control of transcription or another step of pre-mRNA processing cannot be excluded.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	394	Based on sequence comparisons of the cyclin box, cyclin L2 belongs to a group of cyclins involved in transcriptional regulation, comprising cyclins H, K, T1, and T2 (Fig.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	395	View larger version (10K):    FIG.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	396	 Relationship of cyclin L2 with other members of the cyclin family.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	397	 The dendrogram was constructed from an alignment of the cyclin (Cyc) domains with the help of the Clustal program (66).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	398	 The branch of transcriptional cyclins is highlighted by boldface type.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	399	 Data base (Swiss-Prot) accession numbers are as follows: cyclin K, O75909 [GenBank] ; cyclin T1, O60563 [GenBank] ; cyclin T2, O60583 [GenBank] ; cyclin H, P51946 [GenBank] ; cyclin A1, P78396 [GenBank] ; cyclin B1, P14635 [GenBank] ; cyclin D1, P24385 [GenBank] ; cyclin E1, P24864 [GenBank] .
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	400	  These cyclins, in association with the corresponding cyclin-dependent kinases, are components of the basal transcription factor TFIIH (cyclin H-CDK7) or the transcriptional elongation factor P-TEFb that phosphorylates the C-terminal domain of the large subunit of RNA polymerase II (cyclin T-CDK9 and cyclin K-CDK9) (56).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	401	 The present data show that cyclin L2 binds in vivo to the cyclin-dependent kinase PITSLREp110, as previously also demonstrated for cyclin L1 (41, 39).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	402	 PITSLRE (also named CDK11 (57) or Cdc2-like 1 (official gene symbol CDC2L1)) exists in more than 20 splicing variants (58).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	403	 PITSLREp110 isoforms are localized in the nucleus and are co-localized in nuclear speckles with the splicing protein RNPS1 (59).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	404	 Here we show that cyclin L2 is co-localized with SC35 in the splicing factor compartment, supporting the hypothesis that cyclin L2 and PITSLREp110 are associated in vivo.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	405	 Recent reports provide evidence that PITSLRE participates in a signaling pathway that coordinates transcription and RNA processing events (57, 60).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	406	 It should be noted that in our coimmunoprecipitation experiments (Fig.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	407	 8), cyclin L2 did not interact as strongly with PITSLREp110 as it did with cyclin L1, and we cannot exclude the possibility that related kinases such as CDK10/PISSLRE or CDK7 may act as the catalytically active partner of cyclin L2.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	408	Interestingly, we have identified a short variant of cyclin L2 (cyclin L2S) that lacks the RS domain and part of the cyclin box.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	409	 Sequence comparisons of the human gene for cyclin L2 (CCNL2) and its transcripts allowed us to deduce the alternatively spliced transcripts for the long and the short variant (Fig.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	410	 The exon/intron structure of the gene for cyclin L1 (CCNL1) is nearly identical to that of CCNL2, and CCNL1 results in the same alternative splicing variants coding for full-length cyclin L1 and a short isoform of cyclin L1 (cyclin L1S, designated Ania-6a25 by Berke et al.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	411	 By Northern blot analysis with exon-specific probes, we could unambiguously identify the larger transcripts of about 4.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	412	 4A) as the mRNA for the short polypeptides (cyclin L1S and L2S).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	413	 This result is in agreement with the analysis of the murine cyclin L1 transcripts by Berke et al.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	414	 (41) and improves the characterization of the human CCNL1 gene and its transcripts performed by Dickinson et al.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	415	The alternative splicing variants of cyclin L1 and L2 are differentially expressed in human tissues (Fig.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	416	 In most tissues, the mRNA levels for full-length cyclin L1 (T2) were comparable with or higher than those for cyclin L1S.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	417	 In contrast, the mRNA for full-length cyclin L2 was detected mainly in testis, whereas the short variant, cyclin L2S, was nearly ubiquitously expressed.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	418	 Furthermore, we found that the transcripts of CCNL1 and CCNL2 were differentially regulated by extracellular stimuli; phorbol ester and cycloheximide specifically induced the mRNA for full-length cyclin L1 in human RT112 keratinocytes, whereas levels of the cyclin L2 transcripts were only weakly affected by cycloheximide and not at all by phorbol ester.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	419	2 These results are in accordance with a more extensive analysis of cyclin L1 expression in rat neurons by Berke et al.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	420	 (41), who identified CCNL1 as an immediate early gene induced by cocaine and dopamine.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	421	 Taken together, the present characterization of the cyclin L2 gene suggests that CCNL1 and CCNL2 originated by gene duplication and have acquired different patterns of expression by divergent evolution of their promoters.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	422	The fact that both splicing variants are conserved in the paralogous genes CCNL1 and CCNL2, together with their differential patterns of expression, argues against the possibility that cyclin L1S and L2S are products of irregular splicing.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	423	 However, the cyclin domain and the RS domain are truncated or completely absent, respectively, in cyclin L1S and L2S.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	424	 Cyclin L2S neither interacts with PITSLREp110, most likely because of its incomplete cyclin box (as defined by Andersen et al.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	425	 (42)), nor is localized to nuclear speckles.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	426	 Identical results have been reported for cyclin L1S (39, 41).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	427	 The existence of these short variants with no apparent function is reminiscent of the alternative splicing in the CLK kinases (61).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	428	 CLK1 is regulated through alternative splicing of the CLK1 pre-mRNA, yielding mRNAs encoding the catalytically active kinase and truncated polypeptides lacking the kinase domain.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	429	 CLK1 regulates splicing by phosphorylation of SR proteins and controls its own expression, since the presence of the active kinase favors the production of the truncated, inactive polypeptide (61).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	430	 There are other known cases of splicing factors that are subject to autoregulation by alternative splicing (62, 63), and we hypothesize that the existence of the short splicing variants of cyclins L1 and L2 provides a means to control the levels of the full-length proteins at the level of splicing.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	431	We have characterized cyclin L2 both as a substrate and an interaction partner of the protein kinase DYRK1A.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	432	 It appears plausible that these proteins also interact in vivo, since DYRK1A has previously been found to be localized in nuclear speckles (17, 19).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	433	 The original cyclin L2 clone isolated from the expression library lacked the cyclin domain, thus allowing the conclusion that DYRK1A interacts with the RS domain of cyclin L2.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	434	 The results of the pull-down assays indicate that the catalytic domain of DYRK1A alone is able to bind cyclin L2 but that this interaction is greatly enhanced by the presence of a small conserved region preceding the catalytic domain, called the DH box.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	435	 This region contains a large number of acidic residues (35) and is conserved in all kinases of the DYRK family and in several related kinases that are involved in the regulation of splicing (CLK family, PRP4 (48)).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	436	 It appears reasonable to assume that the negatively charged DH box is engaged in ionic interactions with the positively charged RS domain.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	437	DYRK1A phosphorylated cyclin L2 in vitro within the C-terminal domain, but the three in vitro phosphorylation sites identified in the present study were not located within RS repeat motifs (Fig.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	438	 This finding confirms our previous classification of DYRK1A as a proline-directed kinase (35).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	439	 Notably, none of the target sites in cyclin L2 contains an arginine residue in position P-2 or P-3 that we and others have previously found to be critical for substrate recognition (14, 34, 64).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	440	 We could further show that cyclin L2 is indeed a phosphoprotein when expressed in COS-7 cells.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	441	 The phosphate content of cyclin L2 was not significantly altered by co-expressed DYRK1A (Fig.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	442	 10A), probably because RS domains are generally highly phosphorylated by endogenous kinases (47).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	443	 However, overexpression in COS-7 cells of catalytically active DYRK1A, but not of a kinase-inactive mutant, induced a mobility of shift of cyclin L2, resembling the result of the in vitro phosphorylation of His6-CycL2 by DYRK1A (Fig.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	444	 This result strongly suggests that DYRK1A directly phosphorylates cyclin L2 in living cells.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	445	 The phosphorylation of SR proteins is necessary for their recruitment from nuclear speckles to sites of transcription/pre-mRNA processing (44, 65).
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	446	 (19) have recently reported that kinase-active DYRK1A, but not an inactive point mutant, induced speckle disassembly.
0.18519257.14623875.html.plaintext.txt	447	 However, it remains to be determined whether phosphorylation of cyclin L2 is involved in this action of DYRK1A.

0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	0	Tripartite Hemolysin BL from Bacillus cereus HEMOLYTIC ANALYSIS OF COMPONENT INTERACTIONS AND A MODEL FOR ITS CHARACTERISTIC PARADOXICAL ZONE PHENOMENON*.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	1	(Received for publication, June 25, 1996, and in revised form, October 11, 1996).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	2	Hemolysin BL (HBL) is a unique membrane-lytic toxin from Bacillus cereus composed of three distinct proteins, designated B, L1, and L2.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	3	 HBL produces a paradoxical zone phenomenon in gel diffusion assays in sheep blood agar.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Lysis does not begin immediately adjacent to the source of diffusion; rather, it begins several millimeters away.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Cells near the source and at intersections of lysis zones remain intact longer.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Here, we developed a spectrophotometric hemolysis assay system that measures the activities of the individual HBL components and used it to analyze the mechanisms of hemolysis and the paradoxical zone phenomenon.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	7	 The B component was rate-limiting, and erythrocytes were slowly primed by B at an optimal concentration of about 1.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	8	3 nM to rapid lytic action by the combination of the L components (L1+2).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	9	 All of the individual components bound to cells independently, and membrane-associated HBL components were neutralized by specific antibodies, suggesting that lysis was caused by formation of a membrane attack complex on the cell surface.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Osmotic protection experiments indicate a colloid osmotic lysis mechanism.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Concentrations of the B component above 1.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	12	3 nM caused inhibition of L1-mediated lysis, and L1 inhibited the priming reaction of B over a similar concentration range.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	13	 From analyses of spectrophotometric and diffusion assays we constructed a basic model for the interactions between HBL components and for the paradoxical zone phenomenon in blood agar.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	14	 In the latter, areas of slow lysis near diffusion sources are caused primarily by the accumulation of inhibitory levels of L1 reached before cells are primed by B.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	15	Bacillus cereus secretes hemolysin BL (HBL),1 a membrane-lytic system composed of three antigenically distinct proteins thought to contribute to diarrheal food poisoning (1) and necrotizing infections such as endophthalmitis (2).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Separately, the HBL components are nontoxic, but when combined they exhibit a variety of toxic activities including hemolysis, cytotoxicity, vascular permeability, dermonecrosis, enterotoxicity, and ocular toxicity (1, 2, 3, 4).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	17	 When HBL diffuses from a bacterial colony or a well in blood agar, it produces an unusual discontinuous hemolysis pattern (5), called a paradoxical zone phenomenon (6).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Lysis begins away from the well or colony, followed by slow lysis nearer the source (5).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	19	 A similar zone phenomenon is seen in spectrophotometric assays in which there is decreased hemolysis at HBL concentrations above a maximally effective dose (4).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	20	HBL is the first known three-component bacterial toxin.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	21	 The components are designated B, L1, and L2.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	22	2 kDa, and their pI values are 5.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	23	33 (4), as determined electrophoretically.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	24	 The genes for all three components have been cloned, and the sequences have been determined (7, 8).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	25	 The amino acid sequences predicted from the nucleotide sequences are in complete agreement with published N-terminal amino acid sequences determined chemically (4).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	26	 All of the proteins appear unique and exhibit no significant similarity with other known proteins.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	27	 The three genes are immediately adjacent to one another, apparently in an operon (8).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Methods for purification of relatively large quantities of pure HBL components were developed only recently (4); therefore, little is known about the mode of action of HBL at the molecular level.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	29	Here we present a novel hemolysis assay system that has provided significant insight into the mechanism and interactions of HBL components.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	30	 These assays are based on a fundamental difference between the activities of the B and L components and allow analysis of the activities of the individual HBL components.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	31	 When sheep erythrocytes were treated with B they did not lyse, but they slowly became primed to lysis by the combination of the two L components (L1+2).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	32	 The discrete proportion of cells primed at a given time could be used as a measure of the activity of B.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	33	 The priming reaction, which took less than 1 h at 42  degrees C could be nearly stopped by reducing the temperature to 22  degrees C or below, creating a quasistable population of B-primed red blood cells (RBC-B).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	34	 The addition of L1+2 to RBC-B at 22  degrees C caused rapid lysis of cells that was over 3000 times faster than the priming rate at that temperature.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Consequently, numerous samples of the L components could be analyzed against an RBC-B preparation with little change in the primed cells.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	36	All three HBL components bound to erythrocytes independently of the others.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Complete neutralization of membrane-bound L components by specific antibodies suggest that HBL causes hemolysis via the interaction of at least the L components in a "membrane attack complex" and not by enzymatic degradation of the membrane.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Osmotic protection experiments indicated that lysis was by a colloid osmotic mechanism through transmembrane pores.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	39	Analysis also indicated that concentrations of B above 1.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	40	3 nM caused inhibition of the lysis of RBC-B by L1 in the presence of L2.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Conversely, excess L1 inhibited the priming reaction of B.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	42	 The data suggest that B and L1 each inhibit the other above a threshold concentration relative to the concentration of a membrane component.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	43	 The L2 component was required for lysis, but it exhibited little or no interference with the other components.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	44	From these observations we propose a model for the paradoxical zone phenomenon seen in gel diffusion assays.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Hemolysis is slow near the HBL source because excess (and therefore inhibitory) concentrations of B and L1 accumulate before cells can be primed by B.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The initial location of lysis occurs at a point at which the diffusion rate has decreased enough so that the rate of priming by B exceeds the rate at which excess components accumulate.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	47	Erythrocytes, HBL Components, and Antibodies.

0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	116	Osmotic Protection from Lysis by HBL.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	117	It is generally thought that pore-forming hemolysins cause lysis by a colloid osmotic mechanism.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	118	 When pores form in the membrane, external solutes that are smaller than the pores enter the cell, creating an osmotic gradient.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	119	 This in turn produces a net flow of water into the cell, which swells and lyses from excess osmotic pressure.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Osmotic protection experiments are the standard methods for detecting colloid osmotic lysis.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Theoretically, if pores of defined size are produced, and the diameters of the external solutes are larger than the diameters of the pores, those solutes cannot enter the cell.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	122	 This prevents the production of an osmotic gradient, thereby protecting cells from lysis (9).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	123	Hemolysis due to HBL decreased in the presence of isotonic concentrations of carbohydrates of increasing size as shown in Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	124	 These results indicate that HBL lyses cells by a colloid-osmotic mechanism and suggest that, under these conditions, functional pores of 1.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	125	 This pore size should only be considered a rough estimate, because calculated values vary greatly with assay conditions (9).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Osmotic protection of sheep erythrocytes from HBL by carbohydrates of increasing size.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Sheep erythrocytes were suspended in isosmotic concentrations of NaCl or carbohydrates of increasing sizes as indicated and treated with 0.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	128	 The percentage of cells lysed was determined after 75 min at 37  degrees C.

0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	207	The inhibitory effect of excess B on L1+2 was observed even when B was added to previously primed erythrocytes (Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Erythrocytes were completely primed (100% RBC-B) and stabilized, and then excess B (an inhibitory concentration, Bi) was added prior to, simultaneously with, or following L1+2.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	209	 The addition of Bi simultaneously with L1+2 resulted in nearly 60% inhibition of the lysis velocity.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Inhibition did not increase if B was preincubated with RBC-B, and inhibition decreased drastically when B was added after L1+2.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	211	 This indicates that under these conditions, B did not alter the cell surface, but it did interfere either with the binding or an intermediate step of one or both L components, and B did not interfere with lysis once binding or an intermediate step occurred.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	212	The sequential addition of L1, L2, and Bi to RBC-B in various permutations indicated that Bi inhibits L1 and not L2 (Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	213	 When either L component was added to RBC-B, the cells did not lyse until the second L was added (Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	214	 When Bi was added at t = 0, lysis was inhibited regardless of the order of addition of the L components.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	215	 But when Bi was added with an L component at t = 180 s, inhibition only occurred when L1 was added at that time (curve B), suggesting that B interferes with L1 and not L2.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	216	 With respect to curve A (L1 at 0 s, L2 at 180 s), Bi inhibited lysis when added at 0 s but not when added at 180 s.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	217	 The kinetics of the loss of inhibitory activity of Bi is graphically illustrated by the closed circle scatter plot in Fig.

0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	219	RBC were primed by B in the presence of increasing concentrations of either L1 or L2, and the extent of priming was measured by the addition of the complementary L component (Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	220	 L1 drastically inhibited the priming reaction above ~1.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	221	 The inhibition dose response was very similar to the inhibition of L1 by B in Fig.

0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	223	 The L2 component did not significantly inhibit the priming reaction in the concentration range tested, just as Bi did not inhibit L2.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	224	 Inhibition of component B by excess L1.

0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	234	 The diffusion assay was performed, and the blood agar gel was prepared as described previously (10).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	235	 Each well (3-mm diameter) received 4 pmol (~150 ng) of the respective HBL components.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Wells labeled H received all three HBL components.

0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	239	 [View Larger Version of this Image (46K GIF file)].
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	240	An implication of the above observations is that, in blood agar, the inhibition of lysis near the HBL diffusion source and at the intersections of lysis zones (10) is a function of the mutual inhibitory activity between B and L1.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	241	 To test this idea, the separated components were added to wells adjacent to wells containing all three components (Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	242	 Consistent with the above observations, the L1 component inhibited lysis in the adjacent zone, and the L2 component had no apparent effect on the adjacent pattern.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	243	 Lysis was enhanced adjacent to the B component.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	244	 This superficially contradicts the observation that excess B inhibits lysis by L1, but it is consistent with the overall kinetics of the system, as discussed below.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	245	Among the greater than 300 described bacterial toxins, there are several that require two different, individually soluble, proteins for toxic activity (11) but none that require three components.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	246	 These binary toxins include staphylococcal -hemolysin and the related leukocidins (12, 13); anthrax toxin (14); Clostridium botulinum C2 and the related toxins of Clostridium perfringens, Clostridium spiroforme, and Clostridium difficile (15); and Bacillus sphaericus binary toxin (16).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	247	 For all of these (except possibly the B.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	248	 sphaericus toxin), the components exhibit a compulsory cell-binding order.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	249	 Also the protective antigen of anthrax toxin, which acts as a docking protein, must be cleaved by a cellular protease before the complementary proteins will bind.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	250	 The observations presented here allowed us to address related questions about the mechanism of HBL and helped answer three basic questions.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Does HBL cause lysis enzymatically or by formation of a membrane attack complex? Do the HBL components act randomly or in a compulsory order? What is the basis for the paradoxical zone phenomenon exhibited by HBL?.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	252	Hemolysins are thought to lyse cells by two general mechanisms (17).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	253	 First, the cell surface may be enzymatically altered to an extent that causes membrane degeneration.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	254	 This usually involves phospholipases, and there are numerous examples of hemolysis that require two enzymes acting in a compulsory order (18).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	255	 In some systems a phospholipase acts on the cell, which is subsequently lysed by a nonphospholipase enzyme or nonenzymatic protein.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	256	 In the second hemolysis mechanism, lysin molecules insert into the membrane and form functional transmembrane pores (19), or "leaky patches" (20).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	257	 Such lesions are generally composed of oligomers of one protein or multiple proteins.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	258	 Complement is an example of a lytic system that produces lesions composed of more than one different protein.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Complement lesions are called membrane attack complexes (MACs) to account for their multicomponent composition (21).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	260	 Hemolysins may also exhibit detergent-like activity and "solubilize" membranes, but this mechanism may not occur for hemolytic proteins (17).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	261	 3 demonstrates that both L components bound to erythrocyte membranes independently of any other HBL component.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	262	 After priming of L1- or L2-treated and washed cells by B, the addition of antibodies specific to either membrane-bound L component completely neutralized hemolysis by the complementary L component.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	263	 This indicates that the L components remained associated with the membranes after washing and that each needed to be present for a competent lytic lesion to be formed.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	264	 It also strongly suggests that a competent lesion is only formed when L1 and L2 physically interact on the cell surface, which, by definition, describes a MAC.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	265	 If the L components were simple enzymes that caused lysis by independently damaging membranes, then antibodies to an L component would not reverse the membrane damage and protect cells from lysis by the other HBL components.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	266	 It appears, therefore, that HBL ultimately causes lysis by forming a lesion analogous to a complement MAC that has a minimum structure consisting of an L1-L2 heterodimer.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	267	 Osmotic protection of erythrocytes treated with HBL (Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	268	 2) suggests that the putative MAC results in formation of transmembrane pores but does not indicate whether the pores are protein-lined or simply perturbations of the phospholipid bilayer surrounding the HBL components.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	269	Antibodies specific for the B component also interfered with the ability of the L components to lyse B-primed cells (Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	270	 4), suggesting that L components interact with B to form an integral three-component heteromeric membrane lesion.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	271	 However, although the anti-B antibodies completely neutralized the autonomous priming reaction of B, they could only partially inhibit lysis once cells were primed.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	272	 If HBL lysis does involve a three-component MAC, there are several possibilities as to what might occur during the priming reaction that decreases the ability of the anti-B antibodies to neutralize lysis.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	273	 During priming, the B component may insert into the membrane, possibly forming oligomers.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	274	 This would allow antibodies to bind only to exposed portions of B and not to portions sequestered within the membrane.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	275	 Any conformational changes experienced by B might also decrease the avidity of antibodies prepared to its native conformation.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	276	 It is also possible that B is altered by a membrane component, such as occurs in the proteolytic processing of the protective antigen component of anthrax toxin (14).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	277	 Antibodies prepared to native B may bind poorly to the processed version.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	278	The inability of anti-B antibodies to completely neutralize lysis of RBC-B by L1+2 might also be diagnostic of an enzymatic mechanism for B.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	279	 A situation can be envisioned in which B binds to a membrane and converts a substrate to a product that is subsequently recognized by the L components, leading to lysis.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	280	 If the product was to accumulate in a pool in the immediate vicinity of the membrane-bound B, partial inhibition might occur if B-associated antibody sterically prevented access of L components to the product.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	281	 Such a mechanism seems rather unlikely, but it cannot be ruled out with present observations.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	282	The next question addressed by our data is whether the HBL components act in an ordered or random manner.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	283	 1 and 3 that all three HBL components bind to erythrocytes independently (i.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	284	 However, as pointed out by Ponder in 1948 (6), hemolysis is a relatively complex multistep process.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	285	 Pore assembly models for staphylococcal -toxin and for streptolysin O provide examples of such a multistep process (22).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	286	 -Toxin monomers bind to membranes, diffuse laterally into a prepore complex on the membrane surface, and subsequently insert and form pores.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	287	 SLO also binds as monomers and then undergoes a rate-limiting nucleation process involving formation of dimers on the membrane surface, followed by dimer insertion, and then rapid accumulation of monomers around the dimer nucleus to form the functional lesion.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	288	 The complexity of these processes demonstrates that simple association of toxin components with erythrocytes does not provide a picture of the overall hemolysis mechanism.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	289	Our evidence suggests that HBL components form pores after they form a complex.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	290	 The L1 and L2 components rapidly contribute to the complex in a manner that does not appear to depend on the sequence of their addition.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	291	 However, the B component clearly must undergo an autonomous, rate-limiting reaction before a functional lesion can be formed with the L components.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	292	 Therefore, although all of the components bind independently to the cell, final lesion formation appears to follow a specific order with respect to the B and L components.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	293	 It is possible that the appearance of an ordered reaction is an artifact of the kinetics of the individual components.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	294	 All of the components might undergo analogous independent priming reactions, with the reaction of B being extremely slow relative to the reactions of the L components.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	295	 However, our data suggest that the priming process followed by B is fundamentally different from those followed by the L components, because antibodies could completely protect cells when reacted with either membrane-associated L component, but not when reacted with B-primed cells.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	296	The cause of the paradoxical zone phenomenon of HBL is the third major mechanistic question addressed by these data.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	297	 5 and 6 indicate that B and L1 are mutually inhibitory above a threshold concentration and that this antagonism is responsible for the paradoxical hemolysis behavior seen in gel diffusion and suspension assays.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	298	In a dose-response curve for the priming reaction of B (Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	299	 5A), the lysis velocity (reaction 2 in Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	300	 1A) of L1+2 decreased with increasing concentrations of B even when most cells were primed.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	301	 5B shows that lysis velocity could be inhibited even if Bi was added after cells were completely primed (100% RBC-B).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	302	 The inhibition of lysis did not increase if RBC-B were pretreated with Bi (Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	303	 5B, inset), indicating that inhibition was not due to an enzymatic action of Bi on the cells.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	304	 Inhibition decreased, however, if Bi was added after L1 (Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	305	 5, B and C), indicating that Bi interferes with the incorporation of L1 into the lesion and not with the function of a preformed lesion.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	306	The kinetics of the inhibition of L1 by B in Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	307	 Inhibition decreased linearly with time (r = 0.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	308	 This suggests a first order process for the incorporation of L1 into lesions, which is in distinct contrast to the complex shape of hemolysis curves.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	309	 This type of measurement was possible only because of the special situation in which B does not appear to interfere with lysis once L1 has been incorporated into a lesion.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	310	 6 shows that, above a threshold concentration, L1 also inhibited the priming reaction of B.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	311	 The dose-response of L1-mediated inhibition of the priming reaction was nearly identical to that for inhibition of L1 by excess B (Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	312	 In addition, excess L1 inhibited hemolysis caused by HBL placed in adjacent wells in blood agar (Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	313	The hemolysis data presented here provide an explanation for the paradoxical zone phenomenon of HBL and the lysis patterns seen in Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	314	 HBL hemolysis in blood agar is discontinuous and begins away from a well containing the components.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	315	 However, diffusing molecules create a continuous concentration gradient, and the components must therefore reach a concentration that promotes hemolysis at every point between the well edge and the zone in which lysis begins; this is the paradox, and we propose the following model to explain it.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	316	 A cell will not lyse unless it has been primed by B, and maximal priming occurs only at permissive concentrations of B and L1.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	317	 When membrane-bound B or L1 exceeds a critical ratio versus a membrane constituent, the other component is inhibited from forming a functional lesion (or perhaps produces an inefficient lesion).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	318	 Priming by B is slow and, since L1 can inhibit B at any time during the reaction (Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	319	 6A, insert), priming is inhibited near a well when L1 diffuses rapidly enough to accumulate to inhibitory levels before cells are primed.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	320	 Hemolysis only begins in a zone in which the B concentration is high enough to prime cells, but the diffusion rate of L1 is too low for it to reach an inhibitory concentration before the cells are primed.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	321	 Inhibition at the intersections of zones is due to accumulation of excess L1 before cells are primed.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	322	 It is unlikely that inhibition is caused by an excess ratio of B to L1 or vice versa, because a paradoxical zone phenomenon occurs in suspension assays simply by increasing the concentration of all three components at a constant ratio of each to the others (4).
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	323	The influence on hemolysis patterns of the inhibitory effect of L1 is seen in Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	324	 Just as lysis is inhibited at the intersections of HBL hemolysis zones, lysis was also inhibited at the intersection of an HBL hemolysis zone and an L1 diffusion zone.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	325	 6A, L2 had no appreciable effect on an adjacent hemolysis pattern.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	326	 The enhanced lysis between wells containing either HBL or B only seems contradictory in light of the observation that excess B inhibits lysis by L1, but it is consistent with the mechanism of HBL.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	327	 The B component primes cells independently of the other components (Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	328	 1, B and C), and once primed, cells are rapidly lysed by any concentration of L1+2.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	329	 The lysis within the B diffusion zone occurred simply because cells were primed by B in the absence of inhibitory concentrations of L1.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	330	 The priming reaction of B is over 1000 times slower than the lytic action of L1 at room temperature.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	331	 Therefore, even in the presence of excess B, the lysis rate of RBC-B will not be noticeably slower than the rate at which cells are primed by B.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	332	 On the other hand, any inhibition by L1 of the priming reaction of B should be profoundly evident.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	333	 This seems to be born out in the lysis patterns in Fig.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	334	Our hemolysis data provide some insights into the mechanism of HBL, which appears to involve novel modes of interactions between proteins and membranes.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	335	 The three proteins that comprise HBL are collectively called a toxin because of an early simplifying assumption that they represent a single functional unit to the bacterium that produces them.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	336	 This work supports that assumption.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	337	 New findings show that the genes for all three components are arranged immediately adjacent to one another, probably in an operon (8), lending additional weight to the idea that the three proteins comprise a functional unit.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	338	 HBL is unlike any previously described cytolytic toxin, from its complex composition to the unique hemolytic phenomena that it causes.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	339	 Further study of this toxin promises to add a new perspective to perceptions about the mechanisms and utility of cytolytic toxins.
0.18831623.8995253.html.plaintext.txt	340	*   This work was supported by the National Research Initiative Competitive Grants Program of the U.

0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	0	Central Role of a Serine Phosphorylation Site within Duck Hepatitis B Virus Core Protein for Capsid Trafficking and Genome Release* Josef Kock , Michael Kann , Gerhard Putz , Hubert E.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Blum  and Fritz von Weizsacker   .
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	2	From the Department of Medicine II, University Hospital, 79106 Freiburg, Germany and the Institute of Medical Virology, Justus Liebig University, 35392 Giessen, Germany.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	3	Received for publication, January 3, 2003 , and in revised form, April 10, 2003.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	4	Earlier studies in the DHBV model have shown that capsids from infected livers are highly phosphorylated while serum-derived capsids and particles secreted from cultured cells are dephosphorylated (13, 14).
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Furthermore, binding of in vitro generated HBV capsids to the nucleus of digitonin-permeabilized hepatoma cells was previously found to depend on the phosphorylation status of the core protein (15).
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Hepadnaviral capsid phosphorylation, therefore, represents a candidate mechanism for the regulated nuclear targeting and release of viral rcDNA during natural infection.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	7	In the present report we used genetically engineered phosphorylation mutants of DHBV core protein to test this hypothesis.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	8	 The duck model offers the advantage that primary duck hepatocytes (PDH) are readily available and that DHBV infection of PDH with supernatants from transfected cells is highly efficient and reproducible.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Position 245 within the C terminus of DHBV core was selected for detailed analysis since this site serves as a phosphate acceptor in transfected cells (5) and an earlier study had revealed an apparent effect of phosphoserine 245 on plus-strand DNA elongation (16).
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Furthermore, we have previously shown that the phenotype of two C-terminal deletion mutants is compatible with a potential key role of this position in capsid stability (17).
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	11	 In addition to the effect of ionic charge at this position we also analyzed the potential effect of hydrogen bond formation.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Our data suggest that hydrogen bonding is required for the stabilization of newly assembled mature capsids while a negative ionic charge at position 245 of the DHBV core protein plays an essential role in nuclear capsid transport and infectivity.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Based on these results we propose a model for multiple capsid functions based on the coordinated core protein phosphorylation and dephosphorylation, hydrogen bond formation as well as DNA maturation.

0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	128	Relaxed Circular DNA Associated with S245A and S245D Is Sensitive to Nuclease Treatment We have previously shown that two deletion mutants of DHBV core protein encompassing serine 245 yield capsids in which mature viral DNA is nuclease-sensitive (17).
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Prompted by this observation we tested the nuclease sensitivity of the respective S245 substitution mutants.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Incubation of capsids with micrococcal nuclease for 5 h resulted in an up to 50% decrease of total viral DNA (Fig.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Strikingly, however, capsid-associated rcDNA but not ssDNA was nuclease-sensitive in mutants S245D and S245A.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	132	 By contrast, the relative abundance of the respective DNA species was unchanged for wild-type and S245N (compare right and left panel, Fig.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Degradation of S245D-associated rcDNA was observed after prolonged nuclease treatment only, while S245A-associated rcDNA was degradable within one hour, suggesting that S245D capsids were more nuclease-resistant than S245A capsids.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	134	 To address the question whether S245A capsids offer any protection of rcDNA a nuclease titration assay was performed.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	135	 2C, S245A-associated rcDNA was more nuclease-resistant than naked rcDNA but the difference was small.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	136	 These observations indicate that mutations of serine 245 affect the stability of mature, rcDNA-containing DHBV capsids.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	137	Structural Properties of Mutant Capsids It was unclear whether destabilized capsids completely disintegrate during viral plus strand DNA synthesis and become physically separate from rcDNA or whether rcDNA remains associated with core protein.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	138	 To address this issue S245A capsids were further analyzed by immunoprecipitation and density gradient sedimentation.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	139	 3 shows that rcDNA specifically co-precipitated with wild-type as well as mutant core protein.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	140	 When subjected to density gradient sedimentation, rcDNA co-localized with particulate core protein (Fig.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Furthermore, there was no evidence for an accumulation of monomeric/dimeric core protein relative to particulate core protein, as would have been expected in the case of complete capsid disintegration.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Identical results were obtained for mutants S245D and S245N (data not illustrated).
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	143	 It should be noted, however, that empty or RNA-containing capsids cannot clearly be distinguished from rcDNA-containing capsids in this assay.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Plasmid DNA also entered the gradient in this experimental setting, most likely as calcium phosphate complexes.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Importantly, however, the rcDNA peak co-localized with the core protein but not with plasmid DNA, indicating that the sedimentation pattern of rcDNA was not due to a nonspecific mechanism.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	146	 This interpretation is confirmed by the fact that purified rcDNA did not enter the gradient (data not shown).
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	147	View larger version (56K):    FIG.

0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	163	Mutants S245A and S245N Are Defective in Nuclear Targeting and cccDNA Formation Next we investigated the potential effect of DHBV core protein phosphorylation on intracellular trafficking and cccDNA formation.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Preventing viral surface protein synthesis enhances capsid recycling to the nucleus and cccDNA formation (19).
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	165	 We therefore introduced a stop codon within the surface open reading frame of the respective overlength constructs.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	166	 The subcellular localization of core protein mutants was assessed by confocal immunofluorescence laserscan microscopy of transfected HuH-7 cells.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	167	 5 shows a representative panel of core-positive cells for each mutant.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	168	 While the staining pattern was not strictly homogenous, blinded analysis of each individual mutant revealed that wild-type and mutant S245D reproducibly generated intranuclear as well as cytosolic core protein.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	169	 By contrast, the subcellular localization of core was predominantly cytoplasmic for mutants S245A and S245N with individual cells displaying a moderate nuclear core staining.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	170	 This observation may be due to impaired nuclear import or accelerated nuclear export of core protein (24).
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Identical results were obtained in LMH cells (data not shown).
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	172	View larger version (80K):    FIG.

0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	180	 As expected, only the surface-negative variants yielded strong cccDNA signals (Fig.

0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	182	 By contrast, cccDNA formation remained at lower levels for S245A and S245N (Fig.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	183	 This finding was confirmed in three independent experiments.

0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	194	All Mutants Produce Enveloped Particles We then investigated the competence of mutant capsids to enter the secretory pathway.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Culture media of transfected cells were centrifuged to equilibrium in a cesium chloride gradient and fractions were analyzed by Southern blotting.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	196	 7 shows that all mutants were enveloped.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Compared with wild-type, however, the respective levels in virion production were reduced.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	198	 In particular, enveloped S245A particles were only detectable after prolonged exposure of the Southern blot.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	199	 This result is best explained by the reduced overall replication rate of mutant S245A and by its selective deficiency of mature, rcDNA containing capsids.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	200	View larger version (67K):    FIG.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Culture supernatants from transfected LMH cells were subjected to CsCl density gradient centrifugation.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	202	 The transfected plasmids code for the wild-type surface protein.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Nine fractions were collected, beginning from the top of the gradient, and analyzed for DNA by Southern blotting.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Enveloped particles accumulate in the middle of the gradient, while naked particles are in fractions 8 and 9, respectively.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	205	 A, wild-type control; B, mutant S245D; C, mutant S245A; D, mutant S245N.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	206	 For abbreviations, see legend to Fig.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	207	Mutant S245N Is Not Infectious in Primary Hepatocytes  Finally, the respective mutants were tested for their ability to infect primary duck hepatocytes.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Due to the low amounts of enveloped virions obtained with mutant S245A, this study was restricted to mutants S245D and S245N.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Supernatants of transfected LMH cells were added to primary duck hepatocytes, and the cells were harvested at the time points indicated.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Successful infection was demonstrated by the accumulation of cccDNA and newly synthesized replicative intermediates.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Productive infection of primary duck hepatocytes (PDH) by wild-type virions is shown in Fig.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Mutant S245D was also infectious, but the efficiency of infection was reduced with a faint signal of cccDNA becoming visible on day 7 postinfection (Fig.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	213	 S245N virions attached efficiently to primary duck hepatocytes (Fig.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Nevertheless, cccDNA and newly synthesized replicative intermediates were not detectable in cells inoculated with this mutant virus, though rcDNA originating from the inoculating virus remained visible up to 9 days in culture.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	215	 Thus, mutant S245N generated stable capsids, which were unable to initiate a productive infection in PDH.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	216	 In addition, this result rules out that the generation of replicative intermediates observed for wild-type and mutant S245D originated from transfection of residual plasmid DNA present in the inoculum rather than from a true infection.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	217	View larger version (50K):    FIG.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Infectivity of mutant viral particles.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	219	 LMH cells were transfected with wild-type, mutant S245D or mutant S245N constructs.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Culture supernatants were collected and added to primary duck hepatocytes.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	221	 A, infection with wild-type (left panel) and mutant S245D (right panel).
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	222	 B, infection with wild-type (left panel) and mutant S245N (right panel).
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	223	 The cells were harvested four hours (4h), 4 days (4d), 7 days (7d), or 9 days (9d) postinfection.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	224	 DNA from infected hepatocytes was analyzed by Southern blotting.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	225	 For abbreviations see legends to Figs.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	226	Wild-type and S245N capsids were nuclease-resistant while encapsidated mature viral DNA generated by mutants S245D and S245A was nuclease-sensitive.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Possible reasons accounting for this observation include differences in local protein structure preferred by alanine and aspartic acid compared with serine and asparagine and/or electrostatic repulsion of DNA by aspartic acid.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Furthermore, hydrogen bonding mediated by non-phosphorylated serine as well as asparagine may contribute to the stabilization of the quarterny structure of mature DHBV capsids.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	229	 The precise structural properties of mutant capsids that are associated with the nuclease-sensitivity of mature viral DNA remain to be further elucidated.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	230	 We obtained no evidence for a complete disintegration of mature S245A capsids in immunoprecipitation experiments and the density gradient sedimentation assay.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	231	 It should be noted, however that, partially dissociated S245A capsids may have reassembled after DNA release with rcDNA remaining attached to the outside of the capsid.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Alternatively, the sensitivity of rcDNA may simply be based on an increased "breathing" of the capsid.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	233	 This phenomenon involves the slow release of capsid subunits followed by a rapid reformation of the capsid integrity, as discussed previously for HBV capsids (25).
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	234	The fact that only mature rcDNA but not ssDNA associated with mutant capsids S245D and S245A was accessible to nuclease action indicates that DNA maturation itself is an important trigger of capsid destabilization.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	235	 Possibly, interactions of viral DNA with the C terminus of the core protein are of importance in this context (26).
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Our results shed new light on previous data, which had implicated that the C-terminal domain of DHBV core protein is required for DNA maturation.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Rather, this report and our previous study on deletion and insertion mutants of the DHBV core protein (17) suggest that the phenotype of several mutants is at least in part due to nuclease sensitivity of mature viral DNA.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	238	 The fact that nuclease treatment is commonly used to remove plasmid DNA prior to extraction of nucleocapsid associated hepadnaviral DNA explains why fully mature DNA forms have not been observed earlier.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	239	 Indeed, we found that nuclease sensitivity of rcDNA also accounts for the phenotype of a previously described P246G mutant of DHBV core (16).
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	240	2 It will be interesting to determine the relevance of these observations for HBV core protein mutants.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	241	Our data suggest that negative charges at position 245 as contributed by phosphorylated serine or aspartic acid support nuclear targeting of DHBV core protein, cccDNA formation and infectivity.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	242	 The residual cccDNA formation by mutant S245N could be due to nuclear import of small amounts of core protein mediated by the remaining, unchanged phosphorylation sites.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	243	 This may be difficult to detect by immunofluorescence since the polyclonal anti-DHBV core antibody may not react well with core protein dimers in fixed cells.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	244	 Alternatively, capsids might become entrapped non-specifically within the nucleus of dividing cells and be degraded subsequently.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	245	 Nevertheless, our infection experiments in PDH demonstrate that the residual cccDNA formation by S245N does not suffice to initiate productive infection.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	246	Collectively, our observations suggest the following model: maturation of rcDNA within the nucleocapsid is an important trigger of capsid destabilization, which ultimately results in DNA release.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	247	 During viral assembly hydrogen bonds formed by non-phosphorylated serine 245 contribute to the stabilization of nucleocapsids thus preventing DNA liberation in the cytoplasm.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	248	 During infection, phosphorylation of serine 245 directs the capsid to the nucleus.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	249	 At the same time nucleocapsids are destabilized thus facilitating rcDNA release in the nucleus.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	250	 These mechanisms would also apply to progeny capsids that are redirected to the nucleus for cccDNA amplification.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	251	 How newly formed DHBV capsids are directed to the secretory pathway remains to be elucidated, however, since Mabit and Schaller (13) have shown that dephosphorylation alone is not sufficient to confer membrane affinity.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	252	 The suggested model is in line with the previous observation in the duck model that serum-derived nucleocapsids are non-phosphorylated whereas nucleocapsids from liver tissue are highly phosphorylated (14).
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	253	 It is tempting to speculate that incoming and recycling capsids are phosphorylated by a capsid-associated kinase activity of cellular origin, which has been described in the WHV and HBV system (27 to 33).
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	254	The present report demonstrates a central role of serine 245 in regulating DHBV capsid trafficking and stability.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	255	 Clearly, however, the remaining phosphorylation sites within DHBV core may play an important role as well, since earlier reports indicate that serine 259 also affects viral infectivity (10, 16).
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	256	 It remains to be elucidated which and how many residues of individual nucleocapsids are phosphorylated at a given time point and how core protein phosphorylation is orchestrated during capsid assembly and disassembly.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	257	 Further studies in the HBV and WHV system will have to establish whether mammalian core protein phosphorylation is essential for infectivity as well.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	258	 The recently described infection of primary tupaia hepatocytes (34) might represent a suitable model to address this question.
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Interestingly, phosphorylation of capsid protein by capsid-associated kinase activities has also been suggested to play a key role during the early steps of HIV infection (35).
0.19297737.12740387.html.plaintext.txt	260	 Thus, phosphorylation might represent a general mechanism regulating the targeted genome release from viral capsids.

0.19757515.15073154.html.plaintext.txt	17	  In general, each heterochronic gene governs cell fates at a particular larval stage, and a gene that acts early in larval development may affect later stages as a consequence.

0.19757515.15073154.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Broken arrow indicates that the effects of the complex may be either positive or negative, and either direct or indirect.
0.19757515.15073154.html.plaintext.txt	37	 LIN-28 may act as a negative regulator of one or more components of that complex, probably at the level of gene expression.
0.19757515.15073154.html.plaintext.txt	38	  lin-14 has two roles during larval development: first to determine L1 fates only, and then later to affect the L2 and subsequent events (Ambros and Horvitz, 1987).
0.19757515.15073154.html.plaintext.txt	39	 These two activities differ not only by when they occur, but in the nature of their interactions with other genes.
0.19757515.15073154.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Specifically, lin-14 apparently acts alone to govern L1 cell fates, then it interacts with lin-28 to choose cell fates that will occur in the L2 (Ambros, 2000).
0.19757515.15073154.html.plaintext.txt	41	 lin-14 and lin-28 are engaged in a complex genetic circuitry that involves both positive and negative regulatory interactions (see Fig.
0.19757515.15073154.html.plaintext.txt	42	 This circuitry involves the microRNA lin-4 as well as other as yet unidentified components (Lee et al.
0.19757515.15073154.html.plaintext.txt	43	 In later larval stages, both lin-14 and lin-28 are repressed, allowing late stage events to be executed.
0.19757515.15073154.html.plaintext.txt	44	 The changes in activity and interactions of the heterochronic genes through the larval stages lead to the normal succession of larval developmental events.
0.19757515.15073154.html.plaintext.txt	45	The products of the heterochronic genes include at least two microRNAs (lin-4 and let-7), an evolutionarily conserved protein with a unique pairing of RNA-binding motifs (LIN-28), a protein related to the circadian rhythm regulator period of Drosophila (LIN-42), and a nuclear protein of unknown function (LIN-14) (Ruvkun et al.
0.19757515.15073154.html.plaintext.txt	46	, 1989; Ruvkun and Giusto, 1989; Lee et al.
0.19757515.15073154.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Although insight has been gained into how the expression of certain heterochronic genes is regulated, it is not yet known whether the identified heterochronic genes constitute all the components of the pathway.
0.19757515.15073154.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Nor is it known how the products of the heterochronic genes interact among themselves and with other cellular components to effect the precise timing of developmental events in worm larvae.
0.19757515.15073154.html.plaintext.txt	49	We have identified a new heterochronic gene, lin-46, which occupies a unique position in the larval developmental timing mechanism of C.
0.19757515.15073154.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Our analysis indicates that lin-46 functions at a step immediately downstream of lin-28, and acts at a branch-point in the heterochronic pathway.
0.19757515.15073154.html.plaintext.txt	51	 lin-46 encodes a protein that is homologous to bacterial and mammalian proteins, but as a developmental regulator, is novel.
0.19757515.15073154.html.plaintext.txt	52	Strains The lin-28(lf) alleles used are null based on molecular analysis (Moss et al.
0.19757515.15073154.html.plaintext.txt	53	 The nature of the different lin-14 alleles used are indicated in the text and tables.
0.19757515.15073154.html.plaintext.txt	54	 The lin-46 allele ma164 was used in all experiments, except where indicated.

0.19757515.15073154.html.plaintext.txt	59	Microscopy and phenotype analysis Egg-laying ability was scored using a dissecting microscope.
0.19757515.15073154.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Gonad development, seam cell number, and adult lateral alae formation were scored using DIC and fluorescence microscopy at high magnification.
0.19757515.15073154.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Lateral hypodermal cell lineages were deduced from counting seam cells of animals of multiple ages from the L1 to the L4.
0.19757515.15073154.html.plaintext.txt	62	 These cells were identified by GFP expression from wIs78, which contains scm-1:GFP and ajm-1:GFP that mark seam cell nuclei and seam cell junctions, respectively (Koh and Rothman, 2001).
0.19757515.15073154.html.plaintext.txt	63	 The stage of development was determined by extent of gonad and germline development.
0.19757515.15073154.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Data were collected from animals both early and late in each larval stage.
0.19757515.15073154.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Because cell division was ongoing near the beginning of each stage, we present only seam cell numbers when most or all cell divisions appeared to be complete.
0.19757515.15073154.html.plaintext.txt	66	Cold-sensitive period lin-46(ma174) animals were raised at either the restrictive (15 degrees C) or permissive (25 degrees C) temperature until specific stages in development, when they were shifted to the other temperature for the remainder of larval development.
0.19757515.15073154.html.plaintext.txt	67	 The animals were shifted when they were in the lethargus period that precedes each molt.
0.19757515.15073154.html.plaintext.txt	68	 At adulthood, animals were then scored for the presence of gaps in alae.
