0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	69	  Extended duplex formation results in specific ribozyme cleavage To determine whether heterodimerisation and subsequent refolding leads to specific ribozyme cleavage, we performed dimerisation assays at 37 and 55 degrees C as shown in Figure 3.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	70	 In vitro transcribed H1 and L1 RNAs, which should be cleaved upon formation of functional ribozymes, were radioactively labelled at their 5' ends.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	71	 We regularly used a 20- (hammerhead system) to 100-fold (leadzyme system) excess of unlabelled H2 or L2 RNAs to compete out H1 or L1 homodimer formation.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	72	 We observed the appearance of ribozyme-specific cleavage products for the hammerhead and leadzyme systems (Fig.

0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	75	 This is in agreement with previous data that show induction of extended duplex formation of DIS stem to loop RNAs at 55 degrees C (10).

0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	77	 3b) or H1 and H2 (data not shown) RNAs.

0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	79	 3b, compare lanes 13 and 14) thereby demonstrating that the observed cleavage products result from the formation of a functional ribozyme as a consequence of extended duplex formation.

0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	102	 The remaining labelling is as described in Figure 3.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	103	  Kissing loop interaction is essential for subsequent extended duplex formation If extended duplex formation is dependent on a preceding kissing complex, mutations that reduce or abolish loop complementarity should affect reaction efficiencies.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	104	 We used the previously described GC1 mutant which lacks four of the six palindromic loop nucleotides (H1GC1, H2GC1 and L1GC1, L2GC1 constructs, Fig.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Compared with wild-type loop sequences, GC1 constructs showed strongly reduced reaction efficiencies but were still capable of forming extended duplexes.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	106	 This is observed at 37 degrees C in the presence of 50 mM MgCl2 as shown with the hammerhead system (Fig.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	107	 4b) as well as at 55 degrees C in the presence of 10 mM MgCl2 as shown with leadzyme RNAs (Fig.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	108	 We also tested combinations of H1 and H2GC1 or H2 and H1GC1 RNAs, which have only two complementary nucleotides in their loops, and the extended dimers of these two combinations contain two unpaired GC pairs.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	109	 These combinations show a strongly reduced capacity to form duplexes compared with the wild type.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	110	 These results indicate that a reduced complementarity is sufficient to induce extended duplex formation, although the stability of the kissing complex influences the efficiency.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	111	To determine whether the complete abolishment of loop to loop complementarity would also abrogate extended duplex formation, the wild-type DIS loop was substituted by six adenosines.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	112	 This construct, termed L1A, is unable to form loop base pairs with L2 RNA.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	113	 By testing dimerisation at 55 degrees C, the L1A/L2 RNAs do not show extended duplex formation at all (Fig.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Therefore, kissing complex formation is an essential prerequisite for extended duplex formation.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	115	Influence of different loop sequences on extended duplex formation Of 64 possible palindromic loop sequences, only two have been found to occur naturally, namely 5'-GCGCGC-3' and 5'-GUGCAC-3' (20).
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	116	 To compare extended duplex formation of the two major HIV-1 subtypes, the AAGCGCGCA sequence of subtype B was substituted with the loop sequence of the other major HIV-1 subtype AGGUGCACA (subtype A).
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	117	 The constructs derived from L1 and L2 were termed L1MAL and L2MAL, respectively.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	118	 The efficiency of extended duplex formation is comparable with that observed for L1 and L2 RNAs, although the activity of the MAL constructs was slightly, but reproducibly less, efficient than the L1 and L2 RNAs with LAI sequences (compare Fig.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	119	View larger version (30K):    Figure 5.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Influence of different loop and apical stem sequences on extended duplex formation.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	121	 (a) Secondary structure representation of L1MAL/L2MAL and L1nsc/L2nsc RNAs (left) and corresponding cleavage rates in dimerisation assays at 55 degrees C (right).
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	122	 (b) Secondary structure of constructs with shorter apical stems (L1s/L2s) derived from L1/L2 (left) and cleavage efficiency following dimerisation assays at 37 or 55 degrees C (right).
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	123	  In order to investigate whether extended duplex formation is possible with non-naturally occurring sequences another set of constructs was designed.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	124	 L1nsc and L2nsc RNAs contain the non-self complementary loop sequences 5'-AAGAGAGGA-3' and 5'-AACUCUCCA-3', respectively (Fig.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	125	 These non-self-complementary sequences are unable to form homodimers, which might interfere with the dimerisation reaction.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Additionally, these RNAs do not have a central GC pair within the complementary hexanucleotide sequence of the loop, which had previously been suggested to be essential for dimerisation (8,9,21).
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	127	 As shown in Figure 5a, extended duplex formation of the nsc constructs is slightly more efficient than that of the MAL constructs.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Therefore, dimerisation can be promoted by kissing complexes formed by sequences other than the wild-type palindromes.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Neither self-complementarity nor the central GC nucleotides are required for the refolding reaction.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	130	Finally, L1MAL and L2nsc RNAs were tested for their ability to form extended duplexes.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	131	 These two constructs are only complementary for two loop bases with four mismatched bases.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	132	 As for the GC1 RNAs, this sequence combination still shows extended duplex formation to some extent although the reaction efficiency is strongly reduced (Fig.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	133	 This demonstrates that the strength of the loop to loop interaction is a key parameter for dimerisation.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	134	Influence of temperature, magnesium concentration and stem length on extended duplex formation As mentioned previously, incubation at 55 degrees C enhances extended duplex formation in various small DIS-like RNAs.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Some of these RNAs with short stems form the extended dimer even at lower temperatures (22).
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	136	 This is not unexpected as extended duplex formation requires opening of all DIS stem base pairs (12 in the case of L1 RNA) so they can then undergo intermolecular base pairing.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	137	 This refolding process represents a kinetic barrier that has to be overcome to establish the thermodynamically more stable extended duplex conformation.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	138	 We wanted to test the effect of higher temperature and of a shortened stem on extended duplex formation as well as the influence of the Mg2+ concentration on duplex formation.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	139	RNAs derived from L1 and L2 constructs (Fig.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	140	 5b) were designed in which 2 bp from the upper DIS stem were deleted.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	141	 These shorter constructs, termed L1s and L2s, were tested at 37 and 55 degrees C for their ability to form the extended duplex.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	142	 At 37 degrees C, both L1/L2 and L1s/L2s show similar behaviour.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	143	 At 55 degrees C we observed a slight but reproducible increase in cleavage efficiency that lies within the error range of the experiments.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Therefore, weakening of the upper stem by only 2 bp is not sufficient to significantly increase the efficiency of extended duplex formation (Fig.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	145	Figure 6a shows that extended duplex formation of L1 and L2 RNAs is enhanced with increasing temperature up to 55 degrees C.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	146	 A strong temperature dependence was also observed for the hammerhead system, which shows complete extended duplex formation at 55 degrees C after 90 min (Fig.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Since at any temperature the known rate constants for ribozyme cleavage far exceed the rates of cleavage observed in our systems, the limiting step appears to be refolding rather than catalysis.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Therefore, temperature-dependent differences in the observed rate constants likely reflect the rate of refolding.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	149	View larger version (14K):    Figure 6.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Influence of external parameters on extended dimer formation.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	151	 (a) Cleavage efficiencies of leadzyme L1/L2 constructs following dimerisation at different temperatures.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Kobs (min to 1) values were plotted against temperature.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	153	 (b) Influence of magnesium concentration on the dimerisation of H1/H2 hammerhead constructs.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Kobs (min to 1) values were plotted against magnesium concentration.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	155	 (c) Influence of added HIV-1 NCp7 protein on extended dimer formation at 37 degrees C.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	156	 L1/L2 or L1A/L2 dimerisation in the absence or presence of the nucleo capsid protein NCp7 or Pb2+.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Quantification of cleavage efficiencies was plotted against time.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	158	  The dependence of extended duplex formation on Mg2+ concentration was tested using the hammerhead system because high Mg2+ concentrations interfere with lead cleavage (data not shown).
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	159	 The optimal Mg2+ concentration for hammerhead ribozyme activity is usually 10 mM MgCl2 (23).
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	160	 We found that extended duplex formation is strongly enhanced by the presence of high Mg2+ concentrations up to 100 mM MgCl2 (Fig.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Mg2+ might stabilise the kissing complex, which would increase the likelihood of subsequent extended duplex formation.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	162	NCp7 strongly accelerates extended duplex formation It has been suggested that NCp7 plays a critical role in HIV genomic RNA maturation.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Indeed, it has been shown that NCp7 is able to convert low stability retroviral RNA dimers into more stable dimers in vitro (24 to 27).
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	164	 NCp7 also catalyses conversion of small DIS-like RNAs ( < 25 nt) into the extended duplex form (14).
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	165	 However, the specificity of this interaction is uncertain since NCp7 also acts as a general nucleic acid chaperone.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	166	 It has been shown to posses nucleic acid annealing and strand exchange activity in vitro (28,29), RNA chaperone activity in vivo (30) and it also accelerates cleavage of the hammerhead ribozyme (19).
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	167	We set out to test whether the NCp7 protein would also enhance extended duplex formation in our system.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	168	 To discriminate between general RNA to RNA annealing activity and a more specific action we used L1 and L2 RNAs but also the combination L1A and L2, which completely lacks loop complementarity.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	169	 As shown in Figure 6c, NCp7 strongly increases extended duplex formation between L1 and L2 RNAs.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Sixty percent of the RNAs are refolded after only 5 min at 37 degrees C compared with 10% in the absence of NCp7 (Fig.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	171	 6c, compare triangles and squares).
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	172	 The reaction levels off to reach 70% completion after 30 min.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	173	 L1A/L2 RNAs, which lack loop complementarity and do not show any extended duplex formation at 55 degrees C in the absence of NCp7, do react in the presence of NCp7.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	174	 We conclude that NCp7 strongly enhances specific extended duplex formation in our system, but to some extent also of RNAs without loop complementarity via its general nucleic acid structure destabilising activity.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	175	Formation of the active ribozyme after refolding of the hairpins into the extended duplex clearly demonstrated the double-stranded nature of the extended dimers.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	176	 Our results further confirm the current model of HIV-1 DIS dimerisation involving refolding of the kissing complex with melting of the stems into a partially double-stranded dimer and rule out a hypothetical mechanism for extended duplex formation involving symmetric cleavage of both chains and subsequent religation (13).
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	177	 From crystal structure data, it was found that the 2' OH group of the second purine residue 5' to the complementary sequence is in favourable position for an in line attack on the neighbouring 3' phosphate.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	178	 A mechanism involving a nucleophilic attack leading to strand scission, followed by a dangling movement of this base and cross religation of both RNAs was proposed.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Such a mechanism would join both DIS stem to loop RNAs within their loop regions keeping the initial stems intact.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	180	 If this were true, both parts of the ribozyme would remain separated from each other and would be unable to form a functional ribozyme.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Our observation that extended duplex formation leads indeed to ribozyme cleavage therefore strongly supports the refolding model with the melting of the stems.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	182	We further show that formation of a kissing complex through interaction of complementary loop nucleotides is an essential prerequisite for extended duplex formation.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	183	 In contrast to previous reports investigating viral RNA dimerisation in vitro, we found that neither self-complementarity nor the central GC pairs within the palindrome are essential for refolding.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	184	 It has been suggested that the central GC pairs are essential for efficient dimerisation in vitro possibly through the involvement in non-canonical base pair interactions by forming a potential nucleation point of the dimer (8,9,21).
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Our results are in accordance with in vitro selection data that show that this dinucleotide favours dimerisation but is not essential (31,32).
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Self-complementarity of the loops is evidently required for viral RNA dimerisation of homologous strands, but apparently not for the refolding process per se.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	187	 These observations are particularly interesting given the fact that only two different loop sequences have been found in HIV-1 isolates, raising the question on the nature of the selective pressure for these two sequences since they can be substituted by other sequences for extended duplex formation in vitro.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	188	 It has been shown that the entire HIV 5' leader RNA can adopt two different conformations, suggesting that sequence conservation might reflect the need to preserve these two structures (33).
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	189	Extended duplex formation was still possible when only partially complementary sequences or sequences with strongly reduced loop complementarity were used.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	190	 This suggests that loop to loop interaction through partial base pairing itself is sufficient for extended duplex formation at 55 degrees C, although full complementarity, as is the case for wild-type loop sequences, strongly enhances the efficiency of the refolding process.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Assuming that reduction of loop complementarity does not affect refolding itself but only reduces kissing complex stability, then the previous findings of Berkhout and van Wamel (5) might be explained.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	192	 These authors reported strongly reduced infectivity when two GC pairs were deleted from the palindrome of HIV-1 LAI subtype; however, purified virions still contained stable dimeric RNA.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	193	 Reduced stability of the kissing complex might lead to a strong impairment of the packaging efficiency, but any loose dimers that happened to be encapsidated were still able to refold, forming stable dimers.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	194	The study on the influence of external parameters on the refolding process revealed that its efficiency is temperature dependent, suggesting that refolding proceeds by the destabilisation of the stems.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Additionally, it could be shown that the presence of magnesium ions enhances extended duplex formation although it is not essential for this process.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	196	 High magnesium concentrations accelerated the reaction in a way that very efficient extended duplex formation could already be observed at 37 degrees C.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	197	 This could be explained by a more efficient stabilisation of the kissing complex than that of the stems.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Indeed, such a strong stabilisation of the kissing complex compared with the stem is observed in the presence of magnesium ions in UV melting experiments (A.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	199	Schroeder, unpublished results).
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	200	Transition from a kissing complex to an extended duplex in vitro is clearly observed at physiological temperatures in the presence of the viral nucleocapsid protein NCp7.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	201	 This small basic 55 amino acid long highly conserved RNA binding protein was reported to have general RNA chaperone activity (19,28).
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	202	 In vivo experiments demonstrated that a viral protease-dependent maturation resulting in the cleavage of the gag precursor to generate nucleocapsid protein is accompanied by conversion of the dimeric RNA particles into a more heat stable dimer (24,34).
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Our data show that NCp7-induced extended duplex formation is extremely efficient compared with the temperature-induced refolding.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	204	 The amount of extended duplex formed by constructs lacking loop complementarity can be explained by the general RNA to RNA annealing activity of NCp7 (19).
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	205	 This might propose a model for how extended duplex formation is promoted by NCp7.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	206	 It is conceivable that NCp7 induces kissing complex formation by its RNA to RNA annealing activity and/or by its helix destabilising activity (29).
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	207	 The kissing interaction might provide a stable and specific interaction surface as a starting point for an efficient refolding.
0.20245472.14602899.html.plaintext.txt	208	 In contrast, it might be the temporal availability and spatial location of NCp7 during the viral maturation cycle that allows it to use its general nucleic acid refolding activity in a specific manner.

0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	0	 1996 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Lipoyl Domain-based Mechanism for the Integrated Feedback Control of the Pyruvate Dehydrogenase Complex by Enhancement of Pyruvate Dehydrogenase Kinase Activity (*).
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	2	(Received for publication, April 10, 1995; and in revised form, August 18, 1995).
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	3	To conserve carbohydrate reserves, the reaction of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDC) must be down-regulated when the citric acid cycle is provided sufficient acetyl-CoA.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	4	 PDC activity is reduced primarily through increased phosphorylation of its pyruvate dehydrogenase (E1) component due to E1 kinase activity being markedly enhanced by elevated intramitochondrial NADH:NAD and acetyl-CoA:CoA ratios.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	5	 A mechanism is evaluated in which enhanced kinase activity is facilitated by the build-up of the reduced and acetylated forms of the lipoyl moieties of the dihydrolipoyl acetyltransferase (E2) component through using NADH and acetyl-CoA in the reverse of the downstream reactions of the complex.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Using a peptide substrate, kinase activity was stimulated by these products, ruling out the possibility kinase activity is increased due to changes in the reaction state of its substrate, E1 (thiamin pyrophosphate).
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Each E2 subunit contains two lipoyl domains, an NH-terminal (L1) and the inward lipoyl domain (L2), which were individually produced in fully lipoylated forms by recombinant techniques.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Although reduction and acetylation of the L1 domain or free lipoamide increased kinase activity, those modifications of the lipoate of the kinase-binding L2 domain gave much greater enhancements of kinase activity.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	9	 The large stimulation of the kinase generated by acetyl-CoA only occurred upon addition of the transacetylase-catalyzing (lipoyl domain-free) inner core portion of E2 plus a reduced lipoate source, affirming that acetylation of this prosthetic group is an essential mechanistic step for acetyl-CoA enhancing kinase activity.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Similarly, the lesser stimulation of kinase activity by just NADH required a lipoate source, supporting the need for lipoate reduction by E3 catalysis.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	11	Complete enzymatic delipoylation of PDC, the E2-kinase subcomplex, or recombinant L2 abolished the stimulatory effects of NADH and acetyl-CoA.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Retention of a small portion of PDC lipoates lowered kinase activity but allowed stimulation of this residual kinase activity by these products.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Reintroduction of lipoyl moieties, using lipoyl protein ligase, restored the capacity of the E2 core to support high kinase activity along with stimulation of that activity up to 3-fold by NADH and acetyl-CoA.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	14	 As suggested by those results, the enhancement of kinase activity is very responsive to reductive acetylation with a half-maximal stimulation achieved with 20% of free L2 acetylated and, from an analysis of previous results, with acetylation of only 3-6 of the 60 L2 domains in intact PDC.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Based on these findings, we suggest that kinase stimulation results from modification of the lipoate of an L2 domain that becomes specifically engaged in binding the kinase.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	16	 In conclusion, kinase activity is attenuated through a substantial range in response to modest changes in the proportion of oxidized, reduced, and acetylated lipoyl moieties of the L2 domain of E2 produced by fluctuations in the NADH:NAD and acetyl-CoA:CoA ratios as translated by the rapid and reversible E3 and E2 reactions.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	17	In mammalian cells, the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDC) ()controls the oxidative utilization of glucose(1) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Flux through this reaction results in a net depletion of body carbohydrate reserves.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The activity of PDC must be reduced when fatty acids or ketone bodies are being preferentially used to provide 2-carbon units for oxidative energy production by citric acid cycle/oxidative phosphorylation systems, a routine situation in many organs.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Furthermore, under conditions of starvation or diabetes, the activity of PDC is reduced to a minimal level to conserve carbohydrates essential for the brain and other specialized tissues/organs.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	21	 To achieve its critical role in cellular fuel conservation, the PDC reaction is controlled primarily by a highly regulated phosphorylation/dephosphorylation cycle which is carried out by dedicated kinase and phosphatase components.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Phosphorylation of the pyruvate dehydrogenase (E1) component inactivates the complex and dephosphorylation reactivates the complex.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	23	Shortly after PDC was shown to be regulated by this interconversion (2) , the capacity of fatty acids and ketone bodies to promote inactivation of PDC was demonstrated in intact tissues (3, 4) and in studies with intact mitochondria(5, 6) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Studies with purified complex (7, 8, 9) and isolated mitochondria (10, 11, 12) found that increases of the PDC reaction products promote an increase in the proportion of PDC in the phosphorylated (inactive) state.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	25	 With purified complex, the activity of the kinase is greatly enhanced upon elevation of the NADH:NAD ratio and the acetyl-CoA:CoA ratio along with a reciprocal reduction in phosphatase activity as the NADH:NAD ratio is elevated(7) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	26	Accordingly, the E1a kinase has a crucial role wherein it throttles down PDC activity in response to increases in the mitochondrial acetylation and reduction potentials.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Not only are NADH and acetyl-CoA produced during mitochondrial oxidation of all fuels, they are direct products of the PDC reaction.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	28	 This laboratory presented evidence that this control of kinase activity initially involves these product to substrate ratios being translated by competitive utilization in the downstream reactions of the complex which, in turn, adjusts the fraction of the complex's lipoyl prosthetic groups in the oxidized versus reduced versus acetylated forms(13, 14, 15, 16, 17) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Specifically, our mechanism proposes that kinase down-regulates PDC activity due to NADH reacting in the reverse of the dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase (E3) reaction and acetyl-CoA reacting in the reverse of the dihydrolipoyl acetyltransferase (E2) reaction.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Typically a 60-80% enhancement in kinase activity occurs upon lipoate reduction and up to a 3-fold enhancement following lipoate acetylation.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	31	 The potential for understanding the molecular basis of this control has greatly improved with new insights into the structure of E2 subunits and the unusual nature of the association of the kinase with E2.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	32	The E2 subunits of mammalian PDC have four domains connected by relatively large (2-3 kDa) and highly mobile linker regions Fig.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Sixty COOH-terminal inner domains (E2) associate to form a dodecahedral inner core which catalyzes the transacetylation reaction.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Each inner domain is connected to 3 globular domains by linker or hinge regions.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	35	 The globular domains consist of two 10-kDa lipoyl domains (E2 and E2, or L1 and L2) and an E1-binding domain (E2) located between the inner core and the lipoyl domain region.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	36	Figure 1: Domain structure of the dihydrolipoyl acetyltransferase (E2) component and interactions with the kinase and E1 components.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	37	 E2 has four globular domains consisting of an NH-terminal lipoyl domain, L1, an inner lipoyl domain, L2, an E1 binding domain, and a core-forming, transacetylase-catalyzing inner domain at the COOH-terminal end(18, 19, 20) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	38	 The kinase binds to the L2 domain by a domain-specific and lipoyl prosthetic group-requiring interaction(26) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	39	 E1, an tetramer, binds to the B domain of E2 via its -subunit (18) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	40	The subunits of E1a kinases of PDC and the branched-chain -keto acid dehydrogenase complex are related to procaryotic histidine kinases but not to the extramitochondrial serine and tyrosine kinases of eukaryotes(21, 22, 23) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	41	 PDC kinase binds to the lipoyl domain region of E2 through an association that requires the lipoyl prosthetic group(24, 25, 26) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Using lipoylated and delipoylated forms of recombinant L1 and L2 of human PDC-E2(27) , the kinase was shown to bind preferentially to the lipoylated L2 (Fig.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	43	 The E1a kinase was also shown to interchange rapidly between L2 structures(26) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	44	 To account for tight binding and rapid interchange, a dynamic ``hand over hand'' mechanism is proposed in which a dimeric kinase alternates between being bound to one and two L2 domains.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	45	 This interchange and catalytic function of the kinase exert their combined effects in the limited space at the surface of the complex where the a kinase molecule and many E1 components are tightly bound to the mobile outer domains of E2.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The capacity of continuously bound kinase to phosphorylate bound E1 components more rapidly than free kinase can phosphorylate free E1 is termed E2-activated kinase function.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	47	The aim of this work is to determine the compulsory components, domains, and catalytic processes involved in kinase stimulation by NADH and acetyl-CoA, and to evaluate the relative capacities of the recombinant L1 and L2 in mediating the stimulation of kinase in the presence or absence of E2-activated kinase function.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	48	 We have found that stimulation occurs with a peptide substrate of the kinase; that a lipoyl source must be available for catalytic reduction by E3 or acetylation by E2; that the L2 lipoyl domain is much more effective in mediating kinase stimulation than the L1 domain; and that the kinase is remarkably sensitive to the level of acetylation of L2.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	49	 The ``Discussion'' integrates these observations and draws new mechanistic conclusions based on these and previous results.

0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Since removal of lipoyl groups has a disproportionately low effect on PDC activity at early stages, delipoylation is analyzed more accurately by determining changes in acetylation capacity (above).

0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	132	E1, E1-TPP, and Peptide SubstratesThe requirements for NADH and acetyl-CoA stimulation of E1 kinase activity were evaluated via phosphorylating various substrates using the E2XK1K2 subcomplex as a source of kinase activity.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	133	 As in assays below, NAD and NADH were used at a 1:3 ratio to prevent inhibition of E3 by its conversion to the 4 e-reduced state.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	134	 At this ratio, kinase activity is near maximally stimulated by NADH and maximally stimulated by the combination of NADH and acetyl-CoA.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	135	 We used an E1 preparation that gave  < 1% activity in a PDC reaction mixture lacking TPP.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	136	 As shown in Table 1, kinase activity was stimulated 50% by NADH and nearly 2-fold by the combination of NADH and acetyl-CoA in the phosphorylation of E1 whether or not E1 contained TPP cofactor.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	137	 As expected(37) , kinase activity was reduced by TPP.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	138	 However, the stimulation has been due to reversing the inhibitory effect of TPP or activation via the formation of a reaction intermediate on E1 (e.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	139	 hydroxyethylidenethiamin pyrophosphate formed from acetyl-lipoate by E2).
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	140	Table 1also shows that E1 can be replaced by peptide substrate so the stimulations are not dependent on changes in E1(38) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	141	 ()This is consistent with the observation of Reed et al.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	142	(40) that kinase stimulation occurs with tryptic digestion of PDC.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Such PDC digestion produces a complex mixture of lipoyl domains, the catalytic inner core of E2 and the trypsin-resistant E3, all of which are required for kinase stimulation (see below).
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	144	Because some stimulation by acetyl-CoA is detected in the absence of NADH, the level of incorporation of covalently attached acetyl groups from [1-C]acetyl-CoA was determined in the presence or absence of unlabeled ATP under the conditions of kinase assays (Table 1).
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Without NADH, exposure to submillimolar levels of dithiothreitol allows acetylation of a small portion of the lipoyl groups by acetyl-CoA.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	146	 The low stimulation of kinase that occurs in conjunction with the low level of acetylation in the absence of NADH agrees with previous studies (15, 16, 17) (cf.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Thus, our results eliminate the possibility that kinase stimulation is due to changes in the form of TPP interacting with the E1 substrate but they are consistent with the participation of lipoyl prosthetic groups.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	148	Pyruvate StimulationStimulation by pyruvate was first reported by Cooper et al.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Support for this stimulation occurring via reductive-acetylation of lipoyl moieties stems from the findings that adding low levels of pyruvate to TPP-containing PDC generates an increased kinase activity equivalent to that with NADH plus acetyl-CoA and that pyruvate is principally used in the reductive acetylation of oxidized lipoyl groups(13, 14, 15) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	150	 This mechanism for kinase stimulation predicts some TPP bound to E1 and a lipoyl domain source are required.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Using a resolved TPP-dependent E1 preparation, containing low levels of kinase activity but completely free of E2, the kinase activity was not significantly enhanced by pyruvate and/or lipoyl domain in the absence of TPP (Table 2).
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Even in the presence of TPP, pyruvate failed to stimulate kinase activity with E1 unless lipoyl domains were added.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Furthermore, a fragment of bovine E2 that contains both lipoyl domains (designated E2) was effective.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	154	 The results are thus consistent with the view that the enhancement of kinase activity is mediated by the E1(TPP)-catalyzed acetylation of the E2 fragment.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Furthermore, a very low level of E2 fragment (1  microM) was effective.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	156	 This is below the level that gave a small enhancement of the kinase (up to 40%)(25) , suggesting a specific and possibly a stronger interaction of the kinase with acetylated-E2.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	157	Lipoamidase Treatment of PDCThe proposed mechanism of lipoyl-mediated enhancement of kinase activity predicts that complete removal of lipoyl groups would abolish kinase stimulation.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Lipoyl groups were removed by treatment of PDC, E2XK1K2 subcomplex, or isolated lipoyl domains with E.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	159	 The enhancement in kinase activity by the E2 component (in the absence of effectors) declines rapidly as the last portion of lipoyl groups is removed and the kinase tends to dissociate from E2(24) .

0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	263	Direct Product Inhibition of the PDC ReactionThe mechanism of product inhibition of PDC under low salt conditions (43) and the effects of higher ionic strengths on the PDC reaction have been characterized(44) .

0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	267	2 () in the absence of NADH and at 3.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	268	55 in combination with a fixed NADH:NAD ratio of 0.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	269	 The strongest direct product inhibition of PDC was found with a half-maximal effect at a low NADH:NAD ratio of 0.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	270	125 when the acetyl-CoA:CoA ratio was held at 1 (Fig.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	271	 However, near-maximal stimulation of the kinase to switch off bovine kidney PDC occurs with an NADH:NAD ratio of 0.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	272	1 at a 10-fold lower acetyl-CoA:CoA ratio.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	273	 We conclude that much higher ratios of products to substrates are required for direct product inhibition of bovine kidney PDC than for speeding PDC inactivation by enhancing kinase activity (cf.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	274	Randle and co-workers (45, 46) pointed out the importance of feedback control of PDC in satisfying metabolic needs and presented evidence for direct product inhibition of the PDC reaction.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	275	 After regulatory interconversion of PDC between active and inactive forms (2) became known, Randle's laboratory contributed to evidence (cf.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	276	 Introduction) that the products of PDC reaction influence the proportion of PDC in the active form, through diverse studies with purified complex isolated mitochondria, and intact tissues (1, 8, 9, 47) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	277	 In their studies with purified porcine heart PDC, no stimulation by acetyl-CoA beyond that of NADH was detected, and they speculated that enhanced kinase activity might be due to the removal of an inhibition of kinase activity caused by the absence of an interaction between oxidized lipoate and the E1 substrate (8, 9) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	278	 Although not the correct mechanism and detection of an effect of acetyl-CoA required use of higher K concentration (see below), the suggestion of a role for changes in the intermediate status of lipoyl groups was insightful as was their linking of the stimulatory effect of pyruvate (41) to the effect of products(9) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	279	 This laboratory presented the initial and much subsequent evidence that reduction and acetylation of lipoyl prosthetic groups of PDC constituted essential steps in the operation of a sensitive signal translation process whereby increases in the NADH:NAD and acetyl-CoA:CoA ratios markedly enhance kinase activity(13, 14, 15, 16, 17) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	280	 However, elucidation of the minimal requirements for the operation of this control could be accomplished only following a greatly enhanced understanding of the organization of the complex, the preparation of individual lipoyl domains of PDC-E2, and the availability of lipoamidase and lipoyl protein ligase, combined with the selective use of peptide substrate and free forms of lipoamide.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	281	Using these tools, we have found that the marked enhancement of kinase activity by acetyl-CoA requires a lipoate source and its reduction, the catalytic domain of E2, and a peptide substrate.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	282	 These requirements conclusively support a change in the kinase mediated by catalytically forming acetyl-dihydrolipoate.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	283	 Accumulation of this intermediate explains the similarly strong stimulation of kinase activity by low pyruvate via E1(TPP) catalysis.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	284	 The direct stimulation by dihydrolipoamide, its capacity to replace NADH in potentiating acetyl-CoA stimulation, and the complete lack of an effect of NADH on kinase activity in the absence of a lipoate source strongly favor NADH boosting kinase activity through its use in the E3 reaction.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	285	 We have established that this intervention is abolished by complete removal of lipoates from intact E2 subunits or lipoyl domains.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	286	 Of particular importance for understanding the operation and regulation of the kinase is our finding that the kinase-binding L2 domain is much more effective than E2's L1 domain or lipoamide in mediating kinase stimulation.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	287	 The 3-fold increase in kinase activity generated by reductive acetylation of recombinant L2 is comparable to the change in kinase activity produced by acetylation of lipoyl moieties in the intact complex.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	288	 Reduced L1 was only slightly more effective than free dihydrolipoamide when compared at 20  microM, and 50  microM dihydrolipoamide gave at least an equivalent stimulation, suggesting the structure of L1 does not contribute significantly to these effects.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	289	 At higher levels L1 inhibits kinase activity(26) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	290	 Thus, the L2 domain must have structural features that facilitate its dedicated roles in binding the kinase, producing enhanced E1 phosphorylation within the confines of the complex, and further increasing kinase activity upon reduction and acetylation of its lipoyl group.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	291	 This raises the question of the linkage between these L2-supported actions of the kinase.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	292	Detaching lipoates of the E2 core removes the capacity of the E2 core to give a severalfold increase in E1 phosphorylation(24) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	293	 Via lipoyl-dependent binding to the L2 domain, rapid ``hand over hand'' interchange of a kinase dimer between lipoyl domains apparently eliminates constraints normally associated with binding that is as tight as exists between E2 and the kinase(25, 26) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	294	 It is significant that a lipoamidase treatment of PDC, which left only a few lipoates and caused close to full loss of this E2-enhanced kinase function, still allowed marked stimulation of the residual kinase activity upon acetylation of those few domains retaining lipoyl groups (PDC series in Fig.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	295	 This result forcefully suggests that the kinase has moved to the limited number of lipoylated L2 domains and, furthermore, that their acetylation (during a short-lived dissociation and reassociation of the kinase) facilitated kinase stimulation.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	296	 Based on this continued stimulation when very few E2 subunits retain lipoate, we hypothesize that maximal effector stimulation is mediated by an allosteric effect induced by a reductively acetylated L2 domain that becomes engaged in binding of the kinase (i.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	297	 not by interaction of an acetylated prosthetic group on a neighboring lipoyl domain that is not engaged in binding the kinase).
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	298	 Such a highly specific interaction is further supported below.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	299	Beside E1 catalyzed reductive-acetylation giving a nearly equivalent stimulation to acetyl-CoA(13, 14, 15) , -ketobutyrate (38) gives a lesser stimulation similar to that of propionyl-CoA at low levels of propionylation(16) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	300	 In the absence of a lipoyl domain source, kinase phosphorylation of E1 is not stimulated at low pyruvate ((17) , miniprint section); and here we show that TPP and a lipoyl domain source are needed to achieve pyruvate stimulation.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	301	 These findings raise the question as to whether the E1 reaction or the downstream (E2,E3) reactions determine the relative proportion of lipoates in the oxidized, reduced and acetylated forms in the complex.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	302	 Since E1 catalyzes the rate-limiting step(35, 36) , under most metabolic conditions, this distribution should be determined by the NADH:NAD and the acetyl-CoA:CoA ratios and kinase activity should primarily respond to their fluctuation.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	303	With purified porcine liver and bovine kidney PDC, half-maximal stimulations of kinase activities occur at ratios of NADH:NAD of 0.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	304	05, respectively, and, with 2 mM dithiothreitol as a reducing agent, at ratios of acetyl-CoA:CoA of 0.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	305	 Even lower acetyl-CoA:CoA ( < 0.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	306	1) give half-maximal stimulation when a NADH:NAD ratio of 0.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	307	1 is provided to reduce lipoates (data not shown).
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	308	 At these low ratios, there is minimal product inhibition of the PDC reaction by NADH plus acetyl-CoA (cf.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	309	 Significant direct product inhibition occurs with low NADH:NAD ratio when the acetyl-CoA:CoA ratio was held at a relatively high level of 1 (Fig.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	310	 Acetyl-CoA:CoA ratios have been generated at and above this range with isolated mitochondria and are proposed to contribute to direct PDC inhibition (48) ; depletion of CoA may also inhibit PDC due to buildup of fatty acyl-CoAs(49) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	311	 While these probably contribute to a fine tuning role on a small portion of active PDC, enhanced phosphorylation should effectively throttle down PDC activity before onset of these extremes.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	312	A priori, the lesser enhancement of kinase activity by just the conversion of lipoates from the oxidized to the reduced form could involve either removal of an inhibitory interaction of oxidized lipoates, an enhancement of kinase activity by gain of a positive allosteric interaction of the reduced form, or a change in the thiol disulfide state of a kinase subunit.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	313	 Studies with E2-bound kinase found that the kinase is sensitive to thiol reagents(13, 52) , effects probably due to changes in the oxidation-reduction state of the lipoate of L2 domains.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	314	 Although there is a small increase in alkylation of cysteines of the K1 subunit following treatment of E2Xkinase-E3 with NADH, this was not rapidly reversed by excess NAD which opposes kinase stimulation.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	315	 ()Thus, a mediator role for changes in the thiol-disulfide status of the kinase is not indicated.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	316	 Furthermore, our finding that free dihydrolipoamide and to a greater extent acetylated dihydrolipoamide directly stimulated kinase activity in the absence of a lipoyl domain source, eliminating the prospect that stimulation results from removal of an inhibitory effect by the oxidized form of lipoate.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	317	 9, we conclude that kinase activity is enhanced through direct positive allosteric interactions of the reduced or the acetylated form of an L2 lipoate and we further suggest that L2 specificity derives from the L2 domain engaged in binding the kinase.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	318	Figure 9: Model of proposed steps in kinase stimulation.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	319	 The proportion of L2 domains of the E core having oxidized, reduced, or acetylated lipoates responds to changes in the NADH:NAD ratio and acetyl-CoA:CoA ratio via the rapid and reversible reactions catalyzed by E3 and E2, respectively.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	320	 Our model proposes that a change from the kinase binding to one or two L2 containing only oxidized lipoate (nonstimulated K state) to interacting with an L2 containing a reduced or an acetylated lipoate results in the modified lipoates allosterically inducing conformational changes that generate the progressively more active K* or K** states, respectively.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	321	Consistent with stimulation occurring at low ratios of acetyl-CoA to CoA, half-maximal and near-maximal stimulation of kinase associated with the intact bovine kidney PDC are achieved with only 7-10 and 22-26 acetyl groups incorporated, respectively, per PDC(15, 16, 17) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	322	 With the recent knowledge that there are 3 lipoyl domains, two on E2 and one on the E3-binding protein giving a total of at least 126 lipoates per E2, ()it seems likely that no more than 12 and possibly as few as 7 acetyl groups are incorporated per PDC into the kinase-binding L2 domain for near-maximal stimulation, and as few as 3 and no more than 6 are incorporated for half-maximal stimulation.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	323	 ()This constitutes a highly responsive regulatory mechanism in which the kinase must preferentially interact with acetylated L2 and suggests that full stimulation may result from only one subunit of a kinase dimer interacting with a reductively acetylated L2 domain.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	324	 Consistent with this prospect, half-maximal stimulation occurred with free L2 when only 20% of the L2 are acetylated.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	325	 Although a much higher portion was found than estimated (above) for the intact complex, very different conditions are operative at the outer surface of the complex where lipoyl domains are concentrated at 1 mM, making the localized L2 level at least 50-fold higher than the highest level of free L2 used in the present work.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	326	 Interaction of the kinase with acetylated-L2 would be aided by steady state turnover in the overall PDC reaction rapidly changing the location of acetyl groups within the multienzyme cluster.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	327	 Kinase shuffling between L2 domains may also contribute, but this is needed, regardless, since acetylation by acetyl-CoA requires an unhindered lipoate(50, 51) , and the kinase must interact after L2 acetylation.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	328	 We conclude that increased reductive-acetylation is very effective in activating kinase due to this preferred interaction of acetylated L2 altering the structure of the kinase and thereby increasing kinase activity (Fig.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	329	In being stimulated, kinase kinetic properties must fundamentally change since stimulation occurs over a wide range of rates (e.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	330	 even with a peptide substrate that is slowly phosphorylated) and in the absence of kinase movement on the surface of the E2 core.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	331	 Previous studies demonstrated that stimulation of the kinase requires physiological levels of potassium salts(7, 14, 53) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	332	 Increasing K from low (0-10 mM) to higher levels (90-120 mM) leads to a marked inhibition of kinase activity and a gain in the capacity for NADH and acetyl-CoA stimulation.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	333	 Another property of the kinase that changes with increasing K ion is that ADP inhibition markedly increases(55) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	334	 A potential mechanism is that interaction of the kinase with an L2 domain containing an acetyl-dihydrolipoate leads to a conformational change in the kinase that speeds up ADP dissociation, which is probably the rate-limiting step in the kinase reaction at elevated (physiological) K levels.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	335	 Consistent with that prospect are the observation that acetylation causes a greater stimulation of ADP-inhibited kinase (13) and the evidence that kinase-ADP is a prominent reaction intermediate, since pyruvate effectively inhibits by binding to the kinase-ADP in the absence of free ADP(56) .
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	336	 For this mechanism to be correct, it must operate in conjunction with the slow rate of phosphorylation of peptide substrate, a particularly useful system for testing this mechanism.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	337	 Further studies will be needed to define the structural changes that attenuate the kinase through changes in L2's lipoyl group and to determine how the K1 and K2 subunits of the kinase vary in their regulatory control.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	338	In conclusion, our results strongly support E3-catalyzed reduction and E2-catalyzed acetylation of lipoyl moiety of the kinase binding inner (L2) domain of E2 mediating a marked enhancement in kinase activity.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	339	 The effectiveness in intact PDC of acetylating a low proportion of L2 domains in enhancing the phosphorylation of many bound E1 by a single tightly bound kinase molecule is probably accomplished by inter-L2 domain movement of the kinase combined with a stronger interaction of the kinase with acetylated L2 domains.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	340	 Several studies on kinase function and regulation are consistent with a change in a K-requiring process ultimately occurring in kinase stimulation.
0.2066687.8557670.html.plaintext.txt	341	 A candidate mechanism involves counteracting K-strengthened ADP binding to the kinase to speed up slow dissociation of this product from the active site of the kinase.

0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	0	Mutation of Interfacial Residues Disrupts Subunit Folding and Particle Assembly of Physalis mottle tymovirus* Mahadevaiah Umashankar, Mathur R.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the  Department of Biochemistry and the   Molecular Biophysics Unit, Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore 560 012, India.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received for publication, August 6, 2002, and in revised form, December 6, 2002.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	3	Physalis mottle tymovirus (PhMV)1 is a small spherical plant virus consisting of a single-stranded, plus-sense RNA genome with a size of 6.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	4	 The RNA genome is encapsidated in a protein shell comprising 180 chemically identical coat protein (CP) subunits (20,000 Da) arranged in icosahedral symmetry.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Depending on the bonding interactions, the subunits are designated as A, B, and C (2).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	6	 The A-type subunits form pentamers at the 5-fold, and the B and C subunits form hexamers at the 3-fold icosahedral axes.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	7	 The protein subunits are held by strong protein-protein interactions.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	8	Materials-- [-32P]dATP was obtained from PerkinElmer Life Sciences.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Restriction endonucleases and the SequenaseTM Version 2 DNA sequencing kit were obtained from Amersham Biosciences.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Deep Vent DNA polymerase, DpnI, and Ni-NTA agarose were obtained from New England Biolabs and Qiagen, respectively.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Ampicillin, isopropyl-1-thio--D-galactopyranoside, Coomassie Brilliant Blue R-250, and ultra-pure urea were obtained from USB.

0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	197	Thermal Stability of Mutant rCPs-- The partially folded nature of the mutant rCPs was further assessed by monitoring the effect of temperature on the molar ellipticity at 222 nm of the wild type and the mutant rCPs.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	198	 The wild type rCP and S145A capsids exhibited a Tm of 88 and 83  degrees C, respectively (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Q37E, Y67A, and R68Q mutant rCPs did not show a discrete transition, whereas the D83A and I123A mutant rCPs showed a broad transition between 50 and 70  degrees C (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	200	 These results further emphasize the conformational flexibility in these mutant rCPs.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	201	We have resorted to the molecular biology approach to decipher the roles of specific amino acids in the formation of capsids of PhMV.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Earlier studies by site-directed mutagenesis have shown the presence of a 19.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	203	4 S intermediate in the assembly/disassembly pathway (8).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	204	 In this study, we have carried out a structure-based mutagenesis of six residues, namely Gln-37, Tyr-67, Arg-68, Asp-83, Ile-123, and Ser-145, which are predominantly involved in inter-subunit interactions.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Except for S145A, all of the other mutant rCPs failed to assemble into T = 3 capsids, although they were found to be soluble (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Furthermore, these mutant proteins are partially folded, as evidenced by the following: (i) gel filtration elution behavior (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	207	 2); (ii) the presence of secondary structure as shown by far UV CD (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	208	 3); (iii) the lack of a sharp transition in thermal denaturation as shown by CD (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	209	 8); (iv) persistent high levels of innate fluorescence due to the single tryptophan present in the protein (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	210	 4); (v) lack of discrete unfolding transition upon denaturation with urea (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	211	 5); (vi) accessibility of tryptophan residue in the mutants as measured by fluorescence quenching with acrylamide and potassium iodide (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	212	 6); (vii) enhanced fluorescence of ANS in the presence of mutant proteins (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	213	 7); and (viii) the lack of a sharp structural transition in ANS binding experiments in the presence of urea (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Thus, the mutation of residues involved in extensive inter-subunit interactions affect both the subunit folding and particle assembly of PhMV.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	215	 A detailed analysis of the position of the residues mutated and the probable consequence of the mutation on the folding and assembly is presented below.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	216	Gln-37 is conserved in all of the tymoviruses and is present at hydrogen-bonding distance to the conserved glycines 113 and 114 and leucine 109, respectively, at the A-A5 interface (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	217	 Gln-37 also interacts with Gly-113 and Leu-109 at B5-C interface and with Asn-188 at C-C2 contacts (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	218	 This residue does not seem to interact with any of the residues within the subunit.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	219	 The mutation of Gln-37 to Glu should therefore have disrupted only the inter-subunit interactions.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Replacement of Gln with Glu in the structure using the molecular modeling software program "O" showed that there are no short contacts and also that all the interactions of Gln-37 can be retained by Glu.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	221	 However, it introduces a negative charge in the dense interface of subunits.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	222	 The results presented here demonstrate that the mutation of Gln-37, which is involved in multiple inter-subunit interactions, also affects the proper folding of the subunit.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Probably, the negative charge introduced somehow interferes in the folding.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	224	View larger version (51K):    Fig.

0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	242	 The A, B, and C subunits are colored in green, blue, and red, respectively.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	243	Arg-68, another conserved residue in all tymoviruses, is at hydrogen-bonding distance with Asp-136, Ser-137, and Val-138 at the A-B interface and is involved in a salt bridge with Asp-150 at the B-C interface (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	244	 This residue does not have any obvious intra-subunit interactions.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	245	 The replacement of Arg with Gln can be done without short contact within the same subunit.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	246	 However, its mutation to Gln led to the partially folded and assembly-incompetent protein.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	247	 These results further support the observation that the mutation of residues involved in multiple inter-subunit interactions disrupts subunit folding and particle assembly.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Even here, the uncompensated negative charge might interfere in the folding of the protein.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	249	Asp-83 and Ile-123, although not conserved among all tymoviruses, are involved in extensive interactions with residues from the other subunits (Fig.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	250	 The mutation of these two residues to alanine also led to the partially folded proteins that were assembly-incompetent.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	251	Tyr-67 is also conserved across the tymovirus group.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	252	 It is involved not only in inter-subunit interactions at C-C2 and B5-A, but also in intra-subunit hydrogen-bonding interactions.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Its mutation to alanine disrupts the hydrogen-bonding interaction at the quasi-2-fold axis.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	254	 This creates a cavity in the vicinity of residues Leu-34, Leu-63, Leu-180, and Ile-32.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	255	 This may have a destabilizing effect on the same subunit, which could hinder proper folding of the subunit.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Hence, its mutation to Ala led to the misfolding of the subunits and the consequent arrest of assembly.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	257	Interestingly, the tertiary structure of the partially folded mutant proteins is similar to that of the rCP capsids (Figs.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	258	 The single tryptophan residue, Trp-96, is located inside the -barrel, and its mutation led to soluble aggregates defective in folding and assembly (8).
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Furthermore, this Trp is not an interfacial residue.
0.20710783.12477730.html.plaintext.txt	260	 Therefore, it is possible that the partially folded mutant rCPs and the wild type rCP have similar accessibility to this tryptophan.

0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	0	The cytoplasmic tail of herpes simplex virus envelope glycoprotein D binds to the tegument protein VP22 and to capsids Jung Hee I.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Harley, Aparna Mukhopadhyay and Duncan W.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	2	Department of Developmental and Molecular Biology, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, 1300 Morris Park Avenue, Bronx, NY 10461, USA.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	3	Present address: Pfizer Global Research and Development, Groton Laboratories, Eastern Point Road, Groton, CT 06430, USA.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	4	It is generally agreed that HSV capsids acquire their final tegument and envelope in the cytoplasm.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	5	 However, the molecular mechanism of HSV-1 envelopment in the cytoplasm is poorly characterized.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	6	 During infection, viral membrane glycoproteins are expressed and traffic via cytoplasmic organelles to the cell surface.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Several lines of evidence suggest that the cytosolic domains of these glycoproteins may provide a platform for tegument assembly and recruitment of capsids followed by envelopment (Mettenleiter, 2002).
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	8	 In a recent study, a double mutant of pseudorabies virus (PrV) lacking viral glycoproteins gM and gE (or gM and the cytoplasmic tail of gE) showed a failure in envelopment, instead accumulating cytoplasmic nucleocapsids immersed in a dense layer of tegument (Brack et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Following single deletion of either glycoprotein, the production of infectious virions was not affected, suggesting that the cytoplasmic tails of gE and gM act in a redundant fashion during assembly, most likely interacting with the tegument proteins and, indirectly, with the surface of nucleocapsids.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	10	 In HSV-1, simultaneous deletion of the same two glycoproteins did not dramatically affect production of infectious virions (Browne et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	11	, 2004), although simultaneous deletion of gD and gE resulted in a striking defect in particle assembly (Farnsworth et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	12	 This apparent redundancy makes analysis of specific glycoprotein to tegument interactions difficult to perform in vivo.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	13	 To overcome this obstacle, we developed a glutathione S-transferase (GST) fusion protein-binding assay to investigate the interaction between envelope glycoprotein tails and tegument partners in vitro.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	14	 This approach has previously been used to demonstrate the interaction between the cytoplasmic tail of glycoprotein H (gH) and the tegument component VP16 (Gross et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	15	 In the current study, we focused on analysing the tail of the glycoprotein D (gD) because it is a highly abundant component of the envelope (Spear  and  Roizman, 1972) with a short cytoplasmic tail of 30 amino acid residues that can easily be manipulated in mutagenesis studies.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Moreover, it has been shown to play a key, albeit redundant, role in assembly (Farnsworth et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Additionally, Pomeranz  and  Blaho (1999) reported that gD co-localizes with at least one tegument protein, VP22, during infection.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	18	We prepared GST fusion proteins that contained the cytoplasmic tail of gD or mutants thereof at their carboxy terminus.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Following binding of the GST fusion proteins to glutathione to Sepharose beads and incubation with HSV-infected cell extracts, these fusion proteins were tested for their ability to interact with tegument proteins.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Here we report that the cytoplasmic tail of gD bound to the tegument protein VP22 in a manner that was independent of other viral polypeptides.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Additionally, our results indicated that VP22 may be one of the tegument components that mediate the interaction between the cytoplasmic tail of gD and the HSV capsid.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	22	Expression of GST fusion proteins.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Appropriate expression plasmids were transformed into Escherichia coli strain BL21 (Stratagene).
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Overnight stationary-phase cultures were used to inoculate fresh medium the following day to an OD600 of 0 2 and cultures were grown on a shaker to an OD600 of 0 9.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	25	 IPTG was added to the cells to a concentration of 1 mM to induce expression of the fusion protein.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	26	 After 3 h, cells were collected by centrifugation at 8000 r.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	27	 for 10 min at 4  degrees C in a JA20 rotor, the medium was discarded and the pellet was frozen at  to 20  degrees C overnight.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	28	 The following day, the pellet was thawed and resuspended in lysis buffer (0 05 % Tween 20, 50 mM EDTA, 1 mM PMSF, 5  microg aprotinin ml to 1, 5  microg leupeptin ml to 1 and 1 mg lysozyme ml to 1 in PBS) and sonicated using a probe sonicator six times for 10 s each, with 30 s intervals on ice.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Debris and unbroken cells were pelleted at 10 000 r.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	30	 for 10 min at 4  degrees C in a JA20 rotor.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Supernatants were subjected to SDS-PAGE and stained with Coomassie blue to visualize the fusion proteins.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	32	Preparation of HSV-1-infected cell extracts.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Confluent monolayers of COS cells were infected with HSV-1 strain SC16 at an m.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	34	 of 10 in DMEM with 10 % fetal bovine serum (FBS) and 1 % penicillin/streptomycin (PS).
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	35	 After 1 h, fresh medium was added and the incubation proceeded for an additional 18 h at 37  degrees C.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Cells were collected and a post-nuclear supernatant (PNS) was prepared as previously described (Harley et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Briefly, cells were washed twice with cold homogenization buffer (0 25 M sucrose, 2 mM MgCl2, 10 mM Tris/HCl pH 7 6), scraped, pelleted at 1000 g for 5 min at 4  degrees C and resuspended in 1 ml homogenization buffer containing 5  microg leupeptin ml to 1, 5  microg aprotinin ml to 1 and 1 mM PMSF.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Cells were broken by passing through a 25 gauge 5/8 inch needle eight times and then spun at 2000 g for 10 min at 4  degrees C to remove unbroken cells and nuclei.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	39	 The PNS was adjusted to 150 mM NaCl, 0 5 % NP-40, 50 mM Tris/HCl pH 7 6, incubated for 1 h on ice to solubilize tegument proteins and centrifuged at 53 000 r.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	40	 The supernatant (S100) was aliquotted and frozen at  to 70  degrees C.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	41	Production of radiolabelled VP22.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	42	 A VP22/myc to His-encoding plasmid (Invitrogen) and Redivue [35S]methionine were added to the TNT Rabbit Reticulocyte Lysate in vitro transcription/translation system (Promega) following the manufacturer's protocol.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	43	 The resulting in vitro-translated VP22 was mixed with PBS containing 5  microg leupeptin ml to 1 and 5  microg antipain ml to 1 and incubated with GST fusion protein-coated glutathione to Sepharose beads as described below.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Material bound to the beads was subjected to SDS-PAGE and the gel treated with 30 % methanol, 10 % acetic acid for 30 min, En3Hance (NEN Life Sciences Products) for 1 h and 1 % glycerol for 30 min.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	45	 The gel was then dried using a Bio-Rad gel drier and exposed to film for 1 to 2 days.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	46	Preparation of [3H]thymidine-labelled capsids.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Prior to infection, confluent monolayers of COS cells were overlaid with DMEM containing 1 % dialysed FBS and 1 % PS for 2 h and then infected with HSV-1 strain SC16 at an m.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	48	 After 1 h, fresh medium with [3H]thymidine (NEN) was added to a final concentration of 25  microCi ml to 1 and incubated for 18 h.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Cells were harvested as above, and a PNS was prepared and adjusted to a final concentration of 2 5 mM magnesium acetate, 50 mM potassium acetate, 150 mM NaCl, 0 5 % Triton X-100 and 5 mM DTT and incubated on ice for 1 h.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	50	 The treatment removed the membranes and solubilized some of the tegument associated with the cytoplasmic virions.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Following incubation, debris was removed by a clearing spin at 1500 g.

0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	91	  Binding of the tegument protein VP22 to the gD fusion protein To prepare a source of tegument polypeptides for the binding assay, we followed the methodology previously described for isolating HSV-1-containing organelles and putative assembly intermediates from the cytoplasm of HSV-1-infected cells (Harley et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	92	 PNS from HSV-infected COS cells was first treated with NP-40 and NaCl to solubilize the viral structural proteins, as we have previously found many tegument polypeptides to be insoluble in the PNS, perhaps due to their incorporation into assembling virions.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	93	 The detergent-solubilized extract was then incubated with glutathione to Sepharose beads to which had previously been bound equivalent amounts of GST, gDc or gHc, a fusion protein of the viral gH tail with GST that has been well characterized by our laboratory (Gross et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Bound and unbound material was then resolved by SDS-PAGE, Western blotted and analysed by probing with various antibodies.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	95	 1(c) shows binding of the tegument protein VP22 to the GST to gD fusion protein.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	96	 VP22 remained mostly in the unbound fraction when incubated with GST alone, suggesting that the binding was tail specific.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	97	 To test the specificity of binding further, we also examined the association of other abundant cellular and viral proteins with the gD tail.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	98	 The cellular protein -tubulin and the abundant capsid scaffold proteins Pra and ICP35 failed to bind to the gD and gH tails, indicating that the glycoprotein tails do not bind these cellular and viral proteins non-specifically: VP22 bound to the gD tail but not to the gH tail.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	99	 We also observed that gD bound the tegument protein VP16 in a manner similar to gH.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	100	 This was consistent with a previous study by Zhu  and  Coutney (1994), which demonstrated that VP16 could be cross-linked to both gD and gH in purified virions.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	101	Binding of VP22 to the gD tail is independent of other viral proteins The interaction between VP22 and gD may be direct or mediated by other viral proteins.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	102	 To examine this question, we used a rabbit reticulocyte lysate in vitro transcription/translation system to generate 35S-labelled VP22 and added it to our in vitro GST-binding assay.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Autoradiography showed that in vitro-translated VP22 (running at a molecular mass of 45 kDa) bound to the gD tail (Fig.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Since the rabbit reticulocyte lysate contained only the in vitro-translated VP22 and no other viral proteins, we could conclude that VP22 binding did not require any other viral polypeptides.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Although we could not discount the possibility that a cellular polypeptide in the reticulocyte lysate mediated the gD to VP22 interaction, no host protein with the abundance of VP22 has ever been described in the HSV particle.

0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	114	Alanine-scanning mutagenesis of the gD cytoplasmic tail To simplify the identification of amino acids within the gD cytoplasmic tail that play an important role in VP22 binding, we generated a truncation mutant of the tail that retained only the most amino-terminal 17 residues (named T17) (Fig.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	115	 When the GST to T17 fusion protein was tested for its ability to bind VP22 present in cytosolic extracts prepared from HSV-infected cells, it was found to bind VP22 in a similar manner to the full-length gD tail (Fig.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Next, to identify residues that might be critical for binding VP22, we carried out alanine-scanning mutagenesis.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Clusters of amino acids were mutated simultaneously to alanine and named according to the amino acid residues that were mutated (Fig.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	118	 These mutants, along with gDc and GST, were expressed and incubated with infected-cell extracts and the relative amounts of VP22 binding were detected by Western blotting.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	119	 3(c) shows that mutations in the arginine and lysine residues at positions 5/6 or 9/10 diminished the binding of VP22, indicating that these amino acid residues are important.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Although the HRR mutant showed a slightly decreased binding of VP22, this level of binding was variable, and most commonly the HRR mutant bound VP22 at a level similar to the wild-type gD tail.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Next, we examined the role of the key lysine and arginine residues in the context of the full-length gD tail (Fig.
