0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Individual mutation of these residues had a less dramatic effect, indicating that these amino acid residues both contribute to VP22 binding but may play a somewhat redundant role.

0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	170	  If the capsids are binding to a specific site on the gD tail then, for any constant amount of gDc fusion protein bound to the beads, capsid binding should be saturable.

0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	174	 This indicated that capsids were binding specifically to the gD tail, most likely indirectly, via tegument proteins.

0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Capsids were never found within beads, but always at the perimeter, suggesting they were not non-specifically trapped within the glutathione to Sepharose matrix.

0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	188	  In this study we did not attempt to discriminate between B and C capsids, since they are believed to have similar surface compositions (Newcomb et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	189	, 1996) and both B and C capsids are capable of becoming enveloped (Baines et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Interestingly, all capsids scored had some internal structure, either a DNA core or a scaffold, suggesting that under these conditions very few A capsids were present (data not shown).

0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	193	  Capsid binding to the gD tail is dependent on the same arginine and lysine residues that are important for binding VP22 The capsid preparation was known to contain tegument polypeptides such as vhs, VP16 and VP22 (Fig.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	194	 To test the possibility that VP22 might play a role in capsid to gD tail interactions, we made use of the GST to gDR5K6 fusion protein that had previously been shown to have diminished ability to bind VP22.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Beads previously bound to either GST, gDc or gDR5K6 were incubated with cell extract containing capsids.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	196	 of capsids bound to the gDR5K6 fusion protein were similar to background levels.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	197	 This correlative result was consistent with the possibility that VP22 plays an essential role in attachment of capsids to the gD tail.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	198	View larger version (16K):    Fig.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Mutation of arginine and lysine residues essential for VP22 binding abolishes binding to capsids.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Equivalent amounts of GST, gDc and gDR5K6 were added to the GST in vitro-binding reaction and incubated with a crude capsid preparation, as in Fig.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	201	 The level of capsid binding seen for the mutant gDR5K6 was similar to the background binding seen for the negative control of GST.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	202	We generated a fusion protein between GST and the cytoplasmic tail of gD in order to test its interaction with HSV-1 tegument proteins.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Our results showed that the gD tail specifically bound the tegument protein VP22 but did not interact with the abundant cellular protein -tubulin nor with the capsid scaffold proteins ICP35 and Pra.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Furthermore, co-immunoprecipitation experiments confirmed that the interaction between gD and VP22 could be detected in infected cells.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Additionally, alanine-scanning mutagenesis of the gD tail identified two amino acid residues, arginine and lysine (from the amino-terminal end of the tail) at positions 5 and 6, respectively, that were critical for VP22 binding.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	206	Since VP22 and VP16 form a complex (Elliott et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	207	, 1995) and we observed VP16 binding to the gD tail, we were interested to test whether VP22 bound the gD tail directly or via VP16 or other viral proteins.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Therefore, we synthesized 35S-labelled VP22 using a rabbit reticulocyte lysate in vitro transcription/translation system and tested its ability to bind the gD tail.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	209	 We found that in vitro-translated VP22 did bind specifically to the gD tail, showing that this binding was independent of other viral polypeptides.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	210	Under our conditions we also observed capsid binding to the gD tail.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	211	 This binding was saturable, unlike the low level of binding seen with GST alone.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	212	 We speculated that capsid binding to the gD tail was mediated by tegument components present in the crude capsid preparation.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Our results showed that the gD mutant tail gDR5K6 that failed to bind VP22 also failed to bind capsids.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	214	 This suggested that VP22 was mediating capsid to tail interactions.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	215	 However, it is also possible that other tegument proteins mediate binding of capsids to the gD tail, utilizing the same residues as VP22.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Although VP16 is present on these capsids (Fig.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	217	 5a) and can bind to the gH tail (Gross et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	218	, 2003), it appeared unable to tether capsids to the gH tail (Fig.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Additionally, we observed that VP16 was capable of binding to the gD mutant tail gDR5K6, which does not bind capsids (data not shown).
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	220	 This also suggested that VP16 was not involved in capsid to tail interactions under these conditions.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	221	The association between VP22 and gD may be one of many interactions between glycoprotein tails and tegument proteins that facilitate the budding of capsids into organelles and the incorporation of tegument/glycoproteins into nascent virions.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	222	 In HSV-1, deletion of the cytoplasmic tail of gD had relatively little effect on normal virus production (Feenstra et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	223	 However, simultaneous deletion of gD and gE showed elimination of cytoplasmic envelopment and accumulation of large numbers of unenveloped nucleocapsids within a dense layer of tegument in the cytoplasm (Farnsworth et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	224	, 2003), indicating that gD and gE may share overlapping roles in cytoplasmic envelopment.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Our data suggest that at least one of these roles may be in VP22 recruitment and predict that the cytoplasmic tail of gE may also bind VP22.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Interestingly, Farnsworth et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	227	 (2003) reported that the cytoplasmic tail of gE, when fused to GST, was indeed able to bind VP22.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Thus, gD and gE may act in a redundant manner to incorporate VP22 into the newly forming virions.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Alternatively, it could be argued that VP22 serves to gather gD and gE to the sites of capsid to envelope interaction.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	230	Our findings regarding HSV-1 are somewhat similar to data reported for the alphaherpesvirus PrV.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	231	 gE and gM have been shown to interact with the UL49 protein, a homologue of HSV-1 VP22 (Fuchs et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	232	, 2002), and, following simultaneous deletion of these two glycoproteins, the UL49 product does not become incorporated into the PrV particle (Fuchs et al.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	233	 However, in the absence of the UL49 protein, gE and gM are incorporated into virions, implying that they may interact redundantly with other tegument proteins for this purpose.
0.20839827.15659744.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Inhibition of virion maturation by simultaneous deletion of glycoproteins E, I and M of pseudorabies virus.

0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	0	Xanthophyll Binding Sites of the CP29 (Lhcb4) Subunit of Higher Plant Photosystem II Investigated by Domain Swapping and Mutation Analysis* Mirko Gastaldelli , Giusy Canino , Roberta Croce   and Roberto Bassi    ||.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the Dipartimento Scientifico e Tecnologico, Universita di Verona, Strada Le Grazie,15-37134 Verona Italy, Istituto di Biofisica, Consiglio Nazionale delle Ricerche, sezione di Milano.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	2	 Via Celoria 26, 20133 Milano Italy,   Universite Aix-Marseille II, LGBP (Laboratoire de Genetique et Biophysique des Plantes), Faculte des Sciences de Luminy, Departement de Biologie, Case 901-163, Avenue de Luminy, 13288 Marseille Cedex 09 France.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	3	The reason why Lhc proteins require a number of xanthophyll species while reaction center proteins only require -carotene is not completely understood; these carotenoid species have very similar physico-chemical properties, enabling, in each case, efficient light harvesting, triplet quenching, and singlet oxygen scavenging (11).
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Nonetheless, the pigment composition is one of the most conserved traits in higher plants, suggesting a specific function for each carotenoid species.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	5	 The best known xanthophyll binding protein is the major light harvesting complex of Photosystem II (LHCII) for which four distinct binding sites have been reported to be bound into distinct domains of the protein.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Sites L1 and L2 intersect the helix A/helix B cross-domain in the center of the Lhc structure (12).
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	7	 L1 is selective for lutein, whereas L2 can also bind violaxanthin (13).
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Site N1 is highly selective for neoxanthin and is located within the C helix domain of LHCII (14).
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Finally, a low affinity binding site has been named V1 after its major ligand (violaxanthin) in low light conditions (15, 16).
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Each binding site was shown to play a distinct functional role; structure stabilization and Chl a triplet quenching are provided by lutein in site L1 only (10, 17).
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Site V1 is not involved in singlet nor in triplet energy transfer and was suggested to accommodate a pool of readily available substrate molecules for the violaxanthin deepoxydase enzyme (16), whose product, zeaxanthin, can then be bound to the allosteric site L2 (18).
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Site N1 is active in light harvesting and singlet oxygen scavenging (13) and stabilizes the long lifetime conformation of LHCII (19).
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	13	Despite the high homology in the transmembrane regions, which suggests a similar folding, the number of xanthophyll binding sites, their selectivity, and their occupancy in the structure seem to be different in each Lhc gene product.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Considering the different roles of individual sites and the complexity of the Lhc multigene protein family, it is possible that the function of individual Lhc gene products is largely determined by the presence/absence of individual xanthophyll sites and by their selectivity and strength.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	15	Primary sequence analysis of structural determinants for xanthophyll binding sites has been less successful than in the case of Chl binding sites, possibly due to the contribution of neighbor Chls rather than of amino acid side chains, to the formation of binding pocket for xanthophylls (13, 14).
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Nevertheless, four short sequences, located in the hydrophilic domains and consisting into four hydrophobic amino acids and a charged residue, could be involved in the binding by forming a hydrophobic pocket hosting xanthophylls end-rings, whereas the charged side chain was supposed to interact with oxygenated ring substituents (20).
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Alternatively, binding might be performed by interactions between hydrophobic residues with the polyene chain located deeply in the membrane as observed in the bacterial LH2 complex (21).
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	18	 In this study, we report the results of a detailed analysis of the chlorophyll a/b/xanthophyll protein CP29 (Lhcb4) with respect to the xanthophyll stoichiometry, location, and function as well as of the sequence determinants involved in their interaction with the polypeptide chain.

0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	98	Occupancy of the Xanthophyll Binding Sites: CP29 Versus LHCII Three tightly bound xanthophyll binding sites have been described in LHCII, sites L1 and L2 (12), accommodating mostly lutein in the native complex, and N1, which is selective for neoxanthin (13, 14).

0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	121	Orientation of Xanthophyll Transition Moments in CP29   Xanthophylls are bound to the L1 and L2 sites of LHCII, their polyene chain forming an angle of, respectively, 56.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	122	4 degrees  with respect to the normal to the thylakoid membrane plane (12).
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	123	 We have used LD to determine the orientation of xanthophyll transition moments, lying within a few degrees from the plane of the polyene chain (33) in CP29.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	124	 To distinguish between the contribution of xanthophylls in sites L1 and L2 to the LD signal, we have used the CP29 mutants E166V and E174V previously shown to have either complete or partial emptiness of site L2 (17).
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	125	 The major contribution of xanthophylls to the CP29-WT LD spectrum (Fig.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	126	 6) appears as a positive signal at 495 nm, whose amplitude is reduced in the E174V mutant and becomes negative in the E166V mutant.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	127	 This suggests that the xanthophyll bound to the site L1 has its dipole moment transition forming an angle smaller than 54.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	128	7 degrees  with the normal to the membrane plane.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	129	View larger version (24K):    FIG.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	130	 LD spectra at 100K of CP29-control (dash), CP29-E166V (solid), and CP29-E174V (dotted).
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	131	The decreased intensity of the positive signal in CP29-E174V complex confirms that the positive contribution is related to carotenoid in the L2 site.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	132	 In this case, the angle between the dipole moment transition axis and the normal to the membrane plane is larger than 54.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Using an internal standard it is possible to determine the exact values for these angles.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	134	 In CP29 the orientation of the Chls has been determined from the LD signal after normalization.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	135	 We therefore analyzed the spectra previously presented in Simonetto et al.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	136	 (26), and we calculated the orientation of the Cars transition moments.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	137	 The orientation of the xanthophyll located in the L1 site was calculated from the spectrum of the E166V mutant in which the only xanthophyll present is located in site L1.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	138	 The analysis of L2 was performed on the WT - E166V difference spectrum.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	139	 The spectra were fitted with the absorption spectra of the Cars to calculate the carotenoid LD signal as reported in Croce et al.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Then, using the factor of normalization value obtained from the analysis of the Chls transition moments (26), the values for L1 and L2 were calculated.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	141	 These values are, respectively, 50 and 70 degrees .
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	142	L1 and L2 Putative Binding Sequences By primary structure analysis within the Lhc family, four consensus sequences have been identified in the hydrophilic domains adjacent to trans-membrane-helix regions A and B, two on the stromal loops and two on the lumenal loops, which could be involved in xanthophyll binding (20) (Fig.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	143	 These sequences are characterized by an hydrophobic stretch of four residues with a polar residue insertion, thus allowing the formation of a hydrophobic pocket for hosting end-rings of xanthophylls, whereas the interaction of the polar residue with the oxygenated ring substituents could have a stabilizing effect (20).
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	144	 To check the involvement of these consensus sequences in xanthophyll binding, mutation analysis was performed.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	145	 In three cases the charged amino acids in the center of the hydrophobic sequence were either substituted by a non-charged one or by a residue with an opposite charge; in one case the putative binding sequence was deleted together with the whole N-terminal domain.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	146	 In the case of the putative lumenal ligand for the carotenoid in L1 site, the mutation at the central AA (Gln-230, ligand for Chl A3) (17) has previously been performed with no effect on xanthophyll binding.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Close inspection of the LHCII structure (Kuhlbrandt et al.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	148	 (12)) indicates that the end ring of the xanthophyll in the L2 site appears to be closely spaced with respect to the carbonyl of proline 238.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	149	 This residue could then interact with -OH xanthophyll ring substituents.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	150	 This residue was mutated to arginine.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	151	 7A a scheme representing the structure of CP29 with indication of the putative carotenoid binding sequences and of the mutations performed is shown.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	152	 The mutant sequences were expressed in E.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	153	 coli and the apoproteins were reconstituted into complexes using a pigment mixture in which all xanthophylls were available together with Chl a and Chl b.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	154	 The mutant Lhc complexes were purified and characterized by biochemical and spectroscopic methods.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	155	 All complexes showed a high yield of reconstitution, similar to WT complex.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Heat denaturation experiments accordingly show that all mutant proteins have the same stability of the WT (64  plus or minus  1  degrees C).
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	157	 The only exception was the CP29-P238R mutant, which has a denaturation temperature of 57  degrees C (see "Discussion").

0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	166	In Table IV the pigment analysis of the reconstituted complexes is presented.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	167	 The differences in the pigment binding in the mutants with respect to the WT are rather small; CP29-D50L and CP29-N-term showed Chl a/b and Chl/carotenoid ratios identical to the CP29-WT reconstituted in the same conditions, whereas a small decrease in neoxanthin and violaxanthin was compensated by an increase in lutein content.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	168	 CP29-D138L was identical to the WT.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	169	 CP29-D195L and CP29-P238R complexes showed a lower Chl a/b ratio than CP29-WT, especially in the case of the P238R mutant, but not variation in the carotenoid composition, suggesting that these changes were due to the loss of a Chl binding site.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	170	 These data clearly indicate that protein motifs including the mutations here performed do not play a major role in xanthophyll binding.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	171	View this table:    TABLE IV Pigment composition of mutants at the putative carotenoid binding sites relative to the WT composition.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	172	In this work we performed an extensive analysis of xanthophyll binding in CP29.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	173	 In particular, we address four questions, (i) how many carotenoids are tightly bound to this complex, (ii) in which sites they are located, (iii) which is the role of individual sites and individual xanthophylls, and (iv) how the putative binding sequences can influence the binding.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	174	 We approached the problem by using recombinant pigment-protein complexes in which either the carotenoid complement was biochemically modified or the apoprotein was engineered at the putative carotenoid binding sites.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	175	How Many Carotenoids Are Bound to CP29? The data presented clearly indicate that both native and recombinant CP29 tightly bind two carotenoids per polypeptide.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	176	 One mole of lutein and substoichiometric amounts of neoxanthin and violaxanthin together summing up to one per polypeptide were found in all preparations, thus suggesting low selectivity of at least one of the binding sites.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	177	 This is also supported by the analysis of CP29 purified from different plant sources, showing variations in the ratio between the xanthophylls (5, 35, 36).
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	178	Reconstitution experiments in the presence of either one xanthophyll species or a combination of two xanthophyll species indicate that lutein, violaxanthin, and zeaxanthin can enter both binding sites, although with different affinity and binding strength.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	179	 The neoxanthin, instead, can be accommodated in only one of the two sites, and its inability to drive the folding process alone testifies that the occupancy of this site is not sufficient to stabilize the pigment-protein complex.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	180	Which Binding Sites Are Present in CP29? Four xanthophyll binding sites have been described in LHCII; that is, three tightly bound, L1, L2, and N1, and a loose one (V1).
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	181	 In CP29 only two of the three tight sites are conserved.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Previous results show that the L1 site is present in CP29, where it accommodates mainly lutein (17).
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	183	 The second carotenoid binding site present in CP29 shows high affinity for neoxanthin, but it does not participate to the protein stability, and it can be either the L2 or N1 site.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	184	 To discriminate between these two sites, we constructed a chimeric LHCII CP29 protein in which the two central helices (A and B) derive from LHCII, whereas the C helix domain, previously shown to host the N1 binding site, derives from CP29 (Fig.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	185	 7B a schematic representation of the complex is presented.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	186	 The chimeric complex was stable and had spectral and pigment binding properties intermediate between CP29 and LHCII.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	187	 However, no neoxanthin was found in the complex despite high amounts of this carotenoid used during the reconstitution.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	188	 We conclude that the N1 site is not present in CP29 and that the second carotenoid binding site in this complex is homologous to the L2 site of LHCII.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	189	The LD analysis indicates that the dipole moment transition axis of L1 and L2 forms, respectively, an angle of 50 and 70 degrees  with the normal to the membrane plane.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Although it is not possible from these data to determine the exact orientation of the polyene chain, it seems quite clear that the xanthophylls are oriented differently compared with LHCII, where a perfect symmetry was observed.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Although models of CP29 structure have been proposed based on LHCII, the only available Lhc structure (12), it appears that Lhc proteins may carry significant structural differences.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	192	 New structural data are of critical interest for the further understanding of Lhc protein structure and function.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	193	Stability The results presented indicate that neoxanthin can enter only the L2 site, whereas all other Cars can be accommodated in both sites.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	194	 This implies that when a complex contains one molecule of neoxanthin and one molecule of another xanthophyll, the latter has to be located on site L1.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	195	 This allows studying the role played by individual xanthophylls in the two sites.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	196	We applied this model to the stability measurements to determine the influence of different xanthophylls in the L1 and L2 sites.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	197	 We considered the denaturation temperature of CP29-L, CP29-V, CP29-NV, CP29-NL, and CP29-VL, and we resolved a system of five equations with five variables.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	198	 This calculation does not take into account the contribution of Chls to the stability since the Chl content of all the samples was identical.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	199	The calculation yields a value of 50.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	200	3  degrees C for the contribution of lutein in site L1 to the stability of the protein, whereas the same xanthophyll contributed only for 3.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	201	2  degrees C when located in site L2.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	202	 For violaxanthin the corresponding values were respectively 42.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	203	2  degrees C (for L2), whereas neoxanthin in site L2 contributes for 14.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	204	 As an example, we can calculate the stability of CP29-control (62.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	205	33  degrees C) and verify that it matches with the measured denaturation temperature (64  degrees C) of the CP29-control complex.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	206	 The good match indicates the independence of all variables (e.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	207	 lutein in L1 site stabilizes the complex in the same way independently from which xanthophyll is present in site L2).
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	208	 The results confirm that site L1 is the most important in Lhc protein stabilization, as previously assessed in Lhcb1 (10), and lutein in this site seems to confer the highest stability to the complex.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Lutein in the L2 site has almost no effect on the stability, whereas the occupancy of this site by violaxanthin or, even better, by neoxanthin increases the temperature of denaturation.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	210	Energy Transfer The excitation energy transfer efficiency from individual binding sites has been determined by analyzing the absorption and excitation spectra in terms of the spectral contribution of individual pigments.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	211	 The possibility of comparing samples, which differ only for the carotenoid composition, allowed quantitative information to be obtained from this analysis.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	212	 It is worth mentioning that all samples were fully equilibrated with the only partial exception of CP29-Za and CP29-Zb, which showed a small emission contribution from Chl b fluorescence at 660 nm when the complex was excited at 475 nm.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	213	Again, we applied the model used for the stability analysis (see "Stability").
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	214	 It has been demonstrated that binding to either one or the other of the two sites yields into a different modulation of the S2 energy level of the xanthophylls (4).
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	215	 This indicates that the same xanthophyll in the two sites is spectroscopically different.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	216	 In agreement, two distinct values for the red-most peak were found for both lutein and violaxanthin, corresponding to the absorption in the L1 and L2 sites.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	217	 In contrast, a single neoxanthin spectral form was needed for the best fit of both absorption and fluorescence excitation spectra consisting with its exclusive binding to the L2 site.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Considering that in the samples containing neoxanthin, violaxanthin and lutein can only be located in the L1 site, it is possible to associate the two absorptions at site L1 or L2 based on the pigment composition of the samples.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Thus, lutein in the L1 site absorbs at 494 nm, whereas in the same site violaxanthin absorbs at 496 nm.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	220	 The same description found for the absorption spectra was applied to the analysis of excitation spectra, thus allowing discrimination between the transfer from Car in L1 and L2.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	221	 It is therefore possible to read the data of Table II with the understanding that notations "1" and "2" actually correspond to xanthophyll binding sites L1 and L2.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	222	 We can conclude that lutein transfers with high efficiency (up to 91%) when in site L1, while its efficiency in exciting Chl a fluorescence is very low (down to 28%) when it is located in the L2 site.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Violaxanthin transfers efficiently from the L1 site, and the efficiency is around 60% for both violaxanthin and neoxanthin from the L2 site.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	224	 Both violaxanthin and lutein show high (80 to 90%) efficiency from the L1 site, while the decrease in the transfer efficiency from the L2 site is different; lutein decreases its efficiency by a factor of 3.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	225	2, whereas viola decreases its efficiency by a factor of 1.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	226	 This suggests that the arrangement of the two xanthophylls in the L2 site is different.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	227	 The case of zeaxanthin is even more extreme: its energy transfer efficiency from the L1 site is around 60%, whereas from the L2 site it is very low, if at all.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	228	 These results suggest that the energy transfer from a single site is dependent from the site occupancy.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	229	In general the L2 site seems to be less active in the energy transfer as compared with the L1 site.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Moreover, the efficiency of excitation energy transfer to Chl is modulated by the xanthophyll species bound there in the following gradient: V = N  >  L  >  Z.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	231	 The lower transfer efficiency from the L2 site, common to all xanthophyll species, indicates that in this site the distance/orientation between pigments is not optimal for excitation energy transfer.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	232	 It has been recently observed that most of the transfer from Car to Chl occurs via the S2 Car state in less than 100 fs.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	233	 Considering the short carotenoid S2 lifetime, a perfect geometry between donor and acceptor is required for highly efficient energy transfer (3, 4, 6), and small changes in this geometry can strongly influence the process.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Moreover, the finding that the xanthophylls behave differently when bound to the L2 site suggests that this protein domain may change its folding in the presence of different xanthophylls, supporting the proposal that the L2 site has allosteric nature (10).
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	235	 It is thus possible to suggest that when, for example, lutein enters the site, which is usually occupied by neoxanthin and violaxanthin, a conformational change occurs, changing the relative chromophore orientation and, thus, decreasing the transfer efficiency.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	236	 The picture in CP29 is thus different as compared with the case of LHCII, where both L1 and L2 sites showed high efficiency of excitation energy transfer to Chl a (4).
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	237	 This suggests the L2 site has a different function in the two proteins.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	238	 In the case of CP29, a Ca2+ and dicyclohexylcarbodiimide binding site in the loop between helix B and C was suggested to work as a sensor for pH changes in the lumen (37, 38).
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	239	 Dicyclohexylcarbodiimide binding sites have been also found in CP26 (39).
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	240	 At low lumenal pH the substitution of the Ca2+ with an H+ would "open" the structure, allowing violaxanthin to exit and zeaxanthin to enter the site (18).
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	241	 The high flexibility, which is required for this process, can thus explain the low energy transfer efficiency from this site.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	242	 In the case of LHCII, zeaxanthin never enters the central sites, and thus, the structure could be optimized for the function of excitation energy transfer.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	243	Photoprotection The photobleaching measurements show that samples with two or more xanthophyll species are more resistant to photooxidation.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	244	 Among the samples containing only one xanthophyll species, CP29-L and CP29-Z are the most sensitive to photo-oxidation.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	245	 It has been proposed above that lutein in site L2 is organized differently compared with the other xanthophylls and in effect does not transfer energy efficiently.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	246	 CP29-Z has only one xanthophyll molecule located in the L1 site.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	247	 The results thus indicate that the L2 site in CP29 can play an important role in photoprotection and, again, that this role is modulated by the site occupancy.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	248	 In this respect, CP29 differs strongly from LHCII for which it has been clearly shown that L1 is the only site active in preventing photooxidation (10).
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	249	Do Putative Carotenoid Binding Sequences Participate in Actual Xanthophyll Binding? In the last part of this work, the putative binding sequences for the carotenoids in the L1 and L2 sites have been studied by mutation analysis.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	250	 Comparison between the primary structures of Lhc multigenic family members has shown in the loops conserved sequences composed by one charged amino acid hydrophobic residues in between four.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Considering that Lhc proteins cannot bind -carotene, it was argued that these sequences are involved in the xanthophyll binding by establishing an H-bond between the polar residue in the polypeptide stretch and the ring -OH substituent (20).
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	252	 However, our mutation of the four putative binding sequences not only did not decrease pigment-protein stability but also did not change the affinity of binding sites for the different xanthophyll species.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	253	 The changes in Chl composition observed for the P238R mutant are probably due to changes in the D helix domain and loss of the Chl in A3 site, as suggested by the similar effects of mutation P238R (this work) and Q230L (17) detected by pigment analysis, CD spectroscopy (data not shown), and the heat denaturation kinetics.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	254	 The two mutations, which affect the putative stromal binding sequences for xanthophylls in the L2 site (CP29-D50L and CP29-N-term), support the view that pigment-protein stabilization by xanthophyll binding is not provided by hydrophilic sequences.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	255	 A small but reproducible decrease of violaxanthin and neoxanthin balanced by an increase of lutein was, however, consistently found.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	256	 This result may indicate that the sequence encompassing the Asp-50 residue plays a minor role in determining the selectivity of the L2 site.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	257	The pigment binding properties of chimeric LHCII-CP29 complex further support the conclusion that lumenal sequences have little effect on site selectivity: despite the presence of the CP29 sequence in the lumenal region between B and C helices, it still accommodates mostly lutein in the L2 site, as is the case in LHCII (13) rather than violaxanthin and neoxanthin, as in CP29.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	258	 Nevertheless, the absence of a clear phenotype for this chimeric complex can be useful in the search of the structural determinants for the affinity of the Car binding sites for individual xanthophyll.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	259	 In fact, no effect in xanthophyll composition was observed by either deleting the N-terminal domain down to residue 96 (CP29) or by substituting half of the B helix and the lumenal loop.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	260	 We conclude that the structural determinant for the selectivity of the L2 site has to be located in between these two regions, namely within a 28-amino acid sequence (e.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	261	 from residue 50 to residue 77 in the LHCII sequence).
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	262	 It has been recently demonstrated that CP26 has the same L2 occupancy as in CP29 (25); this means that the determinant has to be conserved in CP29 and CP26 and not in LHCII.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	263	 The three sequences are reported in Fig.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	264	 The only candidate is the N-61 in LHCII.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	265	 An aromatic amino acid in both CP29 and CP26 occupies this position.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	266	 In the structure of LHCII this asparagine is within 5 A from the carotenoid in L2.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	267	 The presence in this position of a Phe or Tyr may change the steric interaction between pigments, possibly favoring the binding of violaxanthin and neoxanthin with respect to lutein.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	268	 This may be due to the difference in the ring orientation between lutein and violaxanthin and neoxanthin; lutein is in its low energy conformation when the -cycle is oriented parallel to the polyene chain, whereas the -cycles of violaxanthin and neoxanthin are oriented perpendicularly.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	269	 This difference can play a role in the selectivity of the binding site; an aromatic group in this site has higher steric hindrance and can select against lutein.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	270	 However, the stringency cannot be very high as lutein is able to enter the L2 site when the reconstitution is performed in the absence of violaxanthin and neoxanthin.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	271	 Consistent with this hypothesis is the finding that the CP29-L sample is less stable than the control CP29, and lutein in site L2 is differently oriented in the complex, as proposed above.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	272	View larger version (7K):    FIG.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	273	 Sequence comparison between CP29, CP26, and LHCII in the B helix.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	274	Although the putative carotenoid binding sequences on the stroma-exposed side of the protein can be somehow involved in the selectivity of the sites for the different xanthophylls, it is quite clear that the stabilization of the carotenoid binding cannot be attributed to these sequences.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	275	 Similar results have been obtained for the major light-harvesting complex, LHCII, where the deletion of the N-terminal domain, which contains the putative binding sequence for L1 site, does not influence the carotenoid composition of the complex.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	276	 The dragging force for the carotenoid binding is most probably to be found in hydrophobic interaction in the portion of the complex inside the membrane in a similar way to that observed in bacteria (40).
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	277	 Aromatic residues present in A and B helices can be involved in this binding.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	278	 The position of these residues is not conserved in different members of the Lhc family but maintained in the same gene products from different species.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	279	 Mutation analysis on the Chl binding residues both in CP29 and LHCII have shown that the interactions between Chls and carotenoids can play a major role in the xanthophylls binding.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	280	 In particular, the binding of neoxanthin in the N1 site of LHCII is stabilized by interaction with Chls (14).
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	281	 This is consistent with CP29 lacking the N1 site; if the number of Chls in the domain in between helices A and C is lower than in LHCII, then critical Chl-neoxanthin interactions might be lacking.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	282	 The loop in between helix A and helix C of CP29 is shorter with respect to the corresponding domain in LHCII; this may bring helix C closer to helix A and, thus, prevent Chl A6, A7, and B1 binding in both CP29 and the chimeric LHCII-CP29 complex.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	283	CP29 is a member of the Lhc family, which is conserved in higher plants and green algae and is involved in light harvesting and protection from abiotic stress.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	284	 Knowledge of the biochemical and functional properties of the isolated proteins will contribute to the understanding of the physiological roles of individual gene products in providing stress resistance.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	285	 Recent work showed that during light stress the xanthophyll ligand of site L2 (violaxanthin) is changed into zeaxanthin (18), thus inducing a conformational change leading to fluorescence quenching, whereas the binding of neoxanthin in site N1 stabilizes the unquenched conformation (9, 19).
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	286	 The absence of site N1 in CP29 qualifies this antenna subunit for prompt response to light-induced photoprotective conformational change.
0.2088173.12601013.html.plaintext.txt	287	   FOOTNOTES   * This work was supported by Ministero dell'Istruzione dell'Universita e della Ricerca progetto FIRB Grant RBAu01ECX and by Consiglio Nazionale delle Ricerche Agenzia 2000.

0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	0	Herpes Simplex Virus Type 1 Capsid Protein VP26 Interacts with Dynein Light Chains RP3 and Tctex1 and Plays a Role in Retrograde Cellular Transport* Mark W.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Homa||**, Monica Miranda-Saksena, Frazer J.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	2	 Rixon, Valerio Vittone, Karen Byth, and Anthony L.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	3	From the Centre for Virus Research, Westmead Millennium Institute, University of Sydney and Westmead Hospital, P.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Box 412, Westmead 2145, New South Wales, Australia, ||Infectious Disease Biology, Pharmacia Corp.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	5	, Kalamazoo, Michigan 49001, and MRC Virology Unit, Institute of Virology, Glasgow G11 5JR, Scotland, United Kingdom.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	6	Received for publication, October 24, 2003 , and in revised form, April 22, 2004.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	7	The double-stranded DNA virus HSV-1 has a 1250-A icosahedral protein capsid, surrounded by a less structured protein tegument layer, in turn surrounded by a lipid envelope containing several glycoproteins.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	8	 The major capsid proteins VP5, VP19C, VP23, and VP26 are self-assembling when expressed in vitro using recombinant baculoviruses (2, 3).
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	9	During infection, HSV-1 binds to cell surface receptors (via glycoproteins), enters the cell by membrane fusion, then most but not all tegument proteins dissociate from the nucleocapsid after phosphorylation (4, 5).
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	10	 The nucleocapsid-tegument complex is transported to the outer nuclear membrane where it docks and releases viral DNA into the nucleus, but the capsid itself does not enter the nucleus (6).
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	11	 There is evidence that the rapid "retrograde" transport of this complex to the cell nucleus involves microtubules and is mediated by the minus-end-directed molecular motor cytoplasmic dynein (7 to 9).
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Retrograde transport of the closely related alphaherpesvirus pseudorabies virus (PRV) has been observed in live cells to be saltatory, with brief, rapid transport events (10).
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	13	 The herpes viral proteins that mediate retrograde transport are unknown but are likely to involve outer capsid or inner tegument proteins.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	14	 In support of this, HSV-1 capsids, stripped of envelope and much of the tegument protein by detergent lysis, move in a retrograde direction after injection into giant squid axons (11).
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	15	 The site of attachment for the dynein complex on the capsid has not been confirmed.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	16	Cytoplasmic dynein is a large (1.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	17	2 MDa) complex, with heavy chains providing motive force, whereas intermediate and light chains contribute to cargo binding (12).
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Regulation of dynein function is not well understood but is thought to involve the multisubunit complex dynactin, which is also involved in binding membranous cargo (13).
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Light chain LC8 has been reported to interact with proteins from rabies virus (14, 15), African swine fever virus (16), human adenovirus, vaccinia virus, and human papillomavirus (17), whereas Tctex1 interacts with the poliovirus receptor CD155 (18).
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Despite a recently reported interaction between dynein intermediate chain (DIC) and HSV-1 protein UL34 (19), its role in retrograde transport has yet to be confirmed.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	21	 The protein product of UL34 is absent from mature virions in HSV-1 (20) and PRV (21).
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Furthermore, deletion of UL34 from HSV-1 does not prevent infection of cells (22).
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	23	Previous work in our laboratory has concentrated on anterograde axonal transport of HSV-1.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	24	 We have shown that newly formed HSV-1 capsids, having acquired much of their tegument in the neuron cell body (23), are transported in an anterograde direction along axons, separate from glycoproteins (24, 25).
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Similar observations have been made for PRV (26).
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Fast anterograde, microtubule-dependent transport is mediated by the kinesin family of molecular motors (27).
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	27	 We have shown previously (28) that the HSV-1 tegument protein US11 interacts with the ubiquitous heavy chain of the kinesin motor KIF5B and is likely to play an important role in anterograde axonal transport.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	28	By using a similar approach for retrograde transport, we report an interaction between the HSV-1 capsid protein VP26 and 14-kDa dynein light chains RP3 and Tctex1.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	29	 These light chains are 55% homologous at the amino acid level and are mutually exclusive in cytoplasmic dynein complexes (29 to 31).
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	30	 We propose that VP26 mediates binding of the HSV-1 nucleocapsid to cytoplasmic dynein, via interactions with RP3 and probably Tctex1, during retrograde axonal transport of virus in neurons as well as during infection of non-neuronal cells.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	31	LexA Yeast Two-hybrid Assay Potential interactions between dynein subunits and HSV-1 proteins were tested in a Clontech Matchmaker LexA yeast two-hybrid system as described previously (38).
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	32	Expression and Purification of His6-tagged Proteins His6 tag constructs were expressed in Escherichia coli BL21 (DE3), induced with 1 mM isopropyl-1-thio--D-galactopyranoside for 3 h at 37  degrees C.

0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	185	  Recombinant HSV-1 Capsids Containing VP26 Migrate toward the Nucleus in Living Cells To confirm a functional biological significance for the interaction between VP26 and dynein, Hep2 cells were cultured on glass coverslips and microinjected with a suspension of recombinant HSV-1 capsids (VP26+ or VP26-).
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Cells were then fixed either immediately or after 2 or 4 h (replicate experiments), labeled with anti-VP5 antibody, and the distribution of capsids within each cell determined by confocal microscopy (Fig.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Immediately following injection, both VP26- and VP26+ capsids were diffusely distributed throughout the cytoplasm (Fig.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	188	 After 2 h at 37  degrees C, VP26-capsids remained in a similar distribution (Fig.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	189	 7B), whereas VP26+ capsids had congregated near the nuclear rim in many cells (Fig.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Similar distributions were observed after 4 h (data not shown).
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	191	View larger version (77K):    FIG.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	192	 VP26+ but not VP26-capsids move toward the nucleus in Hep2 cells.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	193	 Recombinant HSV-1 capsids (VP26- or VP26+) were microinjected into Hep2 cells grown on glass coverslips.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	194	 The cells were incubated for 0 or 2 h at 37  degrees C and then fixed.

0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Nonspecific labeling of cell nuclei was observed with NC1 antibody (E), so intra-nuclear fluorescence was not included in our analysis.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	199	 To quantify movement of HSV-1 capsids over time, the distance of individual fluorescent particles was measured from both the cell periphery b and nuclear membrane a, with the aid of image analysis software (F).
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Relative nuclear migration for each particle was expressed as a Nuclear Migration Index, calculated as b/(a + b) (43).
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Thus particles near the cell periphery received values close to 0, and particles near the nucleus received values close to 1.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	202	  To quantify the distribution of capsids at different time points, a Nuclear Migration Index was assigned to each visible fluorescent particle, such that particles near the plasma membrane received values close to 0, whereas particles near the cell nucleus received values close to 1 (Fig.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Over a thousand fluorescent particles were analyzed in two separate experiments.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Fluorescent particles observed "within" the nucleus of injected and uninjected cells (Fig.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	205	 7E) were because of background fluorescence and were not included (see "Experimental Procedures").
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	206	 There was no nonspecific labeling of the nuclear membrane, and fluorescent particles adjacent to the nuclear membrane could be clearly distinguished.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	207	 General linear models were used to formally investigate the data from both experiments.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Within experiments involving VP26+ capsids, the Nuclear Migration Index increased on average by 0.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	209	001, over 2 or 4 h, confirming overall movement toward the nucleus (Fig.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	210	 In contrast, within experiments involving VP26-capsids the Nuclear Migration Index decreased on average by 0.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	211	View larger version (24K):    FIG.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Movement of VP26+ but not VP26-capsids toward the nucleus is statistically significant.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Recombinant HSV-1 capsids, VP26+ ( ) or VP26-(), were microinjected into Hep2 cells, incubated for 0, 2, or 4 h at 37  degrees C, and examined by confocal microscopy.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	214	 The Nuclear Migration Indices (Fig.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	215	 7) of over a thousand fluorescent particles were analyzed in two separate experiments.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	216	 General linear modeling was performed for both experiments (A and B) and confirmed that VP26+ but not VP26-capsids had moved toward the cell nucleus after 2 or 4 h.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	217	Cytoplasmic dynein is the major minus-end-directed, microtubule-associated molecular motor, and each dynein complex contains two copies of the same 14-kDa light chain, either RP3 or Tctex1.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	218	 The two chains, although 55% homologous at the amino acid level (30), are mutually exclusive in each complex, compete for binding sites on DIC, and have differing binding specificities (31).
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	219	We initially demonstrated binding of VP26 to dynein light chains RP3 and Tctex1 in a yeast two-hybrid system, and we confirmed strong expression of the -galactosidase reporter by quantitative assay.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Subsequent work confirmed binding of recombinant, soluble VP26 to RP3 and Tctex1 in vitro, using bacterial expression and GST pull-down assays.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	221	 We also confirmed that immobilized His6-VP26 is able to bind to intact cytoplasmic dynein complexes in cell lysates.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Most important, we have confirmed binding of dynein (RP3) to VP26 in its biologically relevant form as part of a recombinant viral capsid bound to VP5.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	223	Thus we have confirmed specific binding of VP26 to dynein light chain RP3 in three separate assays, including as part of a viral capsid.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	224	 This suggests that the binding of VP26 to RP3 utilizes different VP26 epitopes from those involved in binding to VP5 in capsids (49) and is consistent with the interaction playing a significant role in vivo.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Furthermore, in microinjected cells we have shown co-localization of HSV-1 capsids containing VP26 with RP3, Tctex1, and microtubules, further supporting a functional role for VP26-dynein interactions.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	226	Despite strong interaction between VP26 and Tctex1 in the yeast two-hybrid system and in vitro pull-down assays (using His6-VP26), and co-localization of HSV-1 capsids with Tctex1, we were unable to confirm binding of VP26+ capsids to Tctex1 in vitro.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	227	 We believe that this result most likely reflects a lower sensitivity for this particular assay, in light of the other in vitro binding results.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	228	 The ability to bind either RP3 or Tctex1 would be expected to offer HSV-1 an evolutionary advantage, by allowing retrograde transport of HSV-1 capsids on any cytoplasmic dynein complex in all cell types.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	229	 We cannot exclude that recombinant Tctex1 may only bind to soluble VP26 in vitro and not to VP26 incorporated into recombinant HSV-1 capsids.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	230	 However, the co-localization of VP26+ capsids with Tctex1 in live cells suggests that VP26 interacts with Tctex1, as well as RP3, in this more biologically relevant model.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	231	HSV-1 readily infects mucous membranes in both adults and children, before being transported in a retrograde direction along neuronal axons to establish latent infection.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	232	 RP3 in particular is an attractive candidate to mediate this retrograde transport, as it is expressed at high levels in cells infected by HSV-1, including adult brain and many other tissue types, whereas Tctex1 is expressed predominantly in fetal tissue and testis (30).
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	233	 Furthermore, it has been proposed that RP3-containing dynein complexes play the predominant role during retrograde transport from post-synaptic nerve terminals (29), the site of HSV-1 entry.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	234	VP26, at the hexon tips, is ideally located to interact with molecular motors (48), because most of the tegument is lost soon after cell entry (6).
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	235	 Tegument proteins VP11/12, VP13/14, VP16, and VP22 are known to dissociate from the virus at early stages of infection, whereas the major tegument protein VP1/2 and the minor capsid protein UL25 probably remain attached to incoming capsids (4, 5, 8, 50, 51).
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	236	 VP1/2 appears to attach to capsids at the vertical pentons (52), whereas VP26 is found exclusively on hexons (39, 48, 53) and does not interfere with capsid-tegument interaction (54).
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	237	 This specific binding is probably due to differing orientations of the upper domain of VP5, the structure of which has recently been solved (55).
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	238	Binding of the tegument protein VP11/12 to RP3 and Tctex1 was detected in the yeast two-hybrid system but could not be confirmed with pull-down assays due to poor expression of soluble His6 tag fusion proteins in E.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	239	 The significance of these results is unclear, but any role is likely to be later in the viral replication cycle, rather than during retrograde transport.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	240	 It seems unlikely that VP11/12 is involved in retrograde transport of the capsid-tegument complex, because it dissociates from incoming capsids during cell infection (50), although retention of some residual VP11/12 during retrograde transport will be difficult to exclude.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	241	 An interaction of VP11/12 with dynein may play a role during tegument assembly, however, because newly synthesized VP11/12 has been observed in perinuclear particles undergoing rapid, microtubule-dependent movement (50).
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	242	To confirm that the interaction between VP26 and dynein is important for cellular transport, recombinant viral capsids were microinjected into living cells.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	243	 On average there was significant movement of VP26+ capsids toward the cell nucleus after 2 or 4 h, which was absent for VP26-capsids.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	244	 VP26-capsids in fact redistributed slightly toward the cell periphery, but this may simply reflect diffusion to a truly "random" distribution.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	245	 These results therefore suggest an important role for VP26 during retrograde transport, through interactions with cytoplasmic dynein.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	246	The relative contribution of other tegument or capsid proteins to HSV-1 transport is unclear and requires further study.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	247	 We cannot exclude that VP1/2, or one of the minor capsid proteins such as UL25, may also contribute to dynein binding in vivo, as suggested by others (8, 10).
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Any binding of these or other HSV-1 proteins to dynein would imply redundancy in viral proteins available for retrograde transport, and may explain why VP26 is not an essential protein for replication in vitro (56).
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	249	 Redundancy for such an important process may be advantageous for the virus, and there are precedents for functional redundancy in other HSV-1 proteins (57).
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	250	 In our yeast two-hybrid system there was no evidence of interaction between dynein and a large fragment of VP1/2 (N-terminal two-thirds), but it was not possible to clone the rest of the protein.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Neither was it possible to test UL25 in our system for possible interaction with RP3 or Tctex1, due to autoactivation.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	252	The role of VP26 during viral transport in vivo remains to be determined.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	253	 There has been one previous study, in a mouse eye model, dissecting the role of VP26 in retrograde transport of HSV-1 to, and replication in, trigeminal ganglia (56).
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	254	 Deletion of VP26 decreased the amount of infectious virus in trigeminal ganglia by 100-fold, whereas titers in cell culture (where retrograde transport is less critical) were decreased only 2-fold.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	255	 Simultaneous deletion of thymidine kinase (and thus replication) ablated the effects of VP26 deletion at 72 h after ocular infection, suggesting the virus could still be transported in the absence of VP26.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	256	 However, earlier time points may be needed to detect a decrease in transport velocity or efficiency, because wild-type virus can arrive as early as 19 h postinfection (58).
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	257	In our current study we set out to determine the viral and cellular proteins that mediate retrograde axonal transport of HSV-1.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	258	 Our use of protein-protein interaction assays and minimal recombinant capsids should be a more sensitive way to detect HSV-dynein interactions than traditional approaches, relying on single gene null mutants, which can miss important interactions where multifunctional or redundant proteins exist (10).
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	259	We have demonstrated by two different assays that VP26 binds to dynein light chains RP3 and Tctex1 in vitro, and we confirmed binding of VP26 to intact dynein complexes.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	260	 We have demonstrated co-localization in cells of micro-injected HSV-1 capsids with RP3, Tctex1, and microtubules.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	261	 We have shown further that VP26 in its biologically relevant form is able to mediate binding of recombinant HSV-1 capsids to RP3 in vitro, in the absence of minor capsid or tegument proteins.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	262	 Finally, we have shown that VP26, incorporated into recombinant capsids, is both necessary and sufficient to mediate retrograde intracellular transport of capsids.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	263	 We therefore propose that VP26, although not essential for viral replication in vitro, is likely to be one of two or more HSV proteins mediating retrograde axonal transport in vivo, perhaps another example of redundancy for key viral functions.
0.21750095.15117959.html.plaintext.txt	264	   FOOTNOTES   * This work was supported by National Health and Medical Research Council Grants 107374 and 253617 (to A.

0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	0	Cyclin L2, a Novel RNA Polymerase II-associated Cyclin, Is Involved in Pre-mRNA Splicing and Induces Apoptosis of Human Hepatocellular Carcinoma Cells* Lianjun Yang, Nan Li, Chunmei Wang, Yizhi Yu, Liang Yuan, Minghui Zhang, and Xuetao Cao.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the Institute of Immunology, Second Military Medical University, Shanghai 200433, People's Republic of China.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received for publication, July 9, 2003 , and in revised form, November 25, 2003.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	3	Transcription regulator cyclin/CDK pairs are associated with the initiation, elongation, and processing of RNA transcripts.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	4	 During this process cyclins interact with the large subunit of RNA polymerase II, phosphorylating the C-terminal domain (CTD) via their partner CDKs.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	5	 It is widely accepted that transcription and RNA processing are closely related.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Capping enzymes, polyadenylation factors, and splicing factors assemble at the CTD of RNA polymerase II.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Hyperphosphorylated RNA polymerase II (RNAPIIo) stimulates RNA splicing, and the CTD has been observed to target some splicing factors to RNA transcription sites in vivo (8).
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Although there is no direct evidence to support a critical role for transcription regulator cyclins in regulation of cell cycle progression or cellular apoptosis, some results have implied that one transcription regulator cyclin, cyclin C, may be important for the regulation of cell proliferation in cooperation with c-Myc.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Cyclin C has been reported to regulate both cell cycling and cell adhesion, suggesting that this cyclin may play some part in regulating both the G1/S and G2/M phases of the cell cycle (9).
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	10	 It thus appears that some transcription regulator cyclins may also be involved in cell cycle progression or apoptosis, RNA transcription, and DNA repair, although the precise role of the phenomena remains to be elucidated.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	11	In addition to small nuclear ribonucleoprotein particles and spliceosome-associated proteins, SR proteins compose another group of splicing factors.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	12	 SR proteins have a characteristic C-terminal Arg/Ser-rich repeat of variable length (RS domain) and RNA-binding domains in the N terminus and constitute a family of highly conserved nuclear phosphoproteins that can function as both essential and alternative pre-mRNA splicing factors (10, 11).
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	13	 SR-related proteins, proteins that are structurally and functionally distinct from the SR family, have also been identified.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	14	 These proteins generally contain RS domains but not RNA-binding domains, are associated with the transcriptional machinery or mRNA 3'-end formation, and have been implicated in export.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Cyclin L1 (originally named cyclin L) is the first known example of a cyclin containing an RS domain in addition to a typical "cyclin box" (12).
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	16	We report here a novel candidate cyclin, human cyclin L2 (CCNL2), first identified by large scale random sequencing of a cDNA library of human bone marrow stromal cells (BMSCs).
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Human cyclin L2 is also a cyclin box and RS repeat region-containing protein and localizes within the nuclear speckles, co-localizing with splicing factors SC-35 and 9G8.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	18	 We demonstrate that human cyclin L2 associates with RNAPIIo, CDK p110 PITSLRE kinase (CDK11), SC-35, and 9G8.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	19	 In addition, recombinant cyclin L2 protein can stimulate in vitro mRNA splicing.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Furthermore, overexpression of exogenous cyclin L2 can suppress the growth of human hepatocellular carcinoma SMMC 7721 cells both in vitro and in vivo, inducing cellular apoptosis, possibly by up-regulating expression of p53 and Bax and down-regulating Bcl-2.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	21	 These results suggest that cyclin L2 may be a functional cyclin that associates with transcriptional regulation and participates in regulating the pre-mRNA splicing process.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	22	 The mechanism by which cyclin L2 suppresses the growth and induces apoptosis of tumor cells requires further investigation.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	23	Molecular Cloning of Full-length Human Cyclin L2 and Its Mouse Homologue The main EST of human cyclin L2 was directly isolated from a human BMSC cDNA library by random sequencing as described previously (14).
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Briefly, BMSCs were generated from the bone marrow aspirates of an adult patient.

0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	114	 The cyclin domain is a helical domain present in cyclin proteins twice, as similar all--folds.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	115	 The predicted three-dimensional structure of human cyclin L2 generated by Swiss model did indeed indicate that there was an obvious -helix in the N terminus (data not shown) of human cyclin L2, which was in agreement with the common structural feature of the cyclin family.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	116	 In addition to the highly conserved cyclin box region in the N terminus, there was also a conserved "serine/arginine-rich (RS)" repeat region in the C terminus of the human cyclin L2 protein (Fig.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	117	 1A), similar to that of cyclin L1 and some splicing factor proteins known as SR protein.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Although two transmembrane regions (amino acids 10 to 24 and 224 to 228) were predicted, no obvious signal peptide was found, suggesting that human cyclin L2 may be a non-secretory intracellular protein.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	119	 A significant number of nuclear location signals indicated that human cyclin L2 might be a nuclear protein (Fig.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	120	 The strong hydrophilicity in the C terminus of the human cyclin L2 was also consistent with features of cyclin L1 and cyclin K, both of which are important members of the transcriptional regulation cyclin family.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	121	Identification of an Isoform and Mouse Homologue of Human Cyclin L2 During the cloning and sequencing of human cyclin L2 cDNA, a novel isoform was found in Raji cells.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	122	 This new isoform of human cyclin L2 was designated as human cyclin L2s (CCNL2s) and submitted to NCBI GenBankTM (accession number AY116620 [GenBank] ).

0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	131	 A BLAST search of the NCBI genome data base indicated that the mouse cyclin L2 gene is located in the low terminus of mouse chromosome 4.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	132	 A previous report (20) identified a 224-amino acid protein, mouse ANIA-6B, that was the same as N terminus of mouse cyclin L2.

0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	155	Nuclear Cytolocalization of Human Cyclin L2 Because human cyclin L2 contained nuclear localization signals and was predicted to be a nuclear protein, we examined the subcellular localization of FLAG-tagged cyclin L2 to determine whether it localized within the nucleus.

0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	160	 The result confirmed the structure prediction that cyclin L2 is a typical nuclear protein.

0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	165	  Human Cyclin L2 Co-localizes with Splicing Factors SC-35 and 9G8  The "speckled" nuclear localization pattern is characteristic of proteins associated with spliceosome complexes such as SC-35 (21, 22).
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	166	 The distinct RS repeat region in human cyclin L2 suggested that it might be found in the nuclear speckles co-localized or associated with other splicing components.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	167	 pCCNL2-FLAG was transfected into SMMC 7721 cells, and splicing factors SC-35 and 9G8 were detected by indirect immunofluorescence.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	168	 The FLAG-tagged CNNL2 protein was found in similar punctated nuclear speckled regions (Fig.

0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	170	 3G), which suggested that cyclin L2 largely localized to the same sub-nuclear regions as the splicing factors (Fig.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Curiously, the cyclin L2 and SC-35 signals did not appear to overlap completely.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	172	 The SC-35 protein appeared to be more heavily concentrated than CCNL2-FLAG, although was 9G8 not.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	173	 The fluorescence dye staining of CCNL2-FLAG and indirect immunofluorescence staining for SC-35 may not superimpose one another, perhaps indicating a different functional association of cyclin L2 with SC-35 and 9G8.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	174	Human Cyclin L2 Associates with RNA Polymerase II, Splicing Factors SC-35, 9G8, and CDK p110 PITSLRE The cell nucleus (particularly the nuclear speckles) is believed to contain compartments enriched for nuclear proteins involved in transcriptional regulation and mRNA processing.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Human cyclin C, H, K, and the closest homologue of cyclin L2, cyclin L1, have been proposed to play roles in the regulation of basal transcription through their association with and activation of CDKs that phosphorylate the CTD of the large subunit of RNA polymerase II.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	176	 To explore the possibility that human cyclin L2 may associate with RNA polymerase II or other CDKs and splicing factors and to delineate the domain(s) of cyclin L2 required for these interactions, several domain-negative constructs tagged by myc-6His were overexpressed in SMMC 7721 cells and immunoprecipitated with anti-Myc antibody cross-linked with protein G-Sepharose beads.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	177	 4A, anti-Myc antibody could detect expression of Myc-tagged CCNL2-wt (59 kDa), CCNL2-CL (39 kDa, both cyclin domains deleted) and CCNL2-RS (51 kDa, RS repeat region deleted).
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	178	 We then examined the association of cyclin L2 with RNA polymerases II and other CDKs and splicing factors.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	179	View larger version (52K):    FIG.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Selective interaction of human cyclin L2 with hyperphosphorylated RNA polymerase II, CDK p110 PITSLRE, and splicing factors SC-35 and 9G8.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	181	 SMMC 7721 cells were transfected with pCCNL2-wt, pCCNL2-CL, pCCNL2-RS, pCCNL2-AS, or mock vector.
