0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	183	  RNA polymerase II exists in two major forms: RNAPIIa and RNAPIIo, a hyperphosphorylated CTD of RNA polymerase II.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	184	 Immunoprecipitation results showed that human CCNL2 associated with the hyperphosphorylated form, RNAPIIo, but not RNAPIIa (Fig.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	185	 The hyperphosphorylation of RNA polymerase II correlates with its association with certain splicing factors involved in mRNA processing.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Here we further demonstrated that cyclin L2 associates with both the two splicing factors (Fig.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	187	 4B), which was consistent with their co-localization to nuclear speckles.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	188	Cyclins, together with their CDK partners, regulate the orderly progression of the cell cycle.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	189	 We investigated whether human cyclin L2 could possibly interact with known CDKs.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Because the CDK p110 PITSLRE (also called CDK11) has been identified as the CDK partner for human cyclin L1 (12) and mouse cyclin ANIA-6A (20), the mouse homologue of human cyclin L1, the association of human cyclin L2 and PITSLRE was assayed by immunoprecipitation.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	191	 4B, human cyclin L2 could also associate with p110 PITSLRE, suggesting that p110 PITSLRE might be the CDK partner of human cyclin L2.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	192	 It remains to be determined whether cyclin L2 can partner with other CDKs.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	193	The results also showed that association with RNAPIIo and p110 PITSLRE required the presence of the N-terminal cyclin domains of human cyclin L2, because in cells overexpressing CCNL2-CL, a truncated protein lacking both cyclin domains, no association of cyclin L2 with RNAPIIo or p110 PITSLRE was detected.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	194	 In CCNL2-RS-expressing cells, the levels of RNAPIIo and p110 PITSLRE precipitated were approximately the same as those with CCNL2-wt, suggesting that RS repeats might not be necessary for RNAPIIo and p110 PITSLRE interaction.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Notably, the interactions with SC-35 and 9G8 in CCNL2-CL-expressing cells were similar to those with CCNL2-wt, whereas in CCNL2-RS-expressing cells, interactions decreased.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	196	 Although this indicates a requirement for only the RS repeat region, the possibility cannot be not excluded that indirect interactions between cyclin L2 with SC-35 and 9G8 may occur, perhaps linked by p110 PITSLRE via the cyclin domains of cyclin L2.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	197	Together with the nuclear distribution, the findings indicate that human cyclin L2 might play an active role in the cell nucleus, with involvement in the RNA processing complex via association with hyperphosphorylated RNA polymerase II, the splicing factors SC-35 and 9G8, and the CDK p110 PITSLRE.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	198	Human Cyclin L2 Stimulates Pre-mRNA Splicing Because cyclin L2 both co-localizes and associates with the splicing factors SC-35 and 9G8, does it contribute to splicing function? We performed in vitro splicing assays using HeLa cell nuclear extract (50  microg), assaying the effect of anti-CCNL2 polyclonal sera on in vitro splicing of a -globin RNA precursor.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	199	 5, the presence of preimmune sera or anti-GST antibody did not affect splicing, whereas anti-CCNL2 sera remarkably inhibited splicing activity, suggesting that human cyclin L2 is involved in pre-mRNA splicing.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	200	 We also performed in vitro splicing assays using sub-optimal amounts of HeLa cell nuclear extract (25  microg), with the addition of GST or GST-CCNL2 recombinant protein.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	201	 In the absence of additional protein, or when GST was added to the reaction, the splicing activity was greatly reduced compared with that obtained with 50  microg of HeLa cell nuclear extract.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Addition of recombinant GST-CCNL2 protein (250 ng) strongly stimulated splicing activity (Fig.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Human cyclin L2 thus appears to play a positive role in pre-mRNA splicing.

0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	209	  Overexpression of Human Cyclin L2 Suppresses Growth of Human Hepatocellular Carcinoma Cells and Induces Cell Apoptosis in Vitro and in Vivo Hepatocellular carcinoma accounts for 80 to 90% of liver cancers and is one of the most prevalent carcinomas worldwide, particularly in Africa and Asia.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	210	 We wondered if overexpression of human cyclin L2 would affect the growth of human hepatocellular carcinoma SMMC 7721 cells, which may contribute to understanding the molecular mechanisms of the cellular malignancy phenotype and invasion and metastasis of hepatocellular carcinoma.

0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Human cyclin L2 may thus be involved in the induction of cell apoptosis, with conserved cyclin domains playing a vital role in this biological activity.

0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	250	 This suggests that delivery of human cyclin L2 cDNA into human hepatocellular hepatoma can suppress tumor growth in vivo.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	251	Overexpression of Human Cyclin L2 Up-regulates the Expression of p53 and Bax and Down-regulates the Expression of Bcl-2 Overexpression of human cyclin L2 induced the apoptosis of SMMC 7721 cells in vitro.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Cellular apoptosis involves complex molecular cascades, and dysfunction of a variety of genes may lead to the onset and progression of apoptosis.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	253	 We analyzed the expression of the apoptosis-related protein p53, anti-apoptotic protein Bcl-2, and pro-apoptotic protein Bax by Western blot and RT-PCR analysis.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	254	 8A, transient expression of CCNL2-wt and CCNL2-RS induced an increase in p53 and Bax protein expression (3- and 4-fold, respectively) in SMMC 7721 cells 72 h post-transfection compared with pCCNL2-AS-, pCCNL2-CL-, mock vector-transfected, or parental SMMC 7721 cells.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	255	 Significantly up-regulated p53 and Bax mRNA expression was also detected by RT-PCR (Fig.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Conversely, Bcl-2 expression was down-regulated in SMMC 7721 cells overexpressing human cyclin L2.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	257	 These results demonstrate that overexpression of human cyclin L2 modulates the expression of critical apoptotic factors, leading to cell apoptosis.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	258	 It would be interesting to determine whether other apoptotic factors may also have a relationship with apoptosis induced by overexpression of human cyclin L2.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	259	View larger version (48K):    FIG.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	260	 Effect of human cyclin L2 overexpression on the expression of apoptosis-related proteins in SMMC 7721 cells.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	261	 A, Western blot analysis of protein expression of p53, Bax, and Bcl-2.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	262	 B, RT-PCR analysis of mRNA expression of p53, Bax, and Bcl-2.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	263	 SMMC 7721 cells transfected with indicated vectors were harvested 72 h post-transfection.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	264	The various aspects of RNA elongation and processing, including capping, splicing, and polyadenylation of nascent transcripts, are tightly coupled by protein factors physically associating with the CTD of RNA polymerase II (32).
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	265	 Human cyclin L2 possesses RS-repeat domains, a characteristic feature of SR protein/spliceosome components, and associates and co-localizes with the known splicing factors SC-35 and 9G8.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	266	 RS domains have been discovered in several factors associated with transcription components, including the SR-like CTD-associated factors (33) and in a 3'-end cleavage factor, cleavage factor-I 68-kDa subunit (34), suggesting that communication between splicing and both transcription and 3'-end processing might in some cases be mediated by interactions involving RS domain proteins (35, 36).
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	267	 We have confirmed the stimulatory effect of cyclin L2 in pre-mRNA splicing.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	268	 This activity may be mediated by interaction through its cyclin domains with RNA polymerase II and CDK p110 PITSLRE, or direct or indirect interaction via cyclin domain/RS repeat region with SC-35 and 9G8, as an RNA elongation/processing unit, in the nuclear speckles.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	269	 Of note, while this manuscript was in revision, de Graaf et al.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	270	 (37) reported cyclin L1 and cyclin L2 as interaction partners and substrates of DYRK1A (dual specificity tyrosine phosphorylation-regulated kinase 1A), a nuclear speckle-locating protein kinase with transcription factors and splicing factors as its substrates.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	271	 Because human cyclin L2 and cyclin L1 are expressed differentially at different levels in different cells and tissues, it is possible that these two closely related cyclins contribute to tissue-specific regulation of splicing.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	272	The PITSLRE protein kinases are parts of the large family of p34cdc2-related kinases whose functions appear to be linked with progression of the cell cycle and the signal transduction of apoptosis and oncogenesis.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	273	 PITSLRE CDK also interacts selectively with RNAPIIo but not with RNAPIIa, and PITSLRE proteins also contain many serine/arginine dipeptide repeats, characteristic of spliceosome components.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	274	 The p110 PITSLRE has been shown to participate in a signaling pathway that may regulate the processing of RNA transcription.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	275	 It interacts with the RNA-binding protein RNPS1, an activator of mRNA splicing, RNA polymerase II, and multiple transcriptional elongation factors, regulating some aspects of RNA splicing and/or transcription in proliferating cells (38 to 40).
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	276	 Due to its identification as a partner for human cyclin L1 (12) and its mouse homologue cyclin ANIA-6A (20), it is referred to as CDK11.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	277	 We show that human cyclin L2 can associate with p110 PITSLRE in a cyclin domain-dependent manner, suggesting that it is also likely to be a partner CDK for cyclin L2.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	278	Our work here also revealed that overexpression of human cyclin L2 suppressed the growth of hepatocellular carcinoma SMMC 7721 cells both in vitro and in vivo, and induced cellular apoptosis in vitro.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	279	 Cyclin L2 is ubiquitously expressed throughout the body, and in a variety of human cell lines, including SMMC 7721 cells.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	280	 Under normal conditions, tumor cells such as SMMC 7721 cells may have anti-apoptotic mechanisms in place which antagonize the apoptosis-inducing effects of cyclin L2.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	281	 However, when cyclin L2 is overexpressed, the apoptosis-inducing effects of cyclin L2 may counterattack these anti-apoptotic mechanisms, resulting in an imbalance between apoptosis and cell survival and cell cycle regulation, if any.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	282	 Previous studies have implicated other cyclins in apoptosis and growth inhibition of tumor cells.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	283	 A potential p53-binding site is present in intron 1 of the cyclin K gene, and colony formation assays indicate that overexpression of cyclin K suppresses growth of the glioblastoma cell lines U373MG and T98G and colon carcinoma SW480 cells (41).
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	284	 At high levels, cyclin G1, a p53-responsive gene induced in alternative reading frame-arrested cells, also induces a G1-phase arrest in mammalian cells that coincides with p53 activation.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	285	 Interestingly, growth inhibition by cyclin G1 does not require p53 but instead exhibits partial retinoblastoma protein dependence (42).
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	286	 A recent study by cDNA microarray and RT-PCR indicates that cyclin L1 is commonly overexpressed in well differentiated but not in poorly differentiated primary head and neck tumors, compared with corresponding correlative normal tissues (43).
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	287	 Other RS repeat-containing proteins such as Hs-BTF (44) can also act as apoptosis-promoting proteins that interact with Bcl-2-related proteins.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	288	 To gain insight into the mechanism of cyclin L2-induced apoptosis in SMMC 7721 cells, we assessed the expression of the apoptosis-related proteins p53, Bax, and Bcl-2.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	289	 In our study, following transient expression of cyclin L2 in SMMC 7721 cells, p53 and Bax expression was observed to increase significantly, and down-regulation of Bcl-2 expression could also be observed.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	290	 Previous studies have demonstrated that overexpression of p53 can transactivate Bax expression and inhibit Bcl-2 expression, resulting in apoptotic cell death (45).
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	291	 Combined with other observations, including its association with RNAPII, CDK p110 PITSLRE, and splicing factors, and its stimulatory effect in pre-mRNA splicing, our results suggest that overexpression of cyclin L2 might regulate the RNA transcription and processing of certain apoptosis-related factors, possibly through a p53-dependent increase in Bax and reduction in Bcl-2 pathway signaling, leading to tumor cell growth inhibition.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	292	In conclusion, we report here the cloning of human and mouse cyclin L2, the association of human cyclin L2 with p110 PITSLRE and the splicing factors SC-35 and 9G8, and the potential involvement of human cyclin L2 in the stimulation of pre-mRNA splicing.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	293	 Growth inhibition and apoptosis-inducing effects of human cyclin L2 on tumor cells was also observed both in vitro and in vivo.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	294	 Further experiments are required to elucidate the roles of the novel molecule, human cyclin L2, in transcriptional regulation and cell growth suppression and the related mechanisms.
0.22396544.14684736.html.plaintext.txt	295	   FOOTNOTES   The nucleotide sequence(s) reported in this paper has been submitted to the GenBankTM/EBI Data Bank with accession number(s) AY037150 [GenBank] , AY116620 [GenBank] and AY337018 [GenBank] .

0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	0	Activation of the knirps locus links patterning to morphogenesis of the second wing vein in Drosophila Karen Lunde1,2, Jennifer L.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Trimble1, Annabel Guichard1, Kirsten A.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	2	 Guss3, Ulrich Nauber4 and Ethan Bier1,*.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	3	1 Section of Cell and Developmental Biology, University of California, San Diego, 9500 Gilman Drive, La Jolla, CA 92093-0349, USA 2 Albert-Ludwigs-Universitat Freiburg, Institut fur Biologie I, Hauptstrasse 1, D-79104 Freiburg, Germany 3 Department of Biology, Dickinson College, PO Box 1773, Carlisle, PA 17013, USA 4 Max-Planck-Institut fur biophysikalische Chemie, Abt.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Molekulare Entwicklungsbiologie, Am Fassberg 11, D-37077 Gottingen, Germany.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	5	* Author for correspondence (e-mail: bier{at}biomail.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	6	Key words: knirps, radius incompletus, L2 vein, wing, Drosophila melanogaster, Patterning, Morphogenesis.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	7	Wing vein development in Drosophila can be subdivided into two temporally distinct stages: initiation and differentiation.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Vein initiation begins during the mid-third larval instar (Waddington, 1940; Garcia-Bellido, 1977; Garcia-Bellido and de Celis, 1992; Sturtevant et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	9	, 1993; Sturtevant and Bier, 1995; Bier, 2000) when the wing imaginal disc is a monolayer of cells.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	10	 The wing blade proper derives from an oval region of the wing disc known as the wing pouch, while the remainder of the disc generates elements of the wing hinge and thoracic body wall.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Vein differentiation, the second phase of vein development, occurs during metamorphosis as the wing disc buds out (or everts), folding along the future wing margin.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Ultimately, this eversion leads to the apposition of the dorsal and ventral surfaces of the wing during pupal development, creating the bilayer of cells comprising the mature wing blade.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	13	Genes involved in initiating wing vein development (vein genes) are expressed during the third larval instar in narrow stripes, corresponding to vein primordia, or in broader `provein' stripes, consisting of cells that are competent to become vein cells (Biehs et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Some vein genes are expressed in all vein primordia, while others are expressed in subsets of veins or in single veins.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	15	 For example rhomboid (rho), which encodes an integral membrane protein (Bier et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	16	, 1996), is expressed in all vein primordia and promotes vein formation throughout wing development by locally activating the Egfr signaling pathway (Sturtevant et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	17	, 1994; Bier, 1998a; Bier, 1998b; Guichard et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	18	 caupolican (caup) and the neighboring gene araucan (ara) encode related homeobox genes that promote expression of other vein genes such as rho in odd numbered veins.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Proneural genes such as achaete (ac) and scute (sc) promote neural development in the L1 and L3 primordium (Gomez-Skarmata et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Delta (Dl) encodes a ligand for the Notch (N) receptor, which mediates lateral inhibitory interactions among cells in vein-competent domains during pupal development (Shellenbarger and Mohler, 1978; Kooh et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	21	, 1993; Parody and Muskavitch, 1993).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Delta is also expressed earlier during larval stages of wing development in all longitudinal veins except L2, and is likely to play a role in limiting vein thickness at this stage as well, since loss of Notch function during larval development leads to greatly broadened expression of the vein marker rho (Sturtevant and Bier, 1995).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	23	 kni and knrl, which encode related zinc finger transcription factors in the steroid hormone superfamily (Nauber et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	24	, 1989), are expressed in a single stripe corresponding to the L2 primordium beginning in the mid-third larval instar, and are required to initiate L2 development (Lunde et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	25	 kni also functions as a gap gene in early embryonic development (Nusslein-Volhard and Wieschaus, 1980; Nauber et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	26	The L2 stripe of kni/knrl-expressing cells forms along the anterior border of a broad domain of cells expressing high levels of the related and functionally overlapping spalt-major (salm) (Kuhnlein et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	27	, 1994) and spalt-related (salr) (Barrio et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	28	, 1996) zinc finger transcription factors.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	29	 A variety of evidence indicates that central domain cells expressing the patterning genes salm and salr (together referred to as sal) induce their anterior neighbors, which express very low levels of sal, to become the L2 primordium (Sturtevant et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	30	 For example, in wings containing salm-mutant clones, ectopic branches of L2 are induced that track along and inside the salm- clone borders, mimicking the normal situation in which an L2 vein forms just outside the domain of high-level sal-expressing cells (Sturtevant et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	31	 This ability of sal-expressing cells to induce their anterior low-level sal-expressing neighbors to initiate L2 development requires the activity of the kni locus (Lunde et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	32	 The induction of kni/knrl expression in the L2 primordium therefore provides an excellent system for studying the transition from spatial patterning to tissue morphogenesis.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	33	Once activated along the anterior sal border, kni and knrl organize development of the L2 vein, in part by activating expression of the key vein-promoting gene rho and by suppressing expression of the intervein gene blistered (bs) (Montagne et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	34	 The kni locus is highly selective in regulating downstream gene expression in the L2 primordium as revealed by the observation that several genes expressed in other veins, such as caup and ara, ac and sc, and Delta, are excluded from the L2 primordium.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Thus, the kni locus links patterning to vein-specific morphogenesis by functioning downstream of sal and upstream of genes involved in vein versus intervein development.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	36	The role of the kni locus in L2 formation has been clarified by analysis of likely regulatory alleles of the kni locus, previously known as radius incompletus (ri) (Arajarvi and Hannah-Alava, 1969; Lunde et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Flies with this mutation lack large sections of the L2 vein.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	38	 kniri mutants are homozygous viable, in contrast to kni null mutants, which die as embryos with a gap gene phenotype (Nusslein-Volhard and Wieschaus, 1980; Nauber et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	39	 In support of kniri mutations being wing-specific regulatory alleles of the kni/knrl locus, expression of kni and knrl in the L2 primordium is absent in kniri[1] mutants, and the L2 vein-loss phenotype can be partially rescued by ubiquitous expression of kni in the wing (Lunde et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	40	The findings summarized above suggest that kni and knrl organize the L2 vein developmental program by orchestrating expression of genes that execute distinct subsets of functions required for proper L2 development.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Several important unanswered questions remain, including: what function(s) are disrupted in kniri[1] and other existing kniri mutants?; do these mutations eliminate the function of an L2-specific cis-regulatory element in the kni locus?; and finally, with respect to the definition of L2 versus other veins, is it important to exclude expression of genes expressed in veins other than the L2 primordium?.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	42	In this study we report the identification of an enhancer element upstream of the kni coding region that selectively directs gene expression in the L2 primordium in third instar larval wing discs.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	43	 We show that three separate ri alleles have defects mapping within a minimal 1.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	44	 We demonstrate that two of these mutations eliminate activity of the L2 enhancer, kniri[1], which contains a 252 bp deletion, and kniri[53j], which harbors a single base-pair substitution.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	45	 We find that truncation of the minimal L2 enhancer to a 0.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	46	69 kb fragment leads to ectopic reporter gene expression in the extreme anterior and posterior regions of the wing, indicating that repression contributes to restricting activation of the L2 enhancer.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	47	 In addition, we show that the general wing promoting transcription factor Scalloped (Sd) binds with high affinity to several sites in the L2 enhancer and that sd is required for kni expression in the wing disc.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	48	 We have also employed the L2 enhancer element as a tool to drive expression of various UAS transgenes in the L2 primordium.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	49	 We find that the loss of the L2 vein in ri mutants can be rescued by L2-specific expression of either the kni or knrl genes, or the downstream target gene rho.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	50	 In addition, we find that misexpression of genes in the L2 primordium that are normally expressed in veins other than L2 results in abnormal L2 development.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	51	 These results provide a framework for understanding how positional information is converted into morphogenesis of the L2 wing vein by `vein organizing genes' such as kni and knrl.

0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	188	 A model for L2 initiation: global activation, regional repression and local induction.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	189	 (A) Activation of kni expression in the L2 primordium as a consequence of the action of patterning genes initiates morphogenesis of the L2 vein.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Analysis of the kni/knrl locus L2 enhancer element reveals that this element is activated in a narrow stripe by a combination of global wing specific activation, regional repression, and localized signal mediated activation.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Global wing-specific activation is provided at least in part by Sd/Vg (this study).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Regional repression is mediated either directly or indirectly by Salm/Salr (Sal) in central wing cells (Lunde et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	193	, 1998), and by a repressor(s) acting in peripheral wing cells (green domain)   possibly Brk (this study).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	194	 In addition, a short range signal X (blue), which is produced by Sal-expressing cells (pink domain) is required to induce kni/knrl expression (blue line) in cells just anterior to sal-expressing cells.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Since kni/knrl expression is activated in cells just anterior to the sal expression domain, but not in posterior cells adjacent to the sal domain (dashed blue line), there must be either a repressor (e.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	196	 En?) acting in the posterior compartment (hatched) or an activator acting in the anterior compartment together with X' which provides this AP specificity in kni/knrl activation.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	197	 The AP compartment border is indicated (solid black line).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	198	 (B) The kni/knrl L2 enhancer can be subdivided into separate domains mediating at least certain components of activation (black region) and repression (red region).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Global wing-specific activation, which requires Sd/Vg function (this study), is mediated by some combination of the empirically determined Sd binding sites (brown ovals) of which there are four single sites and one double site in the activation region.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	200	 The action of the hypothetical signal X is presumably mediated by a transcription factor X', which binds to sequences in the activation domain.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	201	 The binding site for factor X' (blue circle) may include sequences containing the single nucleotide mutated in the kniri[53j] mutant (C596A) since L2 enhancer activity is selectively lost in the L2 primordium of these flies.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	202	 This site is also eliminated in the 252 bp deletion in the kniri[1] mutant (dark blue region), as are additional sequences required for activity of the enhancer throughout the wing (e.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	203	 The repression domain contains five predicted binding sites for the repressor Brk (green diamonds), two sites for En (hatched yellow triangles), and one site for Salr (pink diamond).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Since the reporter gene expression driven by the activation region alone is repressed in central cells, this fragment must also contain some yet unidentified binding sites for Salm, Salr, or some other factor mediating the repressive effect of Salm/Salr.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	205	ri mutants have lesions in the L2 enhancer that disrupt its function As a complement to screening genomic fragments upstream of the kni locus for the ability to drive gene expression in the L2 primordium using lacZ promoter fusion constructs, we scanned the approximately 50 kb region deleted in the Df(3L)kniri[XT2] allele for detectable aberrations in five putative independently isolated ri alleles.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Using a series of probes spanning that complete genomic region (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	207	 1E), we found that a single EcoRI fragment (the same fragment E that drives expression in the L2 primordium) contains aberrations in the kniri[1], kniri[92f], kniri[M*] and kniri[M3] mutants.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	208	 For each of these alleles, mutations map within the minimal 1.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	209	4 kb L2 enhancer element (see Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Although no large-scale lesions were detected by Southern blot analysis within fragment E of the kniri[53j] mutant, subsequent sequence analysis identified a single base pair alteration within the minimal L2 enhancer element EX (see below).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	211	 The kniri[53j] allele is also associated with a small deletion (approx.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	212	Further molecular analysis of the various ri alleles revealed that the putative independently derived kniri[1], kniri[92f], and kniri[M*] alleles all contain the same 252 bp deletion.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	213	 As this deletion is not flanked by duplicated sequences that could promote frequent identical recombination events, it may be that the kniri[92f] and kniri[M*] alleles are actually re-isolates of the original kniri[1] mutation.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Consistent with these three alleles having a common origin, they also share a restriction enzyme polymorphism (i.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	215	 loss of a HindIII site) in fragment Q (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	216	 1E) that is not shared by the other ri mutants or our white- control stock.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	217	 To test whether the 252 bp deletion within the minimal L2 enhancer element is responsible for the loss of kni and knrl gene expression in kniri[1] mutants, we made a kniri[1]- mutated E-lacZ construct.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	218	 We amplified genomic DNA containing the kniri[1] mutation and substituted it for the corresponding part of the original E-lacZ construct to generate Eri1-lacZ (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	219	 1G) and transformed this construct into flies.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	220	 We examined lacZ expression in third instar larval wing discs of Eri1-lacZ flies and found that they failed to express lacZ in the L2 primordium or anywhere else in the wing pouch (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	221	 2G), indicating that the 252 bp deletion in kniri[1] mutants eliminates the activity of the L2 enhancer element.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	222	Since Southern blot analysis did not reveal any obvious lesions in fragment E of the kniri[53j] allele, we considered the possibility that this allele might have a subtler lesion in the L2 enhancer region.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Accordingly, we PCR amplified and sequenced the 1.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	224	 1G) corresponding to the minimal L2 enhancer from kniri[53j].
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	225	 We found only a single nucleotide difference between the sequence of this mutant allele and the wild-type fragment EX (C596A, Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	226	 3A), which lies within the same 252 bp region deleted in kniri[1].
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Although it has been observed that single nucleotide mutations can eliminate endogenous enhancer function (Shimell et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	228	, 1994), such cases are sufficiently rare that it was important, as in the case of kniri[1], to demonstrate whether this point mutation was responsible for the loss of enhancer function.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	229	 We used the EX kniri[53j] PCR fragment to make a lacZ construct, confirmed the sequence of the mutant construct, generated four independent transformants, and tested these flies for lacZ expression in third instar wing discs.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	230	 We found that EX(ri53j)-lacZ mutant wing discs fail to express lacZ in the L2 primordium (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	231	 2H), strongly suggesting that this single base pair mutation is responsible for the observed L2 vein loss phenotype observed in kniri[53j] flies.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	232	 One notable difference between the EX(ri53j)-lacZ and Eri1-lacZ mutant wing discs is that in the point mutant construct (ri53j), lacZ expression is lost selectively in the L2 primordium and in the weaker posterior stripe (note the normal levels and pattern of expression in extreme anterior and posterior regions of the disc, Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	233	 2H), while in the deletion mutant construct (Eri1), reporter gene expression is eliminated throughout the wing disc (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	234	As noted above, the kniri[53j] mutant is also associated with a deletion of 50 bp in fragment R, which lies approximately 15 kb 5' to fragment E within predicted intron sequences of a putative transcription unit (see kni locus map, Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	235	 As the ubiquitous expression of this transcription unit is not affected in kniri[53j] mutants (K.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	236	, unpublished observations) and fusion of fragment R with lacZ does not result in gene expression in the L2 primordium, we have no evidence to suggest that this aberration has any relevance to the L2 vein loss phenotype of kniri[53j] mutants.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	237	Analysis of the kniri[M3] allele indicates that this mutation involves an insertion and possibly rearrangements within fragment E.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	238	 One breakpoint of the kniri[M3] allele falls within the 1.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	239	4 kb EX minimal L2 enhancer element (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Because this is a relatively weak ri allele and is associated with a complex lesion, we did not characterize the nature of this rearrangement further.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	241	The wing selector protein Scalloped binds to the L2 enhancer and is required for its activity The 4.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	242	8 kb L2 enhancer fragment E and truncated derivatives (fragments EX and EC) drive reporter gene expression specifically in the wing pouch.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	243	 Recent work has shown that gene expression in the wing primordium is controlled by Sd, which functions with Vestigial (Vg) to define wing identity (Kim et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	244	, 2001; Halder and Carroll, 2001).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	245	 We tested whether Sd might similarly be required to activate endogenous kni expression by generating clones of cells homozygous for a strong hypomorphic allele of sd using FLP-FRT mediated mitotic recombination (Golic, 1991).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	246	 In sd clones, ss-galactosidase expression driven by the E-lacZ element is reduced (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	247	 In clones falling along the future wing margin, however, reporter gene expression is unaffected (not shown; see Discussion).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	248	 These results indicate that Sd plays an in vivo role in activating kni expression within the wing blade.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	249	Because Sd, a TEA-domain protein, functions as a direct transcriptional regulator of several key developmental genes expressed in the wing disc (Halder et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	250	, 2001), we tested whether Sd binds to the kni L2 enhancer.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	251	 We searched for specific Sd DNA binding sites in the 0.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	252	69 kb EC activation domain using DNAse I footprinting and gel shift analysis (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	253	 3G and data not shown) and identified five sites bound by the Sd TEA domain, which conform well to the known Sd consensus binding site and consist of a tandem doublet of Sd binding sites and four single binding sites (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	254	 The four single Sd sites are removed by the 252 bp deletion in the kniri[1] allele, however, none of them covers the kniri[53j] point mutation.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	255	 To determine whether Sd plays a direct role in activating the L2 enhancer, we mutated a subset of these Sd binding sites in the context of the EC-lacZ construct, transformed these mutated constructs into flies and stained for lacZ expression in third instar wing discs.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	256	 We found that mutation of the doublet at 271 in combination with the two single sites at 570 and 640 resulted in a complete loss of lacZ expression in the wing disc (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	257	 These results indicate that Sd is required for activation of kni expression in the wing disc.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	258	kniri[1] mutants can be rescued by kni, knrl or the downstream target gene rho Having shown that the minimal L2 enhancer is mutated in several independently derived ri alleles (kniri[1], kniri[M3], and kniri[53j]), we wished to know whether driving expression of either the kni or knrl genes with this element could rescue the ri vein-loss phenotype.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	259	 We addressed this question using the conditional GAL4/UAS expression system of Brand and Perrimon (Brand and Perrimon, 1993).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	260	 We created transgenic flies that carry fragment E driving GAL4 expression (L2-GAL4) and used this driver to activate expression of UAS-kni or UAS-knrl transgenes in the L2 primordium of kniri[1] mutants.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	261	 As expected, GAL4 RNA is expressed in the L2 primordium of L2-GAL4 wing discs (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	262	 We placed this L2-GAL4 driver and the UAS-kni and UAS-knrl transgenes into the kniri[1] mutant background and generated flies of the genotype L2-GAL4 > UAS-kni; kniri[1]/kniri[1] (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	263	 4B) and L2-GAL4 > UAS-knrl; kniri[1]/kniri[1] (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	264	 These flies have fully restored L2 veins that resemble wild-type L2 veins in that the bulk of the vein is formed on the ventral surface of the wing.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	265	View larger version (64K):    Fig.

0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	274	Misexpression of genes expressed in veins other than L2 alters L2 development As mentioned above (see Introduction), several genes that are important for vein development are expressed in veins other than L2.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	275	 For example, the vein- and sensory organ-promoting gene ara is expressed in the odd numbered veins (L1, L3, and L5), the proneural genes ac and sc are expressed in L1 and L3, and the Notch ligand Delta is expressed in L1 and L3-L5, but not in L2.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	276	 We were interested to know whether it is necessary to exclude expression of these genes from the L2 primordium for normal L2 development.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	277	 To address this question, we misexpressed UAS-transgene copies of these genes in the L2 primordium with the L2-GAL4 driver and examined the L2 vein in adult wings.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	278	 In each case, we observed defects in L2 development.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	279	 Misexpression of the lateral inhibitory signal Delta in L2-GAL4 > UAS-Dl flies results in modest truncation of the L2 vein in females (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	280	 5A) and almost entirely eliminates the L2 vein in sibling males (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	281	 5B), which are the consistently more severely affected sex.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	282	 The near elimination of L2 development in severely affected Dl-misexpressing males is accompanied by a loss of rho expression in the L2 primordium of third instar larval wing discs (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	283	 5D), compare with wild-type rho expression in Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	284	 Misexpression of the proneural gene sc in the L2 primordium of L2-GAL4 > UAS-sc flies results in L2 veins covered with ectopic bristles (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	285	 The great majority of these ectopic bristles are strictly confined to the L2 primordium, consistent with the double label experiments (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	286	 2C) indicating that the L2-enhancer element drives gene expression precisely in the L2 primordium.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	287	 In addition, ectopic bristles form sporadically in a broad posterior domain of the wing, which derives from a region of the wing disc in which the L2 enhancer element is also expressed in a weak diffuse pattern (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	288	 Finally, misexpression of the ara gene in L2-GAL4 > UAS-ara flies causes a reproducible thinning of the L2 vein (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	289	 Cumulatively, these results underscore the importance of excluding expression of non-L2 vein genes from the L2 primordium.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	290	View larger version (93K):    Fig.

0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	296	 (C) rho expression in a wild type mid third larval instar disc.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	297	 Vein primordia L2-L5 and the margin are indicated.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	298	 (D) rho expression in a 2X L2-GAL4 > UAS-Dl mid-third instar larval wing disc is lost selectively in the L2 primordium (arrow).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	299	 (E) An L2-GAL4 > UAS-sc adult male wing.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	300	 Ectopic bristles are largely confined to the L2 vein as well as to a broad posterior domain, which presumably corresponds to cells in L2-GAL4 wing discs expressing high (L2) or moderate (posterior domain) levels of GAL4 (e.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	301	 (F) An L2-GAL4 > UAS-ara adult male wing.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	302	 Note that the width of the L2 vein is reduced in the middle (arrowhead).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	303	 This thinning of L2 by misexpression of ara is a consistent phenotype that we have not observed when we misexpress the related gene caup in the same pattern (not shown).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	304	The L2-GAL4 driver can be used as a tool to dissect gene function and range of action As discussed above, the L2-GAL4 driver activates UAS transgene expression precisely in the L2 primordium.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	305	 The ability to drive highly localized expression of genes in a non-essential tissue with L2-GAL4 suggests that this driver could be used as an effective tool to dissect the function and range of action of various genes.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	306	 For example, since the eagle (eg) gene encodes a steroid hormone receptor closely related to Kni and Knrl (Rothe et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	307	, 1989) we wondered whether this gene could substitute for kni or knrl in rescuing kniri[1] mutants.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	308	 eg is involved in neuroblast specification during embryogenesis (Higashijima et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	309	, 1997; Lundell and Hirsh, 1998), but is not expressed in the wing pouch (data not shown) and is not known to play a role in development of the wing proper.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	310	 We found that, as in L2-GAL4 > UAS-kni; kniri[1]/kniri[1] individuals, L2 formation is rescued in L2-GAL4 > UAS-eg; kniri[1]/kniri[XT2] flies, however, this restored `L2' vein is decorated with a line of ectopic sensory bristles (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	311	 As the same ectopic bristles are observed in L2-GAL4 > UAS-eg individuals (data not shown), this phenotype can be attributed to misexpressing eg in the L2 primordium.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	312	 By employing the L2 expression system it should now be possible to map the domain in Eg that is responsible for inducing ectopic bristles using chimeric Eg/Kni receptors.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	313	View larger version (106K):    Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	314	 Use of the L2-GAL4 expression system to assay gene function in the wing.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	315	 (A) Rescue of the L2 vein in an L2-GAL4 > UAS-eg; kniri[1]/kniri[XT2] male adult wing.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	316	 Note the ectopic sensory bristles along the reinstated L2 vein.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	317	 (B) An L2-GAL4 > UAS-top adult male wing.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	318	 (C) An L2-GAL4 > UAS-vein adult male wing.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	319	 Note the minor degree of ectopic venation (e.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	320	 anterior to L2 and at the junction of L2 with the margin).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	321	 (D) An L2-GAL4 > UAS-secreted-spitz adult female wing.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	322	 Note the ectopic vein running parallel and anterior to L2.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	323	 (E) An L2-GAL4 > UAS-rho+UAS-Star wing.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	324	 Note patches of ectopic vein material anterior to L2.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	325	 (F) An L2-GAL4 > UAS-wingless adult male wing.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	326	 Note change in shape of the margin, ectopic vein material both anterior and posterior to L2 and ectopic bristles near the junction of L2 with the margin (magnified in insert).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	327	The L2 expression system should also be useful in distinguishing cell-autonomous from non cell-autonomous gene activity.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	328	 As a test of this idea we compared the phenotypes resulting from driving expression of an activated form of the Egfr (top) in the L2 primordium versus expression of the secreted Egf-like ligands Vein (Schnepp et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	329	, 1996) and sSpitz (Schweitzer et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	330	 Consistent with top acting in a cell autonomous fashion to promote vein versus intervein development, expression of this gene in the L2 primordium of L2-GAL4 > UAS-top wings (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	331	 6B) had no effect on the development of the L2 vein or neighboring intervein cells.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	332	 In contrast, when secreted Egf ligands were expressed in a similar fashion in L2-GAL4 > UAS-vn wings (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	333	 6C) or in L2-GAL4 > UAS-sspi wings (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	334	 6D), we observed ectopic veins that formed 2-3 cell diameters away from the L2 vein.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	335	 Similarly, when we co-expressed rho and Star in the L2 primordium (e.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	336	 in L2-GAL4 > UAS-rho; UAS-Star wings; Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	337	 6E), which also generates a potent secreted Egfr promoting activity (Guichard et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	338	, 1999), we observed ectopic veins that were displaced from the endogenous L2 vein by a few cells.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	339	 The ability of secreted ligands, but not the top construct, to induce ectopic vein formation at a distance cannot be attributed simply to the latter being a weaker activator of Egfr signaling since UAS-top is considerably more effective at generating ectopic veins than UAS-vn when other wing-GAL4 drivers are used (e.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	340	 MS1096-GAL4 or CY2-GAL4, data not shown).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	341	We also observed a non cell-autonomous activity of the Wingless (Wg) ligand in L2-GAL4 > UAS-wg wings (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	342	 6F), which had ectopic veins displaced from the endogenous L2 as well as ectopic marginal bristles near the intersection of L2 with the margin.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	343	 These ectopic marginal bristles always formed on the appropriate surface of the wing (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	344	 6F, insert), suggesting that this phenotype may result from the inappropriate activation of the wing margin genetic program.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	345	ri mutants are L2-enhancer specific regulatory alleles of the kni locus The results described in this study demonstrate definitively that ri mutations are regulatory alleles of the kni locus disrupting the function of a cis-regulatory enhancer element that drives gene expression in the L2 primordium of wing imaginal discs.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	346	 A crucial line of evidence supporting this conclusion is that mutant versions of the L2 enhancer incorporating either the 252 bp deletion present in kniri[1] or the single base pair substitution present in kniri[53j] eliminate the ability of this element to direct gene expression in the L2 primordium.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	347	 In addition, it is possible to completely rescue the vein-loss phenotype of kniri[1] by expressing either the UAS-kni or UAS-knrl transgenes with an L2-GAL4 driver.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	348	 Consistent with activation of rho being one of the key effectors of kni/knrl function, it is also possible to rescue the L2 vein-loss phenotype of kniri[1] by expressing a UAS-rho transgene in L2, although rescue is less complete and penetrant than that observed with UAS-kni or UAS-knrl.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	349	The isolation of the L2 enhancer also addresses an unresolved question regarding the basis for the failure of Df(3L)kniri[XT2] and Df(3L)kniFC82 to complement (Lunde et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	350	 As these two deletions have endpoints that break within the same 1.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	351	7 kb EcoRI fragment (indicated by the dashed vertical lines in Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	352	 1E), one explanation for the failure of complementation could be that this 1.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	353	7 kb fragment contains the L2 enhancer.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	354	 The alternative explanation for the ri phenotype of Df(3L)kniri[XT2]/Df(3L)kniFC82 is that transvection (Lewis, 1954; Geyer et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	355	, 1990; Pirrotta, 1999), which normally occurs between regulatory and coding region alleles of the kni locus (Lunde et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	356	, 1998), is interrupted by the large divergent deletions that have little if any overlap.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	357	8 EcoRI fragment containing the L2 enhancer maps nearly 10 kb upstream of the 1.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	358	7 kb EcoRI fragment, and a lacZ fusion construct (abd-lacZ, Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	359	7 kb EcoRI fragment does not drive any gene expression in the wing disc (Lunde et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	360	, 1998), the latter hypothesis that Df(3L)kniri[XT2] and Df(3L)kniFC82 are unable to engage in effective transvection is the most likely explanation for the failure of these two mutations to complement.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	361	Global activation, regional repression and localized induction restrict L2-enhancer activity to a narrow stripe of cells The results of these and previous studies of L2 vein initiation lead to a model in which localized vein inductive signaling acts against a background of regional repression and global wing-specific activation (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	362	 Previous genetic experiments have suggested a model in which sal-expressing cells produce a short-range L2 inducing signal (X) to which sal-expressing cells themselves cannot respond (Sturtevant et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	363	 According to this `for export only' signaling model, the signal X diffuses into adjacent anterior cells and activates expression of the kni/knrl genes in the L2 primordium, in much the same fashion as Hh, expressed from the refractory posterior compartment, activates expression of target genes such as dpp or ptc in the anterior compartment (reviewed by Bier, 2000).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	364	 Based on the analysis of the L2 enhancer element described in this study, the 252 bp region deleted in kniri[1] mutants may contain response element(s) to this putative factor X.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	365	 It is worth noting, however, that lacZ expression is lost in all cells of the wing disc (posterior and circumferential cells as well as the L2 primordium) when these sequences are deleted from the 4.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	366	 This observation suggests that sequences mediating more general activation (e.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	367	 Sd binding sites, see below) may also be contained within this 252 bp region.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	368	 The sequence surrounding the single nucleotide alteration in kniri[53j] mutants (C596A), however, is a particularly intriguing candidate for mediating the L2-specific activation of kni since introducing this mutation in the context of the minimal 1.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	369	4 kb enhancer leads to selective loss of lacZ expression only in the stripe of cells adjacent to the sal domain.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	370	The hypothetical transcription factor X' (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	371	 7B) that binds to the region surrounding the kniri[53j] point mutation and mediates the inductive signal X presumably collaborates with the more generally required wing selector Sd (Halder et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	372	, 2001), since mutation of four of the Sd binding sites (the doublet and two single sites) in the L2 activation domain completely eliminates enhancer activity in the wing disc.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	373	 Clonal analysis with a hypomorphic sd allele also indicates that sd is required for high-level expression of the full 4.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	374	8 kb L2 enhancer element in the wing disc.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	375	 It is notable that the reduction in lacZ expression in these clones is not as dramatic as the complete loss of L2 activity observed when Sd binding sites in the activation domain are mutated.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	376	 There are several possible explanations for this discrepancy.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	377	 Firstly, the sd mutation used in these experiments is a hypomorphic allele and therefore has residual activity.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	378	 Unfortunately, stronger sd alleles produce even smaller viable clones in the wing disc and thus were not used.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	379	 Secondly, as only small clones can be generated, they must typically have been produced with only two or three intervening cycles of cell division.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	380	 Consequently, the sd  cells may still contain functional levels of wild type Sd (protein perdurance).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	381	 Another possibility is that other activators can partially substitute for Sd, at least in certain regions of the wing.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	382	 Based on the absence of L2 activity when Sd binding sites are mutated and the reduction in L2 activity in sd  hypomorphic clones, we conclude that Sd plays an important role as an activator of the L2 enhancer.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	383	 These results support the view that Sd functions as a general transcriptional activator of genes expressed in the wing field.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	384	Repression also plays a key role in restricting L2 enhancer expression to a narrow stripe of wing disc cells.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	385	 It has been shown previously that salm and salr, which are expressed strongly in the central region of the wing, repress expression of kni and knrl (Lunde et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	386	, 1998), although low levels of sal may also be required to activate kni expression (de Celis and Barrio, 2000).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	387	 In the current study we also find evidence for repression of L2-enhancer activity in peripheral wing disc cells abutting those expressing high levels of sal.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	388	4 kb (fragment EX) L2 enhancer element results in reporter gene expression expanding to fill the anterior and posterior regions of the wing pouch in a pattern complementary to that of sal.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	389	 The region deleted from the EX fragment contains several consensus binding sites for Brinker (Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	390	, 2001), which may mediate this repression since the pattern of brinker (brk) expression in the wing pouch (Campbell and Tomlinson, 1999; Jazwinska et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	391	, 1999) is very similar to that of lacZ expression driven by the 0.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	392	 One way to integrate the action of the localized inductive signal XX' pathway with that of abutting central and peripheral repressive factors is to propose that the signal-dependent activator X' can overcome the repressive action of the peripheral inhibitor but not repression by Salm/Salr (see legend to Fig.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	393	 One feature common to several prominent signaling pathways is that activation of the pathway converts a resting repressor into a transcriptional activator (Barolo and Posakony, 2002).
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	394	 In the kni L2 enhancer, activation of the hypothetical signal X pathway may relieve repression by a heterologous repressor since the putative activator (i.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	395	 Brk?) sequences in the L2 enhancer are separable.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	396	 One example of a signaling pathway that functions by relieving inhibition by a heterologous repressor is the recent report of Egfr signaling inactivating repression by Suppressor of Hairless (Su(H)) (Tsuda et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	397	 In addition to central and peripheral repression in the wing disc, there may also be a repressor in posterior compartment cells (e.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	398	 7A,B) to prevent activation of the L2 enhancer in cells posterior to the sal expression domain.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	399	8 kb L2 enhancer element lacks some sites for this putative repressor since E-lacZ drives significantly higher levels of gene expression in the posterior stripe than that observed for endogenous kni or knrl expression.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	400	Expression of non-L2 vein genes must be excluded from the L2 primordium All longitudinal veins share several morphological characteristics such as being composed of densely packed cells on both the dorsal and ventral surfaces of the wing that secrete a thickened cuticle.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	401	 The primordia of all longitudinal veins also express the rhomboid gene, which is required for activating the Egfr pathway in vein but not in intervein cells.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	402	 In addition to these shared properties, each vein can be distinguished by expression of other vein genes (Biehs et al.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	403	 For example, vein L2-specific characteristics include: expression of kni and knrl, lack of Delta expression, lack of cauplara expression, and lack of ac/sc expression.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	404	 Given that all veins are ultimately quite similar morphologically, it is relevant to ask whether the differences in gene expression patterns observed in different veins are important.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	405	In this study, we examined the necessity of excluding expression of non-L2 vein genes in the L2 primordium by forcing expression of genes such as Dl, ara, ac and sc in L2 and asking whether this manipulation had any impact on L2 development.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	406	 These experiments strongly suggest that exclusion of non-L2 vein genes from the L2 primordium is indeed important since misexpression of each of these genes resulted in abnormal L2 development.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	407	 The phenotypes resulting from misexpressing non-L2 vein genes in the L2 primordium can largely be reconciled with the normal functions of these genes.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	408	 For example, forced expression of Dl leads to loss of L2, consistent with suppression of vein formation by Notch signaling.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	409	 The ectopic bristles that form strictly along the L2 vein in wings misexpressing ac or sc are also consistent with the neural promoting function of proneural genes.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	410	 It is less clear why misexpression of the ara gene causes thinning of the L2 primordium, since this gene normally activates expression of the vein-promoting gene rho in odd numbered veins and ac and sc in the L3 primordium.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	411	 Perhaps expression of a gene normally involved in development of the odd numbered dorsal veins is somehow incompatible with development of the ventral L2 vein.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	412	The L2 expression system provides a localized assay for gene function in the wing The sharp stripe of gene expression driven by L2-GAL4 can also be used as a rapid assay to test the function or range of action of various genes in the wing.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	413	 For example, in the case of the Egfr pathway, it is possible to distinguish components exerting cell-autonomous versus non cell-autonomous functions.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	414	 In line with the fact that activation of the Egfr pathway in the wing leads to the formation of veins, L2-GAL4-driven expression of the secreted ligand sSpi generates ectopic veins in the neighborhood of L2 while expression of the equally potent constitutively active top form of the EGF receptor does not result in a non-autonomous phenotype.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	415	 The L2 expression system may also be used to compare the functions of related genes such as the nuclear receptors Kni, Knrl, and Eg.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	416	 Although these three transcription factors share nearly identical DNA binding domains and can all rescue the vein-loss phenotype of ri mutants, they differ in that misexpression of eg in the L2 primordium induces the formation of ectopic bristles along L2.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	417	 This distinct activity of eg may relate to its normal embryonic function in directing cell fate choices in the CNS.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	418	 Using the L2 expression system as an assay, it should be straightforward to map the domain in eg that is responsible for its neural inducing capacity by constructing chimeric molecules composed of different domains of Eg and Kni.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	419	 Finally, the observation that L2-driven expression of Dl leads to a highly penetrant loss of L2 in males and a consistently weaker phenotype in females provides the basis for a modifier screen to identify mutations that either suppress the phenotype in males or enhance the phenotype in females.
0.22649837.12466192.html.plaintext.txt	420	 Some of the modifier loci identified in such a screen, which are not specifically involved in Notch signaling, may encode components of the hypothesized factor XX' pathway.

0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	0	Inhibition of Human Papillomavirus DNA Replication by Small Molecule Antagonists of the E1-E2 Protein Interaction* Peter W.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	1	 White , Steve Titolo , Karine Brault , Louise Thauvette , Alex Pelletier , Ewald Welchner , Lise Bourgon , Louise Doyon , William W.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	2	 Ogilvie , Christiane Yoakim , Michael G.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	3	 Cordingley  and Jacques Archambault   .
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	4	From the Department of Biological Sciences and the Department of Chemistry, Boehringer Ingelheim Ltd.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	5	Received for publication, April 7, 2003.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	6	The life cycle of HPV is coupled to the cellular differentiation program that occurs in the epithelium (7).
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Maintenance of the viral genome in infected cells of the basal layer is essential for the viral life cycle and the ensuing pathology.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Maintenance of the HPV episome in primary keratinocyte cultures depends on the function of E1 and E2, a 3'-5' helicase (8) and a sequence-specific DNA-binding protein (9), respectively, which are required for replication of the genome (10).
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	9	 HPV DNA replication is initiated by the co-operative binding of E1 and E2 to specific DNA sequences within the viral origin (11 to 14).
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Formation of this E1-E2-ori ternary complex is dependent on the interaction of both proteins with DNA but also on a critical interaction between the N-terminal transactivation domain (TAD) of E2 and the C-terminal enzymatic domain of E1 (15 to 22).
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Assembly of this initial E1-E2-ori complex serves as a starting point for the recruitment of additional E1 molecules (23, 24) and their assembly into hexamers and double hexamers that have ATPase and helicase activity (25, 26).
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	12	Any of the protein-protein and protein-DNA interactions occurring at the origin could in principle be targeted for the development of small molecule antivirals to treat HPV infections.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	13	 In reality, however, not all targets are readily amenable to inhibition by small molecules.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Protein interactions for example have been considered difficult to inhibit because they often involve large surfaces devoid of small molecule binding pockets (27, 28).
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	15	 In the absence of structural information, one often has to rely on screening large compound collections to determine whether a protein can be antagonized by small molecules and for the identification of lead inhibitors.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	16	Here we present a class of small molecules that bind reversibly to the E2 transactivation domain and inhibit the E1-E2 protein interaction in vitro and in vivo.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	17	 The chemical features and synthetic procedures for these molecules will be described elsewhere.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	18	2 To our knowledge these are the first small molecule inhibitors of HPV DNA replication with cellular activity.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	19	 As such they highlight the potential of the E1-E2 interaction as an antiviral drug target.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	20	Plasmid Constructions The plasmid used for expression of HPV11 E2 TAD (amino acids 2 to 201) fused at its N terminus to a 6-histidine tag (amino acid sequence MGHHHHHH) was constructed by inserting a PCR fragment encoding the TAD and the tag in pET28b (Novagen).
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	21	 The plasmid to express CRPV E2 by in vitro transcription/translation was constructed by inserting a PCR fragment corresponding to nucleotides 3107 to 4287 of the CRPV genome in plasmid pCR3.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	22	 The plasmid containing the CRPV origin of replication was constructed by inserting a PstI restriction fragment corresponding to nucleotides 192 to 7111 of CRPV into pBluescript SK(+) (Stratagene).
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Plasmids pOri-SEAP and pGAL4-SEAP encoding, respectively, the HPV11 origin and five GAL4-binding sites upstream of secreted alkaline phosphatase were constructed by inserting a PCR fragment spanning nucleotides 7884 to 61 of the HPV11 genome or the five GAL4-binding sites from pG5CAT (Clontech) into pSEAP2-Basic (Clontech).
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	24	 The plasmid encoding E1 fused to the transactivation domain of HSV VP16 (pE1-VP16) was constructed by inserting a PCR fragment encoding E1 into pVP16 (Clontech).
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	25	 HPV/CRPV E2 chimeras were constructed by PCR-mediated ligation as described previously (29) and cloned into pCR3.

0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	124	The E1-E2 Protein Interaction Is the Target of Inhibition  Co-operative binding of E1 and E2 to DNA involves the interaction of both proteins with each other and with DNA.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	125	 The inhibitors were found to be inactive or only weakly active in assays that measure the binding of E2 to DNA (Fig.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Compound 1 was also inactive at inhibiting the helicase activity of E1 (IC50  >  100  microM).
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Hence this class of compounds does not affect the binding of either E1 or E2 to DNA.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	128	 These results suggested that the E1-E2 protein interaction might be the target of inhibition.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	129	 This hypothesis was tested using an ELISA.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	130	 The E2 protein used in this assay was either purified from baculovirus-infected insect cells or obtained by in vitro translation; both sources yielded similar results.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Binding of recombinant E1 to immobilized E2 was detected using an anti-E1 antiserum followed by a secondary antibody coupled to horseradish peroxidase.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	132	 3A, the signal was dependent on the interaction of E1 with E2 because it was reduced by the E39A substitution in E2.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	133	 As anticipated, the I73A substitution had little effect.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	134	 3, B and C, all three compounds inhibited binding of E1 to E2 with potency comparable with that measured in the E1-E2-ori complex formation assay.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	135	 The compounds inhibited the E1-E2 interaction regardless of whether the assay was performed with hexameric E1 purified from baculovirus-infected insect cells or with monomeric E1 made by in vitro translation (data not shown).
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Thus the molecular target of these inhibitors is the E1-E2 protein interaction.

0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	144	Inhibitors Bind to the Transactivation Domain of E2 Having found that inhibitor 1 and its derivatives antagonize the E1-E2 protein interaction, we then wished to determine to which protein these compounds were binding.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	145	 First, we investigated whether addition of compound 2 had any effect on the spectroscopic behavior of either E1 or E2.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Fluorescent amino acids such as tryptophan are often found in or close to binding pockets, and the binding of ligands to such sites has been shown to perturb protein fluorescence in some cases (39).
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Compound 2 was titrated into solutions of 400 nM E1 or E2 (Fig.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Although a slight effect was observed on the fluorescence of E1, a much greater level of quenching was observed for E2, consistent with this compound binding to E2.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	149	 The slight effect observed on E1 and the lack of saturation for E2 at high compound concentrations could be explained by weak nonspecific binding of compound 2 to other protein sites, reminiscent of the low level of activity observed in the SV40 T antigen DNA binding assay (Fig.

0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	156	E2 can be divided into an N-terminal transactivation domain (TAD, approximately amino acids 1 to 200) and a C-terminal DNA binding/dimerization domain (DBD, the last 100 amino acids), separated by a 50 to 70-amino acid "hinge" with little predicted secondary structure (9).
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Because for HPV11 it is known that the TAD, but not the DBD, interacts with E1 (16, 40), we repeated the titration with a GST fusion protein encoding the E2 TAD, as well as with GST itself as a negative control (Fig.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	158	 The results clearly indicated saturable binding of 2 to the GST-TAD but not to GST, indicating that the compound binds to the TAD.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Similar results were also obtained with a polyhistidine-tagged version of the E2 TAD (data not shown).
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	160	Next, we quantified the binding of inhibitor 2 to a polyhistidine-tagged TAD using isothermal titration calorimetry (Fig.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	161	 A dissociation constant of 230 nM was obtained by nonlinear regression, in good agreement with the IC50 obtained in the E1-E2-ori complex formation assay.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	162	 The observed 2:1 stoichiometry is consistent with the formation of a 1:1 inhibitor-protein complex, because compound 2 is racemic, and it has been observed for other compounds in this series that only one of the two enantiomers is active (see below).
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	163	3 Collectively, the results presented above provide strong evidence that this class of inhibitor antagonizes the E1-E2 protein interaction by binding to the E2 TAD.
