0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	171	Functional Evidence That the E2 TAD Is the Target of Inhibition During the course of this study we found that in vitro translated CRPV E2 can bind co-operatively with purified HPV11 E1 to either the HPV11 or CRPV origins, albeit weakly.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	172	 CRPV E2, however, was found to be resistant to inhibition by compound 2 (Fig.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	173	 6), perhaps not surprisingly given the low level of amino acid identity between the TAD of HPV11 and that of CRPV.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Similarly, we found that the inhibitors are inactive against the E2 protein of the high risk HPV types 16, 18, and 31 (data not shown), which at the amino acid level are only 41 to 50% identical to HPV11 E2.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	175	 We made use of the observation that some E2 types are resistant to inhibition to substantiate the finding that the TAD is indeed the target of the inhibitors.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	176	 Specifically, we constructed chimeric E2 proteins encoding the HPV11 TAD with the hinge and DNA-binding domain from CRPV, or the opposite combination.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	177	 These chimeras were expressed in vitro and tested in the E1-E2-ori complex formation assay using HPV11 E1.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Both chimeras could bind co-operatively with E1 on the origin, but only the one containing the TAD from HPV11 was sensitive to inhibition by compound 2 (Fig.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	179	 This result provides functional evidence that the TAD is indeed the target of inhibition.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	180	Inhibition Is Reversible It is generally expected to be difficult to identify inhibitors of protein interactions that act by reversible binding rather than by reacting with the target protein or by some other irreversible mechanism (27).
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	181	 To determine whether inhibition of E1-E2-ori complex formation was reversible, we performed the preincubation experiment shown in Fig.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	182	 In this experiment, E2, the target protein, was incubated with a high concentration of inhibitor and then diluted into the E1-E2-ori complex formation assay to a final compound concentration 10-fold below the IC50.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	183	 We reasoned that if the inhibitor is acting by a reversible mechanism, the activity of E2 should be recovered upon dilution of the inhibitor.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	184	 However, if the mechanism of inhibition is irreversible then significant inhibition should be observed even after dilution.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	185	 As a control, we used the known reactive electrophile, 4-fluoro-7-nitro-(2,1,3)-benzoxadiazole.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Preincubation with this compound resulted in significant inhibition even after dilution to a concentration well below the IC50.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	187	 In contrast, preincubation of E2 with compound 2 did not lead to any significant inhibition upon dilution (compare 3rd bar to 1st and 2nd bars from the left in Fig.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Thus compound 2 acts by a reversible mechanism.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	189	View larger version (17K):    FIG.

0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	215	Inhibition of the E1-E2 Protein Interaction in Vivo To ascertain the mechanism of action of the inhibitors in vivo, we established a cellular assay that measures the interaction of HPV11 E1 and E2.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Specifically, this assay measures the expression of a SEAP reporter gene, placed under the control of the HPV11 minimal origin of replication, upon co-transfection of two plasmids encoding, respectively, E2 and the E1 protein fused to the strong transactivation domain of HSV VP16 (Fig.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	217	 In this assay, neither E2 nor E1-VP16 could by itself activate expression of the reporter gene (Fig.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	218	 The lack of transactivation by E2 is consistent with the previous observation that E2 of the low risk HPV types are weak transactivators (41).
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Maximal expression of the reporter gene was dependent on the expression of both E1-VP16 and E2 and on their interaction, because it was greatly reduced by the E39A substitution in E2 which affects E1 binding (Fig.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	220	 As expected, the I73A substitution in E2 had no negative effect.

0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Little SEAP activity is obtained if E1 is not fused to the VP16 activation domain (data not shown).
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	229	Having confirmed that expression of the reporter gene was dependent on the interaction between E1 and E2, we then tested the effect of compounds 2 and 3 in this assay and in a similar one based on E1 and E2 from HPV6.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Compounds 2 and 3 inhibited SEAP synthesis induced by the HPV11 proteins with IC50 values of 14 and 2  microM, respectively (Fig.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	231	 The similar potency of compound 3 in the reporter and transient HPV DNA replication assays suggests that its inhibitory activity on viral DNA replication is indeed due to abrogation of the E1-E2 protein interaction.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Inhibitors 2 and 3 were also found to be active against the HPV6 proteins, albeit with reduced potency, with IC50 values of 22 and 6  microM, respectively.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	233	 Interestingly, the difference in potency between HPV11 and HPV6 protein was about 4 to 7-fold in this cellular assay compared with 25 to 30-fold in vitro (Fig.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	234	 The exact reason for the smaller difference in potency against HPV6 and HPV11 proteins in vivo is currently unknown but could be related to slight alterations in the conformation of E2 in vivo compared with in vitro (see under "Discussion").
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	235	 As a control for specificity, we verified that the inhibitors had little effect on the expression of an unrelated SEAP reporter transactivated by a GAL4-VP16 fusion protein (Fig.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	236	 As an additional control for specificity, we showed that an enantiomer of inhibitor 3 that is nearly inactive in vitro (IC50 = 29  microM in the E1-E2-ori complex formation assay) was also inactive in the cellular assay (data not shown).
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	237	View larger version (21K):    FIG.

0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	246	To gain additional evidence that the inhibitors were acting in vivo by the same mechanism as in vitro, we made use of a mutant E2 protein that has a higher affinity for this class of inhibitors.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	247	 This mutant protein contains a single amino substitution in the TAD, E100A, which makes it 10-fold more sensitive to this class of inhibitors than wild type E2 in the in vitro E1-E2-ori complex formation assay.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	248	 The E100A substitution was discovered during a mutational analysis of the E2 TAD aimed at identifying residues involved in compound binding (data not shown).
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	249	 Importantly, this amino acid substitution also increased the sensitivity of E2 in the reporter assay (Fig.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	250	 This result provides strong evidence that the mechanism of action of this class of inhibitors is the same in vivo as in vitro.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	251	The discovery of inhibitors of the E1-E2 protein interaction from HPV types 6 and 11 highlights the potential of E2 as a drug target for the treatment of anogenital warts.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	252	 The genome of HPV6 and HPV11 is present in episomal form in 90% of genital warts (42, 43), and inhibition of the E1-E2 interaction is expected to provide therapeutic benefits (44).
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	253	 In this respect, it is worth noting that E1 and E2 are likely to be expressed at much lower levels in natural infections than in transfected cells, a fact that could lead us to underestimate the true potency of these inhibitors.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	254	 Determining the real antiviral activity of these inhibitors awaits the development of a straightforward and quantitative HPV viral replication assay.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	255	Specificity of Inhibition The inhibitors presented in this study are active against the E2 protein of the two most prevalent low risk HPV types, 6 and 11, but are nevertheless more potent against the HPV11 protein by 10 to 40-fold in vitro.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	256	 This difference in potency was observed both with purified proteins and with proteins produced by in vitro translation.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	257	 Because we have found no evidence that HPV6 E1 and E2 interacts more strongly than the HPV11 proteins (data not shown), we surmise that the inhibitors must bind less tightly to HPV6 E2.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	258	 The HPV6 and HPV11 TAD are 84% identical at the primary amino acid sequence levels, and any of the amino acid differences or combinations thereof could affect binding of the inhibitor.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Surprisingly, we found that the difference in potency observed in cellular assays is less pronounced.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	260	 Indeed, the difference in IC50 values is only 3-fold in the transient HPV DNA replication assay.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	261	3 This reduced difference between type 6 and 11 was also observed in the E1-E2 interaction reporter gene assay suggesting that this class of compound does indeed inhibit the E1-E2 interaction of both HPV types with comparable potency in cells.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	262	 It is possible that a conformational change necessary for inhibitor binding has a more similar energetic cost for both HPV types in vivo than in vitro, perhaps because the conformation of E2 in vivo is slightly different as a result of interaction with cellular proteins.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	263	 Further studies will be required to address this possibility.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	264	Amino Acids in E2 Involved in Inhibition Prior to this report a 15-amino acid peptide derived from HPV16 E2 and spanning residue Glu-39 was shown to be capable of inhibiting the E1-E2 interaction in vitro (45).
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	265	 Several studies have suggested an essential role for Glu-39 in interaction with E1.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	266	 Specifically, changing this residue to alanine was shown to abrogate the ability of E2 to bind to E1 (36 to 38), as confirmed in this study, while having little effect on its transcriptional activity.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	267	 These findings suggested that Glu-39 might form part of the E1-binding surface on E2.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	268	 Two lines of evidence suggest that our inhibitors may bind near Glu-39 to antagonize the E1-E2 interaction.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	269	 First, the Glu-100 residue, which when changed to alanine increases the sensitivity of HPV11 E2 to our inhibitors, is located on the same surface as Glu-39 in the crystal structure of the HPV16 E2 TAD (46).
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	270	 Second, we found that our inhibitors bind with reduced affinity to the E39A mutant E2 TAD in fluorescence studies similar to those presented in Fig.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	271	 The simplest interpretation of these results is that the surface of the E2 TAD onto which Glu-39 and Glu-100 are located is involved in binding both E1 and our inhibitors.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	272	 Because these inhibitors are inactive against HPV16 E2, we did not attempt to model them into the published structure of the HPV16 E2 TAD.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	273	 However, further studies are in progress to localize the inhibitor-binding pocket on the HPV11 E2 TAD.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	274	Protein Interactions as Drug Targets The compounds presented here belong to a relatively small group of small molecules that effectively inhibit protein interactions.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	275	 With only a few exceptions most protein interaction inhibitors have been identified for cases in which the binding surface for one protein is known to be a small contiguous region, such as for receptor-ligand interactions (47, 48).
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	276	 Many of the small molecules reported to inhibit protein interactions are peptides identified either by screening procedures such as phage display, or from panels of overlapping peptides based on the protein sequence, or selected based on results of structural or mutational studies (49).
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	277	 Most of these peptides are relatively weak inhibitors, and although in principle these can serve as lead compounds for drug discovery, in practice transformation of such molecules into potent non-peptidic inhibitors is quite challenging.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	278	A variety of reasons has been proposed for the relatively low number of small molecule inhibitors of protein interactions.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	279	 One is that small molecules would have difficulty competing against the large surface area typically involved in protein-protein interface.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	280	 However, it has been shown in a number of cases (e.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	281	 50) that substitution of a single critical residue at an interface, which is conceptually analogous to tight binding of a small molecule, is sufficient to greatly weaken an interaction.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	282	 An example of this may be the E39A substitution in E2, which as argued above may abrogate E1 binding because it is located at the E1-E2 interface.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	283	 A second reason why protein interactions are thought to be difficult targets for small molecules is because their interfaces can be fairly flat and devoid of concave pockets analogous to enzyme-active sites or receptor-binding sites (51).
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	284	 Although this is true for some complexes, others have been found to be "bumpy" such that small cavities are often present (52, 53).
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	285	 Perhaps relatively few protein interaction inhibitors have been identified to date only because more effort has been devoted to traditional targets, such as enzymes and receptors.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	286	 We have in fact succeeded in identifying potent small molecule inhibitors of the E1-E2 interaction by high throughput screening.
0.2327217.12730224.html.plaintext.txt	287	 This strongly suggests that other investigations will also yield novel small molecule inhibitors of protein interactions as drug candidates.

0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	0	Overlapping reading frames in closely related human papillomaviruses result in modular rates of selection within E2 Apurva Narechania1, Masanori Terai1 and Robert D.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	1	1 Department of Microbiology and Immunology, The Albert Einstein Cancer Center, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, 1300 Morris Park Ave, Bronx, NY 10461, USA 2 Department of Pediatrics, The Albert Einstein Cancer Center, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, 1300 Morris Park Ave, Bronx, NY 10461, USA 3 Department of Obstetrics, Gynecology and Women's Health, The Albert Einstein Cancer Center, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, 1300 Morris Park Ave, Bronx, NY 10461, USA 4 Department of Epidemiology and Population Health, The Albert Einstein Cancer Center, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, 1300 Morris Park Ave, Bronx, NY 10461, USA.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	2	The GenBank/EMBL/DDBJ accession numbers for the sequences reported in this work are AF436129 (HPV54A) and AF293961 (HPV82A).
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	3	The typical HPV genome contains six open reading frames (ORFs) encoding the structural proteins (L1 and L2), proteins that mediate the viral life cycle (E1 and E2) and proteins that regulate host-cell DNA replication and transformation (E6 and E7) (Knipe et al.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	4	 E6 and E7 bind the cell-cycle regulators p53 and pRb, respectively.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Among highly cancerous types, these oncogenes degrade p53 and pRb, resulting in host-cell immortalization and proliferation (reviewed by Fehrmann  and  Laimins, 2003).
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Some papillomaviruses (PVs) also encode the E4 and E5 genes, whose roles, although largely unknown, seem to involve functions in the later phases of the viral life cycle (Longworth  and  Laimins, 2004; Peh et al.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	7	 The E5 ORF is situated between E2 and L2 in typical PV genomes.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	8	 In most cases, E5 does not overlap with any of its neighbours; however, the E4 ORF is contained completely within E2.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	9	A great deal of effort has been spent studying the evolutionary implications of overlapping reading frames in viruses (Hein  and  Stovlbaek, 1995; Krakauer, 2000; Miyata  and  Yasunaga, 1978).
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	10	 A fundamental question is how natural selection operates on two protein sequences encoded by the same stretch of DNA.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	11	 We address this question in the context of HPV E2 and E4, highlighting rates of synonymous and non-synonymous substitution in overlapping reading frames.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	12	 To this end, we utilized two recently cloned and sequenced viral isolates, HPV AE2/IS39 and HPV AE9.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Although initially thought to be novel types (10 % variance in L1 nucleotide sequences) based on sequence analysis of the MY09/MY11 region of the L1 ORF, upon analysis of their complete genomes, HPV AE2/IS39 and HPV AE9 were found to be subtypes (2 to 10 % variance in L1 sequences) of HPV82 and HPV54, respectively.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	14	 In this report, we examine rates of evolution of each ORF by using dN/dS ratios across these subtype pairs and other closely related mucosal types.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Closely related genomes allow examination of evolutionary change prior to saturation of genetic changes.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	16	 We focus specifically on the modular rates of selection exhibited by E2 and a possible explanation for this modularity, in the overlapping ORF, E4.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	17	To clone the potentially novel genomes, PCR primers were designed by alignment of closely related HPV genomes using the sequences of the partial L1 region amplified by MY09/MY11 primers.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Additional primers were used to amplify the entire genome in fragments by using overlapping PCR amplification, as described previously (Terai  and  Burk, 2002).
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	19	 PCR products were separated by agarose-gel electrophoresis, stained with ethidium bromide and visualized under UV illumination.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	20	 After confirmation of appropriate product sizes, each PCR product was purified (Qiagen gel-extraction kit) and ligated into the pGEM-T Easy vector (Promega) according to the manufacturer's instructions.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Initially, SP6 and T7 primers flanking each HPV DNA insert were used to determine the nucleotide sequence.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Additional primers were designed by sequence walking.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Sequencing was performed in the Albert Einstein Cancer Center DNA-sequencing facility.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Overlapping fragments were assembled manually and several additional primers were used to clarify sequence ambiguities.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	25	 The primer sequences used are available from the authors on request.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	26	Pairwise sequence alignments were performed by using CLUSTAL W (Thompson et al.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	27	, 1994) with a gap cost of 10 0 and the IUB weight matrix.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Multiple sequence alignments, providing prototype and subtype phylogenetic context, were generated in the same way.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Calculation of overall, ORF-wide non-synonymous and synonymous changes and rates of non-synonymous and synonymous change were done by using SNAP (Synonymous/Non-synonymous Analysis Program) (Korber, 2002; Nei  and  Gojobori, 1986) and K-Estimator was used to perform sliding-window analysis of dN/dS (Comeron, 1999).
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	30	Phylogenetic trees were constructed in PAUP (version 4.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	31	10) (Swofford, 1998) from multiple sequence alignments of the E6, E7, E1, E2, L2 and L1 concatenated ORFs, using both distance (neighbour-joining) and parsimony methods.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Alignment gaps were coded as missing before distance and parsimony trees were reconstructed by using equal-weighted characters and 100 bootstrap replicates.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	33	 To ensure adequate searches in the tree space, 100 random-addition heuristic searches and TBR (tree bisection and reconnection) swapping were employed.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	34	HPVs used in this study and their GenBank accession numbers are as follows: HPV7 (NC_001595), HPV11 (NC_001525), HPV27 (NC_001584), HPV40 (NC_001589), HPV44 (NC_001689), HPV54 (NC_001676), HPV55 (NC_001692), HPV82 (NC_002172), HPV13 (NC_001349), HPV26 (NC_001583), HPV30 (NC_001585), HPV32 (NC_001586), HPV42 (NC_001534), HPV51 (NC_001533), HPV53 (NC_001593), HPV56 (NC_001594), HPV66 (NC_001695), HPV69 (NC_002171), HPV74 (NC_004501), HPV91 (NC_004085), HPV54A (AF436129) and HPV82A (AF293961).
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	35	The genomes of HPV54A and HPV82A share a high level of similarity with their prototypes.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	36	 A comparison of whole genomes reveals 93 5 % nucleic acid similarity between HPV54 and HPV54A, and 89 8 % similarity between HPV82 and HPV82A.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	37	 The currently accepted criterion for HPV classification relies on comparison of L1 nucleotide ORFs.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	38	 The L1 ORF in the HPV54 pair diverges by 4 6 %, whilst the HPV82 pair diverges by 7 7 %, placing both isolates within the subtype range.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	39	As expected, subtype and prototype genome lengths are also comparable.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	40	 HPV82 and HPV82A are 7871 and 7904 bp, respectively, whilst HPV54 and HPV54A are 7759 and 7717 bp in length.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Each pair contains the anticipated PV ORFs, including the E6 and E7 proteins, the replication proteins (E1 and E2) and components of the viral capsid (L1 and L2).
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	42	 The only major difference in genomic architecture across the two pairs is HPV54's lack of an E5 homologue.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	43	 HPV82 contains an unambiguous E5 ORF, but lacks a proximal start codon, whereas the corresponding genomic region in HPV54 is as variable as some sections of its upstream regulatory region.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Lack of evidence for E5 in HPV54 reinforces its status as a unique outlier, rooting members of the -PV species clades 1, 8 and 10 (Fig.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	45	 1), all of which contain an intact E5 ORF.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The identification of an HPV54 subtype implies that this ancient part of the tree still appears to be evolving.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	47	 In their greater phylogenetic context, HPV82A and HPV54A sort into species groups 5 and 13, respectively.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	48	 This evolutionary relationship held in phylogenies constructed from either the concatenated ORFs or L1 nucleotide sequences alone (data not shown) (Fig.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	49	View larger version (15K):    Fig.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Phylogenetic trees constructed by using maximum-parsimony and distance methods resulted in identical topologies.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Representative cladograms of (a) HPV82 and its taxonomic context and (b) HPV54 and its taxonomic context are shown.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Both trees were based on the alignment of the nucleotide sequences of compiled ORFs (E6, E7, E1, E2, L2 and L1) of the indicated PV genomes.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Bootstrap values for the parsimony calculation are provided at all nodes.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Numbers to the right indicate the taxonomic species group of the -PVs (de Villiers et al.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	55	  The distribution of polymorphisms across each ORF within HPV54 and HPV82 is shown in Table 1, accompanied by four closely related genital HPV pairs.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	56	 The subtypes HPV44 and HPV55 and the sister taxa HPV6 and HPV11, HPV7 and HPV40, and HPV2 and HPV27 were chosen because they all exhibit whole-genome divergence of  < 15 %.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	57	 These closely related pairs allow unambiguous alignment and are less likely to be subject to saturation of genetic variation.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	58	 To examine the possibility of directional selection, we calculated the ratio of non-synonymous substitutions per non-synonymous site (dN) to synonymous substitutions per synonymous site (dS).
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	59	 A dN/dS ratio equal to 1 indicates neutrality, a ratio  < 1 indicates purifying selection and a ratio  > 1 indicates positive Darwinian selection (Yang, 1998).
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Overall, the small ratios of non-synonymous to synonymous changes and dN/dS values indicate that E1, L1 and L2 are under strong purifying selection, forming a functional core essential to the viral life cycle.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Previously, we had also included E2 in this group because of its presence in all known PVs and its role in viral-genome replication (Narechania et al.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	62	 However, in the current analysis, a remarkably consistent pattern of elevated non-synonymous E2 variation was observed, a pattern more in line with the values seen for the E6/E7 ORFs than the stable core E1, L1 and L2 ORFs.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	63	 The median E2 dN/dS value (0 31) was significantly different from that of the E1/L1/L2 group (0 09) (Mann to Whitney P < 0 0004) (Siegel, 1956).
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	64	All values were calculated with SNAP as described by Korber (2000).
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	65	  Much of E2's variation is attributable to the hinge region connecting the transcription activation domain (TAD) to the DNA-binding domain (DBD) (Table 2; Fig.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	66	 In all cases except for the HPV54 pair, the hinge region did not manifest the purifying selection that constrains the rest of the E2 ORF (dN/dS median, 1 11).
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	67	 HPV16 variant genomes also showed elevated dN/dS ratios in the E2 hinge region (Z.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	68	 The TAD and DBD regions display intermediate median dN/dS values (0 18), lower than that for the hinge, but significantly higher than that observed for E1, L1 or L2 (Mann to Whitney P < 0 002).
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	69	 This pattern holds in all cases except for the HPV54 pair.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Aside from a low hinge dN/dS and a high TAD dN/dS, the HPV54 pair also exhibits relatively high E1 and L1 dN/dS ratios, again highlighting its status as a unique outlier of species clades 1, 8 and 10.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Although relatively elevated E2 dN/dS values are a trend that is consistent across all analysed pairs, there are many functional protein motifs that are conserved across all types.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	72	 For example, the -1 recognition helix in the E2 DBD is well-conserved across all types used in the current study, as are the cognate DBD sites (ACCgNNNNcGGT) in the long control region (reviewed by Hegde, 2002).

0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	82	  The most compelling observations in the current analysis were the high overall dN/dS ratio of E2 and the concentration of non-synonymous changes in the hinge region of this ORF.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	83	 E2 is unique in the PV genome in that it is the only ORF that completely contains another (in this case, E4).
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Moreover, E4 frames the hinge region completely in all pairs analysed (for two examples, see Fig.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	85	 In each sliding-window analysis, except for HPV54 where little time has apparently passed since subtype divergence, non-synonymous changes dominate the E2 reading frame, whereas E4 favours synonymous changes.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	86	 This observation is at odds with the prevailing notion concerning overlapping genes  to  that severe evolutionary constraint should operate on nucleotide sequences encoding two layers of protein in the dense genetic environment of viruses (Mizokami et al.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	87	, 1997; Pavesi, 2000; Pavesi et al.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	88	 For overlapping genes, codon changes at the third position in one reading frame are unusual, because they result in changes in the second position of the +1 reading frame.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	89	 However, what we see here is a pattern of E4 purifying selection superimposed on the E2 hinge, the one domain that can physically accommodate high levels of non-synonymous change.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	90	 The relaxed constraint observed for the hinge is therefore attributable to both its role as a flexible connector between the functionally conserved TAD and DBD domains and the existence of the overlapping E4 reading frame.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	91	 In PVs with no evidence of an E4 ORF, we might expect this phenomenon to disappear.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	92	 However, to our knowledge, all PVs contain an E4-like ORF except for the two avian PVs that have been characterized to date: Psittacus erithacus papillomavirus (PePV) and Fringilla coelebs papillomavirus (FPV) (Terai et al.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	93	 An alignment of PePV and FPV E2 ORFs yielded only 52 % identity.
0.2511286.15831941.html.plaintext.txt	94	 At this level of divergence, saturation becomes a problem and a satisfactory dN/dS analysis could not be performed.

0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	4	The amino acid sequences of L1 proteins are similar among papillomaviruses of all species and are well conserved among HPV genotypes.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Alignment of HPV L1 proteins reveals that within these well-conserved proteins there are localized regions of amino acid sequence divergence.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	6	 These regions contain determinants of type-specificity (Ludmerer  and  McClements, 1999).
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	7	 We and others have shown that the epitopes recognized by HPV neutralizing monoclonal antibodies (mAbs), which are generally type-specific and conformation-dependent, map to these regions (Christensen et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	8	, 1996, 1997, 2000; McClements et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Furthermore, structural studies of HPV capsomers and VLPs have shown that these divergent sequence regions are surface-exposed (Chen et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	10	, 2000), and other studies have shown that substitution of these regions with non-L1 sequences results in the presentation of foreign epitopes on VLPs (Chackerian et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	11	Previously, we mapped type-specific neutralizing epitopes for the closely related HPV types 6 and 11 by demonstrating that HPV-11-like amino acid substitutions in HPV-6 L1 transferred type 11-specific epitopes to VLPs assembled from mutant type 6 L1 proteins and that reciprocal experiments transferred HPV-6-specific epitopes to type 11 VLPs (Ludmerer et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	12	, 1996, 1997, 2000; McClements et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	13	 These studies mapped the HPV-11 immunodominant neutralizing epitope to a sequence of approximately 20 amino acids centred on residue Y132 and found that a second subdominant neutralizing epitope comprised residues 270 to 290 and 340 to 345.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	14	 For HPV-6, neutralizing epitopes are bipartite and comprise two regions of sequence divergence, both of which are distinct from the regions identified in HPV-11.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	15	 The principal region is centred on residues 49 to 54 (region I, Fig.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	16	 1a) and contains determinants for H6.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	17	M48, the three HPV-6-specific conformation-dependent mAbs (Christensen et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	18	, 1996b) that are neutralizing in an HPV-6 pseudovirion assay (Yeager et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The second region is centred on residues 169 to 178 (region II, Fig.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	20	 1a) and modulates binding to region I.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	21	5 require region II as well as region I to achieve full binding to VLPs (McClements et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	22	 The physical association of regions I and II is consistent with the crystal structure of HPV-16 VLPs (Chen et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	23	, 2000) where HPV-16 L1 sequences analogous to regions I and II map to loop B to C and segment G1, respectively, and are predicted to be in close proximity in capsomers and VLPs.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Type-specific bipartite epitopes have also been described for HPV types 11 and 16 (Christensen et al.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	25	, 1996b), a conformation-dependent mAb that is cross-reactive with HPV types 6 and 11, suggested that it also recognizes a bipartite epitope, with one part mapping in the N-terminal region of L1 (N.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Christensen, unpublished observations).
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	27	 This raised the possibility that, in HPV-6, type-common and type-specific epitopes may overlap and could interfere with precise serological characterization.

0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	37	  To extend our mapping studies to address the question of epitope interference and to generate novel reagents for monitoring immune responses to HPV infection or immunization with experimental HPV vaccines, we attempted to transfer the HPV-6-specific epitopes to a less closely related papillomavirus VLP, i.

0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	40	 The CRPV and HPV-6 L1 molecules are nearly identical in length and CRPV VLPs are structurally similar to HPV VLPs, but the CRPV L1 amino acid sequence (SWISS-PROT accession no.

0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Using PCR mutagenesis, we transferred the HPV-6-specific residues of regions I and II into the CRPV L1.
0.25392318.12771418.html.plaintext.txt	43	 The CRPV/HPV-6 hybrid L1, CR/H6:I, had nine HPV-6-like substitutions in region I making that sequence identical to HPV-6 over a 20-residue sequence (CRPV L1 aa 45 to 64).

0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	3	The use of artificial virus vectors consisting of DNA packaged in vitro into or associated with recombinant papillomavirus VLPs was recently described (Kawana et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	4	, 1998; Touze  and  Coursaget, 1998; Rossi et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Papillomaviruses are difficult to propagate in vitro, and thus the production of these pseudovirions offers a model to study human papillomavirus (HPV) cell entry.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	6	 The pseudovirions obtained have the ability to transfer the plasmid DNA into cells where the reporter gene is then expressed.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Entry of these artificial gene delivery vehicles into cells is dependent on the interaction between VLPs and the cell surface.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Two putative cell receptors have been identified for HPVs.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	9	 The first is -6 integrin (Evander et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	10	, 1999) and the second comprises the cell-surface glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) (Joyce et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	11	, 2001), which interact with the C-terminal portion of HPV L1 (Joyce et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	12	Translocation of L1 and L2 proteins to the nucleus is mediated by nuclear localization signals (NLS) containing, as do the majority of NLS, a high proportion of positively charged residues (K and R).
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	13	 The prototype NLS is the SV40 large T antigen NLS (KKKRK).
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	14	 One has six basic amino acids (aa 499 to 504).
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	15	 The other is a bipartite NLS (aa 484 to 486, 499 to 500) (Zhou et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	16	 The L2 protein contains two NLS corresponding to the arginine- and lysine-rich sequences located at the N and C termini of the protein (Sun et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Two DNA-binding sequences have been identified in the L1 and L2 proteins of HPV-16.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	18	 The first DNA-binding sequence was identified at the N-terminal end of L2 (Zhou et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The second was identified at the C terminus of the L1 protein of HPV-11 and HPV-16 (Li et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	20	 In addition, the nine C-terminal amino acids of the L2 protein have been shown to be necessary for infection of bovine papillomavirus type 1 (BPV-1) pseudovirions (Roden et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	21	 The DNA-binding activity of these two domains is sequence-independent.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	22	 However, it has recently been shown that DNA binding to BPV-1, HPV-6 and HPV-16 VLPs is enhanced by the presence of a 120 bp DNA sequence located in the BPV-1 E1 gene (Zhao et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	23	We have previously demonstrated that HPV L1 VLPs obtained by self-assembly of L1 protein lacking the last nine C-terminal amino acids had lost their capacity to bind DNA and transfer genes into target cells (Touze et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Moreover, addition of this sequence at the N terminus of the major capsid protein of an RNA virus, the rabbit haemorrhagic disease virus (RHDV), allowed the production of chimeric VLPs that could encapsidate DNA and transfer reporter genes into cells (El Mehdaoui et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	25	 These experiments suggest a central role for this short sequence in DNA binding, interacting with the cell surface of target cells and facilitating the nuclear import of complexes owing to the presence of an NLS.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	26	 In order to verify the role of this positively charged sequence, we investigated the possibility of using a synthetic peptide corresponding to the 14 C-terminal amino acids of the HPV-16 L1 protein in DNA transfection experiments.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	27	 The study was then extended to positively charged sequences of the HPV-16 L2 protein and the L1 protein of four other HPVs.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	28	HPV-16 and -31 VLPs were expressed in Sf21 cells infected with recombinant baculoviruses encoding the HPV-16 and -31 L1 open reading frames, respectively, and purified according to previously described procedures (El Medhaoui et al.

0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	35	 This charge ratio corresponded to peptide/DNA mass ratios ranging from 8 6 to 15 6 for L1 peptides, except for peptide HPV-16 L1 Cta (peptide/DNA mass ratio of 20), 6 2 to 6 4 for L2 peptides and SV40 large T NLS and 17 4 to 100 for other peptides.

0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	97	DNA binding and gene transfer with positively charged peptides derived from the L1 or L2 proteins of HPVs There are two positively charged sequences at the C terminus of HPV L1 proteins and one such sequence at the N- and C-terminal ends of HPV L2 proteins.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	98	 In order to investigate whether the gene transfer properties observed for the HPV-16 L1 Ctb peptide are features shared by similar sequences observed in HPV L1 and L2, various synthetic peptides corresponding to positively charged sequences derived from the L1 protein of HPV-16, -31, -33, -45 and -58 and from HPV-16 L2 protein were investigated (Table 1).

0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	148	 This confirmed that the PES is not papillomavirus type-specific and suggested that both L1 and L2 proteins recognized BPV PES.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	149	 In addition, the results suggested that the very low level of gene transfer observed with HPV-16 L1 Cta and HPV-31 L1 Ctb peptides in the presence of pCMV-Luc plasmid was not a consequence of the fact that these peptides have a higher affinity for papillomavirus DNA.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	150	Binding of positively charged peptides derived from HPV L1 or L2 proteins to heparin and cell GAGs As L1 and L2 positively charged sequences are able to transfer genes, it could be hypothesized that such peptides bind to DNA and to cells and that the NLS activity of such peptides sends the plasmid DNA to the nucleus where the reporter gene is expressed.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	151	 GAGs have been proposed as cell receptors for HPVs (Joyce et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	152	, 2001) and a sequence has been identified at the C terminus of the HPV-11 L1 protein that interacts with this cell receptor (Joyce et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	153	 This sequence was included in the HPV-16 L1 Ctb peptide.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	154	The interaction between peptides and heparin was tested using a competition assay measuring the binding of HPV-31 VLPs to heparin-coated plates.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	155	 The results were expressed as percentage inhibition of HPV-31 VLP binding to heparin.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Inhibition greater than 50 % was considered to indicate binding of the peptide to heparin.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	157	 To rule out the hypothesis that these findings were due to binding between peptides and VLPs, the interaction between HPV-31 VLPs and HPV-16 L1 Ctb, HPV-31 L1 Cta, HPV-45 L1 Ctb and HPV16 E4 Ag peptides was investigated by ELISA.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	158	 No binding (A < 0 050) of HPV-31 VLPs to any of the peptides investigated was observed.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	159	 These results indicated that all peptides inhibited binding of VLPs to heparin with the exception of HPV-16 E4 Ag, HPV-16 L1 Cta, HPV-31 L1 Ctb and HPV-58 L1 Ctb (Table 1).
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	160	 It should be noted that peptides that did not deliver genes into cells did not bind to heparin, nor did they bind efficiently to DNA.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	161	 In addition, the absence of binding of HPV-16 L19 VLPs to heparin (data not shown) confirmed and extended the results of Joyce et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	162	 (1999) with HPV-11, suggesting that binding to heparin is mediated by the L1 protein 15 C-terminal amino acids.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	163	To test whether GAGs could competitively inhibit gene delivery, COS-7 cells were transfected with all the DNA/peptide complexes that transferred genes in the presence of heparin.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Following exposure to DNA/peptide complexes and heparin, cells were washed, incubated in fresh culture medium and assayed for luciferase expression 48 h later.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Gene transfer was inhibited by 67 to 90 % when heparin was added to the DNA/peptide complexes, depending on the peptide used (Fig.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Inhibition of gene transfer was not observed after pre-incubation of the complexes with BSA in place of heparin.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	167	 The role of proteoglycans in binding of HPV to cells was also assessed by inhibition of their sulfation with sodium chlorate.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	168	 For this purpose, COS-7 cells were grown in the presence of sodium chlorate for 12 h and then transfected with HPV-16 L1 Ctb, HPV-33 L1 Ctb, HPV-45 L1 Ctb and L2 N- and C-terminal peptides.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Luciferase gene expression was inhibited by pretreatment with sodium chlorate in a dose-dependent manner (data not shown).
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Gene transfer was dramatically decreased compared with untreated cells, with a decrease of 69 % for HPV-16 L1 Ctb peptide and 70 % for HPV-45 L1 Ctb (Fig.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	171	 These findings suggested that L1-derived peptides use heparan sulfate to enter cells and deliver genes into cells, as do VLPs.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	172	View larger version (21K):    Fig.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Inhibition of luciferase gene transfer by heparin (black bars) or after pretreatment of cells with sodium chlorate (grey bars).
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Data are the mean of three experiments.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Error bars represent the mean plus or minus SD.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	176	  The results obtained are in agreement with those of gene transfer using HPV-16 L19 VLPs made of L1 protein lacking the last nine amino acids (Touze et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	177	, 2000), indicating that these amino acids are essential for DNA binding and gene transfer.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	178	 These findings are in agreement with those of Giroglou et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	179	 (2001) indicating that HPV-33 VLPs made of L1 protein lacking the last seven amino acids still bind to target cells since we identified a second positively charged sequence able to bind heparan sulfate at positions 472 to 481 of the C terminus of HPV-33 L1 protein.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	180	 However, they are not in agreement with the fact that HPV-33 VLPs made of L1 protein lacking the 22 last amino acids still bind to target cells, since this deletion partially deletes the second DNA- and heparin-binding sequence.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	181	 However, it should be noted that the VLPs used by Giroglou et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	182	 (2001) were composed of L1 and L2 proteins and that binding to heparin could be due to the presence of the two DNA- and heparin-binding sequences identified at the N and C termini of L2.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	183	Structural data available concerning L1 protein (Chen et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	184	, 2000) and immunological and DNA-binding data concerning L2 protein (Zhou et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	185	, 2002) suggest that the peptides tested in this study are inside the virions, where they would be expected to be unavailable for heparin and cell GAG binding.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	186	 However, gene transfer experiments using VLPs have indicated that VLP binding to DNA, to cells and to heparin is linked to the last C-terminal amino acids of the L1 protein (Joyce et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	187	, 2000), suggesting its presence at the surface of the VLPs.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	188	 The absence of heparin binding observed for HPV-16 L19 VLPs clearly suggests the involvement of this sequence in cell binding through its binding to GAGs.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	189	The role of the positively charged termini of the L2 protein in viral encapsidation has been fully established (Zhou et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	190	 The results of heparin binding obtained with L2 positively charged peptides raise the possibility that these sequences could also be involved in VLP and virion binding to the cell GAGs.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	191	 L1+L2 VLPs lacking either the N or C terminus of the L2 protein have been shown by immunoflurescence studies to bind to cells in the same way as wild-type VLPs (Roden et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	192	, 2001), suggesting that these sequences do not play a central role in binding to cells.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	193	 However, in the absence of data obtained with pseudovirions composed of L1 C-terminal mutants and L2 proteins (both wild-type and N-terminal mutants), it is difficult to conclude whether N-terminal positively charged sequences of the L2 protein are present on the virion surface and play a role in its binding to the cell or not.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	194	In conclusion, using synthetic peptides we have confirmed that the DNA binding of the HPV-16 L1 protein is due to the last C-terminal amino acids.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	195	 We also confirmed the binding properties of N- and C-terminal amino acids of the HPV-16 L2 protein.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	196	 In addition, we determined that a second positively charged sequence located upstream from the previous L1 sequence is able to bind DNA for some HPV types (HPV-33 and -45), but not, or not significantly, for other types (HPV-16, -31 and -58).
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	197	 The interaction between these DNA-binding peptides and DNA induced protection from DNase degradation and was sufficient to obtain gene transfer in COS-7 cells.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	198	 However, the level of gene transfer with a peptide was around 150 times less efficient than that observed with the corresponding sequence within the VLPs.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	199	 It was also shown that gene transfer is mediated by binding of DNA/peptide complexes to heparan sulfate receptors, as for VLPs, confirming that positively charged DNA complexes can enter cells after binding to membrane-associated sulfated proteoglycans (Mislick  and  Baldeschweiler, 1996; Mounkes et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	200	 In addition, our findings are in agreement with reports that the inclusion of L2 protein in the constitution of HPV VLPs increases their gene transfer capacity (Roden et al.
0.25950646.12533712.html.plaintext.txt	201	, 2001) and thus suggests that L2 participates in DNA encapsidation and could play a role in binding to cells.

0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	0	Microtubule-mediated Transport of Incoming Herpes Simplex Virus 1 Capsids to the Nucleus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	1	Herpes simplex virus 1 fuses with the plasma membrane of a host cell, and the incoming capsids are efficiently and rapidly transported across the cytosol to the nuclear pore complexes, where the viral DNA genomes are released into the nucleoplasm.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	2	 Using biochemical assays, immunofluorescence, and immunoelectron microscopy in the presence and absence of microtubule depolymerizing agents, it was shown that the cytosolic capsid transport in Vero cells was mediated by microtubules.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	3	 Antibody labeling revealed the attachment of dynein, a minus end-directed, microtubule-dependent motor, to the viral capsids.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	4	 We propose that the incoming capsids bind to microtubules and use dynein to propel them from the cell periphery to the nucleus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	5	The entry of animal viruses into their host cells involves adsorption to cell surface receptors, penetration into the cytosol, and uncoating of the viral genome.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	6	 For viruses that replicate in the nucleus, entry also entails extensive movement of viruses and viral capsids through the cytoplasm.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Transport over long distances is particularly critical for viruses that infect neurons in which the site of entry can be located far from the cell body and the nucleus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	8	Since movement of virus-sized particles through the cytosol is not likely to occur by free diffusion due to high viscosity and steric obstacles (Bray, 1992; Luby-Phelps, 1994), viruses most likely exploit the cell's motile functions for transport.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	9	 The limited information available suggests that viruses can make use of both microtubules (MT)1 and actin filaments.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	10	 EM analysis has shown MT binding of certain viral capsids, such as adenovirus and reovirus in vivo and in vitro (for review see Luftig, 1982) as well as herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1) in neurons (Lycke et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Way and co-workers have described actin filament-dependent intra- and intercellular transport of vaccinia virus during egress from cells (Cudmore et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Moreover, many viruses take advantage of the retrograde movement of endocytic organelles during entry.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	13	 They are internalized by receptor-mediated endocytosis and carried within coated vesicles and endosomes from the cell periphery toward the perinuclear area of the cell (see Greber et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	14	, 1994; Marsh and Helenius, 1989).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	15	In this study we have focused on the intracytosolic transport of incoming HSV-1 capsids in Vero cells.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	16	 HSV-1 has three structural components: capsid, tegument, and envelope.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	17	 The capsid consists of the viral DNA of 152 kbp and a proteinaceous shell comprising six different proteins; it has a diameter of 125 nm, and the proteins are arranged in an icosahedron formed by 12 pentons and 150 hexons (Booy et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	18	, 1974; Spear and Roizman, 1972).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	19	 VP5 constitutes the major protein component of both hexons and pentons (Newcomb et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	20	 The tegument is a protein layer between the envelope and the capsid and contains ~12 different viral polypeptides (Roizman and Furlong, 1974; Roizman and Sears, 1996).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	21	 While the functions of most of these remain to be identified, one is a protein kinase (LeMaster and Roizman, 1980), one induces shut off of host cell protein synthesis (Read and Frenkel, 1983), and some are known to be activators and modulators of viral gene expression (Batterson and Roizman, 1983; Campbell et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	22	 The viral envelope contains at least 12 different membrane proteins, some of which are involved in receptor binding and fusion.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	23	The infectious cycle begins with virus binding to heparan sulfate receptors on the cell surface followed by glycoprotein-mediated fusion of the envelope with the plasma membrane (for review see Spear, 1993).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	24	 After release into the cytosol and dissociation from some of the tegument components, the capsids move through the cytosol to the nucleus and bind to nuclear pores (Batterson et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	25	, 1988), whereafter the genome is released into the nucleus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Transcription, replication of viral DNA, and assembly of progeny capsids take place within the host nucleus (for review see Roizman and Sears, 1996; Steven and Spear, 1996).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	27	 The synthesis of early viral proteins peaks after 4-6 h of virus entry, and the first progeny viruses are produced after 8 h (Honess and Roizman, 1973).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	28	We analyzed the transport of incoming HSV-1 capsids to the nucleus in fibroblasts and found that it occurs rapidly and efficiently by an MT-mediated mechanism.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	29	 The incoming capsids shed most of the associated tegument proteins and bind dynein, an MT-dependent, minus end- directed motor in the peripheral cytosol, whereafter they are transported along MT toward the cell center.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	30	 The viral capsids thus make use of the machinery responsible for retrograde organelle transport in animal cells.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	31	Materials and Methods Cells and Antibodies.

0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	70	 This preparation had a titer of 1  x  107 PFU/ml and contained 0.

0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	203	Results Early Events during HSV-1 Entry.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	204	Due to the large size of HSV-1 virions and capsids, early virus cell interactions can be readily visualized by EM (Campadelli-Fiume et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	205	 We followed the incoming capsids at different stages of entry in Vero cells (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	206	 The extracellular, surface-bound virus particles had the familiar features of a herpes virus: a membrane envelope with spikes, a capsid with an electron-dense DNA core, and a tegument layer between the capsid and the envelope (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Images of fusion between the viral envelope and the plasma membrane were readily obtained (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	208	 After fusion, the capsids appeared to separate from the bulk of the tegument since an electron-dense mass remained associated with the cytoplasmic surface of the plasma membrane (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	209	 1, e and f, arrowheads; see also CampadelliFiume et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Ultrathin Epon sections of Vero cells infected with HSV-1 at an MOI of 500 in the presence of cycloheximide (CH).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	211	 After 2 h of virus binding at 4 degrees C, the cells were either fixed immediately (a and b), or warmed up for 30 (c-f) or 60 min (g and h).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	212	 The main morphological features of the intact virus bound to the plasma membrane (PM) are the viral envelope (b, arrowhead) with the viral spikes (a, arrowhead), the viral capsid (arrow), and the electron-dense viral DNA genome within the capsid.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Upon warming up, the viral envelope fuses with the plasma membrane, and the capsid (arrow) and the tegument proteins are released into the cytosol.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	214	 (e and f) Release of the capsid.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	215	 Preparations, which display a prominent contrast of the tegument, show that the tegument (arrowheads) stays behind at the PM.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	216	 (g and h) Binding to the nuclear pore.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	217	 At later time points, the capsids (arrows) have arrived at the nuclear envelope (NE), where they are exclusively located in close apposition to the nuclear pore complexes.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Occasionally, fibers emanating from the pores (arrowheads) are visible, to which the capsids seem to bind.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Almost all of the capsids at the nuclear pores appear empty and have lost the electron-dense DNA core.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	220	 [View Larger Version of this Image (91K GIF file)].
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	221	After 1 h, the first capsids had reached the nucleus and attached themselves to the nuclear pore complexes (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	222	 1, g and h; see also Batterson et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	223	 They seemed to bind to cytsosolic fibers emerging from the pores (see arrowheads in Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	224	 Since most of the capsids on the nuclear envelope lacked the electron-dense central mass, DNA release had apparently occurred.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	225	 At later time points, some empty capsids were also seen free in the cytosol without connection to the nucleus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Occasionally, 1 h postinfection and later, intact and partially degraded virions were also seen in endosomes and lysosomes, indicating that a fraction of the inoculum was taken up by endocytosis.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	227	The rate and efficiency of cell surface binding and subsequent internalization was assayed quantitatively using [3H]thymidine-labeled HSV-1.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	228	 To monitor binding, cells were incubated with labeled virus at an MOI of 10, 50, or 100 at 4 degrees C, and the cell-associated radioactivity was measured at different times.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	229	 As previously reported, a continuous increase in virus binding was observed up to 4 h with no signs of saturation (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	230	 2 a; McClain and Fuller, 1994; Shieh et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	231	 At 2 hthe adsorption period used in all subsequent experiments ~40% of the added virus was bound.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Efficiency and kinetics of HSV-1 binding and internalization.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	233	 (a) Using [3H]thymidine-labeled virus at different multiplicities of infection (MOI), the amount of virus bound to cells at 4 degrees C was quantified after various time points.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	234	 There is no apparent saturation of virus binding to Vero cells.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	235	 After 2 h, ~40% of the virus added bound.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	236	 (b) Using [3H]thymidine-labeled virus at different MOIs, the amount of virus internalized into cells was quantified after various time points.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	237	 At time 0 min (equals 2 h of virus binding at 4 degrees C), proteinase K treatment removes  > 95% of the virus bound to the plasma membrane.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	238	 Upon warming up to 37 degrees C and viral fusion, the virus is protected within the cells from the protease treatment.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	239	 After 30 min, the maximal amount of virus, ~70% of the bound virus, is internalized.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	240	 The half-time (t1/2) of internalization is 8 min.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	241	 Depolymerization of microtubules by nocodazole (ND) has no effect on the kinetics and the amount of internalization.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	242	 [View Larger Version of this Image (17K GIF file)].
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	243	To follow internalization biochemically, a protease protection assay was used (Helenius et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	244	 After a 2-h binding period in the cold, the cells were warmed up to 37 degrees C for different periods of time to initiate penetration.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	245	 Thereafter, they were chilled to 4 degrees C and treated with proteinase K to detach remaining cell surface viruses.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	246	 The fraction of virus protected from the protease increased rapidly after warming (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	247	 2 b) with a half-time of internalization of 8 min.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	248	 The overall protease resistance reached a level of 70% within 30 min.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	249	 The efficiency and rate of internalization was identical over a multiplicity range from 3  x  104-10 MOI.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	250	 Treatment of the cells with nocodazole, a drug that depolymerizes MT (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	251	 2 b, ND), or with cytochalasin D, which depolymerizes actin filaments (not shown), had no effect, either on the efficiency of binding and internalization or on the kinetics of internalization.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Consistent with previous reports using acid inactivation and plaque assays to assess virus internalization (Huang and Wagner, 1964), these results showed that HSV-1 penetration occurs rapidly and efficiently.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	253	Transport of Capsids from the Plasma Membrane to the Nucleus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	254	Indirect immunofluorescence microscopy was next used to analyze the transport of individual capsids from the cell periphery to the nucleus.

0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	345	 Interestingly, the appearance of cytosolic capsids under the plasma membrane peaked before the transport of virions into endosomes, strongly suggesting that the early cytosolic capsids were indeed derived from fusion of the virus at the plasma membrane rather than by fusion from endosomes.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	346	Reduced Capsid Transport to the Nucleus without Microtubules.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	347	To determine whether efficient capsid transport via the cytosol depended on an intact cytoskeleton, cells were infected at an MOI of 50 for 2 h in the presence of drugs that affect MT or actin filaments.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	348	 Immunofluorescence microscopy showed that neither taxol, a drug that prevents the disassembly of MT (Wilson and Jordan, 1994), nor cytochalasin D, a drug that causes depolymerization of actin filaments (Cooper, 1987), affected capsid transport to the nucleus (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	349	 In contrast, capsid accumulation at the nuclear membrane was significantly reduced by colchicine, vinblastine, and nocodazole (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	350	 These drugs interact with tubulin by different molecular mechanisms (Wilson and Jordan, 1994).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	351	 Labeling with anti-tubulin confirmed that colchicine and nocodazole depolymerized MT, whereas vinblastine caused tubulin paracrystal formation (not shown).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	352	 In the presence of these drugs, the majority of capsids remained scattered throughout the cytosol.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	353	 To test whether the effect of nocodazole was reversible, the cells were analyzed 2 h after drug removal.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	354	 At this time, the MT had repolymerized, and the previously dispersed capsids were concentrated on the nuclear rim (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	355	 Reduced transport of capsids to the nucleus in the absence of MTs.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	356	 Immunofluorescence microscopy of Vero cells infected with HSV-1 for 2 h at an MOI of 50 in the presence of CH and drugs affecting the cytoskeleton.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	357	 Under control conditions, almost all capsids accumulate around the nucleus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	358	 If the cells were infected in the presence of nocodazole, colchicine, or vinblastine, respectively (lower panel), there is no accumulation of viral capsids at the nucleus; instead, the capsids are scattered throughout the entire cytoplasm.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	359	 In cells infected in the presence of taxol or cytochalasin D, the capsids accumulate at the nucleus (upper panel).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	360	 The cells were fixed in 3% PFA, permeabilized with 0.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	361	1% TX-100, and labeled with an antibody directed against purified capsids (HC).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	362	 In the presence of nocodazole, the amount of viral capsids localized to the nucleus is drastically reduced, whereas, after a 2-h chase in nocodazole-free medium, the capsids accumulate around the cell nuclei.

0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	365	 [View Larger Versions of these Images (76 + 86K GIF file)].
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	366	Since we were unable to quantify the localization of the fluorescent spots representing cytosolic capsids reliably, we infected Vero cells at an MOI of 150 in the presence or absence of nocodazole and analyzed the embedded cell pellets by quantitative EM.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	367	 For each experimental condition, 50 electron negatives were taken in a systematic, random fashion and the localization of cytosolic capsids was determined (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	368	 After 2 h of infection, 31% of the cytosolic capsids had reached the nucleus, and only 25% were still in close proximity to the plasma membrane.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	369	 In contrast in the absence of MT, none had reached the nucleus, and 58% were still in the region close to the plasma membrane.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	370	 After 4 h postinfection, 75% of all cytosolic capsids had reached the nucleus, 14% were at the plasma membrane, and the remaining 11% were present in the cytosol.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	371	 In the presence of nocodazole, only 47% of the cytosolic capsids had reached the nucleus, 18% were still at the plasma membrane, and 36% were in the cytosol distant from both the plasma membrane and the nucleus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	372	As nocodazole, vinblastine, and colchicine all affect the network of MT (Wilson and Jordan, 1994), we concluded that MT are directly or indirectly involved in the rapid transport of capsids from the cell periphery to the nucleus in Vero cells.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	373	 In cells devoid of functional MT, the arrival of capsids at the nucleus was significantly delayed.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	374	Viral Infection in the Absence of Microtubules.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	375	Whether nocodazole would have an effect on productive infection was determined by monitoring the onset of viral protein synthesis in the presence or absence of the drug.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	376	 Cell extracts prepared after different periods of infection were subjected to immunoblotting using antibodies against an early HSV-1 protein, ICP4, and a late structural protein, VP5.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	377	 7 c show that the synthesis of both viral proteins was delayed and reduced in the absence of MT.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	378	 Calnexin, an integral membrane protein of the ER (Hammond and Helenius, 1994), was used as a control and remained constant.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	379	 Labeling with [35S]methionine demonstrated that nocodazole had no overall effect on protein synthesis in uninfected or HSV-1-infected Vero cells (not shown).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	380	When immunofluorescence microscopy using ICP4 was performed, we found that, under control conditions, viral protein synthesis commenced in many cells already at 2 h postinfection.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	381	 In contrast, in the presence of nocodazole, only very few cells showed ICP4 labeling.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	382	 At 4 h postinfection, all control cells were strongly labeled for ICP4, whereas in the absence of MT, significantly less cells show strong labeling for ICP4 (data not shown).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	383	 However, at later time points, all cells synthezised ICP4, in the presence and absence of MT.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	384	Thus, depolymerization of MT delayed the onset of viral protein synthesis in cultured fibroblasts, but did not prevent viral infection per se.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	385	Dynein Colocalizes with Incoming Capsids.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	386	Our results strongly suggested that incoming herpes capsids move along MT toward the nucleus.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	387	 Therefore, we ask whether they would use host MT-dependent motors for their transport.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	388	 Since the antibody against tubulin often obscured the morphology of putative tethering factors located between the viral capsids and the MT (see Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	389	 4), we repeated these experiments without immunolabeling.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	390	 Electron-dense material was usually attached to the vertices of the capsids that were associated with MT (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	391	 The morphology of the appendages was variable, but, in some cases (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	392	 8 d, arrow), they had the dimensions and the shape of cytoplasmic dynein, a minus end-directed MT-dependent motor.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	393	 Dynein is a Y-shaped protein complex with a length of ~50 nm.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	394	 It is connected to its cargo via the stalk and to MT through two 14-nm globular domains (Gilbert and Sloboda, 1989; Vale, 1990; Vallee et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	395	 Incoming HSV-1 capsids display appendices at their vertices.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	396	 At 1 h PI, Vero cells infected at an MOI of 500 in the presence of CH were extracted with 0.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	397	5% TX-100 in MT buffer for 2 min at 37 degrees C and fixed in 1% GA in MT buffer.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	398	 They were labeled with anti-tubulin followed by protein A-9 nm gold (a) or embedded directly (b-d), and Epon sections were cut parallel to the substrate.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	399	 All viral capsids display some appendages on their outside (arrowheads).
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	400	 The appendages are visible at three, four, five, or all six corners visible in a section, which represent the pentons of a viral capsid.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	401	 Some of the appendices have a morphology very similar to purified cytoplasmic dynein (large arrow in d): a large globular stalk with two smaller globular head domains.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	402	 The capsid size is ~100-110 nm; the dynein-like appendices are ~50 nm.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	403	 In thick sections of golden color, the appendices are often buried in cytoskeletal material (b and d), whereas in very thin sections of grey color (a and c), they are very prominent.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	404	 The appendices have all kinds of different morphology with varying sizes and electron density, but they are always located at the pentons.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	405	 [View Larger Version of this Image (172K GIF file)].
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	406	To test whether cytoplasmic dynein was, indeed, associated with the capsids, we used an affinity-purified antibody directed against the heavy chain of cytoplasmic dynein (Vaisberg et al.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	407	 Immunoelectron microscopy with the anti-dynein antibody was performed on ultrathin cryosections of in situ fixed cells 1 or 2 h after initiation of virus entry.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	408	 In addition to a low level of labeling of the cytoplasm, dynein was found to be localized on the surface of endosomes (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	409	 9 a), and the Golgi apparatus (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	410	 Very few gold particles were seen over the nucleus and the mitochondrial matrix (Fig.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	411	 The mitochondria, which do not contain dynein, served as a background control.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	412	 Compared with the mitochondrial matrix, there was a slightly higher labeling in the nuclei, and the cytoplasm was labeled 2.
0.26717928.9060466.html.plaintext.txt	413	3-fold higher than background (Table I).
